Hotel is just a few steps from the famous Shibuya crossing, tons of restaurants and shopping within walking distance. The room is definitely five star - spacious (surprising for Japan), very clean, and amazing views. Lots of complimentary amenities in the bathroom (shampoo, conditioner, soap, toothbrush, razor, etc). The bed was very comfortable, and there were several different types of pillows to choose from. Breakfast at this hotel is insanely expensive so we opted to eat elsewhere. If you are looking to visit a shrine, it took us about 15-20 minutes to walk to the Meiji shrine from the hotel, very easy to navigate. We would love to stay here again, definitely recommend!

The cerulean is a big hotel in a very good location, so close to shibuya crossing / station , with lots of shopping and options to eat around. i got an upgrade in my room and it was very spacious and also had an amazing view. the bathroom was huge with a very nice shower a hot tub and the well known japanese toilets with all its technology. if you are traveling to any of Tokyo's airport you can book a bus that will pick you up on the very entrance of the hotel. i will suggest to avoid visiting the toofloor bar , it is absolutely expensive and honestly not relevant.

Decent rooms, comfortable beds, spacious bathroom. Breakfast was good. The hotel had a fair gym but there is an extra charge for using it. The hotel is located in the famous Shibuya district. There is a nice skybar as well as a lobby bar. However, difficult to het coffee after 10 pm.

Great Japanese hotel with amazing service and beautiful rooms. Try to get one with the bath overlooking the city. Very spacious for a Japanese hotel. A little convoluted to get to and from the Shibuya Station which is already confusing - and as usual in Japan next to no signs in English. Lots of restaurant choices and a large 7-11.

We had a wonderful stay at the Cerulean Tower in Toyko. It is walking distance to many great places to eat (we loved the Coco curry house right down the street) as well as a quick walk to the subway. The hotel is stunning and the staff was incredible. I was very impressed with the staff’s fluent English and their customer service. The hotel shuttle is prompt and everything was clean in the hotel.I loved the desserts in the refrigerated case in the lobby – they were all so delicate and the details were impressive. Be sure to close the bathroom door so you don’t set off an alarm with the shower steam – this didn’t happen to us, but I took note of the sign in the bathroom. We stayed on the 25th floor and experienced the 7.4 earthquake on November 22, 2016. I was so grateful to be in a sturdy structure that kept us safe. The building creaked and swayed during the quake, but I expected that since I am used to our California earthquakes. The Cerulean Tower was worth every penny and I hope we can visit again someday.

Hotel is nice throughout, rooms are pretty amply sized for Tokyo, rooms are well furnished and comfortable, and of course the staff is fantastic. The views from room, however, are amazing. I spent my share of time with a bottle of wine just gazing out at the endless sea of lights.

For a first time visit of Tokyo the Cerulean is a great hotel. The staff is efficient but do not expect very much personalized service. But the rooms (view!) are great. I had a deluxe room, so apart from the window in the main room, the bathroom has a window as well. I recommend to book a room directly through the website of the hotel, this allows you to choose from a broader list of rooms and extras. If you are planning to use the swimming pool (which is great, with daylight) and/or breakfast it can be cheaper to book a room on the executive or tower floor. In addition to discounts you get, you have access to the executive lounge for a snack and breakfast is being served there as well, so less crowded. If you become a (free) member during checkin you get some more discount on the room as well.

Great hotel located in Shibuya, a few minutes walk from all the action of Tokyo's loved shopping district.Rooms are large (a rarity in Tokyo) and the views are amazing..... stretching across the shopping district to seeing Tokyo Tower in the distance. There is also a pool and a gym on site. Reception and foyer is grand and staff are super helpful.There is also the airport shuttle which drops off and picks up directly in front of the hotel.

Hotel is very central to everything and access via the train system is great. I think it would be very hard to find more professional staff anywhere. They were very helpful and friendly. The concierge was incredibly helpful and very patient. He assisted us no matter what we wanted. I look forward to returning here again in the future.

Really nice hotel, friendly, efficient staff and our room had amazing views of Tokyo. Really good location for visiting Tokyo. Hotel was clean, rooms were a good size and well furnished. Useful 7-11 downstairs too for those times when you dont want to spend too much money on room service. Very close to the train station and walking distance to a lot of attractions in Shibuya.

This hotel is probably one of the lousy 5 stars hotel I ever stayed. We stayed in this hotel in January this year. Thinking that we could enjoy being a 5 stars hotel guest, turned out everything cost. Below are the few things that I could not imagine I would be charged.1. Breakfast every morning in the hotel restaurant.2. Coffee and teas in the room drawer, which are considered a basic necessity for even a lower star hotel, is chargeable. A cup of coffee cost USD$3.003. Swimming pool, spa and gym? USD$25 a day.4. English channels like CNN and BBC? USD14 a day.At the end of our stay, we were so worry that the hotel might charge us the number of toilet flushing we used on their fancy bidet.We like to stay in 5 stars hotel in every country we visit because we like to be pampered on our vacation. Cerulean Tokyo hotel had nickel and dime us on every move. We are not going to stay there again!

We stayed at the hotel during the holidays until the New Year, for a week. All the personnel are very polite and courteous, which is a common trait in Japan. I would recommend staying here if you want to truly feel the vacation mode. It's worth it even though it comes with a price. I will definitely go back here. Special mention to the 24/7 room service.

If you want to stay in Shibuya area, this is the best option. But price is a little bit high and facilities need renovation for it's 15 years after opening. If you are lucky you can see Fuji mountain from your room.

I order room service, like, A LOT. This hotel knocked it out of the park as far as food for room service goes. I go to many hotels and this one had some of the best food I have ever had. They have many restaurants on premise; however they seem to require reservations - we weren't able to walk into any that we tried during our trip but maybe that was due to the recent New Year. They also have a 7 Eleven convenience store in the hotel which was awesome for extra things and they even have great sandwiches! Great views of the city in the Sky View rooms! Overall great hotel. Make sure to book on other websites (expedia etc) because booking with them direct was A LOT higher in price, which is weird. The staff even told us to go on a different site... so we did.

Stayed at the hotel for four nights.Good location, 3 minutes walk to Shibuya station (Tokyu department store, Mark City 109 men...)Smoking room was large with good view from room at high floor and even spotted Mount Fuji on the second day when the sky was really clear. Must go to the 40th floor bar and enjoyed the skyline at night.The building combined offices with the hotel and there's a convenience at the building.Shuttle bus to Narita right at the hotel, very convenient.One of my good experience in hotels in Japan.

Cerulean Tower Hotel is a smart, stylish, well located, and comfortable hotel. The Shibuya location is great for getting around the city either via taxi or metro. 5 min walk to the famed Shibuya crossing. 15 min taxi to Shinjuku and 10 min to Harajuku, rush hour not withstanding. Excellent location with Tokyo hot spots right near the hotel.  We initially where booked into a king room on a tower floor. These rooms included the executive lounge access. The regular king rooms are small, with small bathroom including glass enclosed shower tub combo. The King Corner room is the best bet, 3 different picture windows including a bathtub window view. The room size is comfortable including couch seating area, desk area, and bathroom with dbl sink, soaking tub, and separate glass enclosed shower.   The hotel website was a bit confusing as there are numerous different types of rooms. I'd suggest the hotel streamline the room categories if they could. We were initially booked into a regular king room and switched to a corner king after one night. The ease at which we were able to switch rooms made me think this might happen with some frequency.   The executive lounge located on the 35th floor was intimate yet well appointed. Holding approx 35-40 people, the lounge never felt crowded. The wall of picture windows lets you enjoy breakfast with Mt. Fuji in view on a clear day. The breakfast was a combination Japanese, American, European. Something for most everyone. I suggest getting to breakfast early as you'll want to linger in the picture window seating and soak up the vibe.  All around solid chose of home base to tour Toyko. Main tip, choose your room category carefully.

Lovely view, room, bed, bathroom etc but only a few floors get the swimming pool for free...we are staying 6 nights and it would cost Y2100 per person per day to use. (20 metres indoor) Needless to say we didn't bother and were disappointed as this isn't a cheap place to stay.

Using the airport limo bus available in terminal, we were the first stop in Tokyo. Hotel was clean and centrally-located. Hotel restaurants were not as good as nearby offsite restaurants. Pool and spa were great. Great hotel.

We had drinks and snacks at the bar at the top of the Cerulean Tower and the views were excellent. I had the Cerulean Champagne Cocktail, which was blue with blueberries and it was superb. We also had a plate of mixed meats as a snack. For a little luxury and great views, this is one not to miss.

Very big room (and bathroom!) compare to most of Tokyo's accommodations we've been to. We stayed in such an amazing room with fantastic view of Tokyo tower and other beautiful skyscrapers. Staffs were very helpful and attentive. Location is superb but bear in mind that you have to cross the pedestrian overpass to make it to Shibuya station and the main shopping area. There is a 7 Eleven on the 2nd floor of the tower which is very convenient. Will definitely return!!

Had a great time , return visit from Feb 2016 and they didn't fail our expectations amazing location and will definitely stay here again . Thanks for making our Xmas happy .No complaints on food or service impeccable as ever . Walking distance to all restaurants better than rest of Tokyo for us . Amazing 5 stars

We stayed 8 nights at this hotel and got to know it a little. The rooms are very quiet, with Tempur-pedic beds, great pillows, and curtains that shut out 100% of the lights, so that you get a really deep sleep after your exhausting days in Tokyo! We ate breakfast almost every morning at Denny's, which is about a 5 minute walk through an interesting neighborhood. You have to go to the Nanpeidai Denny's (not the Shibuya Denny's), which Google Maps will guide you to. Don't use Google Maps inside of the "scramble area" of Shibuya because the tall buildings will block the signal. But when going to the Nanpeidai Denny's, which is in the direction away from the "scramble,", there was no problem following the Google Maps directions. So, about Denny's: we found that they serve a really nice American breakfast set for only 549 yen, including great coffee. That's quite a bit less than the 3,000 yen breakfast at the hotel! We also found out that Denny's is considered at the top quality of breakfast places in Japan. If you're short on time, you can pick up breakfast the 7-11 and have them heat it up for you when you buy it. The other tidbit is to utilize their concierge service as much as possible. Aside from one concierge lady who never smiled and and who gave the most minimalist answer to any question you asked her, the people were very helpful to give advice about anything from which trains to take to where to purchase certain things. If the lady is sitting there, just ask the porters- they were very helpful too. Every hotel in Tokyo charges for swimming/exercise facilities. I think that in Tokyo it is not considered a normal activity. I know that when we stayed in Odawara and Takeyama it was included, however. Our room was a Mount Fuji view on the 31st floor, while our kids got a room overlooking Yoyogi park. What an experience it was to see Mount Fuji at sunset. Best treat ever!

The Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel is absolutely wonderful! The staff were extremely kind and accommodating with unparalleled service. The location is perfect, just a very short walk to Shibuya Station and shopping. The room was First Class, huge King size bed (I think maybe bigger than our King size), plenty of room, and a beautiful bathroom with tub, stand up shower, and multi-function toilet. The building itself houses the hotel along with offices and restaurants, but the rooms are mostly on upper floors and the views are spectacular. The hotel description does say that there is a pool, and there is one in the building, but it is not part of the hotel and is not free. The fitness facility is a separate business and is open to hotel guests from 6am to 7am free of charge, but that does not include the pool. Also, just an FYI, the pool and many of the Tokyo baths do not allow tattoos. I would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Tokyo for the first time!

We had 2 rooms at floors 22 and 29 and both had very fine views, from the Tokyo prefecture building to the west to beyond tokyo tower to the east. Hoteol facilities and amenities were great, with spacious rooms and bathrooms. Great breakfast in the restaurannt. Only negative is expensive (and mean) continental breakfast in the room.

As a family of 6 we always look for a hotel with a pool. I'm sure the one is wonderful, but we never experienced it as they wanted an extra ¥2,500 per person. We were already paying ¥270,000 for 3 nights (2 rooms) so we didn't bother. I think this policy is dreadful in a modern international hotel. I'm not even sure if the cost was per stay or per dip!As a less significant second gripe, I needed 5 small gifts wrapping for some business colleagues. Having little time I asked the concierge to do it for me. It took two attempts and even included a few attempts at Japanese, but both people made me feel like it was a lot to ask. I must say that they came back looking really nice once they had agreed and only charged ¥550, so not all bad, but I have come to expect better service in Japan. The hotel location is close to Shibuya junction and the views of Mt Fuji were nice, but I would not recommend it.

I was in room 2201 and paid for the city view. Had an awesome view of mt. Fuji and felt like a sky view! Fabulous shower and bathroom. Hot water pot, refrigerator, robes etc! Spectacular! Then switched to a sky view room at $75 more a night. It was not available the previous night. New room 2520. On the other side of building. Horrible view blocked by other buildings. Only room available was smoking. We are non smokers. Unlike most US hotels where smoking rooms only differ by having ashtrays due to superior cleaning with no detectable smoke smell, cerulean smoking rooms smell like old smoke smell has permeated the walls and is inescapable. Dispute many attempts to switch rooms and been told they are full all week. So at $375 a night chose your room carefully and smoking means smoking and stinky! The staff is very friendly. Morning buffet $30 and very good!

We stayed at Cerulean Tower Tokyu Shibuya in a winter 2016.All I could say that this hotel is excellent in every way!The location is only a few minutes walk from Shibuya station and shopping area, makes it very convenient to everywhere!There is a 7-Eleven inside the hotel, very convenient!The rooms were spacious, bed was super comfy! Large bathroom with separate bath tub and shower area, complimented with full range of toiletries.We were lucky we got a room that facing the west side of Tokyo, so every fine morning, we would be greeted by Mt.Fuji! Our other rooms were facing other side such as the famous Shibuya scrambled crossing, or Tokyo Tower!The food there was, Mmmmm, very delicious! We had western style breakfast most of the time during our stay. Also we tried the Japanese breakfast which was so lovely and tasty and beautiful! The meal coupons we got, we could choose to have either breakfast (western buffet or Japanese set) or choose lunch sets (many choices to choose) as well.The service from their staff was top! Everyone was polite, knowledgeable and very friendly. Morning, afternoon, evening and night, they will always there to help with smiles!Definitely I would love to stay at The Cerulean Tower Tokyu again and again! And I totally recommend this lovely hotel!

This is a wonderfully located property, a short bridge walk from the Shibuya station and crossing. The hotel has an excellent staff, the service is superb and the hotel decor and furnishing are first class. The restaurant at the top of the building, the Coucagno is first class and a visit there is in order, to be enjoyed. The room we reserved was upstairs with executive priviledges and had a king bed with excellent comforters, down pillows and a comfortable mattress. A great view of metroplolitan Tokyo and the mountains was included. The room included a working business desk, a large closet with amenities, the bathroom was well-appointed and the shower pressure excellent. The maid services were superior. However, the hotel has a few weaknesses. the TV sets are older and only feature Japanese stations, the only English speaking station has Japenese voice overs, ruining the whole thing. The gym is small, and they charge for it ($20) , unless you want to go between 6 to 7 AM, not my idea of a good time, but maybe for some. The exective lounge is great for cocktails and hors d’oeuvres, but the breakfast offerings are average at best and don’t change at all. By day three, you’re ready to go somewhere else for breakfast to not die from boredom or monotony. Lastly, the front desk staff is rigid regarding a late checkout, wanting to charge us $3000 yen for an extra hour after we spent a week at the hotel paying top dollar! Obviously, a reflection of poor corporate policies. An excellent hotel, but can improve without too much effort for what you are charged by the tight-wad owners.

We stayed at this hotel on our way back home to Australia.It was a superb place to get over the long trip from London.The beds were great, the rooms were spotless and the bathroom was amazing, my daughters loved it.The staff were all so very friendly and we had no troubles booking our bus trip back to the airport (1 hour away) at the reception area.The breakfast was delicious and had plenty of options.The location is only a short walk to hundreds of shops both for fashion and tech. There was something for all of us to look at for both men and women.Excellent stay, would stay here again if we get a chance.

Very nice well maintained hotel in Tokyo with a walking distance to the hustle and bustle of Shibuya area.Polite and attentive staff, clean and spacious rooms with great views of Tokyo.has several restaurants in the hotel, as well as many within a waking distance.

“Very good location ”Great near to Shibuya station and the famous crossing restaurants and bars , very easy to go everywhere in Tokyo...Staff is very efficient on all levels thank you for making our stay joyful ...

A huge compliment to the Guest Relations team who really looked after us very well.The guests room was great, however slightly dissappointed with the view as we had emailed the hotel three weeks before requesting a good view as we had paid for the sky view. We were put on the back of the buildingWe had drinks at the 40th floor, but this was a total dissappointment and i wouldnt bother to go there. the staff were NOT interested in service and the bar was out dated and not as expected.Fantastic guest relations, bell team and reception.Had breakfast there two days, which was ok although we experienced some very slow service. Good choice of items and all fresh!

This is a very nice hotel located near shopping mall and many local eateries. It is easily accessible from the airport, just one bus ride to bring you directly to the hotel. It took about 40 minutes each way but no transfer was needed. I was surprised how spacious our room was given that it was in Tokyo. There are restaurants and coffee shops on the lobby level. We tried the breakfast buffet in the restaurant. It was very good, not any more expensive than you would expect in a hotel. The only not too positive comment I have is the quality of the TV. Some channels are OK but some are so-and-so . Overall, we had a very nice and comfortable stay there.

As this was our first trip to Tokyo, we chose Cerulean Tower for its location and comfort. The Shibuya Train Station, which was on the Yamanote Line, was a few minutes walk away (take the south exit to the hotel). Although we arrived at about 12 pm, the hotel let us check-in without any extra charges as the room was ready. We were in a twin-room with 3 beds but it didn't feel cramped at all by Japanese standards. Loved the bathroom with the granite countertops and the amenities provided. It would have been great if the hotel also provided complimentary bottled water or coffee/tea. But that was the only drawback. Everything else was perfect!

Highly recommended for your first trip to Tokyo. It costs a little bit more, but generally in Japan, you get what you pay for. I've been to Japan four times and tried countless hotels, and this is the place I always choose to stay. Please trust me and splurge a little for this hotel, as it will make your Tokyo trip that much better.First of all, the location is absolutely ideal. It is minutes away from Shibuya station, which will easily get you anywhere in Tokyo. However, it is also on the edge of Shibuya, so away from the craziness for when you want to relax peacefully. On the other hand, if you're feeling restless, you can cross a bridge and be in the middle of it all. I highly recommend checking out Shibuya late night, as it turns into something different with merry, drunk youngsters barely able to walk.Room is large by Japanese standards. Bathroom is exquisite with granite showers. Bed is absolutely huge and comfortable. Air conditioning/heating works well. You also get spectacular views of the city from your window.Hotel staff is polite and also warm and friendly. Everything from check-in and baggage handling was great. There is also a 7-11 on the second floor for everything else the hotel cannot provide.One last tip, it is definitely possible to take the Narita airport express to Shibuya and walk to the hotel. However, if you want to do that, make sure you are adequately prepared to find the hotel, as it is a few pedestrian overpasses away and involves scaling some hilly sidewalks. Also, the Shibuya station is usually crazy busy, so take that into account if you plan on traveling with large luggage (it could be a stressful experience if you're lost). Don't be shy and ask the information desks which station exit to use and follow the signs. Alternatively, you can take the airport "limousine bus" directly to the hotel which is much easier.

The Cerulaen is located perfectly for all the must do streets for a quick design trip to Tokyo. Also the Shibuya station is minutes away so it makes staying in a big city like Tokyo very easy. The hotel is huge with large rooms amazing views and a wonderful wine bar not to be missed.

We found this hotel to be exactly what we were looking for in Shibuya. It's just a few minutes walk from the main station there, so the location was excellent in that respect. However, we did find ourselves having to cross to the other side of the highway (via elevated crosswalk) for almost all of our Shibuya destinations, so places that seemed to be just a few minutes away were a bit more than that.With that being said, I didn't see anything too comparable on the other side, so the Cerulean might be as good a hotel as any. Our room was large and decorated very tastefully, and our city view went on for miles, so it really felt like we were perched on the top of Tokyo at times.The breakfast was fairly pricy, but very excellent. For those wanting to start their day like a local, it was a peaceful, zenned-out way to do so.The concierge was helpful in calling some restaurants we had researched, but the one Izakaya that they recommended was the worst meal of our entire trip, so I wonder if they're advice might be skewed, or just dated. In that respect, I would say they are happy to help, but maybe do your own digging as much as you can.

I chose Cerulean tower b/c I wanted a full service hotel after a 12 hr flight for my first time in Tokyo, as well as for its proximity to Daikanyama, Aoyama, Nakameguro & subway links. For this it did not disappoint--my favorite parts of the city were all walkable and/or a short subway ride away (or reasonably priced cab ride if you had enough of the crowds). The room (corner) was huge, well laid out, & was made of high quality materials--I.e. Everything was crisp and clean despite the hotel being 15 yrs old. The granite bathroom was particularly handsome & luxurious. I agree with other reviewers that it is a bit niggardly of them to charge for in room coffee. I found the service to be completely in keeping with expectations. It is located in afar more interesting neighborhood than most 5 star hotels and is a far greater value. Very pleased! Worth mentioning to anyone is a design field is the spectacular garden in the lobby/cafe, one of the best modern gardens in all of Japan designed by Shunmyo Masuno

We stayed here two nights at the end of our trip through Japan. The hotel is located a few minutes from Shibuya Station, but we had some difficulties to actually get to the hotel with our luggage. Being spoilt by another hotel in Tokyo that offers a meet&greet service at the station, Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel kindly answered me by email that the hotel is to be found at the west exit of the Shibuya Station, nothing else. No mention which high rising building it actually is, how to get over the fly-overs outside the station or where the entrance to the hotel is. After some asking (luckily I had the name of the hotel printed in Japanese) and searching around, we finally got to the lobby of the hotel, where we were literally asked by a bellboy what we were doing there? We guess he was still learning English, because what would people with a suitcase be doing at the reception of a hotel? Anyway, we were checked in professionally, but we could not really feel as welcome as in other hotels in Japan. We were taken to the executive floor and when entering the room, our first reaction was really "whow". The views from the room to Odaiba, the sea and Yokohama were incredible by daylight and even better by night. When staying here, one can probably easily skip a visit to the Tokyo Sky Tree, you get the views here from your bed. The room itself was spacious and clean, the same for the bathroom, the colour scheme maybe a bit dull in different shades of dark brown. Unfortunately, the rooms are a bit noisy.Contrary to our impression at the lobby, the staff at the executive lounge was really great, helpful and friendly, the choice at happy hour and breakfast good enough for moderate eaters. We thought it was worthwhile to choose a room at the executive level, we sincerely enjoyed staying here.At the last day of our stay and holidays, we wanted to print our boarding pass, but this turned out to be quite an adventure. It could not be done at the executive lounge, so we were sent down to the lobby, where we were informed that we would have to wait until the business center was available. We could not be informed how long this would take (depended on the person using it) and we could not make a reservation neither. We decided to come back later, but we were lucky, at the moment we wanted to leave, the business center was free. We were informed the use of the computer costs 500 yen per 15 minutes plus 45 yen per printed page. This seemed quite expensive if you look at the price you already pay per night at the executive floor, but we had no choice, so we accepted. The "business center" is a separate room with 2 computers, one Japanese and one international and a printer. We tried desperately to connect to the internet, but nothing happened, had to search for staff to help, to find out that the entire computer had been turned off. When we finally got to print our boarding passes, the printer did not work and we needed once more help from the staff. The printer was out of ink... We needed almost 25 minutes to get something as simple as printing 2 pages done. Because of these problems, we did not have to pay for the use of the internet, only for the use of the paper, so that was a nice gesture. We were on holidays, so this was no big deal, but we would be extremely unsatisfied if we would be on a business trip and would need to use the business center for something really important. The location of the hotel is very central, it is practical to be able to take the shuttle to Haneda airport from the basement of the hotel (difficult to find), but the service at the lobby makes us wonder if we would choose the Cerulean Tower again, specially if taking the price into consideration.It is thanks to the staff at the executive lounge that we rate this hotel at "very good" instead of "average".

I paid a lot to stay at this hotel, and indeed, the view from the top floors is excellent, with a view of mount Fuji on a clear day. However, the hotel never really made me feel welcome or at home. The staff are cool, even cold, and not at all welcoming. The rooms are adequate, but they miss that extra caring touch that makes all the difference in hotels of this class. One particular annoyance was the lack of clarity about the tea and coffee making facilities. From the in-room price list, it seemed as if we were actually supposed to pay for tea bags and coffee !!! We complained about this, and were assured that it wasn't the case. However, when we checked out, they did indeed attempt to charge us for the coffee. That was symptomatic of the cool, "get-your-money conveyor belt" feeling of this hotel. It lacked any character or warmth whatsoever, and I would not stay here again.

The Cerulean Tower Tokyo Hotel is easily reached by pedestrian walkways from Shibuya crossing/Hikarie. If you're doing business in the area, it's ideal. My room was an upgraded room, and as a result the size was on par with what westerners expect in a hotel. The desk and additional seating area made it ideal for working. I love the bedding: tempurpedic mattress and pillows! The overall decor is minimalist, missing a few of those "surprise" moments, but it was a very nice experience. My hotel dining experiences were limited to the buffet breakfast (Japanese and western items) and in-room dining. The room service was unbelievably fast. I ordered dinner very late one evening before a conference call, just 5 minutes before the call was to begin and dinner arrived within 15 minutes! My room was high up, away from elevators and silent.

A very nice hotel. Well located. Convenient limosine transfers from Haneda & Narita. Flawless check-in-out experience. Travelled as a family of 4 with 3 different arrival times from 0900 to 2230. Rooms were clean and spacious. Bathrooms were unusually large. Japanese courtesy and hospitality at its best. Wide (though not large) range of food choices at the in-house restaurant but excellent quality of food. Spent 3 nights and then 1 night later. Will be our go-to hotel in Tokyo!

Good location next to Shibuya Station. Not much going on in the street right outside, but nice and quiet inside and great, authentic neighbourhood - good times. Warning - Smoke free rooms seem to be scarce ... Although they "deoderize" the rooms it's really not the same as an uncontaminated, smoke free room if one is used to it. Late arrival and a bit of whinging seems to have earned me a room on the 36th floor with a great view over Tokyo. If you cannot get the same, do be sure to check out the top floor bar.

I stayed here on business twice in the past three months. It really is a great choice for business travel, but would be great for a city break too. The rooms are spacious (which I understand not all in Tokyo are) and really clean and modern. Amazing views from some of the higher floors. The staff are really attentive and polite and nothing is too much trouble. Breakfast is not as varied as it could be but all the same is great. Great location right in the heart of shibuya. The only thing that lets it down is the fact that even if you are staying here, you have to pay a hefty surcharge to sit in the window at the top floor bar. I just don't think that's right!

We stayed for 4 nights at this hotel in October 2016 over the Halloween weekend. The room we had was high with a stunning city view. It was large and spacious and very well equipped. The bed was large, comfortable and the bedding luxurious. The bathroom was also big with a bath that you could sit in and have great view of the city below.Everything about the hotel was great. The staff were friendly and efficient and couldn't do enough for us. The hotel is in a great location with plenty to do in the evening and with good transport links. The rooms are not cheap but offers luxury and excellent value for money. We liked the hotel so much that we have booked it for a further 2 nights towards the end of November when we have a further two nights in the hotel before we fly back to the UK. We would,thoroughly recommend this hotel if your budget will stretch to it.

Then stay at this hotel. Holy moly. First of all, this is one of the biggest rooms I've ever seen anywhere in my travels, and considering that this is Tokyo, that is amazing. The views are incredible. I could see everything that you would want to see in a Tokyo skyline, right from my room's gigantic picture window. The hotel is located near Shibuya Station, and it's just a short two minute walk. You're in a hip part of town, close to Harajuku, Cat Street, and other trendy shopping areas. The concierge in this hotel is great, super helpful with booking tickets to places and getting you a taxi, among other things. Tours also pick you up from this hotel (depending on which company you go with). It is a pretty expensive hotel, but oh man, no regrets. It was so worth it. The view, the proximity to everything, the service, it was just great.

This hotel was absolutely amazing. We reserved a corner king suite on floor 34, one of the executive floors. The room was great and the views were beyond stunning. We just stood at the window some nights staring out at the metropolis in front of us. The location is such that there are no neighboring skyscrapers to obscure your amazing view of the city. Proximity to Shibuya was perfect for getting around the city, the jazz club in the building was great, and the food in and around the hotel was exquisite. The executive floor features access to a lounge which serves breakfast, tea, and happy hour in a beautiful quiet setting. Compared to the smoky bar on the top floor, the executive lounge is a far superior experience. Would recommend this hotel to anyone looking to travel to Tokyo; make sure to reserve an executive floor room for a truly decadent experience!

Nothing to complain about here. The hotel is beautiful. Wonderfully appointed, amazing views and very friendly staff who go out of their way to help. I wish I was staying longer. If you have the opportunity, you should eat at their rooftop restaurant. One piece of advice, I've tried to get coffee twice and both places told me they only took cash so make sure you've got some on hand. There's a 7 Eleven on property which makes it easy to get tooth paste or anything else you might've forgotten.

I haven't stayed at this hotel before and some of my prior experiences in Tokyo have been far from ideal. But this hotel is great. Our flight landed at 430am and I wasnt expecting check in until 2pm. I thought I would have to go for a very long jet lagged walk. But no. They upgraded me to a corner suite and allowed me to check in 8 hours early. And what a lovely room. With a lovely view. Room 2215 if you can get it. Ha. I will be back

A great luxury hotel near Shibuya Station. Stayed in a room with a great view of the City. Though rooms with the Mt. Fuji view is better. Great amenities and service but breakfast is not yet included and it costs a lot so we opted to have breakfast outside the hotel.

Been staying here couple of times due to great location and delightful staffs. Close walking distance to Shibuya Station (approx 5 mins), restaurants, shopping & entertainment district ( 7-10 mins). On the downside, the room was rather lack of lighting.

We stayed here for the 1st 6 nights of our 3 week holiday in Japan & were very happy with this hotel. The limousine bus from Narita stops right at the hotel entrance. Staff were friendly, helpful & efficient. Our room was large by Japanese standards & very comfortable. It was an easy walk to Shibuya station although we didn't do it with luggage as we sent ours on to our next hotel. Plenty of convenience stores, restaurants & shops close by. We didn't eat any meals at the hotel due to the cost but were able to find well priced options nearby. BYO tea & coffee bags & purchase milk from a convenience store. Tea & cofffee is expensive in Japan & the coffee is of poor quality by Australian standards!

We stayed here for four nights recently on our honeymoon. I will say that we had come from the Marriott in Osaka, so Cerulean Towers had big boots to fill... Which unfortunately they didn't quite fill..Quite a pleasant room on the 28th floor, nice views over Shibuya station/scramble way - even had a brief view of Mt Fuji when the smog lifted one morning which was uplifting. However our first impression on arriving to check in was to be told that the pool/gym were not included in our stay... Considering the cost of our stay I think that was a less than stellar start. Move forward to our room - no complimentary coffee! Even cheap dives I've stayed in have complimentary coffee... (I realize these are small gripes overall, but given the price we paid to stay here AND the fact that Marriott Osaka included everything for much less cost - jus' sayin'...) I will say tho that the staff were lovely, housekeeping did a spotless job each time and the hotel was in a great spot for moving around and seeing the sights. I suspect had we have stayed here first instead of elsewhere my review would not be quite so judgmental (tho the lack of coffee thing is crazy, and should be attended to imo)... Bed was comfy, pillows were a bit weird to my taste and the bedside lamps are just annoyingly and immovably in the wrong spot. Very small choice of tv channels. Shower was great, great views from the bath as well. No moisturizer supplied in the complimentary toiletries. Cannot comment on the restaurants, as we did not eat in the hotel - I did find the prices quite high by comparison- but they certainly were beautifully presented. Would've liked to attend the jazz club onsite, but found a fairly pricy cover charge off putting. This was our first trip to Japan, and I understand that the Tokyo area is more expensive (like most cities)...so perhaps I'm judging unfairly between the two hotels in different cities - but I know which one I'd go back to again.

This is just a short walk from the Shibuya scramble intersection and the metro station. To get to them, you have to cross over the highway by means of a pedestrian overpass. There are reasonably priced restaurants, stores and shopping malls in the neighborhood. The hotel itself is clean and the people working there are unfailingly polite as is the Japanese custom.

This hotel is conveniently located walking distance from Shibuya station and crossing, the largest hub for getting around easily in Tokyo. If traveling from Narita, Shibuya station is the station stop for the Narita Express. The hotel is a close walk but can be cumbersome to navigate the street sidewalks with lots of luggage. The hotel lobby is large and elegant. Our room was spacious, clean, and updated. Room service was delivered warm and on time. There is a 7Eleven located on the lobby level which made it convenient to buy essentials in a pinch. Staff was warm and friendly. About tipping, it was expressed to us that great service and hospitality were considered part of the job and therefore gratuities were not accepted. The gym was small but had all equipment essential for a complete workout. It was never crowded. There are many good restaurants and shops within walking distance of this hotel.

My family and I agree, when we come back to visit Tokyo (and we will!) we can't think of a better place to stay than the Cerulean Towers Tokyu. The room we stayed in (we stayed on the 26th floor (King + Guest Bed) was large and had an amazing view of the city, with the same view from the bathtub. Best of all was the location of the hotel which was about a 8-10 minute walk to the Shibuya Crossing and lots of places to eat and shop. A 4-minute walk from the hotel would also take you to the Shibuya train station. There is also the convenience of having a 7-11 store right inside the hotel for 24/7 convenience. I'm sure there are cheaper places to stay in Tokyo, but this hotel turned out to be an excellent choice for our family.

You get what you pay for. A huge room, lovely L'Occitaine toiletries a large comfy bed and very spacious bathroom. However, charging to for seats to have an expensive cocktail and admire the view in the bar on the 40th floor, even when you are a guest of the hotel is greedy. We sat at the bar and enjoyed our thimble-sized cocktails instead!!

I moved to the tower from across town to be closer to Shibuya station. The location was convenient with a 5-10 minute walk to JR and metro lines. Service was great upon walking into the hotel. The staff is extremely attentive and helpful. The room itself felt a bit dated and not quite 5-star. The shower and bathtub were of good size and the bathroom is supplied with robes and spare toiletries you may have forgotten to pack. I was surprised to find coffee wasn't free and there was no iron in the closet. The internet wasn't very fast but was adequate enough to handle light work. My room included the breakfast buffet. I opted for the Garden Kitchen each day and looked forward each jet-lagged morning to the coffee, fruit, and international variety of morning eats. If you can resist the mini-bar, you'll find a Lawson's on the second floor for your snack and refreshment needs. If you get a higher floor, the views are pretty great. The location was a nice brisk walk away from a lot of popular parts of town to shop, eat and people watch. Finally, if you're doing the Airport Limousine bus, the tower is one of the stops which added to the convenience of not having to lug my bags to the train station.

Fantastic location, just a short walk from Shibuya station. We were lucky enough to get an upgrade to a corner room, I recommend booking one if your wallet allows it. Very friendly service as always in Japan. The only downside is trying to find the South Exit out of Shibuya station, it was a little confusing, especially when we were carrying our bags around. It's a short walk then uphill, but nothing any able bodied person should have any difficulty with.

The Cerulean tower is a great hotel.Very well appointed, the room are very spacious for Japan standards with a massive bed. I went there years ago and it felt phenomenal. It turns out I had an upgrade and my room was certainly a lot fancier than the one I had this time.Last time I had a massive bathroom with a bath under the window. This time the bathroom was ok but not a patch on the last time. The room this time was pretty spacious nonetheless, with a good wardrobe area and lots of nice touches.The bathroom although nice has shower and bath combined, it is pretty dark and I felt the lighting could be improved. The bed is very comfortable. The thing that annoyed me was to pay over 2000 yen to use the gym. The gym is a hotel gym ... ie. not a full fitness centre. Had a decent range of equipment but not even a cross trainer for example. I feel it should be included in the pretty steep price of the room.

We got an upgrade on the room on our two weeks stay here. Check in was very quick. All the staff is so friendly and courteous. They also speak english so that helped a lot. Room was very clean. And the view was just amazing from 32nd floor. Location of this hotel is so awesome that everything is near by. Shibuya station, shopping, restaurants, cafe, bar, and etc. Out of all the venue that hotel had we were very happy about 7-11. I know that sounds really funny. I been to many hotels but never seen a 7-11 that carries at all. lolz. Of course we would just buy water, japanese pastry, coffee, face wipe, and stuff. lolz We only went there to get essentials but it's good to see a place that is open late night to get some items you need. All the staff at this hotel is so friendly and helpful. We got help for making reservations, making change for small bills, getting information about limobus back to the airport and etc. We were very satisfied. Our stay was very pleasant and I can't think of one negative thing about this hotel."Thank you Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel for my wonderful first visit!"

I stayed there with two other people after a concert in Suntory Hall. We arrived back at the hotel after 10pm and were able to have a light snack in the coffee shop in the hotel which is open until midnight. The panini was excellent as was the crab fried rice. The room was spacious for a hotel in the middle of Tokyo - and the bath came complete with all the amenities one would hope for. The view of the city was spectacular. The service was excellent as was the Japanese style breakfast - although a bit pricey. I would recommend this hotel for everyone!

Stayed fours days with family in a 3 persons corner room on 22. floor. We have travelled to Tokyo and Japan many times and stayed at very different types of locations, first time at Cerulean, and very satisfied. Points to share :1) It is an excellent, comfortable. luxurious hotel , not brand new, but does not feel worn in any sense, well kept; a bit anonymous perhaps, but style is grand.2) Location in Shibuya is nearly ideal, less than 5 minute walk from the station, some uphill and over pedestrian bridges, but has elevator where you need it for luggage. Shibuya station area is under massive reconstruction but this does not pose serious nuisances for staying. Very easy to find the hotel - the tallest building in Shibuya.3) View from our 22 floor room (=not executive or top level) was outstanding - we were lucky to get the city side with all of centre from Shinjuku to Tokyo tower in sight. Even the bathtub had this view - amazing day and night4) It was a 3-person room, of extra size (corner room), but the third bed was just added, not 'built in', so even if space was large for Tokyo it was not like enormous.5) Note: WIFI is now free throughout the hotel, we did not have a special deal.6) No noise to notice from the very busy city below thanks to thick window glazing (aircon worked well and was also quiet)7) Breakfast was Ok fine, nothing grand or exceptional. We had to pay for it , so only did it once, plenty other options nearby8) Surprised we had to pay for the in-room coffee, was not indicated on checklist9) Awesome dinner at elegant European style top restaurant Coucagno (separate review), but also very expensive10) Efficient service (although we did not need much of it), no wait at check-in/out. We got our room around 1 pm, 2 hours before official check-in11) Main drawback. It was expensive! We were a bit late with our bookings so many good cheaper options were gone. Under the circumstances Cerulean was a fine solution and not unreasonable for the quality we had, but advice is to book early; unless you really need the luxury.

Location is superb. Down a walkway and you are at Shibuya station/ metro station and the famous Shibuya crossing and all the shops. I was very early for check in after an overnight flight and whilst I had a coffee in the lobby cafe a room was sorted for me. A young girl insisted on taking my case and showing me to the room and no one expects a tip. The room was fabulous on the 28th floor on a corner with amazing views over the city. We had a huge bathroom, lounge area and two big double beds and there was no noise from within the hotel. Everyone was so happy, helpful and smiley. I can thoroughly recommend this hotel for anyone wanting to stay in the city. The only complaint that I would have is that when we went up to the beautiful bar at the top of the hotel we were told that there was a 1300 yen (about £10) charge per person to sit in a comfortable chair at one of the tables even for residents. The only places to sit that did not incur this charge were at the bar or at the back of the bar on high stools. We decided to have some food there with a business colleague one night and even though we had 6 glasses of wine in total and 3 main meals we still had to sit at the bar. The views were spectacular and the atmosphere was super but the next night we ate out as we felt that this was a penny pinching attitude especially when we were spending a lot of money on accommodation and then subsequently more money on food and drink - to expect us to pay £30 on top of this was ridiculous. I feel that the management need to review this policy as it lets down an excellent hotel

Stayed here because the OG Based God Angelo Baque and the Supreme skateboard team stayed here. Had drinks and food at the bar on top and the view was crip. This place did not disappoint. Will stay here again next year. 5/7!

Lovely hotel in central position near transport. However do not expect to swim in their pool unless you pay extra or stay on several executive floors. Check the mini bar list because coffee is 400 yen a cardboard cup. I have never been charged to swim or to have a coffee in the room.

My husband and I stayed here in March of this year for the final leg of our honeymoon to Japan. I can't say enough good things about this hotel. They were nice enough to leave us chocolates and a kind note offering their congratulations, which was such a pleasure to find coming into the room. The amenities were AMAZING, the bathroom was incredible (the tub had the best view of Tokyo), and the room was massive. They had great restaurants and bars in the hotel, as well. For a similar price point, this is probably the nicest hotel I've stayed in. It made our honeymoon so memorable, and I can't thank the staff enough for their incredible hospitality.

The hotel was centrally located and very clean. The rooms were gorgeous and the views even from the bathroom are insane. It was a little silly that one had to pay 25 a day to use the gym. The bar on the rooftop has amazing views and yummy cocktails!

Up to expectation for a 4 star hotel. 5 or 6 restaurant inside the hotel (expensive though, avoid the Japanese one) and great breakfast. At one of them. Room was upgraded for free.Good location 5 min walk from Shibuya station and Shibuya district. Recommend if in your budget.

I stayed here with a group doing an Architecture and Design Tour of Tokyo. The hotel is well situated, close to the JR and Tokyo subway stations in Shibuya.Its a 5 star hotel and has all of the amenities that you would expect. Room are large with a walk in closet and well equiped bathroom with all the amenities that you would expect in a hotel of this calibre. There are a number of restaurants in the Hotel but be warned they are expensive - $80 to $100 per person. Hotel staff are very helpful with good English spoken. You have a choice about which items are replaced or changed daily as part of their Eco program.

the location is excellent-short walk to JR station, subway, Shibuya Crossing etc bit quiet. the hotel is very nice- great views, multiple restaurants, 24 hr 7-11 onsite which is great when you have jetlag/kids. it is a stop on the limo bus from Narita which is great too.

Was here for business and it's lovely and it's ok, nothing terrible.It's not cheap and I imagine a top service but everything costs extra, $20 to use swimming pool even for staying guests, restaurant is not all that for $30 breakfast.Another charge to print a couple of pages...Great if you don't mind throwing money around to get whatever done.Naughty but this gets 4 stars instead of 3 because this trip really was a life changing experience for me and for accommodating me during my stay and for the gratitude, it gets extra star :)

Cannot get temperature below 23 and room stinks, is hot stuffy and humid. They charge extra for tea bags!!! and also gym use $28USD on top of room charge!!. Penthouse bar smells stale also. Would never use again - only here because design tour operator selected but it is not a design oriented hotel. On the upside, staff are generally very helpful and garden is beautiful.

Nice hotel next to shibuya, you can have a drink at the top floor at the lounge bar with an amazing Tokyo view.The hotel restaurants are very good.The negative point is the room size and the old design.

Amazing luxury hotel in the Shibuya area. Check in/out was simple and straight forward and the lovely concierge ladies help you with your luggage and show you to your room. The room itself is stunning. A gigantic bed that was super comfy, walk in closest and lovely bathroom. Great views of Tokyo from your room.The location is excellent, easy walking distance to many attractions in Shibuya.There are many restaurants located in the hotel and also a 24hour 7/11 shop attached.Staff were extremely polite and helpful. They can arrange transport to the airport as the bus stop is below the hotel. In summary, a great hotel with great service. We loved our stay here.

Direct access from Narita airport. Take the Narita airport express (approx. £15pP) to Shibua station and use the West exit (this is the simplest and fastest route as Shibua station is huge). Once you exit, you see can already see the hotel (look diagonal). Easy access by using footpath.When making our reservation, we asked for early check-in and a room higher up in the hotel. Both were possible and the views are impressive. No need to book the breakfast option, there is a bakery with good take away coffee and fresh pastries in the lobby.Although not as luxurious as the Aman Hotel or Mandarin Oriental, this hotel has everything you need from a luxury hotel without having to pay £600 per room per night. The location is great for Shibuya - the famous crossing can be best observed from the Starbucks overlooking the crossing just 2min walk from the hotel. There is also a food market very close by with great sushi at Sushi no midori. You can also walk to one of the most popular shrines - Meiji shrine from the hotel or take the subway for two stops. Tokyo subway is great, just avoid 8-9:30am if you can help it. Enjoy your stay!

Our great experience started even before we checked in - we've asked the concierge to help us book our lunch & dinner reservations to several restaurants as it was difficult to call the restaurants from the US because of the time difference. Yoko and Naoko were very helpful and replied to all our email requests and they were able to book our restaurant requests and even changes in our reservations. And taking the red-eye from SF means early morning arrival in Tokyo. We got to the hotel at 6:30am and was granted early check-in at no cost which could have been an extra day charge! Talk about world class hospitality!! We also asked for a skyview room on the higher floors and were given a room on the 35th floor - and the view was magnificent despite Tokyo's grey skies! The staff was very courteous and could communicate in English so there was no language barrier. We chose this hotel because of it's close proximity to the hip area of Daikan-yama. Of course, a 5-minute walk to Shibuya is an added bonus! There's also a 7-11 on site so it's convenient for quick breakfast or anything in between. Thank you Cerulean for a memorable stay! Yoko and Naoko - you're amazing!!

This hotel is perfectly located in Shibuya . One can easily walk to a number of fantastic eating, bars ect. It is very close to Shibuya station very convenient to reach other spots in Tokyo . I started on my own for a couple of days (was joined by my boyfriend afterwards) . I must mention that the area very safe to be walking around on own all times of day and night. The hotel itself is refined & stunning service . The staff go out their way to ensure you are having a great stay without being too much in your face. The room had a beautiful view of Tokyo (I believe all rooms do ) & the night lights of the city are magical. Tokyo itself is an amazing , busy interesting city. There are so many things to do at all hours. The hotel is a perfect base to do that . Well done to this excellent hotel.

I had a ten days vacation with my wife to Japan Tokyo Shibuya, on 25 AUG 2016, my flight arrived late at Dubai so my connection flight to Tokyo departed half hour early, so I had to stay one night at Dubai, the next day departed to Haneda airport, arrived at midnight, in the airport I went to the bus counter to buy tickets, keep in mind the tickets price will double after midnight but still cheaper than a taxi. Arrived at the hotel door less than an hour drive, I had to figure out which way the hotel entrance, because the bus will drop you at B1, so you wont see the main hotel entrance, luckily saved me the hotel porter, carried my luggage and it was easy check inn, just note that most the porters at the hotel are women, which I had to help her carry my luggage in my room, it wasn't an issue for me, but for some it might be embarrassing especially if your luggage are heavy, the room was nothing but great, the bathroom by it self is a room, separate shower and you have the choice to shower in the tube or standing! , there was a welcome fruit, the view I belief all around the hotel are excellent, why I say that because after four days from my arrival I changed my room just for a change for a view, I had a deferent view were I can see shibuya crossing, Tokyo tower, Yoyogi Park, and most of Tokyo skyscrapers, the A/C in the rooms, the coldest temperature you can get is 20 Celsius the thermostat wont go below this temperature, the hotel location is great, calm with many restaurants and cafes close by, even there is seven eleven supermarket at the hotel building made my stay very comfortable especially for water as the hotel will not provide you with in your room, the hotel staff are very respectful and helpful, as matter of fact that was my first visit to Japan and let me tell you I found not only the hotel staff respectful but most of the Japan people are very respectful from the minuet I arrived at the airport until the minuet I left Japan, nothing bothered me at all, shopping at shibuya is great, if you want women clothing at good price go to Shibuya 109 Department Store's and there is 109 for men close by also, tax free every where in japan, very easy, every shop has its own tax free, right a way, they don't count the tax for you just carry your passport, and if you want Convenience store with groceries & household items, plus take-out sushi, cosmetics & other prepared foods for cheaper prices go to Don Quijote Shibuya, very crowded but it worth the visit, not to forget the Shibuya Station at the Shibuya crossing intersection, where you can visit most of Tokyo by JR or the metro where you can find the Tokyo Subway Navigation for tourist application at the apple store very helpful, but don't forget in the way back to exit from west exit at shibuya station to your hotel, Overall the only thing that I didn't expect from the hotel is that they count my first night that I missed from my late flight at Dubai, which they kept telling me that they will solve it In spite of my call in advance while I am at Dubai.

I am in Tokyo on business and of course I have appointments.Therefore it is inacceptable that you have to queue up for 15 to 20 minutes to get a breakfast. The hotel could with a little management do much better here:First there are plenty of seats in the lobby but the staff of the breakfast restaurant Caramelo does not use them.Second there are several mostly American tourists claiming that their group is already in and they are just passing by the staff. They are sending one member of the group in early to block several seats making everybody else wait.

The room is good, but the fitness rules is unacceptable. When I entered the fitness room, they said that children under 18 years old are not allowed to enter the pool. This rules are different from other hotels in other places part of Japan and other country. I was really upset cause I could swim, and we actually pay for this hotel. The Gym, which my father wanted to go, was chargeable. It was only for higher levels of the hotel to go in for free. My family was disappointed with this hotel rules. Hope Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel would look into my family and I's comment!

Great place to stay, very clean, very friendly staff. Rooms were quite large which was surprising. From the clientele in the lobby, you get the impression this is a hotel for business people more than holidayers. Location is great, very close to station the main part of Shibuya. Would not recommend the hotel for anyone wishing to exercise, as it is a ¥2000 charge to use the gym, per day, per person - this worked out to approximately $25 AUD per day, and was quite steep to train for an hour

I have just checked in to the Cerulean Hotel today. The location is excellent and staff very polite.However I am disappointed with the basic services. This is the only hotel I have ever stayed in where only green tea is provided in the rooms. There is no regular black teas, no sugar, no milk or creamer and no drinking water either. I think even most non-star rated hotels provide these basic needs of a hotel guest.

Stayed 3 nights at Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel on the back end of our Japan trip and it was an incredible ending to our family vacation. Everything about the hotel beginning with the staff, lobby, elevators, rooms, bathrooms, amenities, service, treatment, etc was top notch. The spacious room had a magnificent view of the city. The king bed was huge. Marble countertops in bathroom, stand up shower with separate big tub. Even the lounge chairs were comfortable. Will definitely stay here next time I visit Shibuya area.Location wise, it is within 8 minute walk to the Shibuya train station, Shibuya crossing and all shopping.

You cannot fault this hotel on the service quality.However, the room climate is disastrous and this is a serious "no-go".As soon as we stepped out of the elevator on the 27th floor we noticed, that there was no fresh air in the hallway and that there was an omnipresent smell of a "wet pullover". In our completely overheated room (2720) the smell got worse and turned into "mold" and "wet dog". We asked the bellboy to activate a Daikin streamer (cf picture) which was already in the room. (A streamer is especially made for purifying air form bacteria and humidity - we had to look up the machine because the operating panel is only in Japanese).Nothing happened, we called reception and they were sending up a technician. Meanwhile we took a midnight walk in the neighborhood. Upon our return the room was acceptable at the price of having a strong rattling fan noise. So we had to sleep with ear plugs. Everyday, the cleaning lady raised the temperature on the AC and cut off the air purifier. This meant that each time you got back to your room you had an unpleasant situation. This is evidence for blunt money saving at the back of the well being of the client. Dear hotel manager have you ever considered that an unsatisfied client might cost you more than a few marginal gains on the electricity bill. You proudly state having ISO 14001 - go ahead and subscribe green electricity, replace the old generation of air conditioners, clean the filters but don't compromise on hospitality standards!Same misery in the generously sized bathroom. The air extraction is not powerful enough. Humidity and odors stay for hours.Last but not least, the also generously sized closet has no shelves. We had to live out of the open suitcase put on the floor. After 2 days our clothes were as damp as the atmosphere in the room.Check-out was smooth, no eye contact no inquiry about our satisfaction. This is definitely not how it should be when you want to wear the label "Luxury hotel".

There are no words to describe the experience staying in this hotel. The rooms are quite big with a fantastic view of the city through a really big window. Bathroom is extremely big with all the amenities needed for your stay.Breakfast is really nice even though you're not Japanese.Service is always at your disposal no matter what.Definetely a must in Tokyo

One night stop in Cerulean. Clean, friendly staff, good location and good food as well as quite affordable. Downside: we were 4 (2kids: 8 and 4 and 2 adults) and had a room with 3 beds! In Tokyo, kids under 8 don't count so you have to be specific when you reserve! As its a business hotel, no activities for kids and swimming pool for adults only.

I stayed here with my husband and 16 month old daughter.This is a lovely although perfectly typical 5 star hotel. The hotel is a 7 minute walk from Shibuya station. We had a pram and so needed to take 2 elevators to get across the pedestrian walkway towards the station; this made the walking time 10 minutes all up. Though the hotel is reasonably priced for 5 star in Tokyo (about $500 a night), they make up the balance of their income from what I personally regard as exorbitant prices for ancillaries. Eg: coffee in the restaurant downstairs $10. One load of laundry would have come to $170 but I just washed it myself in the bath. One small bottle of Perrier soda water cost me $13. You get the picture. The rooms are not too cold and you can control the temperature really well. The room was nice and big.The hotel staff was competent and most members of the staff spoke English very well.The views from our room were spectacular and the extra large window was immaculately clean.I would definitely recommend this restaurant to a friend but I would say stay away from the hotel food and services, as it is outlandishly priced.

Travelling to Japan for work I thought it would be good for my husband to come too. On arrival the reception questioned their being two people - the booking, by my understanding, was for a room, not per person. Apparently not the case. We had to pay for my husband to stay - a rather unexpected expense. Having said that the staff and service have been wonderful. The room a great size with the most amazing views - even saw Mt Fuji on two occasions. Location wise very convenient and within walking distance to Shibuya Station.

Last year my boyfriend and I went to Tokyo the first time. and OMG, why can't I just go there more often?!?!?!?! I love the location of this hotel, we are right at Shibuya, we went shopping at Uniqlo, and got some good but very reasonably priced sushi within 15 mins walk. A lot of bars around, just have to check the opening hours since most of them have afternoon break. Oooo... and our room, the night view was amazing. All in all, this is a great stay.

Spent three days there this week for business.Firstly, the location is the best reason to stay here, couldn't be more convenient.Stayed here once about ten years ago and it would seem nothing has changed with the times. Limited plug ins for devices, crappy old TV set and super thin walls between rooms, so you get to hear everything next door going on in the middle of the night.Busy hotel with average service and didn't appreciate being charged extra to use the gym.Not sure I will stay here again.

The Cerulean Towers Hoel is very quiet and comfortable by all international standards. The staff are numerous, attentive, and helpful with good English skills. The dinner in the Coucagno Restaurant at the top floor was excellent with unparalleled views of Tokyo; the Japanese-French fusion was a delight. The hotel's proximity to the Shibuya Metro and JR stations made it a perfect jumping off point to explore Tokyo.

Great service. Great breakfast buffet. Incredible people and great location.It was my first time in Tokyo and I specifically got a room with a view - no regrets there.Staff was super helpful and polite, location was super close to the big and handy Shibuya station - so could get to the other side of town quickly by hopping on the train or a taxi to nearby Shinjuku or Harajuku wasn't that expensive. The area in general was super trendy and cool and well serviced for entertainment. A little bit on the expensive side though. Room was really nice albeit small, but they definitely helped make my first time in Tokyo really smooth!

There are two great things about this hotel: the rooms and the location. Firstly, as the hotel is one of the tallest buildings in the area and the rooms start on the 20th floor or so, you are almost guaranteed to get a great view. Ours was west facing on the 28th floor, which a huge panorama across Tokyo and Mt Fuji in the far distance on a clear day. Secondly, the location close to Shibuya station is great for the nightlife and shopping in the area, as well as being close to a transport hub for easy access to the rest of the city.The hotel may call itself Western, but it is definitely at the Japanese end of the scale, which is no bad thing. It is reflected architectually- it is quite austere and simple in its interior design- more of a Japanese style than Western, which is good.The bar on the top floor is great at night for a view of Shibuya and its famous crossing.Only negative is the pool and gym, which, whilst clean, you need to pay around 20USD for per time if you are not staying on a "premium" floor, which is a bit tight in my opinion as this hotel charges luxury prices even for the most basic rooms.

I had no idea about this hotel but I can tell you ,it will be a keeper. The people from the front desk to the concierge staff, were extremely helpful. Rooms were great. Restaurants a little on the high side but not overpriced. The wine selection by the glass on the roof top bar was medium at best if that all you drink. Beer drinker no problem. Lots of nice restaurants with English menus around the hotel, ask the staff. and rather not expensive. Good value for a 5 star hotel.

Good hotel conveniently located for Shibuya area and good for Shibuya station. Found it the perfect base for our stay. Rooms a little musty but when air con is on it's not a problem, air con quiet enough to be used all night. Bathrooms immaculate. Only negatives for me are the breakfast, I found it to be okay in terms of selection but unnecessarily pricey for what it was. The other negative would be the restaurants, they were average at best, however with the location it makes it very easy to go and find good restaurants locally.

It was nice to arrive after a long flight and stay at a comfortable western style hotel (we stayed at traditional inns for the rest of our stay). There is a bus directly from Narita airport to the hotel which was very convenient. The hotel is about a 5 minute walk to Shibuya metro/rail station, so it is easy to get around. (it is hard to find the correct exit from the station - look for the "South" exit which is closest to the hotel). Tons of restaurants in the area. The hotel breakfast buffet is good, but quite expensive if you are not on a plan. The do not allow children in the swimming pool. The rooms a pretty large and very clean.

We booked this on the fly as our flights got delayed and we arrived late and at a different airport in Tokyo! Booked this based on TA reviews and appreciate the straight forward honest info. If you are eager to shop in Shibuya, this is an ideal location, with an easy walk to the scramble.

We booked this place on the move as our flights got mixed up traveling from Seattle to Tokyo after using the TA app in the airport. It was good to know that we could rely on the other reviews and book with confidence.Our stay was limited to a stop-over night but everything was as described by others.

Staffs were very helpful. Speak good English. The room and king bed are of good size. Bath and shower was very good too. Beautiful view from the 32nd floor. Good quality sleep at night. The location is good, but not great. Still a good 5-10 minutes hilly walk across a busy road to Shibuya station/crossing. If you arrive by train, it's a bit work to drag your luggages across at least 3-4 flights of stairs to get to the hotel. Better to catch the shuttle bus to and from the airport if you have luggages. The hotel is clean and spacious. However, does not feel like a "grand" 5 stars hotel.

Not your typical Japan size hotel rooms, complete amenities for a 5 star hotel, high-rise with a great view of the city of Tokyo, although quite expensive, it's within walking distance very near Shibuya district, only 10 minutes walk from the famous Shibuya crossing and Shibuya train station.

This hotel is conveniently located in Shibuya. The rooms were outdated, but sometimes you have to give up luxury for location. The restaurant downstairs had a great breakfast buffet, which is one of the things I take note of when traveling internationally. Another great plus about this hotel was the 7/11 connected to the outside of the hotel. Every morning I would go and get coffee for 100 yen. STEAL! The downside of this hotel is that to get to central Shibuya where the "happening places" are you have to cross the bridge because it's over a freeway and across the street. Now at night time, the elevator to that bridge closes around 10pm, so if your traveling with a stroller or wheelchair your SOL. You have to then go to another bridge several blocks down and trek your way up to the bridge that has a ramp all the way up. If your stroller or wheelchair is heavy, good luck.

this hotel is nicely situated in shibuya. close to eki, shops and restaurants.i went for a business trip alone, and the location of this hotel is great. hotel staff were nice and they tried to accommodate all my requests with eagerness.i stayed at the 33rd floor and the view was awesome. breakfast at 35th flr in the morning with view of the city is perfect to start the day.

There was no info on the website about the 2160 Yen charge for swimming pool or gym! Would have liked to have used both but for a 30' session way too extortionate! The pics looked tempting. Having said that my wife is allergic to memory foam mattresses which our King room (8' wide bed!!) had so the staff kindly put a King size mattress on top. Amazing views of the Tokyo Tower from room 2713!

We recently stayed at the hotel as a family. It's a fantastic location 2 blocks from the busy Shibuya crossing. The hotel itself is dated, we had issues with air conditioning and rooms were clean and fine but certainly not 5 star quality. Service was decent, not great--had difficulty getting directions from staff and concierge was nearly useless when trying to discuss day trips.

We stayed in a superior non smoking room with a city view on the 23rd floor, we were very impressed with the room and its amenities. The bed was huge and comfortable. The bathroom was large, the wet room was great, there was no leaking of water into the bathroom area. The temperature of the water was always hot too. The AC was quiet too. The staff are very attentive, friendly and go out of their way to help. We received a welcome gift of chocolate and desserts on arrival and during our stay. The staff all speak English well. We also had coffee and cake at the garden lounge cafe at the hotel on one of the mornings. I couldn't hear people in the corridors or from the neighbouring rooms either. The only slight issue we had was that we could hear dogs barking in the mornings, there seems to be some sort of dog store nearby. However I am a light sleeper and didn't hear it again after a few days.The location is central, short walk to the station and many restaurants and shops nearby. I would recommend this hotel to everyone and I would not hesitate to stay here again when visiting Tokyo in the future.

Stayed here recently for 5 days and location was great walking distance to Shibuya Station. Staff was friendly and speaks English and was great in helping us make reservations at Hakushu prior to arrival.Was able to see Mt. Fuji on one clear morning from our room at the 23rd floor. It was awesome as we did not have enough time to make a day trip to Hakone. Would have given 5 stars if not for the coffee which cost us 400 yen each. *****Check the minibar list before touching anything (we've stayed at a lot of hotels and this is the first one that charges for coffee and tea). With the room rate you wouldn't expect to pay extra for a bad tasting coffee, we would not have touched it if we weren't too tired to walk to 7 Eleven attached to the hotel and if we'd known it was not complimentary.Overall, would still recommend the hotel when you visit Tokyo, choose the room with sky view.

I've visited Tokyo the last three years and have stayed at Cerulean each time, the most recent in July 2016 with my family (two kids under 10 and my wife). First, the location is excellent, under a 5m walk to Shibuya station (JR) and walkable to Harajuku if you don't mind 15-20m. Of course, Shibuya has tons of shopping and restaurants as well.The hotel is modern, very clean, with large bathrooms, especially for JP/EU standards. The beds are smaller than US size but fine. Staff speaks English and is super helpful. The concierge can help with tickets, reservations, transportation, etc. There's also a 7-11 convenience store attached to the building (though you have to go outside up the escalator) which is nice.Note that kids 11 and under are "free", meaning if they share a bed with there is no charge - i.e. you can have 2 adults and 2 kids in a double room (essentially two double beds). The beds are smaller than US (not Queen size!) - should be fine for the average US 8 year old or under but bigger kids and adults will be cramped.The hotel caters more towards professionals but I'd come back with my family. It can be one of the pricier options but I've always been able to book rooms between $275-$325 a night.
