You will have freshly squeezed orange juice and eggs (all styles but they love to prepare omlets for you) breads, croissants etc..The hotel is very close to Shibuya train and metro station which is convenient.Some shopping around but for locals ....

The hotel is in best possible location in Tokyo, near Shibuya. The famous Shibuya Crossing is just 5 minutes away. The biggest problem was that they did not provide free water in room. I have been to so many hotels, both big and small and nowhere I have seen this.Pros:LocationDecent breakfast menuGood view from the roomCons:No free water in roomExpensive breakfastRoom size is not that big

Great location! Close to everything, beautiful views from the room and great service. We were upgraded to a better room upon arrival, and although it was clear that my room was upgraded, my friends rooms were much MUCH smaller. I couldnt see how that was an upgrade to be honest, but i guess its the thought that counts. Small really small annoyances:- nowhere to smoke a cigarette at the hotel - no air freshner in the room (even budget hotels in Tokyo provide this, again not a deal breaker)- breakfast was extremely expensive- upgrade of the room did not look like an upgradeThe good- hotel staff was really nice- bell desk was really polite- beds were comfortable- great selection of International TV channels (thats rare in Tokyo)Its a grand 5 star hotel, but i think i would still stick to Excel Tokyo, although not as luxurious, it provides everything i need for half of the price and right int he middle of Shibuya.

The double room we booked was spacious by Tokyo standards, with a full sized bath tub and a separate shower. (We stayed in a Tower floor double room on the 33rd level). Though the complementary breakfast was average, the coffee was decent and there is a great view of Mt Fuji from the lounge on the 35th floor(we did not have a view of Mt Fuji from our room, luck of the draw I suppose).The airport limo bus to and from Narita and Haneda airports stops here, which is especially useful if one has a lot of luggage on the way home.A short walk across a pedestrian bridge over the main road in front of the hotel takes you to Shibuya station, crossing, and the heart of the action.

This hotel was in a wonderful location. Just minutes from the Shibuya train station. Rooms were spotless and we had an amazing veiw of the city from our room. Bathroom was immaculate and had a large shower. We looked at a number of hotels online and a lot of them looks tiny. The rooms at this hotel were very spacious. Minutes walk from Shibuya crossing and the Shibuya area where it is all happening. There is a store just on the corner where you can stock up on cheap drinks and snacks. We had buffet breakfast at the hotel on two occasions which had a great selection. Only downside was you had to pay to use the pool and given how much we were already paying it was a little disappointing. I would definitely recommend staying here overall. Great rooms to unwind in after a day of exploring the city. Shinjuku is just minutes away by train which was another area we contemplated staying in.

I have stayed here several times as this location is so convenient for exploring Tokyo. Location wise, this has to be one of the best hotels if not the best hotel. Possibly the tallest building in Shibuya (you can't miss it), this hotel has convenient access to the train/subway stations (less than 5min walk to JR Shibuya Station) to get you to anywhere in Tokyo. Take advantage of the airport limousine (bus) that takes to to/from the hotel. This is a much cheaper and more comfortable option than a taxi or the train/subway. You can ask for a room with a great view of Shibuya Crossing and much of the area. It also has close proximity to Shibuya Hilarie and Shibuya Mark City (about 5 min walk) which are large shopping centers with great food courts. There is also a 24hr 7-Eleven on the hotel grounds for your convenience. Hotel staff is friendly and helpful. Rooms are very clean and comfortable. Highly recommended.

Stayed 3 nights in Shibuya. Large, modern room with a bathroom to die for. The marble bathtub has a large window with a view of Shibuya. You can even see the Tokyo Tower in the distance. Bathroom has separate tub and shower. Hotel is within walking distance of the Shibuya crossing, restaurants and shops. Check out the food stands in the department stores there. You can find so many sashimi types that simply do not exist in the States. It's also close to the subway with access to all Tokyo attractions. Highly recommended.

I love this hotel. I go out of my way to stay here. The staff is wonderful, the rooms are incredible and the views are truly other-worldly. I'd stay here again in a heartbeat, just in a different room. Quirkiest negative comment of 2015: I stayed in room 2916, below which is a building that has a roof which serves as a....dog park. When the dogs are out, despite being a good 15 stories below, it's all I can hear. Dozens of dogs barking constantly, and surprisingly present given the distance. I took video but thought that would be obnoxious to post. I'd just warn anyone who is sensitive to such a thing to stay on another side of the tower. Obviously there's nothing the hotel can do about it.

This was our final two nights stay and well worth the expense the views from our room were breath taking, get up as high as possible!Close or the crazy end of town but on the quiet side.All the usual mod cons, small simple room with huge expansive windows that made it look larger.

Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel is located in busy Shibuya area.The location is not the best, although it is only 5 minute walk from Shibuya Station, there is some uphill walk, it would be not easy if you walk with a lot of shopping bags. The good side is the hotel is very quiet.The room is good in size (Tokyo standard), clean and comfortable. Service is good, helpful staff and speak good English. The Concierge even helped us to make a few restaurant reservations before our arrival.

This is excellent hotel. Everything worked. Nice views from the upper floors over all Tokyo.I stayed in Executive floor. The executive lounge was bit on the weak side. Not much food offered. You can get to the hotel directly by airport bus. There is metro station in appr 300 m walk away. Some good restaurants at the street just off the hotel entrance.

We stayed here for 5days we had a great time walking distance to shibuya crossing you just need to use the bridge outside the hotel 5mins walk thats it your in shibuya crossing, nice big rooms, clean and big toilet, breakfast is nice, room service my favorite you can order food from the 3 resto located in the hotel. 7/11, family mart, resto, is just outside the bldg. The steak Meal the best you have to try. Cake also very delicious, high speed internet, the concierge people very helpful she gave almost everything map, shopping magazine, tourist attraction guide, Train map. They very polite and they always smile very accommodating I like them. When in Japan check in at Cerulean. You wont be disappointed.

Booked this hotel for a business trip. Staying for a week in November. I had an Exec. corner room, very comfortable and spacious. Bar on 40th floor has little atmosphere, breakfast is ok. I didn't have the chance to try the fitness facilities.

The Cerulean Tower's location was perfect for sightseeing and shopping in Shibuya. Very close to the Shibuya station, tons of restaurants, shopping and nightlife. We first stayed for 3 nights in a room with view of Fuji (only visible one of the days when there were clear skies), and it had an amazing bathroom / shower / bath. Very luxurious. We came back after a week of traveling outside of Tokyo and stayed in a room with huge windows in the bathroom overlooking the scramble crossing which was really nice. Would stay here again in a heartbeat.

We stayed here for three nights and appreciated that is was centrally located and had reasonable rates, but the overall experience left a bit to be desired. While many of the rooms have great views, the general decor rooms is a bit tired and could use an update. The staff that checked us in were smiley and gracious, but our experience with their exceptionally rude concierge has left a lasting impression unfortunately.

This place is great! Across the street from the train station. Surrounded by great restaurants and high floor rooms have amazing views of the city. Priced reasonably for a first class hotel. We had a 32nd floor room and our view was unforgettable. The bar is pricy but around the corner is about 100 bars and restaurants to fit any desire.

Everything was good : the bed, the size of the room, etc.But you see the difference between this kind of hotels and a real luxury one : the staff is just OK (some were even rude), the price of the tea in the lobby is very expensive for nothing (not a very special tea that will justify the price), etc.So quite good for the money but don't expect miracles you pay exactly for what you have.

Huge room on the 27 th floor, great Italian restaurant on the 2 nd. Friendly efficient staff. Excellent gym and pool. I would stay again.The bar on the 40 th floor is somewhat lacking in atmosphere, and there is a cover charge if you sit at a table! The views are amazing. A pianist played briefly while we were there.I looked at the menu for the French restaurant on this floor, as a treat for our last night. There was nothing of interest at all on the menu, and it was very, very expensive. Better to go to Olio on the 2 nd floor!

My boyfriend and I stayed here for a few nights and loved it. Great location, very close to Shibuya Station, a very busy train station that connects to everything. We were able to walk to restaurants and shops. They have very helpful English speaking staff that helped us each morning to plan our day. They also have several onsite restaurants, including japanes, chinese and Italian. The rooms themselves were spacious - our king standard room on the 25th floor had a beautiful view of the city and Mt Fuji, a good size closet and nice bathroom. The room and hotel is modern and extremely clean. Another plus is the shuttle they offer to and from the Tokyo airport. Fare to or from Tokyo to the airport is about $250usd - a shuttle from the aiport was $50 for 2 people. We would definitely stay here again.

I booked this hotel for three nights as a surprise for my daughter for our first visit to Tokyo. What a fabulous hotel the staff where first class from the moment we arrived. I explained to the checkin desk it was our first visit to Tokyo and was there a possibility for a room with a view. WOW 29th floor stunning views. I will most definitely book this hotel again.

Big rooms by Japanese hotel standards! The AC Max temp is 20 deg cel but it has secondary AC to support. The bathrooms are also spacious and the location is great. It's in the center but not the noisy part. The price is also reasonable and the breakfast is superb!

We stayed for four nights and returned five nights later for one night. The hotel is in a perfect location with a 4 minute walk to Shibuya station and shopping areas. The bed was very hard and uncomfortable on the first stay and we advised them upon check out. When we checked back in the bed was very comfortable. Staff are very friendly and knowledgable. I would stay here again.

This is a middle management business hotel. Good value and location. Nothing fancy but I had a spacious room for the standard rate. Great views of the city that one would get from a hotel two or three times the price. Tiny gym and ok swimming pool.

My expectations for some reason were higher than my experience. The hotel does have amazing views of an amaxing city, so that alone is extraordinary. The bar is pretty good but feels like the Patk Hyatt's much older & uncool brother.The rooms (aside from the great view) were decidely average & the foyer feels luke a train station.The main pluses, and they are big ones are the great location and the views. On that basis its a safe but not outstanding option

Stayed here only for 2 nights and I wish we could have stayed longer, but the hotel was fully booked for the rest of our stay in Tokyo. For a 4.5* hotel, this exceeded my expectations with its services, stylish, spacious rooms, and central location, I would definitely stay here again when I come back next year! Only gripe was the extra charges to use the gym and pool, but it seemed like common practice in Japan.

Is is a very nice hotel. Ultra upscale, almost too fancy. Seemed like a businessman's hotel. We had a huge room on the 23rd floor with gigantic windows and an awesome view of Shibuya. The bathroom was enormous and had a deep tub overlooking the city. It was a bit expensive, but a very classy pace to stay.

Convenient location directly across the road from JR line Shibuya and department store. Plenty of shopping and restaurants. Rooms are spacious for Japanese standard, bathroom with enclosed shower and bath.

I've been coming here for the last 11 years 2-3 times every year. Used to be crouded with Fashion designers coming for research / business but now a lot of trourists also staying this hotel. (they have a nanny service too btw).The service was not as superior than it was, although it was beyond best for the price once apon a time - they used to slice a bowl of expensive exotic fruits for you in your room, but now you just get bottles of evien instead, But still fantastic enough to beat other hotels in the area.Single rooms are very spacious and beds massive - bigger than a regular double size bed. There's dressing gown, a pair of slippers etc.. good selection of amenities.When you are tired you can call or massage til about 2am?Double roooms have a big king-size bed, so perfect for my partner and me who likes to sleep diagonal withought a leg fight.I also had a corner room, which has a spacious shower and bath with a large window with Tokyo view.On my last visits, I came back to my room around 4:30pm to drop my stuff from work - OMG a beautifl pink / orange sunlinght coming in to our room with a huge Mount Fuji on the backgroud. Hair raisingly beautiful (if your room was facing the south west).Also beautiful for the evening lights of Tokyo but it's the late afternoon sun set time is more amazing and which most of the hotel guests are likely to miss (too busy with out and about sight-seeing and shopping, anyone?)The hotel staff will accommodate with some tricky requests too in an emergency. I didn't have an extra suit case so I brought a cardboard box, except didn't have anything to secure to use it as a check in luggage on a plane. On check out the staff helped to tie up the box, OK it was badly done, but 3 staff helped to secure my box - super.My past colleagues who had health issues etc. while on a work trip, and the staff had helped with doctors to come in, brought in a toaster because she couldn't move and just couldn't eat anything other than a plain toast etc.. it's quite amasing the depth of service they provide when absolutley needed.It's probably around 150 GBP at today's rate, and for that price in very Central London you'll get a small room with cold shower water or the water leaking from a room above and if you are lucky they can assist in ordering a taxi for you.So it's an excellent hotel for the value at today's rate.

The Cerulean Tower boasts the best view in Shibuya and for good reason. We booked a 'King room' but when I called the hotel prior to check in (I wanted to confirm our view request) I was told that was just the name of the room. The 'king room' came with a queen bed. Needless to say I was a little frustrated because - for the price - I thought the expectation of a king bed in a room called the 'king room' was not out of line. But I chalked it up to a translation misunderstanding. From her tone it sounded like I wasn't the first confused English speaker she had to explain the unfortunate naming to. The woman spoke good English and was very polite. But she told me there were no rooms with king beds available for upgrade as they were all booked. I placed my view request - a view of the Tokyo tower and although they said there was no guarantees they promised they would do their best. In our room category we would only be able to see the tower out of the smaller side window but that was enough. The first plus of the hotel is its location! It's proximity to Shibuya train station could not be better. The walk was super short and easy (even with our luggage). There is a long staircase but it has a ramp for luggage that makes it pretty painless. And Shibuya station is a good hub for getting around the whole city. The walk to nightlife is as equally short and easy. A couple quick street crossings (including the Shibuya street scramble) and you're into the bars and shopping. The metro shuts down about 12:00am so nightlife and dinner options within walking distance is a huge plus. Even at 2:00/3:00am in the morning we were able to find a good place to eat and then walk back to the hotel. We arrived around 7:00pm to a pretty quick check-in process. I reiterated my request for a view of the Tokyo tower and moments later the woman checking us in said we had been given a complimentary room upgrade with a view from the main window! I was ecstatic! The porter service was quick and polite and he showed us up to room 2113. I have to say the room was amazing! The first thing you pass is a walk-in closet nook with plenty of room to store two suitcases and hanging clothes. The next thing you see is the bed! It was huge! It looked like two queens pushed together. We have a California king at home and the size of this bed blew it out of the water! Like most beds we slept on in Japan it was on the very firm side but the pillows were soft and you had so much room to stretch out. Last but not least was view. We had a friend with us who had been inTokyo for about week and he said it was the best view he had seen thus far. Tokyo tower glittered off to the right and the city lights lit up the left. It was the focal point of the room and you could watch the city from the bed and couch. The large bathroom had a view of the city lights all its own that could be enjoyed from the tub (and separate shower). There was a small separate area for the toilet but it did not have its own door. And a nice vanity area for make-up that got good sunlight from the large bath window. The hotel staff was also wonderful - very nice and helpful. It rained one day and on our way out the front desk staff made sure we had umbrellas. I'd recommend this hotel but make sure to check your room type and corresponding bed size.

Great location service is great !!!Chinese restaurant excellent. The price is reasonable . Stayed for 6 nights.Didn't have a chance to use the 42 floor restaurant or the lobby facilities- wish I had more time....There is a 7/11 store downstairs for early morning or late night cheap coffee and snacks!You cross the overpass take the street elevator down to street level and walk 5 minutes to the Shibuya Station ! Lots of restaurants around and shopping options - bottom line - I wish I could have stayed longer. Wonderful hotel in a fabulous city.

The Cerulean is centrally located close to Shibuya station. It is a short stroll to the madness of Shibuya and the craziest crossing in the world! It is a very convenient location for either business or pleasure.We stayed for 2 nights in a Tower's Floor Executive Room. The views from the room were breath taking. The room was very comfortable and well appointed as you would expect. The bed was high quality and the black out curtains worked a treat.The bathroom was very large with plenty of high quality amenities. There were double vanities and a large shower room.The Tower's Floor gives you access to the Club lounge which we enjoyed. It was very pleasant sitting in the lounge drink in hand watching the sunset over Mt Fuji. Breakfast was also available in the lounge but we preferred the restaurant which had a very good buffet with both western and Asian options.I have to make special mention of the staff who were all extremely friendly and helpful. I left my mobile phone on the Shinkansen train from Kyoto and the concierge went out of his way to track it down for me. Unfortunately, it could be not located but I really appreciated the effort he went to in assisting me.I would definitely stay at the Cerulean again.

Stayed in a twin room on a skyview floor with my teenaged daughter. Hotel looks new-ish. Room was very spacious with a small walk-in wardrobe to store our suitcases and all our shopping. Bathroom was also a generous size, with nice new bath tub and separate shower stall, and yet leaving plenty of space to move about in the bathroom. Beds were also comfortable and firm. Just missing a nespresso machine. Free wifi, strength was excellent.Had a fantastic view of Shibuya from the bedroom, as well as from the bathroom.Hotel is located about 7-8 minutes brisk walk from Shibuya station. There are 2 Family Marts located about 100m to the left and the right of the hotel. A Coco Curry House outlet just outside the hotel provided a convenient and delicious late night snack after we arrived. There's also Hoshino Coffee tucked away on a side street just 100 m from the hotel close to the Family Mart (in the direction of Shibuya Station), as well as a bigger drugstore/general grocer. Service at the front desk and concierge was efficient, cordial and proper though not quite hospitable. That did not really bother me, though.

Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel is awesome! It is modern and most importantly clean and up-class. There is humidifier in the room too! Stayed in single room for business trip and the single room is spacious enough compared to other hotel's single room. Service is fantastic. Most importantly, airport limo bus comes directly from Narita to this hotel. It is about 5 -7 mins walk to Shibuya 109 (using this as a guide to help you gauge).

Hotel in centrally located about 6 minutes walk to the famous Hachiko statue in Shibuya. Pretty large rooms for Tokyo standards, but a little pricey. Staff was very friendly and helpful. Access from Narita/Haneda airports via limousine bus is truly a plus. Rooms are clean. Wasn't able to try out their restaurants, maybe next time. Plenty of places to eat and shop around the area. I tried looking for other hotels for my next trip to Tokyo but I keep coming back here. Overall the best value.

So I stayed in room 3406 and the view is breathtaking. The room has the view of Shinjuku in the Horizon and Shibuya crossing. The rooms are clean and well kept. If you like the bustle of Shibuya and accessibility this is the best choice. The shuttle bus to the airport departs from the basement and now that is why I may comeback to stay here again.
Had a room on 33rd floor, huge bed for Japanese standards, plenty of seating space, AMAZING city views and access to executive lounge. Nice for pre-dinner drinks, canapes and great brekkie,Recommend!

We spent 3 nights here in September on a 3 city trip through Japan. This by far was our largest hotel in Tokyo and Kyoto. The hotel is well located near the Shibuya train station. We were on the 33rd floor, a club room floor. We had the most amazing view from our room. In fact, we went all over Tokyo and thought the best view was actually from our corner room. The room was also very nice and clean. Having the access to the club floor was also great with a small but decent selection for breakfast and evening snacks and drinks to enjoy before dinner. They might have also had food during the day but we were never there to check. The staff was also very helpful if we had any questions. I would no doubt stay here again if I return to Tokyo.

I just returned from spending 6 nights at the Cerulean Tokyu Tower Hotel in Shibuya and I thought the Hotel was an excellent choice for the stay. It is close to Shibuya Station, very clean with spacious rooms, good views and very attentive staff.The hotel has staff positioned in several areas of the lobby and I was greeted by one of the staff as soon as I entered the lobby. Everyone made eye contact with me, bowed and said good morning or good afternoon. Very impressive.There is a 7-11 adjacent to the hotel for missing items and snacks and loads of very good eating places close to the hotel. Shibuya Crossing is a 3 minute walk from the hotel.

we stayed at the hotel a few nights in tokyo and it was amazing. Location is great about 5-10 mins walk from Shibuya station. MAny shops cafes in the area restaurant and bar as well. open till late early morning some 24 hours. The Hotel is luxury and has great views of the city. you can see Tokyo tower from your bed. The only issue was wifi in room is not free and was expensive where most hotel offer free access to the internet. customer service is great overall is good.

This is our second time in Tokyo and we stayed again at this excellent hotel. The staff are great and we noticed they have improved the communication skills since 2012 and now most of them speak fluent English and they are always willing to help you with all your needs. We just asked about shipping our bags to Kyoto so we would not carry them in the train and for our surprise they had it all arranged with Yamato the pick-up and had already talked to the Hotel in Kyoto. We love this hotel, specially the Staff.

By far this was the best service that I have ever received. Talk about hospitality. This takes it to the next level. For example upon checking in. Someone rushes to you as soon as the taxi door is open and offers to take your bag. It was raining that day. So when I am waiting to check in another person comes over with a clean white towel and starts to dry off my bag, even though it maybe had a couple of drops of water. Also they show you to your room, which I thought was a nice touch. Breakfast is good but very expensive so I would skip that. The gym and pool are nice but not included which is a downside. Make sure to ask for a room with a view. The location would not be better. The bar on top is amazing, you have to go check it out.

The Cerulean Tower offers a superb view of Tokyo and you can see the Tokyo tower from the room. During clear days you can even see the Fuji mountain! Overall great services and clean rooms. The hotel is a 5 minutes walk to the Shibuya station and lots of shopping malls around. Love it!

Having stayed in the Ginza and Roppongi on other trips to Tokyo, we thought we'd try Shibuya, since the things we planned to see were all over Tokyo and we needed easy access to transportation. This hotel was a perfect choice. The room was large (especially by Tokyo standards), the bathroom clean and modern, and the bed more comfortable than I was expecting. The hotel is less than five minutes from Shibuya Station with connections all over Tokyo. And the view from this hotel is stunning. We often sat by the window looking out over the city and watching the world go by. There are tons of restaurants in the area, so if you are tired in the evening you don't have to go far for a meal. This is one of the more affordable five-star hotels in Tokyo. The service is fine, though not quite Four Seasons, which I find intrusive. Overall, if you can afford it, this hotel is a great value.

We stayed in this hotel our last three days in Tokyo, the room was very large for Tokyo standards, at 27th floors with an Amazing city view in the badroom, but a better view in the bathroom... lying in the bath you could enjoy a breathtaking view while you was lulled by water.Room very clean, staff very kind and English spoken.

Just minutes walk from Shibuya station (if you make sure you get out of the right exit),this hotel towers of Shibuya.We got a beautiful corner king room, which had views of whole city, just amazing day and night.My only problem with this hotel , and Ive stayed at many beautiful hotels is that you had to pay for coffee and tea bags in the room , also water bottles !Normally rooms have coffee and tea complimentary, not here which was really surprising. I think they should rethink that policy!

We had a room on floor 32. The view has got to be one of the best in the world. It's all a little pricey, but extremely good. Room was big and very clean and quiet. Bathroom was very nice. Room service was prompt and ample. The hotels position was terrific, with more nightlife than anyone could possibly want within a 10 minute walk. Top tip - we found really good bars on the second and third floors of buildings. At the back of the hotel we found a couple of tiny six seat family diners, 1000 yen for a superb fixed lunch.We couldn't find an early breakfast anywhere. So the hotel had to do, it was fine, not fantastic. Amazing service from all the staff, a beautiful introduction to Japan.There's a 7-11 on site for water, beer, snacks etc. Bellavista bar again takes full advantage of the views and does a mean Golden Cadillac!

This hotel is amazing. Our room was huge, clean and quiet. Staff could not do enough for us and so polite and courteous. Hotel is the drop off point for the Limousine bus from airport and a pickup point for many tour operators. Also close to train station, cafes and restaurant. Walking distance to the famous Shibuya Crossing and shopping.

This is a great place to stay in Tokyo. It's located right across the street from Shibuya station, so it's really convenient to get to directly from Narita airport and also when you're catching the subway around town. The hotel staff was lovely and spoke very good English, and the concierge made a couple of restaurant reservations for us via email before we even arrived (this is a must if you want to eat at one of the many incredible and small sushi restaurants - Sushi Masuda is a life-changer!). The rooms are large and comfortable with great amenities. You really can't beat the views either! We were on the 34th floor and could see for miles. Highly recommend this place.

We stayed on the 34th floor of the Cerulean and were very pleased. The location, just across a large road from Shibuya station, can't be beat. The room we stayed in was luxurious (very fancy bathroom!). The restaurants are expensive, in that fancy-hotel way and the lobby was on the cold side, with not a lot of seats outside the restaurant area. There's a convenience store within the hotel building, which we found very useful. I'd love to stay here again!

We stayed here for 3 nights on the first leg of our honeymoon before venturing to Indonesia. The service was amazing and the location of this hotel was perfect for us. It's right in the heart of Shibuya (Tokyo's Times Square) which made it easy for us to get around. It's a quick 3min walk to Shibuya Train Station where you can get anywhere from. The hotel has impeccable service and are willing to accomodate your every need. The English here was so-so, but they were so kind you sort of forget about it. We had a great view of the city in a corner room on the 32nd floor. They offered an "American Breakfast" where you can get eggs, oatmeal, fruit, just like in the U.S. If you venture out in town, you cannot find anything like that. We never ate lunch or dinner here so I don't know how their meals were. But we would absolutely stay here in a heartbeat if we go back to Tokyo. The location and room were just too great not to.

Good hotel in the amazing Shibuya block, very close to the Shibuya Station and the famous crossroad.The rooms are very large compared to the standard size of the city and very comfortable, large shower and nice bathroom.The view from the room is very nice and with good weather you can see Mount Fuji, amazing.The breakfast is international with a good choice of salt and sweet food.The only negative point is the staff.Very different from the standard attitude of Japanese people, always sweet, delicate and very nice, the staff here is not too much educate and a little bit arrogant, that is a shame because the hotel would almost deserve 5 star.Anyway I can easily recommend it as, excluding the staff, it's a good place to stay and enjoy the amazing Tokyo.

Hotel was fantastic - superb location, great service, comfortable rooms, great scenic bar, a number of good restaurants. Easy to get to and to get cabs. Concierge couldn't be more helpful. Even met a Sumo!

Where to begin? Every part the the experience here was an absolute nightmare! - hotel is old and depressing - staff doesn't speak ANY english and can't communicate at all - restaurants are a joke. Bad food and slow service. - carpets in hallways and rooms are dirty and stained - guest rooms smell and are musty - it's 50 shades of beige! - the lobby lounge closes at 10pm, what??? - and sells only smirnoff and riesling wine - staff at exec club are rude and unhelpful - concierge is useless - beds are hard as board, pillows like lead and sheets of sandpaper - no coffee service in the room It is NOT a 5 star hotel by any definition of the term, maybe a 2.5 on a desperate day.

I and my wife enjoyed this hotel very much. Great views on the upper floors. The location is the seller for us. Transportation is very close. Very handy seven eleven store which is very convenient. Good items for breakfast that is affordable. I got a nice rain coat there in the rainy season. A nice hotel to stay at for a pre cruise. A little pricey but well worth it.

The hotel isn't the newest, but it is well kept. What makes this hotel worthy is the staff, the views, the location and the cleanliness of the rooms. True to Japanese form, the staff was extremely courteous and attentive to all of our needs. They could not have been nicer and were always eager to assist us with taxis, directions, reservations and room amenities. We had a corner room on the 23rd floor and the view of Tokyo was beautiful. At night, it is worth heading up to the bar/restaurant at the top of the building for some outstanding views The room was decent sized as far as Tokyo hotel rooms go. It was quiet and we never heard any of our neighbors. They supply more amenities than you will find in most high end hotels. The room was spotless and the maid did a great job each and every day. The bed linens were white, high quality and crisp. The Wi-Fi was fast and very reliable. The location could not have been better. The hotel is a quick walk to Shibuya Station, which is probably one of the best places to catch subways from in the city. The neighborhood is great to walk around in. There is also an amazing little restaurant right around the corner called Tappan Yaki Hakushu that has awesome Kobe steak. The gym was small, but certainly met all of my needs.

Great location , beautiful views,great room,great staff,all department will stay the most comfortable beds to sleep more people should come to a rest and a holiday in the most Tokyo romantic. Walk a little to the Shibuya train station...

Our room was situated on the 22nd floor of the hotel and the view were absolutely spectacular. The in-room dining was very good and the presentation was quite something! The location is very close (within walking distance) to the major train station as well. The service was also amazing, the staff was there to take care of our every need.

This is an over-priced, out-dated mess of a hotel. While we enjoyed the view and the large (by Tokyo standards) rooms, we were constantly amazed by the rude and self-important acting staff. We stayed here 5 nights and this is just one example: we paid to stay on the Executive floor and make use of the "Executive Salon" with it's free daily cocktail hour. We invited two Tokyo friends to join us for a drink in the salon. When we took them, the staff at the salon door gave them the dirtest look. Moments later, the staff person came to me and demanded to know; "Who are these people?" and then said "Well, they are going to have to pay to be here." We were embarrassed and appalled by this treatment. The insult to injury was that the food and beverage offerings in the salon were awful-- cheap liquor and items like saltine crackers and canned olives!Also, under no circumstances should you eat in this hotel's "fine dining" establishments. We tried their Kanetanaka-So restaurant's 5 course meal. Every course that came out of the kitchen was nothing like what was described on the menu. After the 3rd course, I asked the waiter why this was happening and he said that the chef decided to change all the courses and they didn't have the time (honestly!) to print new menus. We walked out at the beginning of the 4th course because when it, too, wasn't in any way like what was described in the menu. Besides all the food was bland and boring.For the prices this place charges they act like they are a 5 star hotel. We think they are barely a 2 star hotel. We would never recommend this place to anyone.

Very good service from the hotel staff. Strangely, they don't believe in tipping the staff. I heard that if you attempt to tip them they might feel insulted. I am not sure if that's true. The hotel is near to the shopping area in Shibuya. I like that after shopping, I can retreat to the hotel to have some quiet moments. Stayed at Level 36 and the beautiful skyline is very therapeutic.

stayed for business with group stay. the response from the hotel was always very slow and service was just OK. Staff was generally friendly but if we ask something extra, they are regularly refusing or so reluctant. The facility and amenity were also just OK (e.g. in-room phone was not good for conference call). If you stay at regular room, stay which is more expensive than staying at Westin at Ebisu, you still had to pay $20 for fitness center usage which was absolutely rediculous. Comparing to inernational hotel chain, there is no question that that the facility and service quality is lower.Location is great. but if I just choose by location, I would rather stay at Excel Tokyu which is 40% cheaper and better in location.

I am writing this review in my room on executive floor of this hotel. Could not wait until checkout to share my experience of this place.The room is not so big, which is Ok for Tokyo, but it looks old, it smells old and it is old. Carpeting has so many stains, that barefoot walking inside your room is a scary thing to do. They provide Japanese robes which look as though at least one million people used them. Upon arrival and check-in first needed to wash my bath tub before using it as it was clearly not cleaned after previous guests. And the bed linen had small stains as well!Finally, this hotel is located very close to Shibuya train station which might be not bad, but it sits on a very very busy road approx half a kilometer from an interesting part of Shibuya area.Ah, the good thing: the view. Definitely will not come here again.

I've stayed at a few hotels in downtown Tokyo, but my current employer always puts me up at the Cerulean Tower Tokyu, and I'm glad of it. The rooms are comfortable and, by Tokyo standards, generous in size; service is impeccable; and the location can't be beat.I've only ever stayed in the King rooms, but my understanding is that even the smallest single rooms include a full-sized tub, which I always appreciate when I'm on the road. Speaking of the King rooms, in my experience, the standard King actually features a larger primary window and an additional corner window that's not included in the "Superior King." But the Superior King rooms are larger overall and include a separate shower and tub. In short, if views are your jam, go for a standard King, but if bathroom size is your priority, spring for a Superior King.On the topic of location, the popular "Limousine Bus" from Narita Airport provides door-to-door service to the Cerulean Tower and the famous Shibuya Station is a 10 minute walk away. In short, it’s easy to get to and you won't be at a loss for things to do. And a pro tip for seasoned travelers: The nearby Shibuya Hikarie mall, which is less than 10 minutes away on foot, features a great informal food court (i.e. inexpensive) in its basement levels, along with a small grocery store where you can pick up snacks & staples for your stay.In terms of amenities, the Cerulean Tower includes a small but functional gym, along with a fantastic indoor pool. I think it took me six visits before I discovered the pool, but it's surprisingly nice and now I always try to use it at least once during my stays. For dining, the hotel houses several formal restaurants in addition to a casual cafe adjacent to the lobby where breakfast is served (the buffet is solid, but expensive). A nice benefit to having all of these restaurants in the hotel is that you can order Western, Japanese or Chinese food for room service, but, like almost everything in Tokyo, it'll put a dent in your wallet (or expense report).I mentioned in the title to my review that I think the Cerulean Tower is the perfect hotel for business travelers, and I've outlined my rationale above. I would say that if I were traveling on holiday with my spouse, I'd probably look for a boutique-style alternative with a less "executive" feel. But if you're in town for work, it really doesn't get any better than this.

Centrally located, 5 mins from Shibuya station, with direct trains to Ginza, Harajuku, Shinjuku, and Azakusa, with one change to Roppongi Hills.Beautiful indoor pool and decent gym, with massage chair and Shiseido toiletries.Views to make a visit to the SkyTree (almost) redundant.The staff exemplify the extreme generosity and helpfulness of the Japanese people. Everyone, from the executive lounge hosts, to the concierge, to the porters, try to help as much as possible. One example: I got up one morning too early for the gym, and without my room key. One of the girls in b&w kept my gear while I walked, walked me to the gym on my return, then took me back to my room when I was done.Room service was the best meal of our trip, an intensely flavoured fish soup being the highlight.Tips:Gym is free if you arrive before 07:00.Upgrade to 34th floor was well worth it, with half price access to pool, simple breakfast in the executive lounge, all day access to juices and mineral water, and evening cocktails. Nothing better than relaxing after the day's activities with a glass of French bubbly.The August heat makes it difficult to do a lot of walking outside, but one of the trips we found most enjoyable was to catch the train up to Daikanyama station, exploring the quaint back street shops, and the beautiful Dainkayama T-site, then walking down the hill in the cooler evening to the back of the Cerulean.

The Cerulean kept coming up when I was looking at hotels and then I read an GQ article that said chef David Chang and comedian Aziz Anzari had stayed there a couple of years ago...so I thought I would take a chance. I know that sounds crazy, but I'm so glad I did it.The location is so awesome. Shibuya is a really fun part of Tokyo and it ended up being near so many things I wanted to do. Lots of great shopping, restaurants, bars and beauty treatments. But the best part is that you literally walk out of the train station...(go out the South Exit- not the "New South Exit") and you will see two bridges that form an X. If you are arriving from the airport express train there are elevators for your luggage so don't even worry about getting a cab. Walk out of the train station...and go over the bridge. At the bottom of the bridge go right and about 1/2 block and there are escalators that take you directly into the hotel. And the Shibuya stop is so centrally located. If you buy the JR Rail Pass...you probably won't need another train ticket during your trip. The hotel itself is really nice and well maintained. Go ahead and get the breakfast plan. The buffet is great and even after 5 days I never tired of it. It is well worth it. The rooms are big and the views are insane. The bathrooms is great and there is every amenity you can think of or in case you forget something. The beds are really comfortable and the linens were lovely.The bar and restaurants on the 40th floor are great. I had dinner at the bar and it was fantastic. No need to go to the Park Hyatt...this bar is very similar...they even have a pianist. The French restaurant on the other side is amazing. I chose one of the special menus and it was a really memorable meal. Service was impeccable. Highly recommend it.The only thing I would say is that they speak very little English, even the concierges. I was a little on my own to figure things out. However, the JR Rail Line office is right near the entrance closest to the hotel. They all speak great English and are super helpful. My suggestion...bypass the hotel and go see them. They will get you anywhere you need to go.Also, loved the pool. Really helped with the jet lag!I highly recommend this hotel for business or for pleasure.

This hotel was in a great location and a good size. The rooms were pretty big and comfortable. The bathrooms were clean and had enough space for two adults to get ready. Great restaurants and ammentites nearby.

This is long overdue but this hotel is perfect and flawless in terms of service, food, amenities and location. Location- very close to the Shibuya Train station..easy walking. Also a plus in terms of having all the nearby street food and yakitori joints. Plus the 7-Eleven on the lower floor gives us easy access to ATM machine, good coffee and the never ending supply of their local MontBlanc dessert.Service- took care of our luggages for the takuhaibin transfers from hotel to hotel, received as planned our pocket wi-fi, nice touch of having "welcome" and "birthday" cake boxes from Dalloyou (Paris)!!!Food- Had the Japanese breakfast day one. It was so good we got kind of hesitant to try the Western Breakfast the next day. Good thing we tried the western too---it was equally good and impressive with our made to order macchiattos and freshly squeezed juices. Not to be missed is the omelette station manned by a 'perfectionist' chef. Yum-O!Amenities-Super fluffy beds will make you not want to leave! But alas it's Tokyo and a place of discovery. There was also an amply supply of toiletries including folding travel brushes, toothbrushes and endless shampoo/conditioners. Will stay here again on our next Tokyo trip!

If you are looking for a great location and excellent views of the city, this is the place for you. Nothing super special or life changing, but prices are reasonable for the type of room you are going to get. Definitely pick one with a view it's worth it!

Just finished a four-night stay at the Cerulean Tower. The room was enormous. A corner room has the additional benefit of a fantastic view from the bathtub. The room had both a big, king-sizes bed and a comfortable sitting area. Nice facilities including a gym and a pool, which is great in Tokyo in the summer. On an odd note, if you have tattoos, you cannot use the pool. The locker room had fabulous Japanese massage chairs. The 40th-floor bar had fantastic, unobstructed views over Tokyo. The staff were first-rate and very helpful. Will definitle look to stay here on my next trip to Tokyo.

This hotel has a great location, close to the subway and JR stations. There are plenty of restaurants close by and the 40th floor bar is well worth a visit. Room was comfortable and clean with king size bed. Concierge staff was very helpful.Previously had stayed on west side of Shinjuku station - this hotel in Shibuya was better.

We stayed for 5 nights and wished we could stay more. It's location is excellent and close to Shibuya crossing and plenty of shopping and eating opportunities. The staff are wonderful and could speak good English. The service was outstanding; even changing an a la carte option in the restaurant for our jet lagged daughter. The views are amazing and rooms very well equipped. We couldn't recommend this hotel highly enough and would certainly stay again. Thank you to the staff for a wonderful experience in Japan.

This hotel is very well located, 5 minutes walk from the Shibuya station. Staff is very welcoming and the check in is fast. Rooms are well furnished and quite large comparing to the Tokyo standards. All of them are located above the 22nd floor and the view (from the 30th floor) is really amazing. And price per night was a very good value for money. Would I have to stay again in Shibuya, I would certainly go there

We had a great stay at Cerulean Tower. Located near Shibuya Station. The room was spatious and clean with great views. Good restaurants. Very helpful, friendly staff. Due to a very early flight home we needed to order a very early breakfast, which was no problem!

Nice hotel located near to Shibuya station and it is centralized location within walking distance to major shopping a retails, Restaurants, coffee shops etc. very friendly and they will do their best to satisfy your needs. Rooms are huge and so quite.

We stayed here 2 nights, at the end of a 3 weeks journey across Japan. The room, as promised, had a spectacular view on the south of the city - Mount Fuji appeared from the clouds one afternoon and made the view even more stunning.One big minus was though the smell of smoke throughout the whole floor (soaked in the carpet), including our room, which we thought was a non-smoking room. I suggest you make this point VERY clear when you make your reservation. :(Also, the facility has a swimming pool, but to access it you need to pay an extra fee, which was kind of unexpected from a 5 star hotel.As all the other review say, the location is excellent, just few minutes away from Shibuya station and the staff was super helpful and polite.Extra note: We had dinner at the french restaurant on the top floor and it was absolutely excellent.

The hotel is right of Shibuya station, so it's convenient if you are taking a train to the hotel (you should totally take a train as taxi would be about $250). The breakfast is not included and is about $30, but so worth it -- very nice buffet. The hotel has a gym (kind of small), very nice pool, sauna, and massage chairs (love those!). If you are planning to work out make sure you stay on the floors that include free gym admittance, or otherwise you will have to pay about $20. The area is very fun for bars and clubs; shopping is close by as well. One really nice perk is that you will get a nice view regardless of which way you facing. Also, if you are not a smoker be careful to not book the smoking room, which my friend did by accident and their floor smelled...

regular business travellers like familiarity but after several weeks and multiple stays everywhere starts to grind. I amused myself by chatting in my broken Japanese with the staff in the main lobby restaurant and explored the menu several times over. I even coached them on making the perfect Irish Coffee at the end of each evening. I found them to be charming and professional and would happily stay there again in the future - there are deals to be had on room rate and in the restaurant but just outside is the madness and beauty of Shibuya to be explored...

On our last 2 nights in Japan, we picked this hotel to be close to Shibuya actions. We got upgraded to a Deluxe Twin room. For this trip we have stayed at JW HK, Century Southern, Granvia Kyoto and Cerulean. In terms of comfort and luxury, I would rank 1/JW, 2/Cerulean, 3/Century Southern and 4/Granvia. The room rates go from high to low in that order, i.e.. you get what you pay for. Value for $$ I would pick the Century Southern. The location is convenient but quiet and classy. You can go everywhere in Tokyo from there and still have peace an quiet when you get back to hotel.Cerulean is a beautiful hotel & in a quiet section of Shibuya. Service is amazing, front desk staff speaks enough English and go out of their way to help you. I did not try any of the restaurants as the price is a bit high for what is offered. There are good restaurants all around Shibuya within 5-10 minutes walk. Shibuya is teenage central so my teenager loves the area & prefers it to Shinjuku. I find it too crowded and messy. There are also many overpasses and bridges you need to walk up and down to get to the Shibuya centre and station. So a 10 minute walk to Shibuya is an exercise on its own - forget about dragging luggages.Would I go back? Definitely. I love everything about Japan. However, I will travel very light next time. Bring $$, shop and eat locally.

Stayed here for 6 nights at the start of a 2 week Japan holiday. Coming by train from the airport, the location of the Cerulean is perfect as it is a 5 minute walk from the Shibuya station . Our rooms faced Mt Fuji and we had a perfect view of it early on our first morning. The rooms were well equipped and well lit. The staff were amazingly courteous and helpful. The only thing I thought could be improved was the breakfast which was a little lack lustre. Overall, we were very happy here and will definitely stay again.

This is a very nice business hotel, in an amazing location in Shibuya. Very close to the Shibuya crossing and all of the action nearby. We stayed in during our honeymoon trip to Japan, and this hotel provided a nice base to explore from. The breakfast was good, but it was crowded often, so go early. I would recommend this hotel.

We are a family of four visiting Tokyo. We have already travelled to Osaka, Kyoto, Hiroshima , Nagoya and Matsumoto.  The Cerulean in Shibuya is the best hotel we have stayed in. Any of the rooms here are great value, particularly if you book ahead. We are enjoying the extra space. The 33rd floor views are spectacular. I highly recommend this hotel .

It's the largest hotel in the Shibuya areaIt's definitely 5 stars with many floors and thus good viewsGive the breakfast a miss. It's really quite limited fare unless you enjoy freshly squeezed orange juice.The concierge and check in is conducted in good EnglishThe location requires a 100 meter walk to Shibuya station unshelteredPlenty of street eats in the vicinityThe rooms are big and modern. The beds are comfortable. The king bed is very suitable for Caucasian sized guests.

We requested concierge's help to book for a Michelin starred restaurant and they were quick to respond and had successfully helped us secure the seats. Well done and thank you! On Sunday while we were leaving, we did not know that there was no airport shuttle to Haneda Airport from the hotel on Sunday and they were so kind to inform us and they could all communicate in English well especially a gentleman who speaks very good English. The room was large which was really rare and very clean indeed! The views from the room are great too. However, this hotel may not be ideal for aged people because you need a bit of a walk uphill (about 5 mins). Otherwise, I will highly recommend it!

Room was nice view was lovely, bathroom was beautiful, bed was surprisingly uncomfortable. As a western asian it was hard getting used to a stiff and hard bed. Service was great! However some members of staff were a bit grumpy and didn't seem like they wanted to help. Great location!! With a 7/11 on site and family mart 5 minutes away. Shibuya station was only minutes away by walk as well. However the lobby was too small to cater so many guests in waiting, and the cafe food thing next to the lobby had some rude staff. Would recommend but there are better options

This is a fantastic hotel! What I love is that it is very close to Shibuya Crossing about 5 min walk, but in a quiet area. The staff are fantastic. We were placed in a room facing Shibuya Crossing and Tokyo Tower. The hotel runs very smoothly and the service is impeccable. Yes, the room service and extra charges are a bit pricey, but there is a seven eleven in the hotel. I would equate this hotel to a stay at a Westin. Overall, very positive experience!

We had a nice stay, everything was fine, but this is a rather large hotel, so it felt a bit impersonal and chain-like.Location is either great or not, depending on what you're looking for. It's in a very busy area of Shibuya, which can feel like Times-Square, but for a pure tourist experience it is quite convenient, as it is super-easy to find a place to eat & drink without worrying about the language barrier. It's also very near a very busy train station, so transportation is easy. But the area is very crowded, so it can get a bit hectic, so hard to ask for help as things are very very fast.

Yes, this is not cheap, but it's so worth it. Views of Shibuya are amazing (we were on the 26th floor). Has several types of restaurants (the Italian one was very nice). Very close to Shibuya Station.

I stayed in the hotel for 5 nights last week for business reasons.The hotel is really excellent, reception is really polite and smart, breakfast is in continental style, rooms are quite big with a really nice view over Tokyo (I was at 29th floor).I used the hotel restaurant and it is fine, a little expensive, and I used the room service too, that was really fast.Unfortunately I did not have the time to use fitness room and pool, hopefully next time, because for my next visit in Tokyo I will join the cerulean hotel again.

If you don't know ins and outs of Tokyo and If you are looking to walk, and not walk far, and get some really great experiences for a) tourist sites b) food c) drinks this is a great spot.Shibuya crossing: 3 minute walk, one of the most famous intersections in the worldFood: 1) Go out toward shibuya and go behind the massive starbucks (can't miss it and worth a stop for 2nd floor view), and some unbelievable Ramen houses. Good, good good2) Go out to right and behind cerulean after dark. Look down into the basement restaurants. Look for the ones with charcoal smoke billowing out and crowded insides and just figure out a way to get in and have some unbelievable izakaya charred meat on a stick.Drinks: Same as 2) aboveAll this in 5 mins walk.Hotel is ok. Modern(ish), good size rooms, but we had to get 2 rooms because we have 4 children although all are 6 or below. Normal...but worth noting for those with bigger familiesLast, very cool rooftop bar for LATE NIGHT

We stayed at the Cerulean Hotel for five nights in June having arrived in Tokyo via the Shinkansen and then a local train on the Yamamote line. On exiting the station we were a little uncertain where to find the hotel but were soon pointed in the right direction by one of the many security personnel nearby. After crossing a few roads via the walkway, and a slight walk uphill, it took less than 10 minutes to get there. Finding the correct entrance to the hotel lobby was a small challenge and we ended up seeking assistance from a staff member on the mezzanine level. Funnily enough, we helped a family group with the exactly the same problem just a few days later.Our room was on the 32nd floor and we had a wonderful view over Tokyo, looking towards Haneda airport (we could see planes just as they landed). The room was very spacious and the king size bed was very comfortable. The bathroom and toiletries were excellent and we were very happy with our room and the way it was maintained during our stay.We did not have a good map of the hotel and it wasn't until the second last day that we discovered there is a 7-eleven store in the outer area of the hotel complex. Free WiFi is available at the hotel but we had trouble connecting a tablet in our room (although it worked well in the lobby). Fortunately our mobile phones were OK everywhere in the hotel.The hotel is located in the Shibuya district, an area known for its shopping facilities. During the day the of the shops look like many other department stores. However, at night the whole area comes to life with video screens on many of the buildings and the quite loud sounds that add to the spectacle. Together with the large number of people on the streets in the evening, your senses can become somewhat over-stimulated although it is a fascinating experience.There are many places to eat in Shibuya and the department stores have a very good range of well-priced restaurants often in a basement or a few levels above the street. The hotel is very well located for the shops and trains although you still need to do a fair bit of walking. However, it was well worth it, we enjoyed our stay and we would stay there again.

We were there last June 2015. The hotel is a walking distance to the station with ramp for ease of luggage. There is a Food station nearby with great food choices that accepts credit card. The concierge and people in the hotel are so helpful. We travel on our own with a set of places to go. Since one of the places we want to see was Hatchiko the famous dog, the girl in the hotel walked with us to see it. We frequently consulted Wajiwa-san (sorry if there is lapse in my memory but he is the person assigned in the concierge) with our itinerary. He would give us advice as to the route with regards to the train stops and the sequence of the place. He became our personal travel consultant :)The room was nice. I think there is a hotel power saver as there is a personal cooler in the room to cool down the temperature. I am impressed with the towel as it makes you feel so dry after a shower. Wonder what detergent they are using. The odd thing in the bed set up is that there was 3 single beds. We might be saving a bit had it been a king size bed as there are bed pull out seen in the single bed. Overall it was an excellent stay for us in Tokyo.

My family and I stayed here recently on our first trip to Tokyo and found the property to be more than accommodating. Here's why you should consider the Cerulean Tower for your visit.1. CLEAN: The hotel was spotless, very much up to standards you would find in North America. 2. SPACIOUS ROOMS: Very much in line with western hotels in this regard. The room we had featured two twin beds, plenty of lighting, including floor lights in the night stand between the beds. This was great for middle of the night trips to the bathroom. Speaking of the bathroom, it was fully stocked with complimentary items such as soaps, shampoos, razors and even a hair brush. It also came with a blow dryer. The toilet featured a heated seat and bidet feature which is common in Japan. The shower area with a tub/shower combo; a full tub with a shower wand NEXT to the tub all enclosed with a glass wall and door. Definitely different but very functional. Rooms also featured televisions (not many English choices) and a desk. Each room was equipped with WiFi which was included in our room rate. Since my wife and I were traveling with our daughter, we ordered a rollaway bed, which fit easily in the room. Our room was also equipped with an air purifier machine, which also doubled as a sound machine to mute my snoring!3. LOCATION: You can't beat the hotels location. It's literally a five minute walk to the Shibuya train station, one of the main stations in Tokyo. From Shibuya station, you can get ANYWHERE in Tokyo by either the JR line or the Tokyo subway system. And since the hotel is located on a busy thoroughfare, there are overhead walkways which make your trek to the trains simple and safe.4. OPTIONS: There's a 7-11 located on the property which turned out to be a great stop for filling up on things like snacks, water, breakfast items, etc. It's located on the second floor on the outside of the hotel. The Cerulean features several restaurants, a nice lobby bar and a desert bar that's located close to check-in.OTHER HELPFUL INFORMATION: The staff is fluent in English, so that won't be a problem....I would recommend you skip breakfast in the hotel since it's rather expensive. It ran about $85 USD for three of us and that was less than the cost of the buffet. Either load up at the 7-11 or pick a neighborhood spot. There's a coffee house called Excelsior that's about a 3-5 min walk towards the train station. We had breakfast sandwiches and drinks there for about $16 USD. They also have seating outside which makes for a great people watching spot.....if you are traveling two and from Narita, use the N'Ex train (The Narita Express). It's clean and fast and will get you to Shibuya Station in about an hour.....for those using the Shinkansen (bullet train) during their visit, you can take a train from Shibuya station to Tokyo station to connect. ...bring snacks from home! You will walk ALOT when exploring the city. Snacks are handy when you get hungry or can't find appropriate food. As for food, you'll need to have an open mind. It can be much different than North America, but very good. There are plenty of American style restaurants as well.....bring a tablet with you so you can explore recommended spots. Also, download the Tokyo subway app, a great way to figure out train times and routes. MUST SEE: Plan a day trip to Kyoto. It's two hours via the Skinkansen train and was a highlight of our trip.

We stayed here for the last three nights of our stay in Tokyo and Japan, having stayed one night in Tsukiji near the market and one in the Park Hyatt (a real treat!). After the Park Hyatt obviously it wasn't as amazing, but it's still a lovely hotel. I had emailed to ask for a Shibuya Crossing room view, and they said they'd try to accommodate my request. On check-in obviously this had been overlooked, but they did give me a higher up room with a great view over the Tokyo Tower (east) and I could actually see the crossing at the edge of the view. It was a better room than we booked, so that was good!Spacious room, comfy, temperature fine, no noise, lovely bathroom with huge tub, usual amenities.Only real criticism is that we had to pay for the coffee provided in the drinks drawer - seems really tight for an expensive 5-star hotel to charge an additional Y400 for a coffee that really should be included! Only the green tea is free. Plus they charge to use the pool, so we didn't bother. Didn't make it up to the bar at the top, as there's so much else going on nearby and in Tokyo!

the location is a good reason to stay here as it's a short walk from Shibuya station but I found that the service and standard was disappointing for a 5 star hotelFirstly, our room was not prepared in time for check in which was annoying. On one of the days I came back to the room while it was being cleaned and I was rudely turned away from my own room!The lobby is large but doesn't have nearly enough seating for the number of guests and while the rooms were a good size with nice views of the city,the furnishings and interior seemed outdated and worn for a 5 star hotel. The hallway areas were too hot and had a funny smell. They charged you for using coffee and tea in the room (which much cheaper hotels would provide for free)In all, Cerulean towers may be a good place to stay on business but as a tourist expecting some level of luxury at a price like this, what we received was very disappointing.

Perfect location. A short walk to downtown Shibuya, JR line and Metro line. Airport limousine bus stops directly at the hotel basement so no hassle especially if you have several bags. We were also upgraded, got a bigger room than what we reserved for. There is also a 7-11 just outside the hotel at the 2nd floor. Also, I had a medical emergency and immediately, someone came to our room with medicines. As usual, that level of Japanese customer service is outstanding. When hotel staff at the lobby notices that you are in need of something, someone will quickly approach you and offer their help. I and my husband are so happy with our stay here. We'll be staying here again on our next trip to Tokyo.

Stayed at the Cerulean twice in one week during Feb'15. We had booked high-floor rooms, but noticed that those above 26(?) were actually better quality (slightly better room features) than those lower down, even though both rooms were described as "high" (from memory we stayed on the 29th and then 24th floor). One of the reasons for the upper floors is the great view across the Tokyo skyline, and with some brooding cloud cover gave the city a very "Blade Runner" feel.As a luxury hotel the staff are very attentive and check-in/check-out were very easy. Storing our luggage on our last day seemed less trouble for them than some other hotels we have used.Other comment, as we had some work to get done while in Tokyo, the desk/internet setup was very good - enabled us to get things done with enough space.

A very good hotel for business trips: clean and spacious, free upgrade to city view king, reasonable buffet breakfast, free wifi. I wouldn't choose to stay here for a pleasure trip because it's a bit cool and rather large. But I was on business and it served us very well. The airport limousine bus made getting to and from the hotel a piece of cake, and since I am not very familiar with Tokyo and speak not a word of Japanese, this is an enormous plus. Also convenient to Shibuya Station, which we used to get around Tokyo.

Great hotel, I stayed in two rooms on this trip.The first room we managed to get upgraded to a corner room on the 32nd floor with awesome bath next to a window, spacious shower, huge bed, large HD TV, a couch... it was fantastic. The second room we had, after popping down to Kyoto, was much smaller, technicall the grade we paid for, and was just an average hotel room, no bath, decent shower.BreakfastWe had breakfast twice here, it's an ok selection breakfast buffet. Amazing waffles/bacon/eggs and freshly made omelettes. Then a relatively standard buffet, cereals, code meats, and some traditional Japanese breakfast foods.BarThe bar on the 40+ floor was great, with reasonably priced cocktails (compared to London prices) ie £9 for a negroni/martini. The view is incredible, overlooking the famous pedestrian crossing in Shibuya, and the surrounding areas and most of Tokyo! It's a shame so much of the bar is smoking, and the non-smoking section is tiny with significantly less-impressive views. We managed to get a seat by the window on both occasions even if the second time we had to wait in the bar area for about 15 minutes first, we still had a seat to wait at.ServiceThe service in this hotel is incredible, with such attentive staff ready to take your luggage as soon as you get in to reception and eagerly take it to your room. You don't feel like the service is good because they want a tip because it's not custom to tip here. Reception staff very friendly, everyone spoke a good level of English. We needed advice on the local area a couple of times and the staff were very eager to help.AreaThe area is great for the nearby train station (5 minute walk) to connect to all parts of Tokyo on both the overground and subway systems. And the hotel itself is just a 15-20 minute walk from Harajuku/Omotesando areas which are great for shopping.Gym/PoolI used the pool once while here, the fact there is an additional charge seems strange and the price (about £15) was too high to warrant visiting more than once.That said, the changing facilities were very nice, the pool is huge with nice floor to ceiling windows alongside it letting in daylight, and the jacuzzi is very spacious. The changing room had a good sized sauna in it as well, with decent shower products avaliable. I didn't visit the gym area so can't really comment.

Stayed here for 7 days in June 2015 (city view king).The room is clean and the bed is very comfortable.Hotel staff are welcoming and service is exceptional.Two mins walk to two 7/11's and a Family Mart.Four mins walk to shibuya train and crossing.The one drawback is that the bath is a bit small.I recommend this hotel for its proximity to the rail and great restaurants. We loved tokes and cerulean tower played a part in our fond memories. Thanks.

The Cerulean went above and beyond to make our stay memorable. I sent an email prior to checking in mentioning it was my partner's birthday during our stay. Upon our arrival into the room we were greeted with a gorgeous view of shibuya, a little birthday card and delicious gummy treats. The location was the best for Shibuya with easy walking access to both JR shibuya station and the subway and great access to the night life, shopping and food of shibuya. Would definitely go again! The service was flawless and everyone was so friendly. 10/10

Good location to explore this part of Tokyo. Easy to walk to from the station after a direct train from Narita. In my world this is a good three star hotel in a good location. Rooms are clean but dated. Basic health centre. Service is very good. Lots to see and do in between meetings. Lots of big western companies set up office in this part of the city. Yes, I would use this hotel again.

This hotel is perfectly located a block away from Shibuya station, which is a plus in every sense as this is one of the bussiest areas in Tokyo; you will have subway & train station at hand, nice department stores, restaurants and even the famous shibuya crossing.Rooms are quite nice and comfortable, with the first shower I find ever that doesnt leak! great amenities, daily newspaper, humidifier and a great & comfortable bed.Western breakfast is really great, with eggs made on demand but also some local dishes, excellent service and costumer care.The only downside is that if you happen to leave before 6am they don't have early bird breakfast, so you better buy something at a convenience store the night before.

The room was perfect. Huge and the most luxurious bathroom. No complaints about the room. View was also nice. Location great. Not sure where previous reviewers were walking but I timed it and it was literally one minute walk to the station. Not sure how it can physically take anyone ten minutes!!Now on to the bad stuff. Barely any of the staff speak English including reception which isn't helpful when trying to arrange a wake up call and they don't know what that is!! In general nobody on reception understood even the most basic stuff like where is my key. Kind of vital vocabulary for a receptionist. They also have no clue what customer service is. I am a vegetarian. There was a menu option on room service of spaghetti and tomato sauce with bacon on top. I asked without bacon and they refused. Not possible apparently. Not possible for a five star hotel to give me spaghetti with tomato sauce? What nonsense! Also the worst was a male receptionist who checked me out. Down right rude and got annoyed I refused to pay for an airport van I never ordered!? I was going to kyoto not the airport!! I then asked him to take off a breakfast charge for a day I didn't have breakfast and the rude man refused saying it was included in my deal. It Most certainly was not! I even had proof I hadn't had breakfast that day and asked what loss they incurred and he just barked at me and refused. In America they would have simply canceled the charge to retain custom. I won't be going back. Whilst the room was amazing, for the ludicrous price they charge Everything should be amazing and it wasn't. The staff were also not remotely friendly, even the polite ones. Facilities like hairdressers and spa never had any appointments and I got the distinct impression they all hate foreigners. Pretty useless when you work in a hotel.Spend your money elsewhere. Somewhere they know how to treat customers. Not worth the expense.

The only negative about this hotel is that is a bit expensive. Otherwise it gets an A in almost ALL departments. Great service. In fact fantastic service (but then Japan is like that). Rooms are good sized and mine had a spectacular view. The lobby is grand and welcoming. The location gets a 10 on 10. In fact 11 on 10. The bfast spread is both extensive and exotic. It also has its very own 7/11 within the hotel premises (which has its own ATM). Overall, a splendid property.

Stayed here from March 27 - April 3, 2015. It was our first time in Tokyo and I greatly recommend staying at Cerulean Hotel. The hotel is located at the heart of Shibuya. Around 10 mins walking distance towards the main train station. Should be an breeze as you only cross one overpass and you're already there. Apart from the station, it also also nearby popular tourist spots such as the Shibuya Crossing and Hachiko Statue. There are several restaurants and drinking places around the same strip as well. You just go down towards the overpass to the station. Instead of passing the overpass, turn right. On the other end of the train station are several malls and much of the happening takes place there.Rooms were spacious and clean. I enjoyed their shower as it provided ample space and was separate from the bathtub. We were 4 in a room and two of us shared one bed each. You had two choices for your breakfast: international buffet or Japanese set breakfast. Since we stayed here for over a week, I would alternate eating at both places. I definitely would recommend the Japanese breakfast.When we checked-in, there was no free wifi yet. The hotel later changed this policy and we were able to get free wifi during our last few days when we overlapped during the month of April.Overall, I really enjoyed my stay here. Great hotel, great location in Tokyo. There's nothing more I can ask for.

The Cerulean is a luxury hotel with great views, a professional staff that is friendly and knowledgeable, and in a great location. While the walk from Shibuya Station is relatively short (around 10 minutes), the only word of caution is that it is uphill. So if you have suitcases/luggage in tow, be mindful of this :) Overall, the hotel really is close to Shibuya Station, Shibuya Scramble, Hachiko Statue, and tons of shops and restaurants. We had 11 in our group ranging from 6 months old to 89 years old, and everyone loved it!

Agonized over making the right choice of a hotel for my Tokyo stay. Boy, am I glad I picked this one. The location is perfect-so close to the center of Shibuya ,which itself seems to be the center of everything in Tokyo. Our main interests are photographing, shopping, and eating....Shibuya seems to be the hub of all three. Once inside the hotel, everything runs like clockwork- the reception area never lets you wait for any kind of service-not only are the people behind the counter professional and efficient; but, they have several employees standing on the guest's side of the counter who can't come to your aid fast enough-and, they remember who you are from the moment you check in.Call the bell desk for help-they'll be in your room in two minutes. Our room was on the 32nd floor-large, clean, and comfy (wife loved the bed)-with a view down to the infamous Shibuya intersection.. Bathroom big and functional.You need something(say a soft drink or ATM), there's a seven-eleven within the hotel.

The hotel is close to main shibuya station every thing is so close to you. Restaurants, grocery, shops, The room is very clean specious. We been upgraded to corner room which gives you nice view to the area as well big windows in the bathroom. With both standing and tube shower. The room services is available however is limited and also depending on time you order the food. The looby quite big with lounge area. I really like it and always it will be my hotel to stay in Tokyo

This is a great hotel whether you are on business travel or not. It's central location makes it a good option to explore the city and in case you need to travel the stations of shinjuku and Shibuya are very near by. Huge choice of restaurants and other places to eat near by, and the rooms offer a very good view over Shibuya and shinjuku.
