We stayed on the 23rd floor for 5 nights and it was great. The room itself was very spacious, with fantastic views of the city, and on a clear day you can see Mt Fuji. The bathroom is quite big and has the all singing all dancing toilet, complete with seat warmer.The hotel is located very close to Shibuya station, about a 5 minute walk. There are plenty of restaurants and bars around and it's always busy. There's even a cat cafe just around the corner!The staff is very friendly and most speak English.My only gripe would be that, although they do provide coffee and tea making facilities (kettle) you have to pay for the tea bags/coffee. But there is a 7 Eleven just downstairs in the building so crisis averted. There is also no turn down service.

Since it is in Shibuya, it is very lively till late at night. Convenience stores + restaurants are littered around the area and the hotel is right by the subway lines. I have to knock it down for having no free internet in spite of the pricey rate.

I stayed at cerulean hotel for 5 nights with my family, myself, husband and 5 and 8 year olds. The hotel was very clean and located at a very convenient location, and I was very happy with the hotel. However it is not really suited for families with young kids as it doesn't really have things like Kidsclub or any entertainment for young ones. I wish they'd cater things for families that would have made our stay more memorable one. Initially i got the impression that the hotel was quite family friendly. But it wasn't, what a shame.

This hotel has a fantastic location in the heart of Shibuya district, very trendy area in Tokyo. It is connected with two aeroports with shuttle bus which is very convenient. It is located very close to the underground, JR and the railway station. In this area there are the monument to a famous dog Hatchiko and the busiest in the world Shibuya crossroad.There are a lot of restaurants and cafés as well as big malls. The hotel property is a bit old fashioned but has its unique business Japanese style, rooms are spacious and clean. The hotel is huge, it includes an excellent Japanese, extremely testing Chinese (must try) and other restaurants and bars and jazz bar, fitness, spa and dentist studio(very good) and art fine souvenir shop. Another great attraction of the hotel is the view from the bar on the top which is really fantastic. We had a wonderful view to the city already from our room. The personnel is very polite, the concierge service is excellent and very helpful. The wi-fi is free of charge also in the room! The overall experience is very positive.

If you're looking for a luxury hotel that's right in the hear of Shibuya with amazing views, the Cerulean is a great place to start...if you can get a good deal on a room. For what we paid, we were a little surprised by how dated some of the amenities were. Not bad...just dated. Also, be prepared for a firm bed.The hotel staff was very helpful and spoke English well (which is huge plus), and you can get to and from the airport directly from the hotel via the Limousine Bus service.In traditional luxury hotel fashion, be prepared to pay for everything. Even using the hotel's pool will run you $20. Room service runs around $30-40 per plate. Restaurant prices are $40-120 per plate. Drinks $14 and up. Unless money is no object, it's better to grab food and supplies in nearby Shibuya.The view though, is amazing. Panoramic views of all of Tokyo. Just wait for the sun to set and you get a completely new view of the city: Lights stretching for miles. Stunning.

My better half and I decided to quickly book two round trip tickets from our current location, Seoul, to Tokyo when some cheap seats popped up. We didn't bother booking a hotel because we wanted to be spontaneous and we figured something would be open once we arrived.We couldn't have been more wrong!After wandering around Shinjuku and Shibuya for a few hours, taking in as much delicious food, local beer and all around night life as we could we were getting pretty tired. It was fast approaching midnight and we still didn't know where we'd be sleeping that night. I had a tip that there were some cheap love motels at one end of Shibuya. Surprisingly, they were all booked for the night. With heavy heads and sore feet we trudged toward our last hope, the Cerulean Tower. Taking in the luxurious marble floors, high ceilings and smart design I wasn't expecting an opening, let alone to pay less than 50,000 JPNY. Although, we still tried.They ended up giving us a room on the spot on the 36th floor. It ran about 43,000 JPNY (430.00 USD), which was about double what I'd pay for something similar in Seoul. But, hey, Japan's not a cheap city and it was extremely last minute.Our room was big, swanky and extremely comfortable. The view made the whole thing totally worth it. We could easily see all of Shibuya and into the surrounding area. It's close enough to the subway station and there's plenty to do right within Shibuya. I'd say the location is just about perfect.We didn't check in until about 1:30 in the morning and we had a full day of activities the following morning so we didn't get a chance to really experience any of the added amenities. However, I wouldn't hesitate booking in advance at this place if and when I'm back in Tokyo. What I can say is that the staff were extremely professional and helpful, even to a couple of tipsy tourists trying to get a room in the middle of the night!

I enjoyed my stay at the Cerulean as I spent two amazing weeks sightseeing and immersing myself in the Japanese culture and the Tokyo nightlight. The hotel cleanliness, modern amenities and a gorgeous and spacious room made my stay that much more memorable. Only knock is for the restaurants in the hotel. Non-smoking should mean non-smoking....not 10 feet of space from someone who does smoke.

My stay in Tokyo was perfect thanks to this wonderful hotel! Its location in Shibuya was perfect! It is close to the Market City Mall, the Tokyu Department Store, Shibuya Station, world famous Shibuya Crossing and some of the best restaurants Tokyo has to offer!The staff is very attentive. And there are staff members that speak English very well.The restaurants have nice menus and we did opt to eat at The Szechwan Chen. Excellent! Excellent! A must try!The views are outstanding! Seeing one of the many skylines of Tokyo takes your breath away. I was on the 23rd floor and the view was insane!I would tell everyone to pick The Cerulean!

Location, location, location. My kids and I love Shibuya so this is a perfect hotel, just steps away from everything - Shibuya Crossing and the famous Hachiko Statue, other places we wanted to see were easily accessible from the hotel, nice shopping and restaurants. More of a business hotel, very spacious rooms esp. for Tokyo standards, impressive views over the Tokyo area, especially at night (stayed on the 30th floor), fair breakfast and a nice Italian restaurant on the first floor.

Cannot miss this big tower at the JR exit !The room was very very nice and so big ! They gently upgraded us for my birthday. We had a tremendous view on Shibuya and Shibuya crossing.The room was very cosy, the furniture confortable and the bathroom so large and so furnished !Everyone was very sympathic and helpful.A perfect place to stay if you want to be in one the busiest neighbouroods of Tokyo

Very good hotel: perfectly situated in Shibuya, barely 5 minutes away on foot from the Shibuya station and the famous "Shibuya Pedestrian Scramble". In fact rooms on the high floors even afford you a view of the pedestrian crossing.Floors above 30 have rooms with great views, particularly night views, of the city. Had one that looked beyond Shibuya to the large swathe of green tree tops of Yoyogi Park and the Shinjuku skyline beyond.Food at the restaurants was OK; nothing to write home about. And last orders for dinner generally get taken by 8:30. But the room service was exemplary and quick; it was actually a "service" with a waiter and maitre d' type supervisor in attendance.Staff are very courteous as elsewhere in Japan. However, at the Cerulean they seemed a little standoffish, if that's possible. Some staff were almost robotic in their demeanour. But always polite and courteous.The room was very spacious by any standard; more so when compared to Tokyo's other hotels. Had one which was 37 sq.m. I think. And the bathroom was very comfortably large too.

This hotel is in a great location within shibuya with a breathtaking view of the city from both our bedroom and bathroom. We stayed here on a couple of nights of our trip, our second was even better as we had a view of Shibuya crossing. It is expensive (and breakfast is not included) but the service is absolutely flawless. If your budget allows it, worth staying for even one night to get a taste of the luxury!

Been here 6 times. Nice lobby with cool Danish furniture. Super professional staff as usual in Japan. Location is very convenient if you want to visit Shibuya. Rooms are nice, clean and generally cozy. I like the breakfast and cocktails at the lobby bar. Simple, comfortable and friendly hotel.

Stayed three nights with a friend here as the last hotel in our Japan trip, and was taken care of at every turn.Every facility, every convenice and all sides to the hotel are top-notch. Our view was incredible from our room, and every staff we came across was beyond helpful and interested in where we were from, and to generally have a chat. This was a nice touch for a 5 Star hotel.Location is nice, we were close enough for walking distance to all shopping, the famous crossing, and underneath the hotel was a 7/11 which took care of any snack needs.Our only criticism was that for the price we paid, wifi was not free. Let's face it, it's well past the year where wifi is a luxury, and I've spent time on public buses which offer free wifi, let alone a 5 Star luxury hotel. A small annoyance, and one we paid and swallowed, but still an unnecessary cost tacked on to an already sizable stay.Room service was above par, and will definitely stay again next trip.

Very clean and big rooms. Impressive views over the Tokyo area and it is situated nearby all the places we wanted to see. Only a stone-throw away from the centre of Shibuya. The hotelrooms are weel silenced so you don't even hear the other guests in the hallways or rooms. It has a very nice bar in the upper part of the hotle with a splendid view over Tokyo by night. Drinks are expensive but the ambiance makes up for it! We didn't eat in the hotel because there are so many nice places just around the hotel. We only tried the Italian resto of the hotel wich delivered a nice dinner.

Stayed for 9 nights in the middle of April. Arrived off an early morning flight, catching the airport limosine (bus) from the airport. We left our bags and asked for directions to Shibuya Crossing and the famous Hachiko Statue, which was given with a clear and easy map. Shibuya is on the Yamanote JR line and you can get open day tickets on this line so you can see some sites/suburbs including Shinjuku, Tokyo station area, Ueno etc so it is so convenient.My request for a Fuji view room was met and we stayed on 30th floor. Note, it has to be a really clear day to see Mt Fuji which we only saw briefly for one morning. Room was super clean and fresh and note beds are king single size. Bathroom and room is spacious for Japanese standard and could not fault anything. Wifi is now included free.Didn't have breakfast at the hotel but in hindsight we should have as I have an 8 and 7 year old and ended up eating at the local Tokyu Department store bakeries and other local bakeries. Considering stores and restaurants don't open until 10am this was a hassle.Concierge were helpful and their English was enough to help us find some local attractions.

I stayed this hotel from April/1/2015 for a night.The first surprising thing was when I got off the taxi from the airport, there was no bell boy to carry our luggage. I never experienced this with 5 star hotel in my life and we have to carry the luggage until the bell service find us inside of the lobby.Secondly, the check in was totally unpleasant. The guy who handled us was very unprofessional with bad attitude.Beside this person, all the other staff was very polite, but it is important to standardize the service as this person's attitude ruined the image of this hotel a lot this time.Room was just OK. Interior looks a bit cheap to be honest.With the same level of hotel, I recommend Westin Tokyo.

I would not call Cerulean a memorable hotel. For that, it lack uniqueness of character or that special human touch that makes a place endearing to the heart. Rather, it is a hotel I would describe as "excellent", and begrudgingly stay there every time, because no other hotel in Tokyo offers the same level of comfort and convenience. First of all, you simply cannot do better in terms of location. 2 min walk from Shibuya-station, where half a dozen train lines intersect. Perfectly ideal for both business and leisure. The city of Shibuya is at your footsteps, providing shopping and dining at every price range. Rooms are understated but tasteful. For Tokyo standards, it is almost spacious. Bedding is comfortable. The bathroom is luxurious and well appointed. And if you manage to book a room on the higher floors, you are pretty much guaranteed a fabulous view owing to the fact that Cerulean is the only high rise tower in the immediate vicinity. Buffet breakfast is served at the sunny 1F restaurant. They always have fresh squeezed orange juice at the far corner, which I personally think is a great touch.The hotel has several restaurants. If you love Chinese food, do try out Chen. Wifi worked fine during our stay. Owing to its superior location and the fact that it is a relatively new property, this is an extremely popular hotel for both the local population as well as foreigners-in-the-know. As such, the lobby area is always crowded. In fact, the only real complaint I have about this hotel is that there aren't enough comfortable seating in the lobby. While Japanese servers are generally reserved, but tend to go out of their way to please (within the rigid confines of what is deemed proper for them), don't expect any service staff at Cerulean to go an extra mile. Their service is in demand and they know it. Any special request will generally be handled in a somewhat hesitant manner or charged a hefty price. Case in point, when we asked the concierge if they could keep a small package in their freezer, they accepted, after telling us repeatedly that their refrigerator may not be able to accommodate the size. Also, when we asked for an check-out extension as our flight was leaving at midnight, they wanted to charge 1/3 of the room rate (47,000 yen for 3 hours).

The Cerulean Tower is probably the best hotel in the Shibuya area. This is partly because there are very few hotels in Shibuya. The best part about the hotel is the location, rooms, and view. My biggest disappointment was the attitude of one of the concierges. When we first arrived, we asked for directions from the woman concierge (the one who is a little on the heavy side/sits on the left). When we approached the desk, she didn’t say a word. We finally said something to her and she didn’t smile nor did she seem to want to help. This happened every time we spoke with her. I was so surprised since my last visit was to the Westin Ebisu where all of the concierges were always smiling and ready to help. That being said, the rest of the concierges were very helpful and friendly. The hotel is very convenient to the train station but there are a series of walkway bridges to get to the hotel. It is a little cumbersome in the cold and rain. The rooms are very spacious, clean, and modern. The views are also very panoramic. We could have paid less at the Westin Ebisu which is a much grander hotel but if you want to be where the action is in Shibuya then the Cerulean Tower is a great choice.

we stayed in 2 adjoining rooms on the 20th floor of this hotel so our 2 kids could be close but we could still have our own room. it was luxury hotel accommodation but without the hefty pricetag. we were within a very short walking distance to Shibuya Intersection (made famous by Scarlett Johansson in "Lost in Translation") and abundant restaurants, bars and shopping. We had the best sleeps at night because we had block our curtains and the buffet breakfast was a hit for our kids. loved how close this hotel was to everything.

Yes, I really do think that title is justified -- this hotel has now replaced my previous choice for that title (The Yokohama Royal Park Hotel, the Landmark Tower, in Yokohama) which I like for the same reasons as I do The Cerulean, this hotel manages to do it even better. Okay, I'd better justify that high praise so, from the top...The BasicsThis is of course a luxury hotel so at the very least, it has to do the essential things properly. And so it does. The building exterior is smart and modern, the entrances and lobbyies spacious and elegantly decorated with clear signposting and a logical, intuitive guest journey through check in and onto your room. The rooms themselves (I stated in the slightly larger rooms on the 30th+ floor but I don't doubt that this is true for all rooms) are very good with a stylish, neutral decor and an understated opulence. There standards of maintenance and cleaning are excellent too, as are the in-room facilities. The free WiFi is very easy to set up and extremely fast. The air conditioning is quiet and effective.The LocationThe hotel is very well located a short walk from Shibuya station. By the way, If you're not familiar with Tokyo, I'd always recommend that you find a hotel adjacent to a station on the Yamanote line (as is Shibuya) at whatever price point you are interested in. 80% of Tokyo can be reached from the Yamanote line with just one change and 90+% with two changes so really will help with your travel arrangements. Connecting with the Yamanote is what all other metro stations like to do ideally so being near the line is so much more convenient. Just my tip, hope it helps. What Makes Good into SuperbHaving established this hotel gets the basics right (even allowing for price and the fact that this is of course Japan we're talking about here so you'd expect everything to "just work") what did it do to a) surprise and delight in ways you didn't expect and b) differentiate itself from the huge competition in the central Tokyo upscale hotel market ? Well, let's start with what I said about location. Shibuya is an exciting and vibrant district which is great fun to visit but you probably wouldn't want to live there. So what you'd really like in a hotel is to feel that when you enter it, suddenly the noise and chaos of the hussle and bussel of the outside world has magically disappeared. The Cerulean manages to do that. The building lacks the drama and verve of the Shinjuku Park Tower's Hyatt Hotel but instead has a restrained opulence and quiet understated feel of a London private club. But it isn't stuffy or pretentious.Not being any sort of foodie, I didn't visit the showcase restaurants so if you're the foodie type I'm sorry that I can't help -- but I did go to the informal cafes on the ground floor and use room service which if the main restaurants match the standard of these, you shouldn't be disappointed. What really sets this hotel apart though is the staff. And this is the hardest things to get right. Too much drilling and rote learning means you've got curteous automatons rather than warm and friendly human beings. The staff at this hotel are nothing short of a delight. Polite and professional, of course, but there's a rare quality of seemingly genuine charm that pervades the entire team and lifts the atmosphere of the whole place. You can't put your finger on it, but you know when it is there or when it isn't. The lobby clark guy who made sense of my complicated reservation. The room service lady who made sure that everything was perfect. The endlessly patient woman at the porter's desk who politely and flawlessly sorted out when I left my room card in the room (and didn't mind at all me having the temerity to say that she might have inadvertently kept it when I reserved a limousine bus to the airport when in fact I'd mistakenly locked myself out of my room -- and in the process turned what could have been a toe curlingly embarrassing incident for me into an enjoyable whizz up and down in the lifts, turning the room upside down to find the key card and, all-in-all probably the high point of my stay. The ability to do that is little short of magical. It isn't always down to how much you're paying. There is a hotel in the Home Coutnies of England (I won't name names but it's where the English national football squad stay) where the is no lack of blingy swank. The staff are neat, scrubbed and polished and will do whatever you ask, but you can feel them assessing your net worth when you enter the building and bigging up the haughty attitude if they don't think you're worthy enough of staying there. And that isn't the only hotel where the management and staff mistake condescension for what is actually required - care for their guests. That comes across in everything about the Cerulean. Best hotel in Japan? A big claim, but I'll stick to it. No, you can't compare, say, a $1000 a night ryokan with a western style hotel like this and it would be silly to do so. And a $150 a night airport hotel that is quiet, pleasant and restful can seem like Heaven maybe because it is just the right place at the right time. But no, I genuinely think that, this hotel is in a class of its own.

I explicitely booked a "City View" room for my first visit to Tokyo and as the "City View" rooms are charged at a higher rate than what the hotel calls their "Sky View" rooms (rooms with a view on the suburbs of Tokyo) I trusted that the hotel would handle my reservation correctly . When I checked out the day after I enquired again and found out that not only had I been given a "Sky View" room but extra charge would not be compensated. Nicely done. I call that downright dishonnest.

Really well located, five minutes from Shibuya station. It is not cheap but the rooms are huge and really well appointed, with wonderful views out over Tokyo. It is all a bit soulless, but very comfortable. I stated away from the bar and restaurant because they looked expensive, and there are tons of places just outside.

I stayed here with my daughters for 5 nights. The location is great, the restaurants are good especially the Chinese. The service is courteous and as from the 1st of April the Wi Fi is free but it was very expensive and a little soulless, it felt like a business hotel. The best thing is the view from the rooms which is stunning!

brought the family for our first trip to Tokyo and stayed at The Cerulean Tower Hotel at the recommendation of friends who used to live in Tokyo. First class hotel amenities and excellent service. Everyone at the hotel was polite and courteous which made our stay quite pleasant. Shibuya train station is a quick 5 minute walk from the hotel . There was plenty of shopping in the Shibuya area to keep everyone happy as well as lots of restaurant choices. Hotel restaurants were very good and so we ate in many times. Stayed for week and would definitely come back again. Highly recommended.

We enjoyed our stay at Cerulean. The guest rooms were perfect (modern, spacious, immaculately clean, and with excellent city views.) there are inter-connecting rooms for families. Wifi is now free and the speed is fast. Th piano bar on the 40th floor is pleasant and with magnificent view of city lights and Tokyo Tower. The hotel is around 300 to 500 meters walk to the JR station, subway, Hachico attraction, Shibuya Crossin where shops and restaurants abound.

Pros: Very luxurious, great robes, good location, helpful conciergeCons: ExpensiveOverall: If you don't mind the price, then you'll love the stay. This was the nicest hotel within Shibuya that we stayed at.The room: Great views from the tower, and I assume there's no room you could go wrong with. Very spacious and everything you'd expect from something of this price, but even better, there's a heater in the bathroom mirror! Nice to have when everything else is fogged up. The location: An easy walk to the Shibuya station as well as everything else in the area. There's also a 7-11 near the lobby, so if you need anything, there's easy access nearby.The staff: The concierge was happy to book a restaurant, and offer suggestions for places to visit. Everyone was polite and courteous and happy to offer any help needed.

Love this hotel!! The rooms are bigger than expected, very nice and clean. The twin beds are comfortable, mattress is just the right amount of firmness. We were on the 30th floor with an awesome cityscape view at night. The staff is very friendly, attentive, and polite always greeting us on the way in and out of the building.It's about 5-10 minute walk (leisurely, no luggages) from the Shibuya station, and 15 minutes to Shibuya crossing. To get to the hotel, from the station, use the stairs/ramps on the left side (facing the Tokyu building) or cross the street to the Tokyu buiding and take the stairs/ramp there. There is an overpass walkway to/from the hotel as well to cross the boulevard and explore the side streets. The Shibuya Mark City can be accessed from one of these side streets.We had daily breakfast/brunch at the hotel's Caramelo restaurant. The buffet was delicious with variety of menu - eggs, sausages, condiments, pastries, breads, different jams, soup, salad, fruits, cereal, hot vegetables, green salad, juices and coffee, cereal, porridge, and a side special each day like pieces of steamed fish or gnocchi. Everything was high quality. It's not cheap at around $27 pp but considering we ate enough that we didn't get hungry until mid afternoon, after hours of walking around, it was definitely worth it. Plus felt good that we were eating healthy! There are other restaurants in the hotel that we did not get to try.There's also a 24-hour 7/11 with an ATM in the same building by the Mediterraneo restaurant.We checked out after 5 days to go to Kyoto, and came back to Shibuya on the last last day for our return to the U.S. The hotel agreed to keep our luggages on this last day until our flight time. They didn't have to do this but they did!We were able to get a good deal on the room rate via Expedia, which really made the hotel reasonably priced.

We were surprised that the rooms were quite big. The beds were soft and the amenities were pretty good too. Our only issue was for such a nice hotel, it didn't have free wifi which we got in all the other Japan hotels we stayed in this trip. Location: a few minutes walking distance from the JR shibuya station. Pretty near all the different shops and department stores of shibuya too. We also had meals at the nearby restaurants. There's also a 7-11 on the second floor and a family Mart nearby. Had our 1 year old daughter with us and we loved going to the convenience stores for onigiri and other snacks. The airport bus stop at the basement was also very convenient

We didn't stay at the Cerulean Towers Hotel, but we did go to Bellovisto Bar on the 40th floor for a few drinks, and it was really really lovely!We were looking a little shabby after a day wondering around Harajuku and Shibuya in the rain, but that didn't matter. The staff at Bellovisto we're just delightful; friendly, attentive, polite, yet not pushy or overbearing.The views are epic, it's worth going up there just to gaze out at Tokyo.The drinks are not cheap and there is a per person table charge. However, the prices are not exorbitant. We sat there for a few hours, had a few cocktails each and ended up spending less than we would over all on a similar night out in Sydney (and the service, view and whiskey were all better than in Sydney).

This is a solid business hotel which delivers on many basic things one would expect in a hotel w/ extra perks - ie, dependable wifi, comfortable room, convenient bus pickup and drop off from the airport, etc. The unexpected perks come in the form of an amazing view of Mount Fuji, an extremely aesthetic and modern bathroom, a large and spacious room, etc. In particular the rock floor of the shower is extremely aesthetic and comfortable. I find hotels like this a rarity in Tokyo and I'll begin making this place a routine stop for me if possible. The service is dependable but as usual, they don't allow you to control the temperature of the room. However, I find setting the temperature low in the room reduces the temperature a lot and makes it quite comfortable. I'm a big fan of this hotel !

Helpful staff, beautiful accommodations, great location. Although I typically stay in smaller, boutique hotels Cerulean was recommended to me for my first trip to Tokyo and it was the perfect choice. The city can be overwhelming on your first visit but the hotel was serene, luxurious and happy to answer any (and all!) of our millions of questions.

The Shibuya area is very lively and a very short walk to good transportation. I was most impressed with the extraordinary level of attentive service. Every employee we encountered gave us great service. The room was quite large especially by Japanese standards and so was the bathroom. Everything was very clean and well maintained. The staff were helpful and the fact that this hotel is a shuttle stop for both airports is a big plus.Thanks for a great stay!

Fantastic locationVery clean Amazing viewsGood sized room for 3 of us and excellent bathroom.Only had one breakfast so can't comment on thatThe Japanese resturant was very disappointing - no atmosphere and very overpriced. Take the time to step outside and find some fantastic local bars to eat in instead.A good level of English spoken.Not tbe cheapest option but we felt good value.

great location, beds were rock hard, pillows also felt like they had rocks in them also, for $400+ a night then they charge extra for wifi and breakfast thought it was very average, only plus was close (5min walk) to shibuya train station, wouldn't recommend to friends

The location is fantastic! It's a five minute walk from the Shibuya station. It was so convenient! The rooms are spacious and comfy, the service is great. The view from the room is also great; you can see a lot of the city from the room.Room service was convenient, but pricey. The only complaints we have is that the reception staff weren't that nice - it felt like we were an inconvenience, which was very strange compared to the rest of the people at the hotel, and pretty much everywhere. The other thing we didn't like is that the hotel charges for everything separately: water, wifi, access to the gym, etc. It would be nice if at least those were included.

Great location! In shibuya the times square or Tokyo , you have everything right at your feet and is a nice clean hotel. Service was great room a bit small but have read most spaces in japan are small so didnt bother me too much since we were barely in room. Heated toilet seats!! You have to pay for wifi like almost every hotel . Room service is expensive but so is everything in japan. Highly recommended !

Perfectly located next to Shibuya station, this tower provides an amazing view on Tokyo city.Rooms are quite big, nice bathrooms, perfect service, several restaurants, swimming pool.Ideal place to stay for any touristic or business stay

Clean, efficient, larger than normal rooms, attentive serviceit is just a little character less as most large business hotels areroom service and mini bar expensive but there is a seven eleven in the same building as a cheaper option

OK this is a business hotel and we are not business travellers, infact we travel with 9 month baby. The 2 reasons why we chose this hotel location and on site creche for our baby. There is a Poppins Creche right in the building which looked after our baby during the day sometimes and even into the evening until 11pm. The staff there are excellent are looked fater our baby well, the facilities, toys etc really well done. It can be billed to your room. We stayed in 3405, this was upgrade becuase on checkin our room was not ready. It was the same room class but 4 floors up so we were pleased becuase the views were incredible, we looked over the Shibuya Crossing, over the park and up to Shinjuku. The room was much larger than expected and fitted us all in very comfortably. The bathroom is large with a fancy toilet. It would benefit from infloor heating during the winter becuase the stone floor can get very cold. The cleaning maids were excellent and did an inpeccable job every day. The hotel however has a distinct business feel to it. There was only a few seats in the lobby to wait for our room. When waiting for airport transfer bus there was only 4 seats below which were all taken of course, so I had to feed my baby on the floor. This hotel needs more chairs for the large amount of people using the public spaces. The restaurants are expensive and people are paying with company money, this didn't really bother us becuase there is many many many good places nearby to eat much cheaper. My god the food in Japan is good! THere is a 7/11 across the road which has good kids snack food like fruit and yoghurt. Concerge were very helpful in directing us to a chemist and big supermarket for nappies. The is an amazing food hall nearby which is quite possibly the largest I've ever been to and has amazing dinners and food to go. There is also a great kitchen and smaller food hall down the hill, near station (underground floor). On the last night we got room service and it was so expensive for the measly plates of food that came, for 6000 yen it was a very tiny bowl of bolognese which was plated just boring (even just adding a slice of baguette with garlic butter, costs nothing but would add to the appeal) and a ceasar salad again a few leaves with dressing, (again a slice of baguette, an egg, an anchovy or two) it was just so unappestising, this was surprising given the italian resturant in house. Just because its room service doesn't mean it shouldn't look good and be tasty. Use their website to book and become a member, the rates are cheaper, you can use the gym/pool (no kids) and free internet. Also the limo bus for 3,100 was excellent, door to door and for us with a baby and luggage much easier than metro and narita express train. Book with conceirge the day before who will give you times and organise the ticket on your room bill. All the staff we talked to were very nice.

We had a really nice triple room. Comfortable beds, great bathroom and perfect blockout curtains. The view from the room over the tokyo skyline was awesome. Did not try any food, however the service on check-in was great. One downfall was the fact that you had to pay for wifi, considering it is an expensive five star hotel it should be complimentary.

A group of 6 of us who were first time travelers to Tokyo chose to stay in the Cerulean Towers. Lets start with the positives, its in a great location about a 5 minute walk to Shibuya station. However, you have to walk over the footbridge to the station (which does have lifts) but it is a bit of chore. The room was remarkably spacious, very clean and well appointed and has a cracking good view of the city. The room service breakfast was serviced bang on time and was of good quality. The hotel staff were very polite and efficient and were basically great! A couple of downsides was we were charged for wifi which I think is not good nowadays and you are charged to use the pool area quite a lot considering it isn't brilliant and you have to wear swimming caps which aren't exactly comfortable if you want to laze in their Jacuzzi. In summary this is a great hotel and I have no complaints. Its location is ideal if you want to get around Tokyo as a tourist as its in the middle of a great tourist district and close to the station for both over ground and underground trains.

Before I went to Tokyo for this trip, I really had a doubt whether this hotel would be good. And now everything has been got the answer. I really had a pleasant stay in this hotel. This hotel is located very close to the JR Shibuya Station that can bring you around Tokyo through JR line. Another plus point of its location is the short walking distance from the hotel tower to many shopping and foodism places. This made us easy to spend our whole day with fun by exploring the district. Hotel staffs were very friendly and helpful. Room was completely clean and neat. And for the bathroom, I really love the design that they use. It's modern and cozy. If you read some other reviews said nothing is free in this hotel, I guess they are true. You will be charged for the usage of wifi connection. Even they didn't give you some water complimentary in the room. Hotel management should be re-evaluating these free facilities in order to gain some customers satisfaction. But overall I can say I had a pleasant stay and everything worth the amount I paid.

Only the concierge and porter had the best service.Management has changed with poor service.Terrible house keeping crew, and front desk service was unsatisfactory.I would rather stay in a 3 star hotel than this hotel.No free wifi, no free breakfast, extremely expensive price.

We stayed here for 3 nights in room 3419. The room was huge and gorgeous. The bathroom had a separate bath/shower room, semi-screened toilet and a make up stool at the basin. There's a spacious desk/work area and a comfortable 'chaise lounge' style seat and ottoman combo. The bed was so comfortable it was hard getting up in the morning. We had a fantastic view of Tokyo from our room. We had booked on-line some months ago and got a 50% off price. It is close to Shibuya Station and, as we only have one suitcase each, walked to and from the station.

I stayed here while speaking at a conference at the hotel's conference centre.Positives:- Location is perfect - so close to major shopping, restaurants.- Rooms are very spacious and comfortable (except for bed, see below)- Views are fantastic- Bathrooms are spacious and very well appointed- Staff are friendly and helpful- Quick checkin and out - I cannot abide long complex check in procedures when they have all your info alreadyNegatives:- Very expensive- Wifi was expensive - I would expect free wifi at the price paid- Breakfast was ridiculously expensive - I ended up going to the local 7/11 as I could not justify the price charged- Bed was VERY hard. I like a hard bed but this was like sleeping on a plankSo overall is great if someone else is paying!

This hotel has a very cool location and is very nice inside. I thought the rooms were very nicely put together. The view was awesome also as we could see Mt Fuji from our room. The breakfast was excellent. We ate at Chinese Restaurant which I thought was ok not great. It is in an ultra cool area with great shopping.

The Cerulean Tower hotel is my favorite place to stay in Tokyo -- eight stays and counting over ten years. The reasons? 1. Location. Shibuya station is a short walk away and is a major hub for getting you to where you need to go. 2. Service. The staff at the Cerulean always makes you feel comfortable. Taxis always available and bellmen to help be sure your driver knows where they are going. Specific call-out to the concierge staff. They know EVERYTHING about Tokyo! They are the best I've ever experienced, and in a city the size of Tokyo, a great concierge can make all of the difference. 3. Rooms. Nothing fancy, but quiet, clean, predictable, and always with a great view.

I stayed here on my own for a long weekend. It was expensive but I believe very spacious for Tokyo. The room ws lovely and had fantastic views of the city. I especially loved the top floor restaurant great wine and some snacks looking over the city....absolute bliss. The hotel was in walking distance of the metro which was brilliant. Lots of tourist attractions within 20mins walking. I was here in July so it was hard going walking in the heat. Overall a lovely stay but I'd recommend somewhere cheaper if you were there for longer than a weekend.

I've stayed at the Cerulean Tower Tokyo Hotel at least 5 times and I've always been very happy there. The views are incredible you can see all of Tokyo from your bedroom window. Large rooms, great bar at the top of the hotel. Good location and if you can, top floors are the best. Meals are great and of course, it is Japan, so service is excellent.

Cerulean tower tokyu hotel is not a bad hotel. highly recommended. internet is unfortunately paid but it was fast. Room is average size, clean. Few good restaurants. Location is good. Service is very good.

Perfect location for shopping, dinning, bars, spacious room compared to other Tokyo hotels, very quick and helpful staffs, taxi available anytime, and the greatest thing is you can catch airport limo bus from/to hotel. The internet is not free but once you accept to pay reasonable amount, you can use very fast and stable internet.

Stayed here for 2 nights over NYE and NY day as a treat for my birthday while we were on our trip. It was a lovely big room with great views and the bathroom was huge (had a shower and a bath in a room separate from the rest of the bathroom)! It was in a great location as well - nice and close to Shibuya crossing. I wish we had more time there to really appreciate the rest of the hotel.

The location is perfect... 2 minutes walk to the train station, excellent shopping, ease of getting around, the right area.. all the right ingredients, but it falls short. The rooms are dated and old, the club floor offers nothing special, rather disappointing actually. IF they could modernize the rooms, they would change this from 3 to 5. The views are wonderful.

We slept our last 2 nights in Tokyo at the Cerulean Tower.After 3 weeks staying at apartments rented online, it was great to stay at such comfortable property before heading back home on a long long flight.The service is super, front desk crew is excellent, rooms are clean, bed is great, and the roof top bar is amazing.

We stayed as a family of 4 and had two rooms over New Year. We has executive floor rooms, and they were amazing. The rooms themselves were very large, but the view was the best bit, Being at the top of the tower, you had an amazing view of Tokyo. We used the executive lounge, and this also had a great view, and a good selection of drinks and snacks in the evening. We did visit the Jazz Club, which was also a fantastic experience - full of young trendy Japanese and several great bands playing modern jazz. We enjoyed exploring the area, lots of shopping, and also a lovely walk in the park (next to the old Olympic area). Loved the hotel, loved the location. Would highly recommend.

When we first arrived at this hotel we were very impressed with the way everything looked both outside and in the lobby. The check in counter and this was where I had the problem that stops me giving this hotel a better review. The check in staff were extremely rude and argumentative. I'm a Japanese teacher so I frequently travel to Japan, and this is the only place in Tokyo that I've ever had a staff member argue with me. So my problem is that I don't have a credit card because I've never needed one. Whenever I check in to a hotel I have everything pre-paid and usually agree to not use room service or something like that, if they really need a card I hand over a visa debit card. I e-mailed this place before I arrived to make sure this would be ok. They e-mailed me back and said that was fine. Well when I got there that wasn't good enough. They demanded a credit card. I said I didn't have one, they tried to say I couldn't check in even though I'd already paid for the room. I said if I couldn't check in I'd take my two thousand dollars back and go somewhere else. They said they can't give me a refund but I can't check in. Eventually they said I could check in if I gave them a cash deposit that was more than the entire cost of the room (so, more money than I had on me). After much arguing and speaking to the manager they eventually let me check in and made a note saying I can't use room service, but it really put me off this hotel. I understand 99% of people won't have this problem because they have a card, but still think it's worth mentioning because I travel a lot and have never had a problem with not having one. Anyway! We got to the room and it was very large for Tokyo (but we paid extra for a larger room on a higher level). Decor was very boring and business-like, but the room was spacious and very clean, it was nice. The beds were big and comfortable. If you pay extra for a nigh level floor it's really worth it, because the view is amazing. We stayed in January last year, and it started snowing! (snow is a novelty for us, being from sunny QLD, Australia) Seeing the snow blowing from up high was really beautiful. Location is pretty good, it's close to Shibuya, but not directly part of the chaos of the city because the hotel is also an office building. There's not much right outside the hotel, so you have to walk to the areas around the scramble crossing to find things to do and the train station. It's about a 5min walk up a lot of stairs/hills to get to the station/city.I definitely think when you pay as much as you do here, WiFi should be free and use of the pool should be free.

Cerulean Tower is a great 4/5 star hotel, we had initially chosen it for its location in Shibuya, it is 5 minutes from Shibuya station where you can catch the JR line, the metro and the Narita Express. It is also the only hotel that has a triple room to cater to our three teenage boys, within a reasonable price range, yet with all the mod cons. The hotel rooms are spacious for Japan standard, the beds are very comfortable, crisp white sheet, fluffy towels, clean rooms, all important for fussy travellers. However, the best thing the hotel has is their staff, or one in particular, at the reception. At 6am on 15 January, 4 hours before our flight out from Tokyo, my son announced that he has lost his passport, the night before, somewhere in the shopping district of Shibuya! Thinking that we will be stranded in Tokyo until the passport is sorted, I approached the reception to get an extension of our stay. The young lady at the reception after finding out our problem, rang the police station and unbelievably located our passport! The passport had made its way to the Shibuya police station. She then negotiated with the officer for us to pick up the passport at 7.30am, so that we could still make it for our 10.30am flight. The relief of finding the passport was unbelievable, especially in a country where we couldn't speak their language. I felt like she had handed me a lifeline when I was drowning, and to that I am so grateful. This young lady might be just doing her job, but to us, she is the embodiment of goodness, and for that, I would highly recommend this hotel.

Great location and amazing staff! The only constructive feedback I would offer the hotel is that for such expensive rates there should not be an additional charge for access to the indoor pool or use of wifi.

Excellent hotel that caters primarily to business travelers. Pay a little extra for a room on a high floor with a view - the views are incredible. Close to the train station so you can get around Tokyo easily. Most of the clientele is dressed in business attire so you might need to upscale a bit if you are a vacationer. There are several cafes and restaurants around the hotel so you can explore for breakfast if you don't want the hotel choices every day.

My third or fourth stay at this property in Shibuya and it does consistently well. The value for money is not tremendously good as you pay a premium for this 4 star stay. The real selling features besides prime location are the rooms which are massive for Tokyo and have decent views. The tower is raised in a podium so even the lower rooms have city views. You can usually see mount Fuji from your window if facing the right direction. Service can be hit or miss and there is a certain coldness and aloofness that sometimes arises. The lobby can be a bit of a rush-hour disaster at peak times as well. Otherwise it's an expensive but luxurious little oasis in the capital.

Recommended. This is a high rise hotel where rooms start on the 23rd floor and go up to 39th floor. Rooms are a generous size. Each has a huge picture windows looking out over Tokyo with no tall buildings nearby to obscure the view. A view of Mt. Fuji if you are lucky. Bathrooms are large with the shower seperate to the bath. Has one of those complicated toilets with bidet. Hotel is near Shibuya station and the dense shopping area. Shibuya has the worlds busiest pedestrian crossing. Pricing for food at the hotel is high, you get much better deals in nearby Shibuya which is crowded with restaurants. You even have the pay 300 yen for a tea bag in your room. Go to the nearby Tokyu department store which has a big foodhall including western foods (you can get 50 twinings teabags for 400 yen). There is a 7/11 store in the building for snacks and drinks. Still charging for internet access 1080 yen per day although it is free in Shibuya generally if you are a tourist. Staff are very helpful and the Airport Limuosine Bus stops here. Good metro access to most interest areas in Tokyo.

This Hotel is an amazing place to be when visiting Tokyo. The view is breath taking and the service almost spotless. Yes, I said almost...My flight arrived in Tokyo early morning. Knowing that, I specifically called the Hotel few days prior to my arrival to ask for an early checking. Problem is, my room was not ready when I arrived and I was ask to wait 1 hour and 45 minutes after a 14 hours flight plus trip from the air port (which isn't very near). I was exhausted and could have used a hot shower after over than 24 hours without cleaning myself. But I was kindly advised to to go check the surrounding area...I felt it was quite inappropriate to ask to take a walk after I explained how tired I was.Besides this unfortunate episode, I must confess it was a wonderful stay.

We had a gorgeous view from our hotel room BUT an achingly hard bed, a buckwheat (or similar) pillow, no place to hang a towel (of course they had to be washed every day when there was no towel bar to put them on), no place for a woman's toiletries or makeup (and for that matter no makeup mirror), a grab bar to get out of the tub but not out of the shower, and the restaurant food was way overpriced. I will give a shoutout to the concierge crew. They were very helpful. Perhaps this is really a businessmen's hotel, but that's not how it was presented to us. My husband and I were there on our own for a few days. Regarding the question below -- is this a luxury hotel?, it may think of itself as one, but it's definitely not in our opinion.

This is a nice hotels, location is great and rooms, even though small, are comfortable and well laid out. Where it falls for me , as a non Japanese speaker, the staff is stiff and not many have ability to help in english. They are efficient when they understand but not warm. Probably due to language barrier, but would not recommend unless your functional or want just location.

Whenever we travel, my wife and I like to experience as much of a place as we possibly can and also have the luxury of going back to a quiet retreat at the end of the day. We wanted to experience the grittier side of Tokyo that Shibuya, Shinjuku, Harajuku and it's surrounding environs had to offer, but we knew that staying at a hotel right on top of the "Scramble" just won't do. The Cerulean, despite the mixed reviews, was our best option. It was also a plus that the hotel is a mere 5 minute walk from the Shibuya station which serves as a stop for the Narita Express. The Cerulean is located across an 8 lane road from the Shibuya station. The neighborhood behind the hotel pleased us as it is quiet and affluent. The topography is hilly. Crisscrossed by narrow lanes that encourage a leisurely stroll. Home to the Shibuya Cultural Center, a scattering of cafes and restaurants, low-rise apartment buildings, small homes straight from an architectural magazine and a few old wooden houses, it is a world apart from what images of Shibuya usually convey.The hotel is par for the course in Asia as far as 4 to 5 star hotels go. The modern lobby with its high ceilings, medium-toned wood paneling, immaculate dark tiled floors and floor to ceiling glass walls looking out onto a lush garden is imposing, dignified and elegant all at once. It was meant to be this way as The Cerulean is not a budget hotel. The restaurant beside the lobby has a split-level design to allow diners at the rear to also have a view of the garden. The rooms were huge. Really. And we had an amazing view of the mountains. As is expected in Japan, everything was up to spec. The decor was modern, but the medium tones brought the energy level down a notch. The bed and linens were fantastic. The bathroom was big and clean. For the amount of money we paid for it, we were surprised at how much we got. As it is in a mixed-use development, there is even a Family Mart (24 convenience store) and an Italian restaurant just outside the side entrance.During our stay, we found that the hotel is truly a convenient base from which to experience what we call the "left side" of the Yamanote line (on the JR route map, the Yamanote Line is depicted as a circle). There is, of course, the Shibuya "Scramble" touted as the busiest intersection in the world. It is easy to find as the intersection is right outside the "Hachiko" exit of Shibuya station. Also, if you want to experience eating like a local, head to the food court at the basement of the Shibuya station called the Tokyu Food Show. Your. Jaw. Will. Drop. There are no tables and chairs. Instead, what you get is wall to wall of any kind of Japanese food you can think of. Tempura, sushi, sashimi, sukiyaki, ramen, tonkatsu, yakitori, etc. From Shibuya station, it is just one stop to Harajuku station which is the gateway to five, yes, five points of interest. Yoyogi Park where skaters and the youth of Tokyo hang out. The Meiji Shrine which is a must see. Takeshita Street of Cosplay fame. Omotesando/Aoyama which is touted as the Champs Elysee of Tokyo. And Cat street. (Top Tip: Don't get turned off by the description of Omotesando/Aoyama as the Champs Elysee of Tokyo, otherwise, you'll miss the chance to wander the side streets off of the main drag where hip and cool local labels have located their stores.) Shinjuku, known for its shopping, eating, non-stop nightlife and red light district, is also just a couple of stops from Shibuya.If you want a Shibuya hotel that removes you from all the hustle and bustle at the end of the day, then The Cerulean is the right choice.

Large hotel in a great location in Shibuya. Only a 2min walk from Shibuya station. Bathrooms were great and the beds comfy (though the normal hard Japanese style). Views were great over Tokyo and the mountains. We stayed here for our only night in Tokyo and loved it. Shibuya is great place to walk around at night and take in all the Japanese culture. Very safe also. Recommend for a short stay in Tokyo. Easy access from Narita on the NEX, only the third stop.

Cerulean tower is a large hotel with no atmosphere and slightly unhelpful and unfriendly staff. We found it to be impersonal and cold. The food in the hotel was extremely expensive - $8 cappuccino for example. The foyer was very busy. The hotel does have convenient access to shibuya station

This hotel is generally well equiped and very well located in terms of the airport bus and the metro stations but is not focused on the needs of foreign tourists. I booked this hotel online and got quite a good price for my week long stay. The price didn't include wifi, charged per device, nor breakfast at a rather high 3326 Yen per day.Room quite large but rather compact luggage and hanging space, inadequate for two guests each with large suitcases. Room very overheated and offers complementary tea bags but charges for in room coffee. Reception, concierge and porter Staff not terribly helpful possibly due to their limited English language skills.

Best view and very close to shibuya station and not so far from shopping area. The room is big and very nice city view. The food was very nice. There is shuttle bus to airport but need to pay an additional.

The hotel is located a short walk from Shibuya Station and a great shopping area. The room was clean and modern. Our room had a fabulous view of the city. The staff were extremely helpful and friendly. We needed a late check out and they allowed us to pay for a half day to secure the room until 5pm. That was very helpful. Would stay again!

Baller hotel. High ceilings, dimmed sexy lights, friendly staff making this an experience. This hotel's rooms offer amazing views onto different parts of Tokyo. Super easy to navigate Tokyo and the first place I got to experience the Tokyo toilet. #technology.Hard beds are different to get used to but it's stock standard everywhere you go. Ventilation is a bit funny too. Would be rad if you had a window to let some fresh air run through the rooms (disclaimer - not sure tokyo air is fresh)

The rooms are spacious and well connected within Tokyo for business and holiday trips. Walking distance from Mark City West which has excellent eating joints.The view over 28th floor is breathtaking. From certain sections, you can also view Mount Fuji.

There's something about this hotel that I enjoy. They are extremely helpful but not superficially, the staff genuinely wants to help you and make your stay a comfortable one no request to large or small.The rooms are well sized, especially for Japanese hotels and the bed extremely comfortable.the location of the hotel is excellent as it is just a short walk to Shibuya station and there are SO many things going on in Shibuya it's just perfect to unwind after a day of meetings.One thing however, I love the pens they have on reception and I asked to buy one, alas just not possible :( Perhaps next trip..

Conveniently located in Shubuya Ku, 5 minutes walk to the Subway station. Being member of the giant Tokyu railway group, the hotel runs bus services to and from both the international airports, i.e. Haneda and Narita. Bus fare is Y3100 one way,Ask for room with a Fuji view. If you can't get one, view of the Tokyo Tower is not bad either.

If you want to stay in Shibuya, this is the hotel to be in. The rooms are very nice and clean. The hotel service was great. I do not recommend the Italian restaurant that was in the hotel. Food was very bland. The subway station is minutes walk from the hotel and it connects you everywhere. The JR Rail also connects from that same station. There are a few huge department stores in the neighborhood which we ended up discovering while walking around the hotel. I definitely recommend it and if we were to visit Tokyo again, I would definitely stay there!

My wife and I stayed in this hotel for 4 nights in March this year and I have to say I don't think I have experienced better service almost anywhere I have travelled (although you could say the same about most of Japan, amazing and courteous people everywhere you turn!).Very comfortable rooms, incredible views from the hotel bar, and very conveniently located close to Shibuya station making it easy to get around.As a bonus, I was very pleasantly surprised to open the blind and find Mount Fuji staring back at me on my first morning there.All round great experience - thank you!

Good room, very clean, with a big bathroom, the restaurants are good, and it is very welll placed in shibuya (shopping, restaurants, ...) and nice service.Very nice view of Tokyo.A very nice souvenir from Tokyo.

This hotel is in a very central location and close to transit. The rooms are quite large and comfy, with big windows and huge bathrooms. Decor is pretty standard for this type of hotel - nothing special. The service was great, and the hotel even kept our larger bags in storage while we took an overnight trip to Kyoto. Overall, very accommodating. The breakfast in the lobby restaurant wasn't memorable, and the gym was really small. If I remember correctly, gym use was only free very early in the morning, which is a little strange. A plus is that the airport bus makes a stop here. Definitely not a luxury hotel, but very a comfortable and convenient base while in Tokyo.

We stayed at this hotel on two seperate times on our trip to Japan. On both occasions the rooms were wonderful, modern, with a subtle Japanese wibe. The location is great, close to Shibuya, the subways, JR Rail, and department stores with their incredible basement food stores. We went all over Tokyo and really liked this location. The service at this hotel was some of the best I have ever experienced. Finally the views are wonderful, especially at night-don't miss the bar!! We used the airport limo bus-door to door-no hassles very easy.

This hotel is in an incredible location - just a 5 minute walk to Shibuya station, where you get off if taking Narita Express from airport, and also minutes away from the famous Shibuya crossing as well as stores/shopping/restaurants/nightlife galore! The hotel is beautiful - rooms very contemporary and a nice size, not too small at all. Bathrooms are quite large with bath and shower area. The most incredible part was the view. We were on 34th floor room 3420 that had a beautiful city view during the day and especially at night. Our hotel rate included wifi and breakfast in morning so try to get that since I saw reviews that weren't happy since wifi is extra. The breakfast has either a Japanese buffet or American buffet to choose from. Wide variety for both. Overall an excellent hotel with great service and would definitely come back for the location, high quality of rooms, and the view.

My husband, teenaged daughter, and I spent nine days at the Cerulean Tower Hotel this October. This was our first time there. The hotel is very well located, especially for a teenager. It's a short walk to the Shibuya train station where there are a few department stores and no dearth of cafes and restaurants. Staff at the hotel were lovely and our rooms and bathrooms were clean, bright and cheery. The only reason I wouldn't go back is that we had to pay for wifi (not expensive) and for the use of the fitness centre (an expensive daily rate that pinched when all I wanted was a 40-minute swim). Breakfast wasn't included in the room rate and the hotel breakfast was predictably expensive and just adequate. But the saving grace was the many cafes close to the hotel from Starbuck's Coffee to the home-grown Hoshino Coffee. If you need your cup of black tea with milk in the morning and evening - as we do - carry your own. The rooms come with tea and coffee-making amenities but the hotel only provides Japanese tea and no creamer. There is a 711 in the tower block adjoining the hotel so that was convenient.All in all we had a good stay and were pleasantly surprised given that we knew almost nothing about the Cerulean Tower Hotel and chose it mainly for its location.

I think the true test of a fine hotel is truly earned with multiple stays. I have stayed at this fine hotel many times over the past two years. My company has an office in the same building so my selection goes without saying. Why I’m writing to share my experiences with this hotel is because each time I stay, its gets better and better. The hotel staff, food, service and selection of fine restaurants inside, or near the hotel is overwhelming. A train station is located only two blocks away and is across of a Mall. Each time I return, I’m impressed with room and its state of the art features. The views can’t be beat and the feeling of being welcome and appreciated is always present. You can’t wrong at the Cerulean Tokyu Tower.

As others have noted this is in the heart of Shibuya and thus within walking distance of restaurants, shops and the metro. That said, it is very quiet. Comfortable good quality rooms maintained to an excellent standard. Best way to get to hotel from Narita airport is to take the Airport Limousine bus straight to the door (non-stop). Cost is 3100 yen pp (around US$30) each way. Travel time in was 90 minutes but leaving on a quieter afternoon took less. Buses run once every hour (but not on the hour) so it is a matter of luck if one is available when you exit customs.

I was staying for work -- an excellent hotel overall. Expensive, but with great facilities, service, breakfast and staff. Location is in the heart of the Shibuya and really great. The only downside is that there is no tea and coffee in the rooms (the only ones are in the minibar for sale). It would have been nice to have that. Much recommended!

Stayed here one night before flying back to the States. Located near the Shibuya Subway/Train station with Narita Express. Getting to/from hotel and subway can be a pain with luggage and the busiest intersection in the world, but look for the walkways with elevators, it isn't that bad. Solid luxury hotel, with great rooms and views. Shibuya offers a lot, plenty to do right around the hotel. Would stay here again and recommend it to others.

A well appointed hotel with great links to eateries and shopping areas. The hotel is few minutes walk to Shibuya stations, which provides good connections across the Japanese railway network.The staff were extremely courteous and helpful. The breakfast was a bit overpriced, but hey you are staying In a high end hotel. Come on Cerulean listen to your customers and provide free wifi and then you would remove most of the TA negative remarks ...

I stayed four nights at the Cerulean while traveling on business. The location is super convenient and right at Shibuya station, which made it extremely easy to get around. There are lots of excellent restaurant and shopping choices in the immediate vicinity too, from little dive-y katsudon and ramen joints to much higher-end restaurants. The hotel was good. My room was larger than I expected, and the view was excellent -- I even caught a glimpse of Mt. Fuji on one evening. All in all, this is an excellent hotel. The only complaint I have is that the breakfast buffet was expensive at 3,500 yen and not all that great. It was pretty basic, and the selection was quite limited. I've seen much, much better breakfasts at other hotels of this class.

Service was only average because it was a very busy hotel and reception area. It was mainly geared towards business travelers, so don't expect too much personalised service. Great location, short walk to train station. Brilliant views of Shibuya.

This hotel is very modern in the heart of Shibuya, a few 100 meters from the JR Line. We decided to upgrade form a normal room to the club room. Love the club great breakfast, and cocktail time free moet and french red and white wine some sprits and beer. The room modern clean and not bad size with a view of mt. Fuji. from ours. Staff all very polite and helpful. Spoke very good English.Can't wait to go back.

This hotel promised the world and delivered one of our worst hotel experiences. We expected Tokyo accommodation to be expensive, so the kids and I spent first night in a hostel (also reviewed) and when my husband joined us we moved for 3 nights to this hotel. It deserves it's 4-5 stars for location, cleanliness and buffet breakfast but the service was 1 star. After communicating via email before we arrived, asking if possible for inter-connecting rooms as we were travelling with 3 kids, I was told we could have adjacent but not inter-connecting which was great. At check-in I was given rooms on a smoking floor - no mention of this at check-in and we phoned from the room to ask for a non-smoking floor as the kids had runny noses and itchy eyes within minutes of arrival. Couldn't help via phone so we went down to lobby. I was told they couldn't accommodate me. They could, it just took some time and patience. When my husband arrived later that night he was told he couldn't have a 2nd room key as all had been provided. One key per room. When I called to ask for a second as my kids locked themselves out they said they would charge the room $5 for a second key. And $5 again for my husband. On the second day we left the hotel at 7am and returned mid afternoon to uncleaned rooms. I called front desk and was told that housekeeping is done in the afternoon and I should have notified front desk if I wanted the room cleaned in the morning. They asked us to leave the room for an hour for each room - and no, we couldn't use the pool downstairs as the kids were under 18 and the pool is not just for hotel guests but Club Members. I just found everything about the service provided at this hotel was unpleasant. I don't mind paying $1800 for great accommodation and service but when the experience makes you feel like you are an inconvenience I think it's better to spend the money elsewhere. I would have felt less inclined to write a review if at check-out they had just asked one question: if we enjoyed our stay.

Wow, this hotel is very wow! Where to begin? When you arrive at the hotel, you are greeted by a super friendly porter who is as excited to see you as you are of touching down in Tokyo. The reception staff is very professional and oh so welcoming. The room is quite large and the bathroom....amazeballs! I love that the shower and tub are together. The toilet is a comfort like no other, trust me, just leave the seat heater on and your bottom will be happily surprised. The room is very clean, as is the whole hotel. There is a water kettle in the room that the hotel fills up for you, no need to buy your own water. I have stayed here twice and both times had the view of Shibuya, spectacular!. If you can, try to sneak up to the top floor where you have panoramic views of Tokyo, and on a clear day, you can see Fuji mountain. This hotel is top notch, would highly recommend!

We stayed in a king room which was very large by Japanese standards. The bathroom was modern and spacious. Service was also fantastic. The location is a stone throw away from Shibuya crossing, so after a long day of shopping and exploring the frantic energy that Shibuya exudes, it is only a short walk home! Would definitely stay again.

We stayed at the Cerulean Tower Tokyo for 4 Nights (Sept 6 2014 to Sept 10 2014).Ease of Access to Hotel:Arriving at Narita Airport, the hotel is probably one of the easiest to get to. This was our first time in Tokyo and only did minimal research into getting to the hotel. The hotel staff also provided emails on which routes to take. The easiest including cost efficiency was using the Airport Limousine (Bus) to get to the hotel. Is it the orange and white bus. When you leave baggage claim and exit the doors, just look for the "Airport Limousine" bus kiosk desk. Tell them the hotel name and the bus drops you off directly under the hotel checkout desk. They even store your baggage under the bus for making it easy. The bus is clean and very comfortable. Seems very new as well. We were worried about traffic and transit time, and landed around 7:00PM, then took the 7:30-8:00PM bus with no issues. We arrived at the hotel in about 90 minutes. Check-in & Check-Out:The staff speaks great english with both check in and checkout services an easeConcierge:Very friendly and helpful. They even offer free umbrellas if it is rainingHotel Lobby and Hallways:The hotel lobby is excellent, what you would expect from a high class hotel.The hallways from the elevator to the rooms, a little worn in and small but non-issue odor. The main reason for this, in my opinion, is the lack of central air and making the air feel fresh and clean. But this is not an issue at all. Room:We stayed in a queen sized bed single room with a great view of the city on the 32nd floor. Room was very clean as well the bathroom. TV provided a few international channels as well local channels. Read the book in the room on how to show international channels. All amenities, provided in room, shower gel, shampoo, toothbrush, combs, the usual. Beds a little hard, and pillows can be a little better for the price of the hotel, but all in all good. Housekeeping came everyday while we were out and cleaned the room as well new towels and restocked the shampoos and bath supplies. There is also a mini-bar, but way overpriced. Just go around the corner on floor 2 to the 7-Elven and stock up. Staff:As stated above the staff of the hotel was great, providing an iron board and other things as needed. Very professional and courteous. Location:Great! Shibuya is a bustling area with lots to see. The hotel is within 5 minutes walk from Shibuya station which will get you wherever you need to go. The Minor Issue that kept it from getting a 5 star rating:Stay away from the Bar on the 42nd floor unless for the view (if they let you just watch it) and the restaurants downstairs. While the staff is great, they have rules they follow that are not welcoming. The Bar on the 42nd floor provides a great view, but you must purchase a drink to even walk around up there. (And it was not even busy) The drinks are way over priced as well. The restaurants downstairs have the friendliest staff, but we purchased a coffee and breakfast tart that was $10 to go, then realized the coffee cup lid was not secure so asked to sit down and eat our breakfast there, but they told us NO! The chairs are for dine in guest. I can understand if they were busy, but there wasn't a single person in the restaurant. We found this just rude and very ignorant on their part. The hotel really needs to review their rules and how they treat customers.

Elegant and classic hotel just a short walk to Shibuya's shopping, restaurant area, and JR train station. Superb views of Tokyo (we stayed on the 33rd floor), classic luxury rooms and excellent service make this a top pick for Tokyo accommodation.

This hotel was great to stay in. The location was perfect to public transportation as well as several restaurants. The staff was very friendly and the rooms were beautiful. We even had amazing views of the city!

We stayed a week in Tokyo at this hotel. As per general consensus, the location of the hotel is great—less than 5 minutes' walk from Shibuya station (via elevated walkways suspended above traffic). There's a 7-Eleven on the second floor of the hotel with an ATM, and a dozen convenience stores in the area besides. The hotel itself is nice. A very standard 4-star hotel; there's nothing outstanding on that part, but the staff at the hotel was the epitome of politeness. The front desk was friendly when checking us in, and they were efficient in getting our luggage to our room. We stayed in a corner twin, which had a fantastic view of Tokyo from the 30-something floor. The room was very spacious by any standard, the beds were comfortable, and all basic amenities were provided. Wifi at this hotel isn't free so we had to pay for that, but they do offer a nice deal for a week's worth of wifi. It's also pretty easy to get here from the airport, at least via limousine bus, since they'll do drop-offs right at the hotel front entrace.

This was our last hotel on a stay around Japan and without a doubt the most disappointing. I had high expectations because the concierge desk was SO extremely helpful prior to our trip, helping to make plans and securing baseball tickets. Immediately upon check in, I realized that level of service was not standard apparently. The fellow that checked us in was rather standoffish, not very informative and actually needed me to prompt him for basic questions (such as, do you need my passport...which he did. And then forgot to give back). Things he didn't tell us: what's up with the wifi? Don't I get breakfast? Anything at all we should know? So, not having wifi passwords and breakfast coupons, I went back down to the desk to ask about these things and spoke to another girl who proceeded to tell me these things were not included because we were upgraded, so the upgrade was our benefit. Now, not only did that not make sense, it wasn't even correct. After five minutes she finally looks at the computer and says "oh, you are right" and then tries to say that what we don't get is access to the executive lounge. Whatever. Here is the problem at this place. They live off their location and don't seem to do much over and above that. We stayed at Marriotts, Sheraton's and little hotels during our stay and each time felt like the most important people who ever lived. Here, I felt looked down on as if I didn't belong there. There's no question this is a nice hotel. But between what I've written, the lingering odor of smoke in the drapes and what I can only describe as the worst club sandwich in the world from the restaurant, I wouldn't suggest this hotel to anyone I knew.

Booked here at the last minute wanting something near to Shibuya Station and Hikarie.Price was good for the quality of the room (especially for a same-day / last minute booking). There were some other options further away from Shibuya Station (e.g. APA hotel) at about half the price. But Cerulean was at least double the room size, and quite a bit nearer to where I needed to be.Room was spotlessly clean and everything worked as expected. Only mildly annoying thing was no power points easy accessible beside the bed, where I like to keep my phone. Wifi was available but only as a paid option, so I didn't use it.Reception staff were friendly. Couldn't have asked for more, and this was a great "upper middle" option at this price.Bar at the 30th (?) floor was stylish and has a good night view. Also attended a function here in the ballroom that was good.While this hotel looks (and is) very close to Shibyua Station, there are some elevated walkways to navigate and get over the busy roads in this area. That was slightly confusing, even using Google Maps to help figure out where I was going. Also the stairs up and down the walkways could be a challenge to navigate if you have heavy luggage.

The Cerulean at first glance is a wonderful hotel, reception area is beautiful and it looks to be a 4.5 Star hotel. However once you get to the room itself, it is a mediocre style Business Mans hotel room. The bed in the room was atrocious. It was hard and you could feel the springs on your back. I slept on the duvet cover to help solve the problem for the night. When I called down to the front desk in the morning to help explain the discomfort, the associate at the end of the line was laughing with the other associate. Clearly, they did not care to help the situation - or did not understand. They were smug.

This was a really great hotel. Easily one of the best around, but very expensive. For the price, it felt sometimes like you weren't really getting everything that you paid for. For example, we got a little ticket to go to the pool/gym for free, and were told that there's 1 hour per day when the gym is free. Otherwise, it's a fairly large charge. It's definitely the first hotel I've been in which charged an extra fee to use the pool. Again, it was a nice room and a nice experience.
