Great location, close to the train station and the "night market". Just a bit expensive, and kinda feels like you don't really get what you pay for.

Arrived after a very tiring flight and train journey into Tokyo. Staff couldn't have been more helpful. Because we needed to sleep, we were allowed to check in early and were even given an upgraded room. The view out of the window took our breath away - the skyscrapers of Shinjuku, Yoyogi Park and the hustle and bustle of Shibuya down below. Clean, spacious, modern. The bar on the top floor served best chilled sake I've ever tasted. Thoroughly recommended.

Cerulean would be one of the better hotels in Shibuya area. It is located a few minute walk away from Shibuya station. I stayed there twice for 3 nights each, beds are quite comfortable and clean room. Most of the rooms in Japan hotels are pretty small but the rooms in Cerulean are just spacious. The view is amazing oveelooking Shibuya. Some of the room could have a view of Mount Fiji when the weather is good. The charges for wifi is quite expensive and frontdesk staff are not too friendly at check in with no smile on their face and feels that guests are not well respected by them. On the other hand the bell staff were very helpful and polite, greeting every single customers and assisted on every request.

Stayed at Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel twice. Loved it both time. Excellent location, super convenient (right on top of JR station). Big rooms for Tokyo standard. Get the rooms you can look at the city views if you stay here! Would definitely book here again for my next trip to Tokyo.

This hotel was lovely and very close to Shibuya station. Our room was spacious and I would advise anyone booking any accommodation in Japan to ask for a twin room as they are always bigger. We were on 22nd floor with a huge window and an amazing view. Our only letdown with this hotel that they charge for Wi-Fi . We were away for three weeks and stayed in 8 different hotels and everyone offered free Wi-Fi. We were also surprised at the end of our stay when we were charged a Tokyo prefecture tax. Was only 600yen but we weren't charged when we stayed in Ginza.

We are not usually fans of large business hotels but our 5 night stay was a dream mainly thanks to the incredible service and concierge. Perfect guidance, support, welcome and restaurant booking - even preempting our own needs!Our room on 23 rd was large and well appointed. Great bedsing and quiet! Breakfast is fresh and extensive. Delicious. And the bar upstairs is stunning.

This hotel has an ideal location - Shibuya, which is great for exploring Tokyo. Overall good hotel, cleaning service would be the only thing I would complain about because they were lazy, but as far as I know hotels in Tokyo, this one is a better one with great value for money. Even the rooms were not too small, bathroom is nice, beatiful view from the room, quality bathroom amenities, friendly staff... Definitely worth of coming back.

This is the best hotel I’ve stayed in Tokyo (best of four comparable hotels). I was met with professional, pleasant and welcoming service. The lobby is beautiful; plenty of seating and accessible wi-fi. The room was very clean and the decor is “simple and modern” – as the cerulean promotes. I actually think the room is nicer in person than in the professional photos. I had a problem getting my iphone on to the room wi-fi, but I notified the front desk and they promptly send someone up to assist me. It took about 15 minutes to get my phone connected, but tech support succeeded. I thought that was great customer service! I did not use many of the hotel amenities, but I would definitely stay here again to try them. If fact, I think I’ll book my room at the Cerulean Tower for the 2020 Olympics right now!

This was our first time to Tokyo. The hotel is very large. It has several restaurants. It is in a neighborhood that is bustling. It would be a great place with teens. A great neighborhood for young people. The people at the front desk were very accommodating. We had a corner room with great views. The air conditioning worked great. The room was very quiet. There was a jazz bar, but very expensive cover charge. 50$ per person. We did not go. I would recommend to take the airport shuttle. It is worth the money. The cleanliness of the hotel and the cleanliness of our room was amazing. A very generous amount of toiletries. They even had a sign offering complimentary make-up for women. They do not offer complimentary coffee or tea in the room. There is a delicious little curry place a few doors down. Go there. We only ate one time in the coffee shop at hotel. We did not like the food there. So we did not eat at the hotel again. One time burned. Pool and health club and wifi extra.

Started my holiday here with my girlfriend (who is Japanese) - the receptionist (Shimada) made a sarcastic remark about us staying 2 nights but paying for 3 (as we wanted early check in). Then when we stated we wanted to pay cash, he repeatedly stated that "it's a lot of money are you sure you can pay cash?" I have never experienced such rude staff in Japan. (my 4th time in the country and 8th hotel). We also asked for a room with view of Tokyo Tower, considering that we were paying a whole night extra for early check in - and this was denied.When I raised this with management they handled it poorly, and instead of speaking to the manager as I requested - the receptionist Shimada made a half-baked apology stating that it was my misunderstanding (although it was all spoken in Japanese).I cannot stress enough that this was the worst service I have ever encountered in Japan and one of the very worst hotel experiences I have had. I was meant to stay there again in August and instead chose to stay at Tokyo Hilton - which provided a wonderful experience.

Our first stay, a few years back, had been a very pleasant surprise, so we had high expectations, which were largely met. Very good value for a room on a high-rise floor with stunning views of the city. The hotel is located in the heart of Shibuya, which provides plenty of opportunities for restaurants and entertainment. The room was reasonably sized, not just by Tokyo standards, with a well-equipped bathroom. The room rate included breakfast with several options available including Japanese breakfast. The latter was not just a buffet but a luxury style bento with table service. The hotel has a top-floor bar, which also serves light bites, really worth a visit for its views of the skyline; but beware the prices there. We were offered free gym access at check-in, which includes the swimming pool: this was a real plus for our stay and the gym is a proper one with a good choice of weight machines. Check-in and check-out were both efficient and accurate in their dealing with prepayment and incidentals.

We took the Limousine Bus from the airport to the hotel, which was approx. a 1hr 20 min trip. We arrived at around 10.30am and as we walked into the vast, beautiful marble lobby, someone came over straight away to help us with our luggage. Check in was not until 2pm and my husband, who had been to Japan a few times before and stayed at other hotels, had said that he was not able to check in any earlier. I must admit, I wasn't looking forward to having 3.5 hours to kill, as after flying for 7 hours from Adelaide to Singapore, having a 5 hour stopover and then flying another 7 hours from Singapore to Tokyo, all I wanted to do was have a shower and a power nap!! To our surprise, we were told that the room attendant was just finishing off their final checks and that we'd be taken to our room, WHICH WAS ON THE 30TH FLOOR, in 10 minutes (YAY!!) and were taken over to a comfortable seating area to wait. About 5 minutes went past and another attendant arrived, loaded our luggage on to a trolley and asked us to follow her to the lifts. We walked out into a carpeted corridor with subtle lighting and soft music playing in the background. We stopped outside room 3013 and when we opened the door - WOW!! - you certainly knew that you were staying in a 5 star hotel!! The room's décor was light ash wood and neutral, earthy tones, with a luggage closet/walk in robe on the right as you walk in, a light ash wooden cabinet that housed the fridge, tea/coffee, kettle etc and the TV. Facing that, were 2 large, comfortable twin beds with a bedside cabinet with a safe between them and a large light ash wooden headboard behind them, a comfy lounge chair with matching footrest and a small round table, an oval writing desk in front of a huge picture window and a granite topped oblong table with a desk lamp, telephone and sockets to charge up your laptop, telephone etc. The bathroom has granite floor and wall tiles, a huge light ash wood vanity with a black granite top and plenty of storage. A bath that runs along the length of one wall in front of a huge picture window, a huge shower big enough for 2 and a toilet which is partially enclosed from the bathroom. The views were spectacular!! All of Tokyo was spread out before you. The living area had views of the Tokyo Tower and the Tokyo Sky Tree, whilst the bathroom had views of the world famous "Scramble Crossing" and Shinjuku. At night, the twinkling lights from all the buildings were amazing!!The staff were extremely courteous and friendly and nothing was too much trouble. Each time you walked past them, they smiled, bowed and said hello.Breakfast is served in the Garden Restaurant and there are a number of options to choose from, We had the "Western Buffet" which was an all you can eat affair. The service and the food was exceptional, but at around AUD$70 for both of us, we thought that was rather expensive.The hotel itself is about a 5 minute walk from Shibuya's shopping area, restaurants, coffee shops, the world famous "Scramble Crossing", train and bus stations and the famous statue of "Hatchiko", as well as the busiest Starbucks in the world, where, if you time it right, you can have a front row seat overlooking the "Scramble Crossing". We had breakfast there every day for around AUD$25 for both of us.We thoroughly enjoyed our stay at The Cerulean and would definitely stay here again

This hotel combines everything, bus from Narita Airport, beautiful entrance with a great coffee shop and sitting area, great views of Tokyo, 5 minutes walk to Shibuya metro station.Just behind, you have a few lovely streets with restaurants (both classy and fast food) and if in Sakura season one of the most amazing blooms.As everywhere else in Japan, extreme politeness and dedication of the staff

Chose the hotel based on being served by Narita Limo Bus. I wanted to avoid dealing with large suitcases on trains. Our room was comparable to a nice hotel in the US and was modern and clean. We had a fantastic view of Tokyo looking south. Service was very good with enough of the staff that spoke English. Hotel is is a short walk, less than 5 minutes, from the start of the restaurants and shops of "downtown" Shibuya. Less than 10 minute walk to the Shibuya station. This is a good location for experiencing Shibuya and the surrounding area. We were only at this hotel for a couple of nights concentrating our sightseeing to the Shibuya/Yoyogi/Harjuku areas. With the temperatures in the 90sF it was draining to be walking for around for more than a few hours. With the convenient location we were able to go back to the hotel once or twice during the day.I would agree with another reviewer that the breakfast buffet was very nice but a bit pricey. But there is a 7-11 in the same building for a convenient cup of coffee and snacks. Our next stop was Kyoto and the hotel staff took care of forwarding our luggage to our hotel in Kyoto. We were visiting our son who lives in Tokyo and for traveling throughout Tokyo he thinks the Shinjuku station is a better starting point.

We stayed on the 26th floor and requested a bathroom with a view. Not only did the bathroom have a view but the main room did too. Very Cool, could see lots of Tokyo. The room was spacious by Japanese standards, the bathroom was very nice. We got a morning paper everyday which was fun to read. The only negative was the restaurant was way overpriced.

The room is on the smaller side, however, very clean with amazing views of Tokyo. The subway station is a short walk. Great service by staff. Good breakfast, however a bit overpriced. If looking for breakfast options, ask hotel for the name of the French Bakery with seating within 5 min walk.

Despite some of the previous reviews, the service t the Cerulean Tower Tokyo Hotel was impeccable. In fact they could not do enough to help. Many of the staff we had dealings with throughout the hotel spoke excellent English and were keen to make sure our stay was as enjoyable as they could make it.We had our luggage transferred from Kyoto and, like the previous reviewer said, it was waiting in our room for us. We had views of the lights of Shibuya crossing and the room was spacious with an amazing bath beside the window. It's ideally located being only a 5 minute walk from Shibuya JR station and would suggest that you head for the South Exit when you arrive as it's the quickest way to get to the Hotel. The bar/restaurants on the 40th floor has amazing views but I you are only having a drink the sit at the bar as there's a surcharge for the tables unless you are eating. A great Tokyo hotel with an amazing location and staff!

Fantastic hotel, the rooms are amazing as are the views. Everything was upto scratch, food and service first class. Staff are very helpful and welcoming. Hope to return one day. Interesting swimming pool.

Our stay at the cerulean was excellent from start to finish. We used the luggage service so sent our bags in advance from Okayama and our bags were already waiting for us in the room. The room was spacious and the views were amazing - we were lucky enough to see Mt Fuji from our room one day! Sunset time was really nice from the room too. The best things about this hotel is the location - so close to Shibuya and good transport links; the views from the room and also the concierge service was incredible. They take care of everything for you from sightseeing in the day to restaurants. We booked a couple of restaurants and they provide you with a leaflet of the location, map and details of the restaurant. I would highly recommend this hotel. Truth is its not a cheap hotel but the feeling we got from our stay was that it was money well spent overall.

The location and the rooms were absolutely fantastic. We took a limousine bus from Narita airport that stopped at the actual hotel, which made it even more convenient. The rooms are spacious and modern. We had a fantastic view of the city and the room had lots of natural light. The breakfast was not included, but it was a better deal to pay for the full buffet than to just buy a pastry and a coffee or fresh juice (it cost almost the same as the buffet to do that). The breakfast buffet was expensive, but you certainly get your money’s worth. There’s also a Seven Eleven attached to the hotel where you can buy yogurt, juice, and snacks (Seven Elevens in Tokyo are actually kind of cool). And there are a few places to get breakfast within walking distance from the hotel. The location cannot be beat. We will definitely stay here again.

Yes the rooms are larger, therefore pricier, and yes its modern/clean.But I write today about customers service.Situation:We stayed here 2 nights. Last day of stay, my wife went out to get breakfast with our 1 year-old in tow and dropped/lost her wallet on the way back to the hotel. She didn't notice for 2 hours until the rest of us were awake.Neither of us speaks fluent enough Japanese, so we contacted the hotel staff hoping for help contacting the police and assisting with translating the situation. We explained our situation and the fact that we do not speak japanese when asking for help. Result? Instead of offering to call the police to file a report, the staff gave us the location of the nearest police station and told us to go there ourselves. Also, the hotel would not assist in anyway after we had checked out, meaning if the police had recovered the wallet and contacted the hotel, the hotel would not have the courtesy to notify us through email or otherwise, and would not help recover it.…Wow…we paid $400 a night for this place and this is the customer service you get when you need help?Also they charge per day and device for wifi.Definitely NOT staying here again, i can get this kind of service and attitude for much less elsewhere.

And it boils down to location, yet again. It's great. Right in the middle of things, and a short walk to Shibuya train station. The hotel in itself is nothing special. It's huge, the kind of impersonal four star you'll find anywhere. But the views are great, especially from the skybar. You have to pay extra for almost everything, from breakfast to wifi. Rooms are fairly large for Tokyo. A 7-11 in the same building, for those late night necessities. About 30 minutes to Haneda with no traffic. There's a direct bus. Worth staying? I'm sure you can do a lot nicer with a little more research.

Would I stay there again? NOGood location, nice view but airless rooms, you cannot open a window.Breakfast not included, you pay strictly for the room only.Daily extra charges $10.00 if you want to use the wi-fi, $20.00 for the hotel swimming pool and the gym, disappointing.

I stayed here for 1 night on my first visit to Japan, I was disappointed to find out when I arrived at 10:30am that I would not be able to check in until 15:00, this was the last thing I wanted to hear after 18hrs of travelling, they did however let me have a shower and store my bags in the luggage room until check in was allowed!Breakfast wasn't included even although the room worked out at over £240 per night, an even bigger shock was that you have to pay to use the gym even although you are staying in the hotel.Overall the hotel was very clean and it is in the main district for shopping, parks etc, loads of places to eat and drink around the hotel and only a 2min walk from Shibuya station.

We had a long journey flying to Tokyo, airline lost our baggage and we were pretty tired upon arrival at the Cerulean Tower. Getting to Cerulean from Narita was a breeze using the Airport Limousine Bus, https://www.limousinebus.co.jp/en/Since we were delayed there was no bus directly to Cerulean before another hour, but the attendant kindly suggested that we go Westin hotel on one of their other routes, take a taxi to Cerulean, and that worked out just fine, 1500 Yen for the taxi.Reception at the hotel was a bit underwhelming, which almost made me award 4 stars. Got the feeling the person receiving us wasn't too happy with out travelling attire. Anyway that's about the only complaint I have. The hotel is gorgeous, location is unbelievable and the views from both standard rooms and tower rooms (we have tried both) are stunning. In my view you are not missing much if you go for a standard room, but the gym is half price, wifi is free and you can eat complementary breakfast at the executive salon, there is a dvd player and some better bathroom amenieties if you go for towers room or better. Breakfast is rather expensive and will cost about 3500 Yen per person, but quality is very good, Execute salon breakfast is adequate but cannot compare, but is complementary as far as I can make out.Rooms are good size for two persons, nice bathroom, nice beds, stunning view, quiet.Good restaurants in the hotel, a bit on the expensive side as expected. We haven't sampled all of them, I thought the Italian style was average, but the Chinese restaurant was very good. We didn't try the Japanese restaurant, hey we're in Tokyo, eating Japanese in the hotel seemed heineous.We are close to Shibuya station, but far enough (and high enough) that little noise is heard. Location is one of the things that we are most pleased with,Finally I will mention the incredible service we've got on the service desk. They've assisted us on travelling suggestions, navigating the subway to peripheral parts of Tokyo, writing down notes for us and assisting with most everything. Best information service ever.We haven't checked out yet, so I hope nothing untoward happens in our final part of our stay (we are staying for 10 nights). Should that happen I will update the review.

We stayed one night at the Cerulean on our first night in Japan and was very impressed with the location and room size.There was 3 of us sharing a room and we had plenty of space and the bathroom was very modern and a good size. We were on the 21st floor and the views of Tokyo were fantastic.Shibuya crossing was a 5 minute walk from the hotel and there are plenty of places to eat nearby.We had breakfast at Caramelo in the hotel and the food was good and plentiful, but we did have to wait a while in getting a cup of hot tea with milk! The staff were polite but they weren't overly friendlly and we assumed that was just how Japanese people were until we visited other places and were warmly welcomed.Also, there was no free wi-fi at the hotel.

Great hotel that is central to the JR station and close to Shibuya crossing. Plenty of places to eat at and stop and watch the people drift by. Comfortable and clean beds. The only downside was it was very windy some nights and the walls made cracking sounds, which was annoying. But apart from that it was great!

Found the room in this hotel to be large enough for 3 persons. It was important because of experience with tiny rooms in Japanese hotels. The twin beds are double beds and can accomodate one adult and a child easily. The bathroom is also huge by Japanese standards. The hotel is conveniently located near Shibuya station, about 10 min walk over the pedestrian bridge. Shibuya station is next to Tokyu Department store. Foreign passport holders can get password from the Shibuya station information counter for free wifi access in surrounding area, which extends to Tokyu department store. Because the hotel charges for internet access, naturally, we resorted to the free wifi at the station. I have also noticed that the department stores offer free wifi but you have to show your passport to prove you are a foreigner.We arrived earlier in the morning and did not expect to have a room. However, the reception staff was kind enough to have found an available room and we managed to check in in less than half an hour.One tip for passengers arriving in Haneda Airport, is to buy the Subway and metro pass from the airport, if there is plan to be in Tokyo for at least 3 days and planning to travel alot. This is different from the JR pass we realised but in the end, the costs might equal what you would spend on the subway but save on the hassle of having to buy a ticket each way. I believe it costs yen 2500 for 2 adults and 1 child. An average subway ticket might be at least Yen 250 one way and alot more depending on the distance. This ticket does not entitle one to take the JR but we didnt see that as an issue as the the lines appear to be run alongside anyway but the JR tickets costs more.The bus ride from Haneda to Cerulean is about 30 mins and costs Yen1300 one way.

We stayed 4 nights at the Cerulean Tower, and while its a beautiful hotel, I'm sitting between a 3-3.5 rating.The goods:- Location is fantastic, 5 min walk from Shibuya station, Shibuya crossing and all the excitement that goes with it. Perfect station to hub from. Also a ton of shopping, restaurants, bars in the area. While it would be considered a younger area - lots of teenagers with the types of stores you would expect (Forever 21) but definitely a fun area to check out.- Room was huge and had a very nice view. I'm told we were upgraded which was a nice touch, however, after trying to book another night and hearing the actual cost of the room - certainly not worth it in my opinion. - Staff was friendly, albeit impersonal. Nothing was bad per se, but was I wasn't as impressed with was:- Personality - the hotel had zero personality, sorry to say. We basically came and left. Really no place to sit down in the lobby except for the restaurant/bar areas.- No free wifi, pretty much tablestakes in my opinion. However, I've found the more expensive the hotel gets, you pay for wifi. The less expensive the hotel is, you get free wifi. Not sure I get this? Good thing we had a mobile wiFi device which I highly highly highly recommend in general around Tokyo as wifi is hard to come by and things are not the easiest to find if you don't read or speak japanese. Cost is nominal - less than $10 US per day or so and you can rent at the airport (or in advance and its even cheaper if you're more organized than I am!)- Expensive breakfast, didn't partake - however, good patisseries (Viron), coffee shops (Fuglen, Streamer Coffee) - within 10 min walk If you like and need a large breakfast (western style) it will not be cheap. However, again, pancakes are all the rage in Tokyo right now and there are 5+ places within a 10-15 min walk with delicious breakfasts (Bills, Eggs & Things, Sunday Jam Harajuku, Cafe Kaila). Only downside is most have huge lines daily.- We tried to stay another night but ended up changing hotels. We were more than willing to move to a less expensive room given the upgrade, however, given that room was going to be significantly more per night than what we originally paid, we decided to move on.Overall, great location - however, for the price which doesn't include wifi or breakfast I'm not sure we would stay again.

This hotel is centrally located near Shibuya Crossing and subway. Great restaurants nearby. Get a corner room or twin for maximum space. We saw Mt. Fuji from our rooms. Love the bath tub with view of the city, and the toto toilet with warm seat and bidet is on my to buy list whenever we get to renovating our house. The 7/11 downstairs saved us a bundle on snacks and breakfast items. Also has an ATM. And, don't miss the lounge for coffee and the most fabulous desserts this side of Paris! The Mont Blanc was easily better than the one originated at Angelina Maison, and at half the price!

Cerulean Tower is a beautiful, clean hotel with a friendly and helpful staff located in the heart of Shibyua station. However, it is an expensive stay. This is not to say that the hotel itself is not worth the cost of a night, it well may be, but there was ultimately no reason to spend so much on a room. If ritzy is what you are looking for then Cerulean is a good place to go; otherwise, stay elsewhere. There are other perfectly good hotels in Tokyo that are cheaper. Also, because the hotel is a high end one, the food (and especially drinks) are way overpriced. $12 for coffee? $33 for breakfast? It just didn't seem worth it.

This was my first visit to Tokyo and as the we would be celebrating our 25th wedding anniversary whilst we were here we wanted somewhere nice. The cerulean did not disappoint! Perfectly located in Shibuya within a 5 min walk to the station and the famed shibuya crossing. The room was a lovely size, with a comfortable bed and fab shower. I think that the highlight of our stay will be for both of us our anniversary meal which we chose to celebrate in the Tower Restaurant. On booking the table my husband let slip that it would be a celebratory meal and why. Well the staff were superb the meal was delicious. Thank you Cerulean for a great five day break. The only criticism I would have was that although the hotel provide tea and coffee making facilities in the room, this has to be the only hotel I have ever stayed in that charges for them. Thanks again Cerulean for a great stay.
cozy and delicious rm service,,,, - no pizza but can be enjoying yammy beef pates et healthy vegi pickles,,,w all the beverages,,.. :))

This was not only my first visit to Tokyo but first to Japan.When I first went online to find a hotel I was completely lost on where to stay, what area to stay and what exactly I wanted to see. I did have some help from my girlfriend who is from Japan. Anyway we chose this hotel for the area it was in. And it's location is prefect for shops food and most importantly the underground. Tokyo is huge with many different districts.Hotel staff were friendly, room always very clean and comfortable and bed was good. Great window for observing this huge city.We did not eat in the hotel as there was so much to offer in the surrounding area. When we arrived the top floor bar was full so we had to leave the hotel for my fist beer in Japan. The nice man at the bar entrance pointed out a wee bar on the streets below which we swiftly made a b line for.Just as we ordered drinks the phone rang in the bar, it was the nice man from the hotel bar asking of we made it safely. I thought this was a nice touch. This was however the only personable thing I can say about the hotel which was ok as we did not really have to engage with the staff anyway. The hotel was in the best location for our needs and was very comfortable. We would stay again if we returned to that area.

I stayed at the Cerulean for four days in May. It met my hotel snobbery expectations. I had a great view of Mount Fuji (wasn't visible the last day due to clouds), which was a great surprise! The hotel was clean and the room was big. Like most things in Japan, the service was impeccable. It was only a couple of sky walks away from the station, and fairly easy to get to, even with my over packed bags. (This seems to be a good option for people to stay at who don't want to completely blow their travel budgets on hotels. I've noticed everyone from Aziz Ansari & David Chang to Fashion Toast & Anna Dello Russo have stayed here.)

I have chosen this hotel as ANA's "fly & stay" deal.The room was big enough and comfortable and excellent view.The highlight of this stay was their staff. When i checked in I have asked the female staff who escorted me to my room about the good local restaurant as I needed to entertain my colleagues from Australia. Apparently, she immediately went back to concierge to checked it out and came back less than ten minutes with several recommendation, and offered me to arrange the reservation for us, which turned out be a huge success.Apart from that, all staff were very polite and friendly, and very keen to help me with even a small things.I definitely stay this hotel again for my next visit to Tokyo.

You will love the 180 degrees views on Tokyo from virtually every room. Every room is also above Toyko's standards in terms of size. Now, all this comes at a price. Beyond the good room and view, you will have to pay for almost everything: breakfast, internet... and also gym. It left me with a bitter taste as I had to open my wallet for almost everything I do in my normal life. I do not find this very interesting from a guest-perception point of view. The (paid) breakfast at the lobby level is wonderful. Attention to details.I had also an excellent solo dinner at the rooftop lounge. Extremely expensive (70$ for a daily fish recommendation + dessert) and portions were very small. I would recommend to eat somewhere else. There is huge choice just right next to the hotel.Overall recommended, for the room size and, especially, for the view. From 5 to 4 start because of the pay-per-everything model.

We have spent 2 nights in the hotel and really can't fault it at all. Room was excelebt size and views were also very good. Breakfast was the best one we have experienced in our whole trip in Japan with big choice of food. We travelled with our 2 year old daughter and fond hotel to be accommodating and friendly. Only think I think would improve our stay further would definitely be free WiFi which I think should come as a standard in this class hotel.

I put a lot of effort in to planning my Tokyo leg and landed on Cerulean Tower. All in all you can't go past it with the location being the biggest draw card. You are less than 5 minute walk to the famed Shibuya Crossing.The hotel room itself is very spacious and a big plus is the 'walk-in' robe which most hotels do not have. The view from the room over Tokyo is a welcoming site when you first wake up in the morning and when you fall asleep.Customer service is exceptional, they helped us find any restaurants/bars/shops we were looking for that day.ONLY negative is they charge an additional fee for wi-fi which I think is ridiculous. If the made wi-fi inclusive then I would give it a 10/10.The price may come across as expensive to some but if you do your research you'll find that it is value for money and definitely worth it.

A luxury hotel in a great location. We stayed in a corner suite, and could see Mt Fuji on a clear day. There wasn't free wifi, which for an expensive hotel in this day and age I think is bad. (We stayed at the Granbell, a much cheaper hotel later and the wifi was free). But the staff are Exceptional and the hotel has everything you need. Ask for a room facing Fuji, it's worth it. Have a drink in the evening at the bar on the top level for an amazing view - but it's not that cheap.

We got a room in the 34th floor facing Shibuya station and the view was spectacular. The staff is really nice. The restaurants inside the hotel are really good. Great location. The bathroom also has a huge panoramic window with spectacular views.

The room itself was rather small, but well, considering the prices in Tokyo, it's acceptable. The overall quality of the facilities are very high. We arrived a little bit earlier than the check-in time and to be honest we expected to be shown into the room, but we were made to wait till exactly the check-in time. Very punctual and not very flexible (and very Japanese). Might have sounded ironic, but it's located within walking distance from the station and we enjoyed our stay here. This will be one of the options when we come back to Tokyo.

The Cerulean is in a great location, the service is excellent, and the rooms are spacious, clean and quite comfortable. The staff is plentiful and are 100% great at providing service. A large number of the main floor staff speaks English.The Shibuya train station is nearby, access to taxis is easy and there are always some available, and buses to either airport are readily available. Haneda is a short 30-ish minute bus rid; Narita is estimated to be an hour, but even on weekends do not play it close. Traffic, road work etc. can easily make it an hour and a half drive and the airport is enormous so it takes a solid 20 minutes just to get to your gate once you are there.The breakfast buffet is good. The choices are all there from warm Asian foods, omelets, fresh squeezed juice etc. It is not an inexpensive buffet by any means. The service in the restaurant is excellent.Highly recommend the hotel for business travel!

We had a twin deluxe room on the 27th floor, with a great view, especially from the bathroom. The room was spacious, well appointed, and very comfortable. The concierge gave us some good restaurant recommendations within walking distance... sushi, yakitori, teppanyaki, shabu shabu & suki yaki. The bar on the 40th floor has a spectacular view, and was great for settling down with a drink and a cigar at the end of a tiring day. Shibuya is buzzing with shops, restaurants, bars. The famed crossing is a great experience, masses of humanity moving in all directions, but in a very structured and disciplined way.. so different from the chaos of Mumbai! Shibuya station itself is very well connected with various JR lines as well as subway lines, so that you can get to most places in Tokyo directly or with just one change.

The location is the best. I could see the Shibuya station from the hotel room's window, no other 5 stars hotel in Shibuya could be closer to everything. The hotel is one of the tallest buildings in the area and the view I had was really amazing, over looking Shibuya and Yoyogi park and Shijuku.Lovely people too, the check in staff and the lobby manager were very helpful with good english. The room that we had was a bit aged and could needed a bit of renovation, but the size was good and the bathroom was excellent.Overall, it is my first choice in Shibuya and its location is the best you can get.

Chose this hotel because of location close to main train station. Nearest train station Shibuya is only small walk away, carried our suitcases there which was not much trouble, elevators and walkways over the road with ramps made it much easier to access. Close to shopping malls and lots of restaurants around. Lovely views from room, beautiful marble bathrooms, only gripe no free internet. Great views from bar on top floors, worthwhile for a drink around sunset

The hotel is quite good in the rooms which are absolutely quiet. The hall is not so big and if you look for a business centre, probably this is not the right place to be. The location is good right in shibuya where you can easily find shops, restaurants and bars.

Upon check-in, we were upgraded to a corner Sky View room because at the time of booking through expedia we had mentioned it would be our honeymoon. They also have us a card and box of sweets as a welcome gift. Friendly and helpful staff, well outfitted room, great bathroom, incredibly clean with views that can't be beat. Bed and pillows were really comfortable. Location was perfect for exploring Shibuya and other areas thanks to easy metro access.Only a minor complaint that the air conditioning in the room wasn't very powerful and couldn't be set below 20 C so the room felt stuffy. It's by no means a cheap hotel but for that price I would expect to not be charged 300 Yen to boil water for a green tea bag from the minibar. (Luckily we brought our own) And 7-11 across the street for snacks and drinks.

I really enjoyed my stay ath the Cerulean. Its well priced for a larger room compared to alot of others in Tokyo. Comfortable beds, great bathroom and most of the rooms have fantastic views of Shibuya.

This is certainly the best hotel in Shibuya in terms of service, size of rooms, location, and cleanliness. Of course all of these will come at a price, so be prepared to shell out some serious dough for it. That said, you do get what you pay for so this hotel will not disappoint.The room is very large for a city hotel smack in the middle of Shibuya. The last time I stayed in a hotel in Shibuya the room was the size of my walk-in wardrobe at home, so I was pleasantly surprised how spacious the Cerulean is. It is also very new, or at least it seems to me as it is new, which means the room is also very clean. I love it. The only downside is that the room is slightly too "cool". It does not have the luxury taste that you get at the Four Seasons or Grand Hyatt; then again, you are not paying those prices!The bathroom is enormous - and so tastefully designed. The whole decor is modern Japanese and it reminds me of a modern ryokan. The bathroom has a huge "wet area" where the shower and bathtub is in one room. Service is excellent, as is expected from a top hotel in Japan. I did not have breakfast at the hotel so am unable to comment on it. There are plenty of noodle restaurants in the vicinity so it is easy and efficient to get a quick bite.Apparently there is a airport limo shuttle bus that brings you straight to the hotel so that makes it easy. I took a MK taxi with a meet and greet service; the bill was slightly under ¥10,000 and for two people I thought it was worth paying for the convenience. Otherwise the hotel is well connected with the subway just around the corner.Great hotel to stay - worth every dollar!

This hotel was worth the cost, and for something similar in Sydney for example, it would cost double. Its worth getting a corner room. Very romantic and the location is superb. Room service was extremely pricey but bells and whistles galore. Very sweet and touching

Stayed @ the hotel for 3 nights for a first time visit to Tokyo. The hotel was gorgeous, in a super fun location and the staff was amazing. Loved the room- especially the bathroom and the cleanliness of the hotel. I would definitely recommend staying here!

We had a great time staying at this hotel. The location is very convenient, it took us only 5-7 minutes to walk to the train station. The hotel room is also big especially for Japan standard. It also has a very nice bakery in the lobby which comes in handy to grab a croissant and coffee on the go in the morning. The hotel service was also excellent from reception, concierge and room service, everybody was ready to help with a smile. For those with kids, we noticed a kid care facility from the sign in the elevator, but we didn't try it.Drinks and foods at the hotel lobby and restaurants were a bit pricy, but there are tons of restaurants nearby. There is also a 711 on the 2nd floor where we can grab snacks and drinks for our room.

A bit disappointing. The hotel is large and rather lacks charm. The standard rooms are quite cramped with a somewhat spartan decor, although the deluxe corner twin to which we were moved is much larger and more comfortable, although again a bit on the drab side. The rooms are, however, well maintained and very clean. We had a booking mix up which they were not able to entirely resolve, although I cannot fault the on-duty manager for making every effort to do so. The staff - particularly the concierge - are extremely polite and did their very best to be of help and to accommodate our requests. The hotel is very well situated within a 5 minute walk from the Shibuya station, one of the main hubs in Tokyo's ultra-efficient public transport system, which means you can basically connect to anywhere in the city. The buffet breakfast is rather expensive for whats on offer. Certainly not the lap of luxury, but this is a good solid hotel with clean rooms, good facilities, and a helpful considerate staff, with a great location.

Despite the price is at the high side. But I always believe good thing doesn't come cheap. We took shuttle bus from Narita Airport to the hotel. Upon arrival, we greeted by the friendly staffs who can speak good english. Checked-in done pretty quickly. Our room located at level 32 oversee the beautiful Tokyo Skyline. Special love the big bathroom... :) Location wise, it's located near the shibuya station, within walking distance we managed to find plenty of food stalls, restaurants, shopping malls... etc.

The Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel is easily the best hotel in Shibuya - a crazy, youth oriented part of Tokyo. The hotel is within easy walking distance of Shibuya Station which gives you access to the JR Yamanote Line and several useful suburban train lines. Easy access to the train system in Tokyo is essential.We stayed on the Cerulean floor. The views from our spacious and very comfortable room on the 35th floor were absolutely spectacular – particularly at night. Housekeeping and laundry services were faultless. and service throughout the hotel was unfailingly polite and effective. Champagne in the executive lounge was a lovely way to start the evening before heading out for dinner. We enjoyed dinner at Chen, the hotel’s Szechuan restaurant and Oli, the hotel’s Italian restaurant. This is a very professionally operated hotel if a little corporate and soulless. If you need to stay in Shibuya, the Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel is a very good choice.

I stayed here for 2 nights back in February 2014 whilst travelling on my own. Great location, right opposite the Shibuya crossing and close by to shops, bars etc. Walking distance to the train station which was handy to go sight seeing.Hotel staff can't do enough for you and are very warm and friendly.The rooms are large,very clean and stocked with lovely toiletries. I would stay here again if in Tokyo.

This is a typical business hotel. The bus from the airport will stop directly at this hotel and return to the airport for your departure at a cost of approximately 3,100Y. Request a non-smoking level if at all possible, as the smell of smoke is quite strong on some levels. The service at this hotel has always been professional.

We just had a brief one night stay here, but it was a lovely experience. Rooms are as luxurious as you'd expect for the price, with an amazing bathroom. The room was surprisingly roomy (for Tokyo standards), and our group of three adults fit comfortably despite there being 3 single beds, 2 arm chairs, and 2 small tables. The beds were really quite hard, I was surprised I slept as well as I did given they were so firm. Location is excellent, just a short walk (up a reasonable hill) up from Shibuya station. When you exit Shibuya station from the West exit, just stand on the street and look up, and the highest building you can see ahead and to the left is the hotel. You have to cross an overpass to get over to the correct side of the hotel, but there are lifts you can take if you have a lot of luggage. Just an easy 5min walk to Shibuya crossing and all the great shopping in that area. We enjoyed a lunch and a dinner on the top floor of the Seibu shopping mall, which was very well priced and delicious. (In Tokyo, it seems that most shopping malls have excellent top-floor eating areas which are comprised of smaller restaurants that are well priced and good quality.)As mentioned by others, the only downside to this hotel was the exorbitant costs for anything that wasn't included. Internet was $10 a day (not a 24hr period I believe), to sit down and have a coffee in the foyer was upwards of 1,300yen, and to use a tea bag in the room was about 300yen. Ouch!!The service was amazing, with super polite staff on every corner just to greet you and assist in any way. We booked the airport limousine to return to the airport through the concierge, and they took care of every aspect. It was wonderful having the porter come up to our room to collect our bags when we were ready to check out, which they then stored for the day and then packed onto the limousine bus for us at the end of the day as we left the hotel for the airport.

We were really pleasantly surprised by the Cerulean Tower. I was expecting a pretty standard business hotel - it is located in a tower that also has offices etc - particularly as the reasonable price didn't suggest it would be anything special. But it was a really great end to our stay in Tokyo. The hotel is in a handy location - we were able to walk just a few minutes, pushing our suitcases, from Shibuya station. There is a great pedestrian overpass that gets you up and over the very busy intersection outside the station. So only a few minutes from trains and from all the shops, bars and restaurants of Shibuya - you are really close to things, but get a little bit of peace and quiet as you are a few minutes away. The view of the city from our room on floor 32 was amazing. The rooms are modern and spacious with big bathrooms and lots of space to put bags. Our only option when booking through the Expedia website was a Queen Room, and the reception desk confirmed our booking in a Queen Room, but when we got up there it had a huge King bed so that was a nice surprise. Not sure if that is standard or if there was a mix up, but the bed was very comfy. I didn't touch the mini bar but it seemed to have only drinks, no snacks. The toiletries in the bathroom are only average, but snuggly bathrobes and a good hairdryer made up for it. We caught a limo bus back to Narita Airport for about 3000 yen each - really easy. The concierge organised for us the day before and we got picked up downstairs from the hotel carpark. Annoyingly, we could get a coffee in the nice looking lobby café either time we tried - the first time it was full and the second time they weren't letting people in because they were expecting a large group. That was a bit of a blip which they should sort out. Overall an excellent spot and we would return.

We have stayed in various hotels and precincts over the years in Tokyo, and this hotel wins out for good service, roominess and location. A corner room provided enough space for 3 adults, still leaving enough room for a small table, desk and sofa….quite a lot of space for a Tokyo hotel. Room 2315 had a good view of the famous crossing from "Lost In Translation" and straight up the main street of Shibuya. The bathroom was spacious too with a double basin, separate shower and bath.Location wise this hotel is excellent, being close enough to Shibuya Station to make luggage not a problem and an easy walk to the busy Centre Gai area, with all its little restaurants and bars. We had some great days wandering through nearby Harajuku and shopping along Shibuyu's chic Omotesando Street. For a dose of nature in the big city, the Meji Shine is close and if you can manage it, go on a Saturday morning when you should see some traditional weddings taking place.Best of all is the nearby Tokyu Food Show situated under the train station, which is a fascinating food hall full of delicacies from all over the world. After some very pricey restaurant experiences and two weeks of (delicious) Japanese food it was still a pleasant change to indulge in some French wine and cheese. Having said that, the gyozas were tasty here and the sashimi fresh. There's also a small noodle cafe and a good ice-cream bar. After 1500 lots of sushi and sashimi items were reduced.Behind the hotel there is also a little street of restaurants with what seemed to be a very popular sukiyaki restaurant - so busy we couldn't get a table. Go out via the hotel door to the taxi rank, take the exit on the left, left again once on the street, cross the street and you will see a small, though busy restaurant area on the right.The hotel staff in general, are very helpful and accommodating and happily arrange onward bookings, transfers and tickets. My only criticism of the hotel staff, concerns the 40th floor bar. We went for a quick drink and to enjoy the wonderful view. There were very few people there as it was early evening. My husband and I both ordered cocktails however our daughter chose not to drink. We were firmly told that it was one person, one drink. I could possibly understand it if we hadn't already ordered 2 cocktails or if there was a seating issue, however such a policy should not apply to a young person accompanying her parents to a bar and an pretty empty one at that.The lobby bar is a busy place in the afternoon both for drinks and afternoon tea. The cakes were excellent. We ate breakfast in the cafe for convenience only as the food was not great - typical of our experiences in Tokyo for European style breakfasts. Tokyu Food Show provides some excellent alternatives however.This a a good hotel, easily accessed on the train and connections to most major areas were easy too. Be sure to get a corner room if you are staying long enough and definitely if there are more than two of you. Non smoking rooms are available.

My first time in Tokyo and this hotel was just in the best location, everything at your fingertips.Great big rooms, fabulous view from the bar upstairs.Special mention to the concierge desk - they were fantastic!

We spent five days in Tokyo and the hotel was great. We were greeted with excellent service and they showed appreciation for staying with them. I advised the front desk we were celebrating my boyfriend's birthday. He understood a bit and had someone put chocolates in the room. They were great and he enjoyed them. We asked for an upgrade, but due to hotel being booked, they weren't able to. The room was gorgeous and the view was amazing. You cannot go wrong with any view as lights and city are grand. The area is great to walk around, get around, shop, eat and enjoy. I would recommend this hotel if you are on business or getting married. I think they cater to that big. Getting to hotel was easy as the limo bus picks up and drops off directly from hotel. Break down :Room- great space and bed is very comfortableBathroom- big with a nice tub and shower so two are able to soak and shower at the same time. Service- Excellent and they try to please and accommodate as much as possibleFood- Expensive, but not bad. We ordered room service steak special. Not the best steak, but set up was beautiful (a table is brought in to room and set up for you). There is a Jonathan's close by which is their version of Denny's and its cheaper and good!(7-11 is across the street from Jonathan's)Location- Great. Shopping, Shibuya crossing(must see), Tokyu malls, trains, Starbucks, malls, food, movie theater, etc....such a great area but a walk over the bridge and inclines will tire your feet so comfy shoes is a must!Enjoy if you make it and bring body lotion, deodorant, and sneakers! (in case you forget)!

We afforded ourselves the luxury of the Cerulean for 4 nights as part of our 15 night tour of Japan.From the second we entered the hotel reception the staff could not be more helpful and this set the tone for the duration of our stay.On arrival at approximately 2pm, our rooms were not ready however the porter staff relieved us of our luggage and it was there waiting for us in our room one hour later.We utilized the service of the concierge on several occasions and each time the service and support provided were above my expectations. The rooms were extremely well appointed, modern and spacious. Our room was on the 32nd floor with breathtaking views of wider Shibuya. My only minor grumble was the charge of 400 yen for using the instant coffee within the room and overlooking this charge.I would not hesitate to recommend this hotel for those wishing to experience a little bit of luxury during a holiday stay in Tokyo. It’s not the cheapest but no regrets.

Spent 10 days with the family and loved: the careful personnel, the concierge (that will solve just about anything), the great location and the restaurants within. Had a great time overall. View from upper floors are absolutely beautiful.

We had reserved connected rooms for our family and they were not able to provide with this and did not even apologize for it. Hotel location isn't great either, too busy, noisy and long walk to the station.Breakfast is just average.I would not recommend this hotel.

We chose to stay at the Cerulean due to its location - Shibuya is a great area for a 1st time visit to Tokyo with great train accessibility to the rest of the city (and airport), a lot of restaurants and great busy atmosphere. The hotel is beautiful but I would not stay there again.POSITIVES:The hotel stands out in Shibuya from far away - it is one of the tallest building in the area and is very easy to find. It has a nice, grand lobby with a lot of staff to help you check-in, take your bags, and guide you around. The rooms are nice and spacious by Tokyo standards - we didn't have enough room to do cartwheels around the bed, but there was plenty of room for two people to move around. The bathroom was really nice and big, with an enclosed glass shower and tub, double vanity and "washing" toilet.Prior to our arrival, I emailed the concierge to help us make some dinner and lunch reservations (including at the famous Jiro's) and they were very quick to respond and help us out. When we arrived they had a printed map to show us where to go and details about the reservation. NEGATIVES:The Cerulean is a 5 start hotel with a pretty hefty price tag, so I had high expectations. It was very disappointing to learn that wifi was not free in the hotel - it was $10 a day and you got a code that worked for only 24hrs at a time. This seemed outrageous! How can you charge this much for a room, in a busy tourist area and not include wifi?!There is a bar at the top floor of the hotel with an incredible 360 view of Tokyo. BUT if you want to grab a seat or a table, there is a $10 per person charge (the only "free" seats are the bar). Again, outrageous, especially since the drinks are really expensive as well - I had a $26 cocktail and my husband a $17 glass of whiskey.There was a gym at the hotel, but we did not visit it as it was also NOT free. It was $10 a day to use it, and only free for two hours at 5am. Very strange.Overall, I was happy with the location, the room and the staff, but a hotel this expensive should not charge its guests for every small amenity. Unfortunately, I would not book the Cerulean again.

This hotel has beautiful views of the city. We were upgraded to a corner room that had the bath with the window next to it. All of the staff were very helpful, polite and accommodating at all times. It is so central to Shibuya, and I'd definitely stay there again.The only small negative point I have to this hotel is that you have to pay mini bar rates if you make tea or coffee in the room. I have never seen this before in any hotel I've ever stayed in. They are always complimentary in other hotels.Also you are required to pay for the use of the wifi and gym, which I haven't had to do in any of the previous hotels I've stayed in.

Beautiful Hotel in the Shibuya district of Tokyo with great views from the rooms of the city. Spacious rooms with excellent facilities and very helpful staff. The gym and health club are excellent however there is a daily charge if you are not staying on the executive floors which was disappointing. Great selection of restaurants and a 7/11 is located within the complex for convenience. Enjoyed my stay and would recommend the hotel for both business and leisure travel to Tokyo

I arrived from interstate at 7.30am and went to the hotel just to drop off my bag. The staff were great and, as my room was ready, checked me in so I could hang up clothes and then go to work. The room was small but spotless, well appointed and full of historic ambience. The bed was great and the Rocks breakfast was the best I'd had in a long time. Great staff, great service and a fabulous location. I will be back !!

I stayed at the Cerulean for the first time during my last trip to Tokyo (mid April 2014). It was the first time I had based myself in Shibuya, usually I stay in Shinjuku.I am definitely coming back again. We got upgraded to a club floor where the view from our room window was breathtaking. The room was spacious, clean and comfortable and staff were attentive and polite.But the location is the main draw. It's a stone's throw from Shibuya station where you can get all the trains you need, especially to those trendy western suburbs!

Stayed here for a total of six days. The room is very nice with good views. The absence of proper tea and coffee facilities in the room was surprising and inconvenient. The hotel has many restaurants and bars. The restaurants are over priced and it is better to eat outside the hotel. There are many little restaurants within the vicinity. The bar bellovisto on the 40th floor is worth a visit. A seat at the bar gives you a great view of the city and the cocktails are fab. The hotel seems more catered for business guests and it seems to be a local hub for business lunches and meetings. The location is what really sells this hotel. You are within 5 minutes walking distance of the subway and two minutes from the centre of shibuya. Also the airport limo bus stops at the basement level of the hotel. This is really convenient for getting to and from the airport. The concierge can book your tickets for you in advance. The staff are very helpful and friendly and I can't fault the service. Would return.

I have stayed at this hotel many times now, first time was in 2008 when we splurged on a high floor bath- view room, which was amazing. It included access to the exec. lounge with drinks & breakfast at set times. Very luxurious. We have always asked for the Shibuya crossing-view and luckily gotten it every time, It´s really the best to watch dusk falling over busy Shibuya and all the lights of Tokyo from the 34th floor. The view & location are some of the best things about this hotel, it is very close to Shibuya station (maybe 4 min) BUT you have to walk across a elevated walkway to get to it. Luckily there is an elevator on the station side if you have heavy bags. The hotel itself has a luxurious feel i think, big lobby, superfast (earpopping) elevators and attentive lobby-staff. Sometimes we had to deal with some confusions, like trying to charge us for internet-access even though it´s included in our plan or different quotes on charges which was a bit annoying. But overall totally worth it for me, because they always give us the room (view) we want, and the misunderstandings are worked out. The rooms are big, the closets roomy & beds are big and extremely comfortable. Even though we were annoyed a few times it´s still totally worth it, so i give it a 5.

Total stay 5 nights. I'll start with the pros. Good location only 3 min walk to shibuya station. Comfortable/clean room & beds.Good sized rooms. We had a corner room on a high floor with nice views. Efficient check in/out Stored our excess luggage while we travelled to kyoto for 4 nights (stayed in cerulean again on return to tokyo) Narita Airport limo ( bus service) goes straight to hotel Cons:Room rate is expensive. Food/drink is expensive. You must pay for wifi in hotel.No coffee/tea making facilities in room.

What a great hotel, professional team at front office, all our families special request where arranged such as rooms close by and a baby cot.Mornings in 'Caramello' offering a great breakfast, easy to reach by foot to everything in Shibuya.The team are professional throughout from Front office, Concierge, Bell desk etc...Close to train, shopping and the Airport shuttle runs all day until 17:10 from downstairs in the hotel to Narita so its easy to arrange.7 Eleven also inside the hotel for anything one maybe forgets to buy.Kids club offered - called Poppins and babysitting which we made use of.A night cap on the 41st floor great, but be aware they charge for best seating area.Overall I would suggest this hotel to anyone planning to stay in Shibuya who wants the best service and location possible.

We stayed here for 3 nights on the 32nd floor with a stunning view of Fuji-san. By modern Japanese standards a good sized room with a large full bath/ shower suite. Beds with choice of pillows, were supremely comfortable, bath robes and towels all fluffy and new with an outstanding free offering of complimentary ladies cosmetics! At US$350 a night it's about the same or even less than it's equivalents in NYC and London, and the service for every requirement, from room service, to bell-hop, to concierge, was impeccable and seldom bettered in my experience. We spent little time in our accommodation as we were in full tourist mode to look around at a Shibuya I last saw 40 years ago . A few changes and no better place for a base camp than the Cerulean Tower - just 3 minutes from the throbbing centre of Shibuya and the train station for easy access to everywhere else in Tokyo. Like other reviewers I found the wi-fi charge totally chintzy in this day and age and for that reason alone I am only giving 4 stars. Wake up Cerulean, it's 2014 and the age of free wi-fi everywhere! But, nevertheless, a highly recommendable hotel.

Picked this hotel as it was highly rated by previous travellers and only 5 mins walks from Shibuya Station, which is a great place to base yourself for visiting any part of Tokyo/Yokohama or Bullet Train services from Tokyo.It is also 5 mins from all the shops, restaurants and entertainment in central Shibuya, so everything you needed on the doorstep.Hotel and rooms were very well appointed, slick and very friendly service from everyone we met.Very comfortable and quiet rooms with stunning views.Great view from bar on 40th floor at night and well worth paying Tokyo prices for the drinks.Would definitely use this as my base for future visits.

This hotel is ideally located near Shibuya station with access to Yamanote Line which is very practical to reach many parts of Tokyo.There is a nice jazz club on the premises and also a cool lounge on the last floor where we had a nice sake flight.I would stay there again in the future.

Located in a great spot, easy access to train station and local amenities. Staff very courteous in all regards. Breakfast with extremely good selection to suit both Western and Eastern taste.The Top floor bar is brilliant, very vibrant with fantastic views - not cheap though!Rooms are of great size, well decorated with nice bathrooms

Just getting set to leave here. Great room huge with a view of Mount Fuji if it's clear , which it has been. All amenities here , haven't used gym and dont mind paying for wifi as many dont't use these things. I haven't eaten here just had a quick cup of tea and some fruit from the local shops and then headed out. Minutes away from the bustle of shibuya and the station and lots of little bars and restaurants behind the hotel. Ideal for me .

Stayed there for two nights. Gym was charged extra 2,100 ¥ even though poorly equipped and dirty. Breakfast was included but not available on day of departure in the restaurant, the executive floor restaurant opens late so I had to leave w/o bf. Staff was kind (as always in 5* hotels) but very inflexible. Location is good but there are many hotels in Shibuya. Will never stay here again.

Stayed here on a 5 day trip to Tokyo...first trip. Staff were great...polite and helpful. Room was great, comfortable and wasn't stuffy as so many air conned rooms can be.The top floor bar has great views over the city and Mt Fuji. The hotel is a couple of minutes stroll from the very busy shopping/tourist area of shibuya and around the hotel there are hundreds of small eateries???although you'd walk past many not realising they are there.I'd definitely come back and use this hotel.

Great location - 15-min walk from Shibuya metro station (may be 7 minuet without luggage and snow). Shibuya itself is a hip area, closes to the coolest things to do and to see + couple stops away from other famous neighborhoods. Tip: Shibuya is a big station. look out for Tokyu mall, there is a footbridege on the left. That's your way to go. Airport limo has a stop here as well, therefore, you can save hassle finding your way around. (we took taxi from hotel to HND, JPY8,000 if you have no time wasted for limo bus).Spacious room - We got a corner room which seems like a suite - separate living room and writing desk areas, king bed and closet. Spacious bathroom Breathtaking view - simply we got a view from both living room and bathroom. You can absolutely enjoy glass of wine over a bubble bath. Breakfast - standard also outstanding quality of food. Not a lot choices comparing some big hotels but seriously, fresh squeezed OJ and bakery, eggs, cereals, fruits ... good & health enough to start the day. Hotel rooms start from 19th floor, your view won't be disturbed anyway. and i really like the hotel non-busy feeling, everyone was so chilled & relax (but serving you)

I stayed here with a friend in February and really enjoyed it. Though it was a little pricey, the room was far larger and grander than most in Tokyo. In fact, our bathroom was about the size of a normal Tokyo room!The location is great, it's about 3 minutes walk to shibuya station and the famous pedestrian scramble.The buffet breakfast was about 3,000 jpy and worth every cent.Checkout and the bus transfer to the airport were quick and easy.The only downside was that the wifi was not free, though it was cheap at about 1,200 jpy per day, for the price you are paying to stay here you would think it would be included.All in all, I would recommend this place if you can afford it.

Amazing rooms with a view across Tokyo to die for.Outstanding staff who passed the postage test( try posting a large box of goodies home from any hotel - only the best can handle it well from overseas )Fantastic location in the heart of the action of Shibuya.My only complaint is that the pool is adult only

As has been previously said in previous reviews the Cerulean is a great hotel. The location, quality of the rooms, views from the higher floors, bars, restaurants and general levels of service are all very good indeed.However, four stars rather than five because, for the not insubstantial money paid, I would absolutely expect free WiFi and free use of the gym and pool. It frankly seems petty to charge for either and I suspect most people would visit in the expectation that they would have both without incurring any additional cost. It rankles to feel that you are being squeezed for every last Yen and sours an otherwise great hotel experience.I should put in a good word for the concierge service. Very helpful and friendly. Although, once again, be aware of some additional costs for some of their services.

The location is great. Only a five minute walk from the Shibuya station - you can get anywhere in Tokyo from that station. The staff is extremely helpful and friendly. You can take the airport limo bus straight to the hotel from any of the major airports. The rooms are relatively big for Tokyo. Try to get a room higher up - the views are amazing.

My husband and I stayed here for our honeymoon in November of last year. It's a five minute walk from Shibuya station and the craziness do the Shibuya Crossing, which is exactly what I wanted. What really amazed me was the size of the room. We had a gigantic room with a huge king size bed. I never expected to see anything that big in Japan! And the bathroom was equally as amazing with a separate tub and shower. But what really won me over was the view. We had a gigantic picture window with views of Shibuya Crossing, Tokyo tower, Tokyo skytree, and Odaiba in the distance. Truly amazing. The hotel is very large, with English speaking staff. Their concierge was very helpful in helping us book restaurant reservations and getting us a taxi. There were also tours that picked you up from this hotel. The room was expensive, but we splurged since it was our honeymoon. Majority of the people that stayed in the hotel, from what I observed, were foreigners and business people. Overall, I liked the location, but I don't know if I could afford to stay here again!

My husband & I stayed here for four nights and over the New Year period. I choose this Hotel due to its location (5 minute walk from Shibuya JR Station) so we would have access to plenty of night life for NYE. The Hotel itself was really nice and with acceptional views of the City from the Bar on top of the Hotel. The room was very spacious and the beds very comfortable and everything was very clean. Our room had a great window so you could sit on the ledge and watch the City below and also had an amazing view of Mt Fuji. When we required anything from guest services it was there within two minutes and for the size of the Hotel that was very impressive. The food in the restuarants though are very expensive and I don't like paying $11.00 AUD for a cup of coffee (drip coffee) so we found it cheaper to grab some breakfast from Tully's Cafe or even the 7 Eleven. There are some great restuarants and shopping around this area. All in all a very nice Hotel.

Some other reviewers have complained about the room price, but I guess it depends on your point of comparison. Considering Tokyo is supposed to be one of the most expensive cities in the world, I thought the standard rooms were very good value. We had a double, twin and single each under $300. For the size and amenities, it compares very favourably with Toronto, Vancouver, New York, Chicago and London, where we've been in the past few years. Service was impeccable. The location in Shibuya was very central.

I stayed here early Jan 2014. It was a great hotel, clean and spacious rooms (space is rare for Japan). The staff were efficient and they have a great buffet breakfast in the morning. It will set you back over $30 Aud per head, but well worth it if you want a nice western breakfast for a change. My two qualms were that I had to pay for wifi, when you pay over $300 per night you want free wifi included. This is a top class hotel seriously?! It worked out to be over $10 per day which really isn't on in this modern century. Also one morning we were not well so we slept in and put the DND on the door. The room service never came back to service our room later in the day. I was a little disappointed with this as needed fresh towels.Good location.We did get a free upgrade on arrival though to a king room and the beds were super comfortable. The bar at the top of the hotel amazing. A nice stay all in all and I would stay here again, but guys seriously you rate yourself a top hotel, don't make us pay for free wifi when we already pay a decent amount for the rooms.

Stayed here for 3 nights just before New Year, in a Deluxe Twin room (22nd floor). The room was lovely as was the spacious bathroom. However, both bedroom and bathroom windows suffered from constant condensation - whilst a minor point, one of the selling points was a 'view bath', so it was noticed more. The 30-day advance deal for the room was excellent value, and included free wi-fi. Shibuya as a base was fantastic. One can get anywhere easily in the city (and beyond) via the JR/subway options, and the local areas were great for eating/drinking options. The Friendly Limousine bus service stops direct at the hotel, which is so convenient, and one can also take the Narita Express to Shibuya direct. Just behind the hotel is a small village-like area of 3 blocks or so, which was a great alternative from the non-stop life of Shibuya proper - busy but not hectic.Overall, an excellent stay and a very good hotel - recommended.

The room is very clean, spacious and the hotel location is extremely convenient. Airport shuttles just stop at the hotel. The noise proof is good. A lot of shops and restaurants are nearby. Subway station is very close to the hotel.

With my 2 adult daughters, we stayed first for 4 days, then left our luggage for a few days while we travelled around, and then returned for 5 more days. Fantastic location 5 minutes from the ubiquitous Shibuya scramble (crossing) , as well as from the Dogenzaka district with great evening atmosphere , bistros and small cozy restaurants. Very large room by Tokyo or any standards (plus we had 3 single beds in there), an enormous divided bathroom with a powerful shower and separate tub in their own glasses in section , and unbeatable city views from 20th and then 21st floors facing Sky Tree etc. Even better from 39/40th windows which faced Mt.Fuji. Excellent front desk and concierge staff who helped us with everything from JR railways tickets (organized all connections to snow monkeys land and then Kyoto and back), had them delivered to the hotel for a 5% commission. Then they managed to track down a specific coat which my daughter wanted at Takashimaya department store. Internet is extra , but one charge for unlimited devices (we had 6) , once codes are punched in it lasted for entire stay. They offered the weekly rate ($36) which was cheaper then the daily. Pool is also an extra charge but we never had time to go anyway. We felt at home and were well taken care of at all times in the incredible city of Tokyo. Will happily return.

Cleanliness, room, location are very good. Having that said, For a $350 a night for double room I would expect a free wifi at the least especially in Japan where I would badly need internet. In fact I have to pay $10 for a device for daily internet (revoked in midday wtf?). Even the gym is only free at 6 to 7 in the morning. You have to pay for entrance in later hours. Even in a more expensive city like London, I had all of those basic facilities for free in my previous hotel (LOT CHEAPER, competitive facilities, and also located near city center). I also stayed in an airport hotel in Japan that was 75% cheaper yet gave me a free wifi. If you have money, just go to an international hotel like hilton. At least they would give you your moneys worth and save you from all these bollocks. This hotel in the other hand tries to rip its guests off. Terribly disappointed.

The location is greatin the middle of the Shibuya area of town gives u the perfect start to reach everywhere in townSHIBUYA station is the busiest underground station on the planet 2millions people walk by it everyday!!!!GET THE UPPERFLOOR ROOMS more expensive but the view all over TOKYO is amazingthe food is good u can choose japaneese chineese italianthe only matter is that even at the concierge they don't speak english,just a little.....but this istrue all over japan

Become a member and you will save on your next visit. The best is the breakfast and the fine dinning in the hotel. Moreover the service is amazing and punctual. All you need do is arrive and they will take care of you! Choice of pillow floor and mattress. Can I ask for more?

I stayed in the Cerulean in early December for a business trip. Let me just say, this is a great location, with restaurants and convenience stores just next door. Also, I thought the service around checkin and breakfast was great. While those were positives of this hotel, there are a few things that would make me reconsider staying here in the future. First, while the room was a nice size, the bathroom was very dark and there was limited counterspace. I had a hard time getting ready and finally just started curling my hair and applying makeup in the bedroom where there was more light and space.Next, I visited the gym twice and both times was disappointed. There were not very many cardio options, only treadmills. Also, the weights area was very small and there were no complimentary waters. Finally, my coworkers and I were disappointed with the bar on the 40th floor. We visited for a drink after a long day of work but were met with a VERY smoky bar and poor service. It took our group of 4 a half hour to recieve our ordered drinks! Only when we said we were leaving did our drinks appear.All in all, this isn't a bad hotel. However, I would likely choose not to stay here again.

Stayed here for 4 nights with husband and 2 sons. Loved every minute of our stay in Shibuya! The hotel was perfectly located just few minutes walk from the Shibuya Station and a short stroll to the famous Shibuya crossing. The room was very comfortable and had the most wonderful view over the city. There were many places to eat nearby. The hotel staff were most kind and helpful. I would certainly recommend this place for comfort and convenience.

Superbly located in must see Shibuya The Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel delivers for this standard of accommodation. Being on the limousine bus stop list enables a smooth transit from Narita straight to the buzz of Shibuya. Professional staff welcome you to their well managed and designed business hotel where you can feel very comfortable for your stay however long. Our twin room with extra bed was large enough to enable the three of us to not feel under each others feet and the view toward Mt Fuji is pretty special. The beds were firm but better than a tatami room we experience a few days later and the buckwheat pillows were also surprisingly good. The contemporary lobby lounge enabled us to host some important friends for morning coffee and a freshly squeezed orange juice as part of an a la carte breakfast was in keeping with this hotels attention to detail. The lack of a small room safe is the only markdown here otherwise if your budget allows put the Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel in Shibuya at the top of your list for Tokyo.

I stayed at the Cerulean tower hotel for two nights.
