I thought I'd splash out and get a Tower room, and it was definitely worth it for the incredible views, plus the breakfast buffet in the executive salon. Free and reliable wifi too. I didn't have time to use the leisure facilities unfortunately. The staff are super-polite and very friendly, and always happy to help out. Overall this is a top notch hotel just a few easy minutes walk from Shibuya station. Some people have said it looks about tired but I thought it was lovely. It's pricey but I'd definitely stay here again

The hotel is near to Shibuya station. From Narita airport, we took N'EX train and reached the hotel easily. It was easy to catch the JR Yamanote Line or subways for visiting various hot spots in Tokyo. When we left Tokyo, it was also very easy for us to take Yamanote Line to Shinagawa and then transfer to Tokaido Shinkansen.The room is big, comfortable and has a nice view. The bath room is impressive; spacious, clean and equipped with all facilities including a shower separated from the bathtub.Hotel staffs speak good English and helpful. My family arrived very early due to midnight flight and the room was ready. We were allowed to check in early without paying additional charges.There are many good shopping, restaurants and convenient stores around the hotel. Definitely my choice for next visit to Tokyo.

This hotel has three things going for it: 1) Location: it's the only upscale hotel in Shibuya It's just a few hundred meters from the station, and within walking distance of Omotesando.2) Views: great views, particularly from the high floors. Try to get a room facing Shibuya station.3) Service: impeccable service throughout the hotel.The rooms in this hotel are more business-like than luxurious - unassuming and understated. Given their age they are in very good shape. Bathrooms are spacious in grey marble. The public spaces in this hotel feel too busy. Particularly the lobby area resembles a train station rather than a luxurious.Certain services are far too expensive. Internet is not free for certain room rates, and even water and coffee aren't always provided. Babysitting in the evening costs an unbelievable 5000 yen / hour.

Wonderful hotel, spacious rooms, great restaurants, excellent gym and SPA. Service is impeccable. Breakfast is delicious with lots of choice.Views from the rooms (try to get a room on a high floor) are stunning. Expensive, but...it's Tokyo!

This is a high rise hotel with great city views, well-appointed rooms, comfortable beds (softer than most in Japan), relatively spacious rooms, and good service. We chose the hotel because it is in the central Shibuya Station area and the hotel's basement is one of the stops from which the direct buses, the Narita and Haneda Airport Limousines, leave several times a day for the airports. We stayed one night, our last in Japan, and after checkout the bell desk kept our luggage until departure time, then delivered it to the bus stop on their lower level. Very convenient, and great service, as is usual in Japanese lodgings. The elegant reception lobby is is on the main floor of the building and hotel rooms begin on floor 14, with offices between. The hotel is close to the bright lights of Shibuya Crossing and many restaurants, and has restaurants in the building as well. It is an easy walk from the Shibuya Station west entrance, over the busy street by an overpass that is accessible by elevators at both ends. Wi-fi is available for a charge, a surprise when all other hotels and inns we stayed at, even much less expensive venues, provide free wi-fi now. Water is also frequently provided at lesser places, but here the bottled water is in a minibar for a charge.

I stayed here on a business trip, so I have no idea what this hotel costs, although I suspect its prices are equal to the luxury offered. The rooms were insanely quiet; i never heard a sound from the rooms surrounding me or anywhere else in the hotel. Fantastic views of Tokyo, a very comfortable bed and a great bathroom (I love Japanese bathrooms). And an easy walk to all the sights and sounds of Shibuya. What else could you want? Oh, the rooftop bar is also great, although you do have to put up with cigarette smoke.

Stayed here several times, recently last week, mid NOV."13. Excellent service in all areas. rooms well appointed, beds are a touch hard and need to get the right pillows. Club lounge is nice touch and saves from expensive breakfast....lounge on 40 is quite nice...limited menu in lobby area, particularly on liquor/wine. so there really is not a lobby bar here.....the staff are excellent, location great and hotel is quiet so i would recommend and return. GB

My husband and I have spent our wedding anniversary at this hotel for 4 nights (Oct 17-21, 2013). The concerige team did an excellent job to make our sepical day extraordinary. They've upraded us to a larger room. I've received chocolates and card upon my arrival in my room. They had helped us make restaurant reservations for every single night of our trip, all of the restuarants are aware that we have a special occasion to celebrate. Best of all is that I walked in to my room after my anniversary dinner, a bouquet of ballons and a box of chocolate is awaiting for us. It was so thoughtful and sweet of them. Very happy that I've picked this hotel for this special occasion. Will definately stay there again during my next trip to Tokyo. Besides the concerige team, the location is superb , very close to Shibuya station, and there's a 7-11 on the 2nd level of the hotel. Excellent view from the top. The room size is spacious for Japan standard, especially the large bathroom. House keeping did a great job too, very tidy!!Definately a great choice in Shibuya!!

We were booked at the 33rd floor. Excellent view from the top indeed. In the morning the buildings below looked very white, very clean. The hotel is located a couple of blocks away from the Shibuya station. (You can see the statue of Hachiko the loyal dog here). Many shops and restaurants nearby. For morning ramen, you can take a sip at the nearby ramen shop which is located a few steps from the hotel entrance. Nice place.

What an amazing hotel. We booked a Standard King Sky View room located on the 33rd floor. The room is around 50$ more than the City View rooms but you get a better view, bigger room, free breakfast and internet access. Is totally worth it.

Just spent 4 nights in the Cerulean & whilst it is very convenient to Shibuya Station & the shops, it is overpriced for what you get. The bed was one of the most uncomfortable I have ever slept on and the pillows were atrocious. After a long day of sightseeing the last thing you want is a very hard bed. We were on the 24th floor & the views were OK especially at night.A cup of tea cost upwards of $10 downstairs so we didnt even attempt to eat here and the motel facilities were average for the room cost.Would not stay here again and probably not in Shibuya which is not very western friendly.

My title sums it up. We were very grateful to stay here as part of our wedding trip, and know Shibuya well and have never stayed so centrally/conveniently. However, the astronomical price didn't justify: -dirty carpets-being nickel-and-dimed for every little thing, including gym usage (US$20) and internet usage (US$11)-expensive, uptight restaurant-no common areas to do work and drink coffee. I guess it's a generational thing. We're in our 30s and want to feel free and easy and grab a cup of coffee while checking email in a cafe. This place is like a relic from the 1980s "bubble era" with fawning service, a million charges... and not much else. Save your money and stay in a business hotel like Tokyu Stay or Toyoko Inn or a JR hotel.

One of the best hotels I ever stayed in Hong Kong. First of all you can take the bus direct from Narita to the Hotel nonstop. The hotel is just across the bridge from Shibuyas famous Square. Its amazing how convinient it is. Train Station 3 min walk. 109 Tower with all the shops is 5 min walk. Just for your notice, because its really difficult to find ATM for overseas Credicards, next to the bridge where you walk to the station there is a 7/11 with a postoffice ATM Maschine. Not the one in the hotel. Use it. So u dont have to loook arround. The hotel has an amazing view over the city. Clean Rooms, spacious Corner Suite and the people are just brilliant. The restaurants inside are ok. But downstairs the coffee shop is great with fresh pastries every day. Book it you pay what you get! amazing Hotel

Good location for Shibuya and Harajuku and Shinjuku. Nice areas for Shoping and food. Hotel is good. Don't let "kids" under 18 visit the pool or the gym. Stupid rule. Its not a vaccation place for honeymoners or elderly people. Told my 11year old son that he could stay in the playroom with 3 year old kids. not so cool. Pls change this stupid rule.Executive floor is 35 and above. Nice lounge. Don't know if its worth the extra money.

Clean, spacious for Tokyo, good access to transport (Train/Bus is less than 5 min walk), friendly and helpful staff with English widely spoken.Adds on can become pricey, Gym is 2000Yen/session (normally free at 5 star hotel), Breakfast is 3150 yen, WiFi.

I stayed 4 nights at the Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel in May 2013 with a friend. It was our second stay with the hotel and we left feeling as positive as it were previously.Personally, the hotel has become synonymous with Tokyo. We stayed on city view levels on both occasions and the complete skyline of Tokyo was splendidly before us. Living close to the well connected JR Shibuya station was definitely a big point of content because we didn't have to walk too far 'home' after lots of walking during the Tokyo day but being in Shibuya was always the highlight as the vibrancy always leave us feeling nothing less than euphoric!The size of the rooms in Cerulean is luxurious - 37m2 at the minimum - by Tokyo standards and as much space as we enjoyed, our room was cosy and the beds were excellent for good sleep after a hectic day of traveling. Furthermore, I think fellow reviewers would agree with me that the bathrooms in Cerulean were made from heaven. :)The service was impeccable. Staff always greeted us personally, were very attentive to the needs of guests and readily dispensed guidance on directions and recommendations. I would, however, caution that the prices of rooms in this hotel are lavish and unless one is willing to splurge on accommodation, there are definitely quality economical alternatives in Shibuya and around Tokyo that one may otherwise consider.

Friendly and efficient check-in and check-out. Lobby and common areas are gorgeous. Bathroom was large and luxurious, and the views were out of this world. Overall, I felt privileged to be able to stay there. Have to agree with others on the cost of the amenities, though--looking at the breakfast menu and seeing that coffee was 10 bucks made us eat elsewhere (which really couldn't have been easier due to the hotel's location right in Shibuya). Speaking of location, it's great - an easy walk to the station and multiple subway and train lines, easy walk to the "crazy intersection" and shopping. I would love, love, love to be able to stay here again; will just plan on wandering out into the world for meals.

We stayed in October 2013 and overall found this hotel well located to the Shibuya area and was a blessing to walk there from train station. We had lunch at their French restaurant located on the 40th floor which was delightful whilst our kids were wonderfully entertained in the Kids Room located on the 3rd floor. Service and local knowledge by staff excellent. Have to agree with Maryam A about the extra cost to have a coffee in our room although by the time we arrived at Cerulean we were well used to paying an arm&leg for it. Japan's expensive although I think Australia slightly outdoes it on many accounts. We'd definately stay there again, if not for the hotel, it's proximity to one of the best shopping areas around.

Beautiful hotel, wonderful views, and large spacious rooms. Can't beat the location, less than 10 min walk from Shibuya. Wonderful service, but pricey. Was annoyed no complementary tea or coffee, throw us a bone! at the cost of the room, please. Gym and internet were also an additional costs :( Expenses can add up. Very nice overall, but don't need to experience again.

I've stayed in this hotel several times and have always found it excellent. Attrractive, large foyer and reception area, super-polite and helpful staff, spacious and comfortable bedrooms with comfortable beds and a choice of pillows. They do great breakfasts too!The restaurants in the hotel are generally very expensive, and not really geared up for someone seeking a more basic dining experience. Not a real problem - plenty of inviting and varied alternative restaurants within easy walking distance.

My husband and I, spent 4 nights at this wonderful hotel. Everything was excellent: 1) the location, just a few minutes from Shibuya metro station, which also is a direct stop of the Narita airport express train (NEX), very convenient. Shibuya itself is a very vibrant and modern area of Tokyo, with a pedestrian area full of restaurants, bars, café, shops, malls, etc.2) facilities are well cared and very nice. Our room on the 35th floor has a stoning view of the city. The room was modern and quite big for Tokyo standards; the bed, pillows and linen were of highest quality and of course super comfortable. The bathroom was roomy, with a shower and bathtub, but the star was high-tech toilet.3) the breakfast buffet at the lobby restaurant was delicious. The Bellovisto bar at the 40th floor, is a nice place to have a drink while looking at the city lights. I recommend the cerulean champagne cocktail.4) The fitness club has world class facilities.5) The most beautiful experience about Japan is without a doubt its people, and of course at the Cerulean hotel you have a taste of the courtesy and warmth of japanese people.I definitely recommend this hotel, it is a premium level, worth more than you pay for it.Tokyo has a lot to see and experience, but do not miss the fish market, you do not need to go too early, because now it is open to tourists at 9am (a nice policeman will lead you out of the business area before that time), but get there before 9am anyway (6am-7am) and you can get a glimpse of that unique and chaotic place, and most of all try sushi at any restaurant around, the sushi, best in the world, fresh food has a new meaning over there, do not leave without eating sushi, and do not worry about finding the right place, it does not need to be the one with the largest queue or the one mentioned in the last blog, just any of them will serve delicious and fresh sushi.

Very comfortable stay.....smack bang in the middle of Shibuya. As with most good hotels in Japan, brilliant service. Nice breakfast......and incredibly comfy bed, Pricey but then Tokyo is. I think worth it.

Recently had a two night stay on a stopover visit to Tokyo. My wife and I were upgraded to a room on the 33rd floor which we found clean, well appointed and surprisingly spacious. The view from the room overlooking Shibuya Crossing was unreal and large windows, even in the bathroom, give you a real panoramic view of the city. Highly recommend heading up to the bar on the 40th floor for drinks and even more spectacular views. Great location, close to Shibuya station and great base in which to explore Tokyo. Look forward to my next visit!

Large and modern hotel with all amenities. Walking distance from the Shibuya station, shops and restaurants .The executive floor is quiet with private dining room for breakfast.Large rooms ( the view is fabulous from the upper floor bathrooms !)Excellent breakfast buffet. The Italian restaurant is also good and good price for the set lunch.

Stayed here for 3 nights on a business trip from the uk. After a long flight with a big lecture and not much sleep this hotel is fantastic. Very efficient staff, checking was swift and the room superb. The internet was fast and easy to connect. The Resturant is a little busy at breakfast, a bit of a wait for a table. But the food and selection was great, and the wait only about 5 minutes. The location couldn't be better and easy walk right into the heart of this fantastic city and for trips further afield the tube station is 150 yards away. Would stay here again any time.

The Cerulean hotel is super convenient to shibuya station and as a result easy to get to the airports.  The hotel itself is clean and staff are excellent.  The real plus for the cerulean is the spectacular views.  We had a sky view room which was great but if we were to stay there again we would get a city view room as the view in the evening was fabulous.

The Cerulean Tower in Shibuya, Tokyo is a spectacular hotel. The location is an ideal home base from which to explore Tokyo as it is situated in the heart of Shibuya with easy access to just about everywhere else in the city. The hotel itself is stunning and extremely well-put together. It is highly modern but has traditional Japanese touches everywhere, from the art work to the furniture to the linens. A higher-level room will provide an amazing view of Tokyo. The beds are comfortable and the linens luxurious. The bathroom is the best part though... very modern with all the amenities. It felt like my own private spa. The deep bathtub next to the window overlooking the city was a highlight and a place where I spent lots of time. Also, if you are in need of some late-night room service, I highly recommend the Hamburg Sandwich. It's their version of a hamburger, and it is de-licious!

This was a first class hotel. Stayed on a very high floor with a great view of Tokyo. The room was very spacious and clean. The bathroom was big and clean. Lots of windows in the room made for great views and spacious feel. This was 5 minutes walk from Shibuya station so it made moving about the city easy. Hotel staff was exceptionally helpful. They were quick with info, maps, and even umbrellas when it rained. I would stay there again, no question.

My wife and I love this hotel. We just stayed a few great nights in Kyoto and hoped our stay in Tokyo would be comfortable too. We were not disappointed. Check-in was super quick. Our reservation was found quickly, our bags sent from Kyoto were waiting for us. Since we booked through Expedia, we got an additional upgrade. Initially we booked a queen on the Sky Floors for a better view.... we were put in a deluxe king room on those Sky Floor. First thing you notice as you enter is that the room had nice size closet that fit all our large luggage. After that you see a nice size room with large bed and HUGE window with great view of Shibuya with Shinjuku in the distance. Angle your head and you can also see Tokyo Sky Tree.The bathroom was also amazing. We had a separate shower and tub. The tub was very deep with another HUGE window. Such an amazing view. From here we could also see Tokyo Tower easily.Room was super clean always. Very comfortable bed. Plenty of room for us when we spread our souvenirs out to check.The staff is always friendly and took care of every need we had from room service, to laundry service, even to help us ship boxes back home to the States.The hotel is very close to the JR Shibuya station. There is shopping very close. Just cross the street into the heart of Shibuya.Only few minor cons I can think of it that the sheets had a funny feel to them as though the soap wasn't completely washed out. The mini-bar was really expensive compared to the same available drinks less than a block away (330JPY for a can of Coke when you can get a bottle downstairs for about 150-180JPY). Of course, mini bar can be skipped, but the sheets had to be switched out. Very minor issue compared to how nice it was staying there.Would we stay here again? In a heartbeat.

I stayed few times in Cerulean for business.The breakfast is really good and fresh. Rooms are comfortable and clean.Staff need to make an effort to be more agreeable and provide a better service (specially for wellness/swimming pool). The overall atmosphere needs to become more friendly and comfortable.

Cerulean Tower Tokyu is in the bustling Shibuya area, very close to business centers, shopping malls, restaurants, subway and well connected to every corner of Tokyo. Hotel architecture is very modern and imposing. The hotel is huge with so many rooms that suit your budget and needs. Entrance lobby is large and has many counters at the front office, there are other counters to help you with local transport arrangements and other stuff. Rooms are elegantly designed, well lit and have all basic amenities. View from my hotel room was breathtaking with a sight of city’s skyline well illuminated at night, you can even spot mount Fuji on a sunny day. The hotel has a variety of restaurants serving authentic Japanese, Oriental, other Asian and Continental cuisine. Variety of fruits, breads and salads are on offer for breakfast. Being a conservative Indian veggie, I couldn’t try much though. Staff is friendly and courteous.Cerulean Tower is ideal for both business purposes and for leisure travel. Everything is expensive at Cerulean. Buffet breakfast costs in excess of 3,000 Yen & even internet access is charged, and then that's Tokyo, costliest mega city.

A great little find .... great location, hospitality and impeccable service, understated luxury and quiet way, perfect cleanliness and attention to detail, friendliness and courtesy ... everything and maybe even something more, very beautiful skyscraper in an enviable location close to the shopping streets .....Great service, clean, comfortable and in a great location, fantastic views of the city from the rooms higher up. Great staff, quick and informed for any need. Surely I will recommend to my friends.I was very happy to have been in this hotel.Stayed March 2013, traveled for business

We spent three night in this hotel and everything we needed was there.Very kind and warm staff, also very good English speaking, perfect location ideally close to the subway station, beautiful view (and we were "only" at 23th floor), clean and spacious room.It is a big hotel, if you are looking for a typical Japanese-style ryokan this is not the place, but you will find all the typical characteristics of Japanese and Tokyo style!
user_location: City of San Marino, San Marino

review_body: I stayed at the Cerulean for 6 nights in September with grandparents and a 6 year old. Our rooms was gorgeous, very spacious, huge king size bed, with separate dressing room for luggage. The bathroom was all marble, with a view over Tokyo, so no need to visit the Tokyo Sky Tree for a city observation. There is a window ledge where you can sit to watch the sun rise (depending on which side of the building you're on) which was just beautiful. We were on the 23rd floor. We were a 5 minute walk from Shibuya station which has access to both the Metro and JR lines providing seamless travel throughout Tokyo. It's also a stop for the Limousine Bus from Narita airport so there was no juggling with train stations on arrival in Japan, simply door to door service, 3000yen per adult, 1500 per child each way. I couldn't find fault with the room, the service, or the cleanliness, but it was devoid of any personal touches that you may get with a smaller hotel. Also, it seems ridiculous free wi-fi is not offered in the rooms. It is not cheap to stay at the 5 star hotel so surely the cost can be included in the room rate. It is available for about 1000yen I think for a 24 hr period. An early checkin was not available even though it was requested in advance, but they did accommodate us in the fitness centre where we could have a shower and change after an all night flight. Regarding the fitness centre too, under 18s are not allowed to use it, including the pool which I thought was too restrictive. Maybe it would be better to set aside certain hours where children may use the pool and not interfere with business guests so everyone could be accommodated. So all up, the hotel was superb, but not very family oriented or traveller oriented. There were no little extras provided, most likely because business travellers have an expense account and don't worry about the incidentals. I wouldn't stay here again, because I would like to try a different area, there are so many to choose from in Tokyo, and a more family friendly hotel would have been better.

This is a quite nice hotel. The check in process is smooth, the rooms are a bit small and understated (some might say outdated, although I din't mind the somewhat traditional decor) and the large bathtub/shower glassed is quite nice. The club lounge is very nice, although small, and with limited selections during happy hour and breakfast. There is a wonderful view of Mount Fuji from the club lounge on clear days! The service is friendly, but VERY slow, in the restaurant and bar on the ground floor and the lobby is a Zoo. Surprisingly not well layed out for the amount of people coming and going. The location is top notch for exploring Shibuya and Harujuku. The Shibuya train station is a 2 minute walk across the big pedestrian bridge. It's an easy ride on the shuttle bus to and from Narita, arrange for a ticket from the concierge (who is very friendly and efficient). All in all, a very comfortable and pleasant place to stay.

Our family of 5 (2 kids, 1 MIL), stayed in 2 rooms here 3 nights and the only minor problem was the air conditioner. The rooms were larger than our first Tokyo hotel, easily fitting a 3rd bed, and the bathrooms were immaculate. The views were fantastic - one room was a corner, so that was the best view. Service was excellent - when I noticed the room was warm, the workman told me they have sensors that turn off the AC when you leave the room. He disabled the sensor for us so it would stay cool, but that would be helpful to know in the future. We ate dinner one night in the Italian restaurant just outside the lobby, which was fine, and got breakfast every morning from the Circle K in the building. Staff was helpful trying to find a coin laundry for us. Fabulous location if you don't want to be right in the middle of Shibuya crossing, but still be able to get there in 5 minutes.

We just returned from a long weekend in Tokyo and stayed at the Cerulean for the first time. Convenient location, helpful / pleasant staff and amazing Tokyo view (32/f) were the highlights of our stay. Wifi was also provided at no charge for the duration of our stay.As noted by other reviewers, the property is showing some age and our non smoking room, while clean, did have a slightly musty cigarette smell to it. I think the rate was fair despite it not being a 5 star experience since you really are paying for location. You can always pay double the amount and stay at the Peninsula or Shangrila, but we decided since we didnt have the kids, it was fine for a quick shopping and eating excursion over a long weekend.

I've been sending my clients here for years and last week found myself staying there for a conference with them. Oh gosh... feel quite embarrassed to think this is what I've been recommending! From the outside, things seem quite nice... decent looking lobby and staff with a professional manner. And the location is great, in walking distance to the center of Shibuya, which is why I always recommend it. But once you get into the room things feel immediately disappointing. I paid over $300 for the night and expecting something that would reflect that price. Not so unfortunately. The carpet was stained, decor was beyond boring (no colour at all), room size was poor for the price, view wasn't even that inspiring. The shower room didn't have a fan and the toilet didn't have any of the latest functionality (if you're a visitor, you're seriously missing out if you don't try the latest in toilet technology whilst in town!).. I had forgotten my facial moisturizer but nothing in the amenity kit (in fact the amenities didn't look impressive at all). To top it all off, they didn't have free wifi!! Over $300 per night and they wanted to charge me for wifi!! Got to be kidding me. My client told me the next day he paid for it and that the reception was terrible. During our conference we also had to go without wifi as it was not available there. I'm semi-vegan and asked them where in the hotel I could get lunch. The answer was nowhere... so again, definitely not to an international standard.Even the service wasn't top notch. Not bad, but not nearly as good as what we've experience elsewhere in Japan for a lower price tag.We were totally unimpressed and will not be recommending this hotel to our clients again.

We stayed in this hotel for three nights when we just arrived in Japan. First of all, starting with the positive sided; the location is perfect and the breakfast buffet very good. But the room charge is substantially higher than it should be, the rooms are outdated and smelly. The rooms definitely need a renovation, especially when you charge 300 AUD per night. I would not recommend this hotel in Tokyo.

Recently stayed in the cerulean hotel on the first part of our japan trip. The room was nice size beautiful bathroom. Great location close to Shibuya subway station. Great gym and pool facility. Very pleasant and helpful staff, We shared a triple room. Three single beds . The biggest con of the hotel were the beds. The beds felt like we were sleeping on a box spring with no mattress. With springs poking up through . They were very uncomfortable. I talked to the front desk and they seemed very concerned . Putting a mattress pad cover for the next night. With really no difference in comfort. Maybe it is the bed configuration . Maybe I had the cheap room. We left the next day so did not pursue it any further. I can't imagine anyone could find those beds comfortable.

The service in Japan is really above expectations. The information desk helped us book for all our reservations and all the places we want to go to. We were always greeted when we entered and exited, even getting out of the elevator. There is a bit of walk to Shibuya Station, but the place is really 5-star so if you are the type to really relax in the hotel, then this is a good pace!I just didn't really like paying for the internet. This should be a given in 5 star hotels by now in Japan.

Stayed here for two days at the start of our trip. Great room, great views, decent restaurants, utterly spoiled by the management thinking it's 2003 - to get wifi access for *each day* I had to go down to the lobby and get a separate slip of paper with a password on *for each device*. That's 5 slips for the 5 devices my friend and I had between us.Each slip cost 1000jpy or so.. I dunno, maybe more, maybe less. The point is it's such a small fee compared to the room that I genuinely don't care. What I care about is not having a daily chore of collecting slips of paper to access something that in cheaper hotels is free.Towards the end of the trip stayed in an Urban Ryokan, just for the experience. Nice bonus? Free, unlimited wifi.It is unseemly to penny pinch, and it is stupid to inconvenience your customers. Charge me an extra 5k jpy per night and don't make me screw around to get the internet. It's like making me get a special password for the toilet, and a seperate one for the shower, for each person in the room, every day.

First time in Japan and I was very happy with the Cerulean towers. Yes the view from my room is awesome. Panoramic view for sure. But what really stands out to me is the service! Most of the employees can speak enough English to enable me to communicate (I only know thank you in Japanese!). And they are spot on with white glove treatment. When you come in there is always someone to greet and assist you (sometimes with a refreshing cool wash cloth) before you get to the front desk. If you call room service or anyone for service they are prompt! One time I called the front desk to ask about laundry facilities (they only have laundry service) and they sent someone up within minutes to pick up my laundry even though I had not requested it! I also had called down to inquire about an ice machine and they informed me that room service delivers ice. I said okay and hung up figuring it seemed to much of a hassle and would likely have to pay for it. Nope! Within 5 minutes room service was at my door with a bucket of ice delivered in very much a 5-star manner! Great room and roomy for Japanese standards from what I've been told and the bathrooms are awesome and appointed nicely. The only negatives: Well the beds are a bit hard; but I didn't have any problems sleeping. Also the carpets in the halls especially near our elevator were a bit worn but that pales in comparison the superiority of everything else. Oh yeah, yes the Tower bar rocks (had to pay $8pp for a window table instead of bar but view was worth it). Service awesome there too! And yes the 7-11 on the 2nd floor is convenient. BTW the Food Show (a grocery store with everything!) at the bottom floor of the Shibuya station is also nice when you are coming back and want some ready made food. One last thing, the gym is decent for a hotel gym. Just go from 6-7am which is free. Would definitely stay here again!

A great hotel on tokyo, certainly on the pricy side, but its worth it. The rooms are just great, i have stayed there now for several times, and every time i am amazed that every room looks different but has great comfort and luxury. The breakfast is great too, but continental and japanese is available. The staff is very attentive and service oriented. Access to tokyo is easy, staff is helping a lot with logistics and getting around.

The Cerulean towers was a very clean, friendly hotel to stay at bot for business and shopping in the Shibuya district of Tokyo. There is lots to see within walking distance and they have a great breakfast selection.

Tis hotel ticks every box in my book:- Rooms: roomy, great finishings and brilliant views for one of the most expensive sqm in the world- Service: along the expectations of a high-end hotel in Central Tokyo. Impeccable...- Location: located in the heart of Shibuya, minutes walk for the neon-buzzing district and its train station, you will not get a better positionI staid there repeatedly for a week every other month over 2 years for work, and I enjoyed every day of it, with my own room especially assigned to me every time I visited! Now that's service for you!!!

As a 12 year old boy, the Cerulean Tower Hotel was an ultimate Tokyo hotel. I've been learning Japanese for 10 years and Shibuya is exactly what you think of when you think of Tokyo. High buildings, fluorescent lights and iconic sights are all 5 minutes from the door of the hotel. The hotel itself is 40 storeys high with a sky bar at the top and awesome views of Shibuya, Shinjuku and even Mt Fuji!I would recommend this hotel to anyone traveling to Tokyo for it's position, views and friendly staff.Perfect for traveling with children.

We stayed here for 5 nights with our 6 year old son to visit Tokyo.The hotel is ideally located 5 minutes from Shibuya station with its several lines for an easy access to all tourist locations in Tokyo. There is a 7/11 with an ATM accepting foreign card so it's very convenient.The hotel itself is very fine. We took a king bed sky view room overlooking Shinjuku. During the day it's very pleasant, and it becomes amazing with the night falls.The room was spacious and spotless but the TV selection was limited as there were only japanese channels (but we did not go there to watch the television so that was ok).Service was excellent, everyone was very helpful and spoke fairly good English. They handled restaurant reservations, pointed us to stores, all this while being exceedingly friendly (the Japanese have a perfect sense of service).We were mislead to believe internet was quite expensive (more than 10000Y a day for cable access) whereas it is was free, so that was a pleasant surprise.All in all a perfect stay.

My Partner and I stayed here for 2 nights in July 2013, as frequent travellers we found that the service and facilities in this hotel could be rated above other hotels in a similar price range worldwide. The Japanese have a unique manner of service and at every point we were greeted and attended to in a warm, friendly and professional manner. Rooms were spacious and clean, and we had an excellent view. We transported to and from Narita Airport by Airport Limousine Bus which runs directly to the hotel, and is a good value option at 6000 yen return including a ticket on the Tokyo metro. Excellent facilities in the Fitness centre...massage chairs!!! Another positive is the location of the hotel, walking distance to Shibuya Station and surrounds. The only negative is paying for wifi approx $20US per day, however they did accommodate all devices for this price. We will be staying here on return trips to Tokyo.

Stayed once again there, everything was fine, staff perfect and cherries for breakfast a kill! Hope the rooms will be renovated, they are starting to look tired! Good location, close to subway stations, very helpful staff

This hotel is fantastic. It is right next to the JR station and is walking distance to everything in shibuya. The rooms very roomy considering we had previously stayed in a japan style hotel, these are western size accommodations. Out bathroom had a huge window where the tub was overlooking the city. I would and have recommended this hotel to anyone going to tokyo.

Stayed here in April 2013 with some friends during our trip to Tokyo. It is a really nice hotel and the service is great. The hotel itself is really easy to find, it is the tallest building, and it is located really close to the center of Shibuya. However the Wi-Fi could have been for free.

This is a great hotel located conveniently to the great shopping opportunities in Shibuya. It has excellent service, good breakfast and very nice view from the guest rooms. It's easy to get around as the station is just around the corner.

We stayed here for four nights. We got there early and got an earlier check in which was nice. I have stayed in many hotels and this is one of the best. Not just that The staff is so nice, they are nice every where in Japan. Everything about this hotel is good. They have a lovely breakfast buffe and the food is nice in the restaurants that we tried. The location of the hotel can not be better. So easy access to the train/metro station, max 5 min. We took the train from the airport and it was so handy. You get a card that takes you to the hotel and that is loaded with 1500 yen and is refillable. No rush on that train and stops at Shibuya station. Can not be easier. Someone said it would be hard to understand the train/metro system. It is dead easy, do not hesitate.The rooms are great size and with fantastic view and clean. The only thing was that one can tell it is mostly men travelling in Japan. If ypu wanted women toiletteries you had to ask and the schampoo was men smell. I solved that by using the products in the gym/pool. They had good products. Loved the gym and the pool except that you had to pay (free 6-7). I think that should be included on the other hand it was almost empty. The gym/pool is from 18yo, I liked that. No kids junping and screaming but maybe a minus if you have kids.You have to pay for internet too but not too much and it was fast. I tried to book a spa apointment when we arrived, i so needed one but they were full for the next days. So if you want to use it book in advance. Was a bit disapointed over that.This is the best area in Tokyo. There are so much going on and great shoping area. Easy to access the rest of the city. Lots snd lots of great reastaurants. We found that many good restaurants were in the basements. They do not have menues in English but that does not matter be wild and crazy and they try to explain as good as they can.I liked it so much so we cancelled our other hotel for when we get back from the trip around Japan and rebooked this one. I then tried to store a small bag to with things we bought but that was not possible. Done that in Thailand and there it is never a problem.

This is a very nice hotel. Customer service and cleanliness are impeccable. Most of the staff speak English. The hotel is expensive and the size of your average hotel room in the states with very nice amenities and very comfortable room. Hallways were hot but, I believe that was related to energy conservation and I assume the tsunami. It was like that all around Japan. Some of my family members stayed at Shibuya Excel hotel. Still nice but, I got to see the average hotel size in Tokyo which is half the size of a room at the Cerulean. We had two rooms with 3 in one and two in the other. Yes folks who are new to visiting Japan apparently most hotel rooms in Tokyo do not sleep 4 people. It worked out for my family because we had an extra adult traveling with us to house one of my kids. We took the Cerulean Airport Limousine Bus which drops you off at the front of the hotel. They were very organized getting everyone's luggage straight which I appreciated as we were all tired from the long flight. Airport bus transport is definitely more expensive than the train but, I most definitely would not have wanted to get on a crowded train to get to the hotel after a long flight. Shibuya Train station is a 5 minute walk away from the hotel across from East/West Mall near the Hachiko statue and the Shibuya Crossing which should be a requirement to cross at night just to experience the strangely organized chaos. Pay attention on the walking bridge. If you get confused just look up for the Cerulean towers and you will get your bearings. We were in Tokyo during a massive heat wave and one day I was by myself and felt like Chevy Chase in European vacation walking around on the bridge. I am going to blame it on dehydration. My only complaint would be the expensive WiFi and the gym is only free from 6am-7am in the morning. Any other time you have to pay along with the hotel bar. Restaurants in the hotel are also very expensive. I think we paid $12 for a coke which brings me to my love affair with the 7-11 right next to the hotel. You literally get off on the 2nd floor and head to the exit on the right staying right walking past the restaurant you come up to my beloved 7-11. This isn't just any 7-11 that you would see in the states. This place offers fresh fruit, salads, sandwiches, cold ramen and soba at very reasonable prices. We never ate in the hotel again and enjoyed one or more meals a day from the 7-11. I especially enjoyed the salads and sandwiches with lots of greens as I found it difficult at most restaurants to get lots of veggies. Trains are definitely worth taking getting around Tokyo. I was lucky enough to be with Japanese speaking people so it helped that they knew the transit system already. I think I would have had a hard time otherwise. If you get confused while managing the train system or a cab for that matter and the person does not speak English I found just showing the Japanese version of the website of the place I was going to on my phone helped the cab driver and the attendant at the train station. Can't wait to go back to Tokyo and stay at the Cerulean again!

The hotel situated in short walking area to shibuya shopping center. Room is average size but clean and well equipped. Breakfast is average. You can choose international buffet or traditional japanese breakfast set. Fitness is free only from 6.00am-7.00am. Try to wake up early!

This was my second stay at this hotel and I enjoyed it more than the first time. It's right in the heart of Shibuya and 2 min walk to the subway so it's easy to get around. Service is great and the room is luxurious especially the bathroom and bedding. My only complain is you need to pay for wifi which should be included at this level.

Very nice hotel in a great location. A bonus, the Airport Limousine Bus drops off right at the door of the hotel. It is more expensive than the train but you don't have to worry with your luggage at all! The staff was incredibly nice. The hotel impeccably clean. The rooms are good size by any standard. The bathroom was very nice, along with the amenities. The Shibuya train station is a 4 minute walk. Shibya Crossing is 5 minutes, where there are many shops and restaurants, including a couple of department stores. Just a couple of complaints. The internet and gym/fitness center are not included in the price of the room. In many other hotels in Shibuya, both of those are included. I will stay here again, given the opportunity.

stayed at this hotel for 2 nights! big spacious rooms with the most amazing bathroom. great view of the city. 2 minutes walk to train station and many restaurants and shops. great staff who spoke excellent English and were more then willing to help with any request, for example we wanted to go to Harry potter exhibition so they rang ahead for us to get tickets and organised a car there and back. also had English tv Channels. the only thing I would complain about was its expensive to use the gym/pool which seems to b a trend in Japanese hotels and no free wifi. I think with it already being quite expensive to stay in that little things like this should be taken into account. however other then that I loved the hotel and would recommend it if you are staying in this area

I wanted big views of Tokyo in Tokyo, and I got them at the Cerulean tower. The hotel was 5 star in every way -- large rooms, a gorgeous bathroom and a big picture window for the big view. It was rainy the week we stayed so I couldn't see Fuji but that wasn't the hotel's fault. The location in Shubuya is great and the sky bar is worth a visit to look down on the vibrant scenes at night. here are plenty of restaurants and coffee shops nearby: we didn't try the hotel food apart from a small snack the night we went to the bar. The service was unobtrusive but friendly. Overall a great stay for a fair price. I would stay again when visiting tokyo.

I wanted to stay in Shibuya and so we picked this one to start our 8 day trip. It is very new and modern, and has a 24 hour 7-11 just outside on the second floor, discretely hidden but really convenient at 1AM when I couldn't sleep. Just the 7-11 had me in awe, the cleanliness, customer service. I could barely figure out what the heck I was buying snack-wise, but still fun to walk around and shop. The room was very new and modern, great walk-in shower/tub room thing, amazing large window view. My only little complaint is they charged me for a coffee from the mini-bar ($4) which is standard in Tokyo, though, and the breakfast was expensive, like $30 - $40 a plate so my husband and I ordered one and split it. Great location for tour pickups for Viator tours. Great drop off spot for airport limo. In a business area near the Shibuya station, another sight to see at 8PM, jam packed. The "Times Square" type area in Shibuya is just about 1 or 2 blocks over, but we didn't know that until we stayed at the Excel hotel a few days later. High floor hotel bar was great, I got the soft shell crab, yum. Serious, modern atmosphere. Not too crowded in July, although it is very hot so maybe not too many tourists..?

The location is great -- close to lots of restaurants, transportation and convenience stores. Customer service was VERY good. The decor was new and clean, but nothing elaborate. The room was big for Japanese standards with a very large bathroom. We could see Mt. Fuji from our room! Although everything was wonderful, it seems like this is more of a business-type hotel rather than a place for romance.

This is our second stay at the Cerulean Tower in Shibuya It is a really lovely hotel, well appointed, comfortable and well located. The staff are impeccable and nothing is too much trouble. I will hopefully be back for a third stay soon!The concierge recommended Teppanyaki Hakushu just near the hotel - i will write a separate review for it - but if you have a free night and want a treat, go there. Its small, authentic and the food is very very Oishi! (delicious).

We stayed 4 nights. The location was very good. The staff friendly, they spoke ok english. The consierge was nowhere to be found! Furniture needs an update. We tried to go to the rootop bar and it was always full. We had dinner in the japanese restaurant and food was BAD.

I really wanted to give this a 5, I did! The hotel is lovely, the service staff are very friendly and helpful, the room we stayed in was outstanding and we were close to everything! The only problem was the attitude in the fitness centre! So many little rules that for a modern international hotel really doesn't stand up! Such a pity because the hotel has a lot going for it!It is quite pricy but I would recommend it to friends!

Stayed in executive floor for 3 nights. Very comfortable and large room with fantastic views over Tokyo. Breakfast included was reasonable although a little limited in scale and scope. Service generally attentive and helpful. One black mark was additional cost of pool/gym with multiple pedantic rules applied fairly officiously by fitness club staff. A shame because pool was lovely after hot day, but few use it because of cost and fussy rules. I would stay here again although the Excel where we stayed earlier in the trip was better value for a lower cost and closer to the station.

We stayed in a triple City view room for 5 nights. The room was spacious for Tokyo, and we especially loved the bathroom. The shower was amazing. The service was exceptional. The concierge helped us make restaurant reservations, gave us directions and rented our umbrellas daily. We had free wifi included in our room rate which was very helpful. The only downside is that it is not easy to reach the hotel if you have many suitcases. The walk to/from the Narita Express is quite long. Next time I will catch the airport shuttle instead so you are dropped right outside the hotel (though the N'Ex and Suica card combo was a better deal).

We enjoyed staying at Cerulean. The family room we had was very gorgeous & spacious with a fabulous view of the city and mt.Fuji. The location is great, a few min walk to the metro station and walking distance to the botanical garden. My daughter had misplaced her stuffed toy animal in the room. The manager personally bought her a gift and apologised- even though it wasn't his fault. They later found it and posted it to us all the way to France. Talk about great service, I mean how many hotels would go out of their way to do this. Lots of places to eat around Shibuya. The area comes alive at night, it's magical. I just love Tokyo. Cerulean hotel will always be my no.1 choice.

This upscale spot is located closely to the heart of Shibuya, albeit directly besides the highway. However, no noise impact since the rooms are splendidly sound-protected. Overall, a very comfy place to stay. However, the full range of services from breakfast to restos to gym... seems overpriced considering the room rates.

Shibuya is one of the best area to stay in Tokyo..lively and full of bars , restaurants and shopping mecca! just walking distance from Shibuya Station. not easy to reach the hotel if caring suitcases, better to get at the hotel with limo bus service from Narita Airport. Otherwise you can take Narita Express train to Shibuya then a short taxi drive to the hotel . friendly atmosphere although they don't easily upgrade you even if you are a regular guest. "OLI" the Italian restaurant at the hotel serves a good selection of pastas ( cooked al dente ) and many other good dishes. If for a business trip the hotel is very convenient location wise.

Shibuya is the best area to stay in Tokyo, it has a great atmosphere and this hotel is 5 min walk from the station, and is served by the airport limo bus service which drops you off right at the door from the airport, so saves getting the Narita Express and having to carry your bags from the local station. It really is a fantastic hotel for the money, a proper 5* hotel with all the trimmings, you could easily pay double elswhere in Tokyo for the same standard. The buffet breakfast's are a must, quite expensive but brilliant - Anywhere that serves feshly squeezed orange juice is ok by me!

I really enjoyed staying in this hotel with a spectacular view on the city from my 27th floor room. I was very lucky to see Mt. fuji from the window on the morning I left the hotel -could have stayed there all day!The staff was very helpful although when I asked the front desk staff how to reach Haneda airport by subway the first words I heard back were 'Are you staying in this hotel?'Anyhow I was indeed and got my explanations; To go to haneda from the hotel location, you can either take a shuttle bus that is more expensive and takes more time than catching the subway followed by the monorail line to the airport. Or take a taxi - but I assume this is even pricier.

Travelling with my husband and 3 daughters aged 23, 22 and 20 Shibuya was the only place I considered when searching for a hotel. We always stay in areas where all the action is and you can't beat Shibuya for the restaurants and shops and transportation.Because we were getting two rooms one to be triple-shared I wanted to make sure that my 3 girls would be comfortable. It's quite hard to find good-sized rooms in Tokyo so when I found Cerulean in my search I knew this was the hotel for me. The room was big (about 30sqm) and the bathrooms were perfectly-sized. I considered another hotel to book but what clinched it for me (although the Cerulean cost $100 more per room) was the fact that the shower was separate from the tub. We all know that Tokyo is the cleanest city and all hotels would be very clean but I just don't trust tubs. The bathroom was large and tastefully-designed. Ask for the Shu Uemura pack which has makeup remover and toner. They didn't have body lotion though which was unfortunate for me as I forgot mine and lotions are incredibly expensive in Tokyo!The concierge was always very helpful. We would ask for directions everywhere and he or she would always take pains to make sure we would find what we were looking for. Have dinner in Gonpachi which is a 5-minute walk from the hotel. We all loved the atmosphere of this Izakaya and their sakes were superb.

The Mrs. and I stayed here on the 24th floor facing the city (great view especially during sunset) for 2 nights on our recent vacation to Japan. The hotel is located in a pretty convenient location close to tons of shops, restaurants, and a few blocks from the Shibuya train station. Shinjuku or Shibuya are the best locations to stay in Tokyo for vacation. They have wifi in the rooms (it was free for us as a promotion but they seem to charge typically as noted when you sign-in for the first time). Also, to use the swimming pool and fitness center there's an additional charge so we did not use either.The room was pretty clean and spacious relative to other hotels in the area which was expected considering the premium we paid. The condition of the room was good, the bed & pillow was comfortable, and the towels were soft. Customer service was very attentive even compared to the other hotels we stayed at in Japan. (My experience has been that all the hotels seem to have good customer service especially compared to high-end hotels in the U.S.). In additiona, Housekeeping was superb. It's nice that there's a 7-11 convenience store located at the building. A major plus is that the Cerulean is a stop on the Limousine Bus service to and from the airports so we didn't have to deal with paying a ton for a taxi or lugging our suitcases and backpacks to and through the train station on our way home. It's only 3000 Yen per person and was stress-free.Overall, our stay at the Cerulean was a great one. For the price, I feel that it's worth the premium if you can afford to splurge a little bit. I have no big complaints thus I highly recommend it.

A great hotel centrally located in the bustling district of Shibuya. As a woman on my own I found the area very safe.There are three main reasons to stay here:1. Shibuya is central and a good place to be. The train station is minutes from the hotel. It's also at the end of the line making it easy to find. 2. The limo express (airport bus) travels directly to this hotel. It makes commuting in and out of the city a breeze. 3. The views. Every corner of this hotel exudes a stunning view to rival even the much talked about Park Hyatt.In addition to this, the staff are truly wonderful and the rooms are spotless with minimal decor. The hotel would have been perfect if the beds were more comfortable (it was like sleeping on wood) and if wifi had been free. If you can, sign up to Starbucks free wifi in advance and head to their coffee shop in Shibuya by the crossing. It's fast and free!This is a great hotel and much like the people of Tokyo, make you feel very welcome.

The room at the Cerulean was great. It was well kept and the view was amazing. At check in we were upgraded to a higher floor (thus the great view, see picture). The beds were comfortable and the room was very clean.Pros: Great Location, Friendly Staff, Nicely appointed roomCons: Extra cost to use the pool, extra cost for WiFi, extra cost to go to rooftop bar.Then again you cant avoid these extras in Tokyo.

Service was 5 star. Room was nothing special, but was big, clean, great view of shibuya, huge bathroom. I was traveling with a friend and the room was not uncomfortable for 2 people with tons of stuff. The location was very convenient for puttering around in Tokyo, and overall seemed like a good value at the price we paid. I would stay here again on my next trip.

I was here on business travel for 4 nights in this hotel. I stayed on the 35th floor with sky view. It was the room nearest to the executive salon. The bedroom is one of the largest in Tokyo that you can find. The housekeepers are polite and attentive to my needs. As there are too many pillows on the bed for one person, I left them at the side and on the couch. On the following day, the housekeeper left the extras aside(saves me the effort to remove them from the bed). It is at a great location as it is a 5 mins walk to JR Line and Metro. Also, you are 5mins away from food haven and Shibuya Crossing! There are several restaurants and convenience store just next to the hotel. There are a airport limousine buses from/to Narita and Haneda Airport. Though it is on the high end for pricing, it is definitely one of the most comfortable hotel in Tokyo!

Convenient by location, walking distance from Shibuya station, nice rooms, very good service - Japanese standard at its best.Breakfast is a bit dissappointing for the little offer of food, even though the very fresh orange juice can make up for it, and also the lunch offer (same restaurant as breakfast) is not so wide.I find it a bit too pricey and I think they should provide free wifi, for all the devices you have (the first device might be free of charge, but they charge you the other ones).I wonder why in 2013 in a modern country wifi is at charge!

We decided to splurge on a 5 star hotel and picked the Cerulean Tower. It was magnificent. The room was the sky view (31st floor) and we had a corner room queen with a side window and large bay window overlooking Tokyo. The room was large, and very comfortable. You are a 5 minute walk to the Shibya crossing and all the amazing streets and shops. Also, the station is located there so you have access to all the sights. A fine place to splurge. The only issue is you have to pay $21 to use the pool/exercise room per day. And a $15 a day Wi Fi charge is utterly ridiculous. If you want people to return, you don't nickel and dime when they are already paying a large amount. Aside from that, it was a beautiful hotel!

The Cerulean is my preferred hotel in Tokyo because of its location, service, and ambience. It's a short walk from Shibuya station, which is on several subway lines, the Yamanote JR line, the Narita Express, the Shinkansen, and offers good connections to the rest of greater Tokyo. It is also in the Shibuya district, which has a variety of restaurants, clubs, and other nightlife. The hotel is slightly expensive, and the restaurants in the hotel are rather expensive, but it's very easy to eat elsewhere. Some of the rooms offer views of Mt. Fuji, and all of them look out over Tokyo. The rooms are quite large, and the upscale corner rooms are like a small suite. I like being able to get a king sized bed easily. The staff all speaks good english. The lounge for the rooms above the 32nd floor (concierge rooms) has a nice view but is only so-so.My only complaint is that the gym is somewhat small. It's bettter than most American hotels but worse than the full-service gyms you can find in Southeast Asia. The gym is free between 6 and 7 AM. Also, like most Japanese hotels, you can't drop off laundry after 5 PM, so if you need something pressed for the next day, you had better arrive early. No irons in rooms, also typical for Japan.

For starters, I confess that because my office is literally in the same building as the Cerulean, it would be silly not to stay at this property every time I'm in Tokyo. That said, if cost was not an issue, I would like to stay there anyway simply because the location is unbeatable. To me, hotel is like any other real estate: location, location, location.As for the facilities, rooms, service and all that jazz, well it's right up there with any top end business hotel. I wish the rooms could be bigger, but frankly having stayed at the Hyatt and the Hilton in nearby Shinjuku, their room sizes are about the same so it's that's all even. There's no wow factor about the Cerulean except the view of the most famous intersection east side of Times Square. On a clear day depending on which side of the hotel you are, you might even get a glimpse of Mt. Fuji.

First of all the hotel. Great hotel, Very nice very clean only a little expensive. The bar on the top floor has awesome views and I would definitely recommend a visit for a drink or two. We went for a room facing Mount Fuji and were lucky enough to have a amazing view of the mountain on a clear day. We managed to get upgraded to a corner room which – for Tokyo standards – was massive. Now about the area: Shibuya is now one of my favorite places in the world. There is such a chilled out party atmosphere. Its got great metro connections so you can get yourself to anywhere within Tokyo relatively easily. I was not 100% sure whether I should stay here or the Excel Shibuya. In the end I chose the Cerulean Tower because in a couple of reviews I had read that the Excel are very strict on their 2pm check-in time and we were due to get into Tokyo at 7am. We ended up checking into our room at 10am and the reception staff gave us a room without any problems. If its your first time I would recommend hotel swapping at least once. Tokyo is such a amazing place it would be a shame not to stay in a couple of the different districts.

We stayed in a corner tower room for 6 nights. The view from 34th floor towards Shibuya crossing, Shinjuku and Mt Fuji are to die for. Room was huge for tokyo conditions, bathroom had an extra windows next to the tub so the nice view can be enjoyed whilst having a shower. Rooms were very clean and very well maintained. Lounge serves breakfast from 6- 10 am and a selection of alcoholic drinks from 5-8 pm, both ok bot nothing to write home about.Service is professional and very friendly.Location is extremly suitable, just 5 minutes walk to Shibuya´s JR Station and Shibuya shopping/dining area.This is one of our favorite hotels in Tokyo ( this was our 4th visit) and we will definitly come back.

Loved the hotel and the views, clean and large room , nice service , would recommend this hotel without any doubt. In a strategic place in the city to move from a place to another, From the Shibuya station you can take the shinkanzen lines too.

I've stayed at plenty of Tokyo hotels for business. This nearly tops it. Location, room size, service, cleanliness...etc all excellent. 3 minute walk to shibuya station, executive floor with complementary snacks and drinks in the evening. Great hotel

The service at this hotel is superb. The rooms are clean and modern. We stayed at the hotel at the beginning of our trip in a "Sky View Floor" category room, which are floors 25-32, and at the end of our trip in a "Tower Floor" category room on the 33rd floor. Our Sky View room was facing Shibuya station while our Tower Floor room faced the opposite way. The bathroom in the Sky View Floor room was better (had a shower and bathtub) while the Tower floor room only had a tub. The location of the hotel is excellent - it's very close to a major train station and one of the busiest street crossings in Tokyo (Hachiko). Lots of things to do in the area, you could spend a week just exploring the surrounding blocks. Many restaurant and entertainment options nearby. The hotel also has a 7-11 in the building which was very handy, both for withdrawing cash and for a late-night snack. I highly recommend this hotel. The hotel also offered a bus to the airport.

If you are looking for amazing views over the bright lights of Shibuya then I think Cerulean Tower would be hard to beat. I stayed in a wonderful large deluxe twin with city views, one of the most bizarre experiences I had was lying in the enormous bath looking out of the bathroom window over the lights of Tokyo. Amazing views taking in Roppongi, Shibuya crossing, and Shinuku. Close to Shibuya station and the bars and shops of Shibuya.

I stayed for 4 nights. Highly recommendable. Nice staff. Very professional. It's worth doing the upgrade for the executive floor and have breakfast or a drink at the 35th floor. Very quiet. It's close to everything but apart from all the noise that you won't like to have at night. As the city is extremely safe the is no problem walking the streets at any hour.With the upgrade you will be able to check out even from there and in case you have a late flight (my case) you will be able to leave the luggage there and even take a shower before leaving.

I stay at the Cerulean Tower whenever I visit our Japan office. I find the hotel has excellent service, great views, nice restaurants and excellent work out facilities (great pool and spa). The bar at the top is an excellent place for a night cap, but does get smoky. If you're into cigars, that's great, if not you might want to find your views elsewhere.

If you want to get an insightview into Japanese lifestyle - and a glimpse into the future - there is no other place than Shibuya. And to immerse, stay there in the nicest hotel, which is the Cerulean Tower Hotel, a five star accomodation on the edge of Westen - Japanese style hotel. The best are the views. If you are lucky, you can see Mount Fuji. But in fact, all directions are are interesting and extraordinary.Rooms are a nice size, depending on the price you are willing to pay. Staff is f´very friendly and accoodating. Breakfast buffet is a very good deal. But you can also walk to Starbucks across the famous Shibuya crossing in front of Shibuya station and to satisfy your coffee addiction.There is a lovely swimming pool in the hotel as well as a good gym and a typical Japanese hot o-furo (bath) in the changing room.We have been staying at the Cerulean a number of times, and we were never disappointed.

We were upgraded, that s always a good start! Very nice and professional staff. The look of the rooms is a bit old fashioned to me however I did appreciate the perfect quietness and comfort of the room. tokyo is exhausting and it very nice to have a place were you can really rest. . We had a view on the city, there is a wide baywindow in the bathroom Shibuya is a good location to explore Tokyo.I

My wife and I had the privilege of staying at this hotel during a weekend visit to Tokyo to meet my mother-in-law who was on business at the time from the USA. This was my 2nd visit to Japan but my first time spending time in Tokyo. The hotel is located in the Shibuya district about 5 minutes walk/ 3 minute taxi ride. Shibuya is a lively and trendy part of town with plenty of shopping, eating, and entertainment. Everything about this hotel was excellent. The reception staff were very friendly upon check in and handed us a hand-written note from my mother-in-law who had arrived a few hours earlier than we did telling us when and where to meet. We stayed in a king room on the 32nd floor with an amazing view of the city. The room was perfect in every aspect. Clean comfy sheets, two types of pillows, and soft mattress, nice TV, WiFi worked perfectly, mini-bar stocked with a nice variety of drinks. The bathroom was immaculate and was quite big considering the room size. Separate shower and bathtub, huge vanity and sink space, and of course the wonderful Toto Washlet heated toilet. We ate at the breakfast buffet twice, which was very nice. Decent, but not excessive variety of food. Mainly western-style. We really enjoyed the fresh squeezed orange juice made to order. For dinner we asked the concierge for suggestions and directions to nearby places and were very happy with their suggestions. Our favorite was a casual Japanese restaurant about 5 minutes walk, which featured yakitori, sushi and full service bar. The pool and fitness center were superb as well. Pool and huge hot tub have large windows with views of the city. Sauna and showers were super clean and always had everything perfectly organized and ready for use. I used these facilities twice and both times I was the only person in the pool, which was very relaxing.Overall, this was an amazing stay at this hotel in Tokyo. I have zero complaints about this hotel and would recommend it to anyone looking for a luxury business hotel in Shibuya. I hope I can be lucky enough to stay here next time I am in Tokyo.

My first time in downtown Tokyo. I took the excellent bus service from Narita and was checked in early with minimum fuss. I had been warned that Tokyo hotel rooms are tiny, not here. Everything in the room was just fine with a great view of the city. Staff were very friendly and eager to help. My only small tick was the breakfast service being guided to the table next to the screaming kid throwing itself on the floor, when the place was almost empty, was a bit strange. May be they expected a rush. It was quickly sorted though. You could stay here all day every day with so many different things to see and do. Venturing out into the evening city turmoil was an adventure, one I hope to repeat very soon.

We are a family with 3 boys (4/6/11 yrs) We stayed in a triple room with city view for 4 nights from April 12-16 2013. Our room is on the 21st floor; the room is spacious and bathroom is nice. The 3 beds in our room are twin beds. The third one is a real bed not the extra bed so it was comfy. There was still room for a baby cot but we didn't get to use it. The view from our room is a plain boring city view. We arrived at late night and the female porter was very helpful. Check in and check out was quick because we prepaid for the room. The hotel is well located. it's 5 minutes away from Shibuya JR station. You just walk out the hotel and cross the street to reach the station. The hotel is, however, not in the middle of Shibuya area. There's a nice soba restaurant near the hotel in case breakfast in not included in your stay. The airport shuttle bus stops at the basement which makes it very convenient for us.The down side is there was no complimentary bottled water in room and you have to pay for aboyt 1000 yen/day for WIFI which was quite disappointing. You could ask for travel size Shisedo cosmetics sets rom the housekeeper. But I would rather have a bottled water :)Information desk staff is helpful. I would consider staying here again because of its location and spacious room. Though I would rather be closer to Shibuya crossing if possible.

A very comfortable hotel in the heart of Shibuya. We stayed for 2 nights on our arrival in Tokyo and had a spacious triple room with an amazing view and excellent bathroom. The building is an amazing landmark so we found it very useful if we happened to get lost in the streets around Shibuya.

The hotel is 5 minutes away from the JR station and within walking distance to all the shops, restaurants, bars in Shibuya. We liked the bar on the top floor which had fantastic views of the city and very capable bartenders. The concierge provided great local restaurant recommendations which we appreciated. The room and bathroom were spacious and clean but somewhat tired. The negative for us was that you needed to pay to access the swimming pool.

The Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel is certainly deserving of its 5-star rating! Located in Shibuya, it is a 1.5 hour (weekday traffic condition) journey from the Narita Airport via the Narita Limousine service. The JR station is a mere 5 min walk from the Hotel and the major shopping areas of Shibuya are nearby. I stayed on level 26 in a corner room. The room is clean and relatively spacious, especially the bathroom. I am pretty particular when it comes to hotel bathroom, and I must say that Cerulean Tower did not disappoint. There is a luxurious feel to the bathroom and one can look at the skyline while taking a soak in the bath tub. The bed is okay and decently good but not the most comfortable I have experienced. The staff are extremely polite and proactive, and never failing to bow to guests when they return to the hotel. I did not try the eateries in the hotel but there is a good and affordable Soba eatery very near the hotel. If there is one thing I like least, it must be the lack of free wi-fi in the hotel. Even the lobby does not provide free wi-fi. Overall, I still recommend the hotel highly for the comfort and the good service.

I recently stayed at the Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel for 6 nights whilst we took a city break. The hotel is spotlessly clean, the staff are attentive and it is in a fantastic location close to Shibuya station and ample restaurants and convenience stores.We booked via Expedia and had a twin non smoking room on the 22nd floor, the views were brilliant and the beds were very comfy with a choice of two pillows. The room is cleaned daily if requested and you are given a robe and slippers as well as copious amounts of toiletries! As many other reviews state, the rooms are very big as is the bathroom.Each day we decided to source our own meals, sometimes purchasing snacks from the 7eleven which is accessible via the escalator near the entrance. Most of the action is over the bridge from the hotel, 5 minute walk.There is a Tully's coffee shop and excellent food hall at the Tokyu department store ( it makes Selfridges look poor!). I'd also recommend the Ginza cozy corner which served amazing chiffon cakes. We managed to eat well each evening for between £8-£10. Shibuya has every food type you could wish for, we stuck to the Japanese options which included an amazing sushi place where you order via touch screen and it arrives on a track! There are the usual KFC and McDonalds for those less adventurous!It is easy to get around and the station gives you easy access to the main sites. We took the limousine service to and from the airport, it costs 3000 yen, which is around £24 pound each way. It is convenient and drops you off outside the hotel. You should pre book your return journey though.The staff at the hotel spoke good English, they booked us a visit to a tea ceremony and helped us locate tube stations aswell as providing us with local area maps. I couldn't fault them, they also gave me some plasters when I'd hurt my foot. I am pleased that I chose this hotel. There are many facilities we didn't use as we were on a budget and wanted to sample what Shibuya had to offer.

I have just returned from my first trip to Japan!This hotel is vast and in many ways is great. I will start with these:1) Organisation and friendless is paramount. Everyone smiles all the time, checking in and out is swift and the information desk bends over backwards to help however big or small the query. Everything is incredibly well organised with porters eager to help with luggage too and from your rooms, to the coach- airport luggage ticketing system (a must if travelling from Narita airport) about £25 its easy, direct and perfectly organised, leaving from outside the hotel.2) The breakfasts are AMAZING!! At £21 it isn't cheap (the hotel in general isn't) but you can have a fully cooked breakfast (sausage, egg, toast etc) and the egg is cooked in front of you so you can choose how to have it. I asked for a hot chocolate (instead of tea or coffee which was no problem and delicious) a selection of juices (again squeezed in front of you) cold meats, cereals, and icy cold selection of fruit. I was totally stuffed after eating as much as possible and really set me up for a full days sight seeing.3) The rooms - We were very lucky to be upgraded to a corner room on floor 25 where both the bedroom (2 windows) and bathroom (1 window) had sweeping views of the city below. They are a nice size, with walk in showers and extreamly comfortable beds. There is a nicely hand drawn "map" of the landscape so you can identify various buildings from your room (and maybe Mt Fuji on a clear day) which is also a nice touch. Room service and laundry is impeccable, room ordered breakfast comes and exactly the time its ordered and any maintenance involving your room (we couldn't get the CD player to work) a porter is sent up to help immediatly.On our return from Kyoto, we stayed at The Cerulean again and were upgraded for a second time on to the 34th Business floor which granted a smaller non corner room but smarter smellies and an extra table.4) Attached to the hotel is a Seven11 which was very handy for water, coffee and the best cheesecake in the world- a must try really!!The not so great..1) For English speakers, the TV choice is poor and we struggled to find a music station or news channel that was understandable. There is also no I pod docking station but they do have CD players2) The swimming pool you have to pay for which I thought was unacceptable. As a paying guest, this should be a luxury that everyone could enjoy. We actually ran out of time to even try it, but when I popped up to have a look at it, it was completely deserted and I'm not surprised!3) They have (amongst others I think) a few restaurants in the hotel. A word of warning...DO NOT BOTHER with the Japanese one. It was empty, we had to wait 45 mins for ANY food to arrive, the portions (when they did) were tiny and HUGELY over priced for what was served. We all left disappointing, hungry and few pounds lighter. This is NOT a bench mark for most restaurants in Tokyo. However, both the Chinese looked buzzy and the Italian lively and with a neat interior which both (although we didn't try) would have probably been better options if eating at the hotel.4) Although the staff are attentive, helpful and continuously smiling, this is a very large hotel with office space in the middle taking up about 13 floors so the volume of empty space in the entrance can often feel overwhelming and pointless.
