The general style of the entrance is slightly old fashioned (I think) but is their attempt at modern with a traditional Japanese twist. It's obvious from the website that it is large so if big is not you you then neither is this hotel.IN CONCLUSION: A very enjoyable stay and would highly recommend :-)

I was on business and decided to stay at this hotel on a recommendation - it did not disappoint. Clean, spacious rooms with fantastic views of the city, faultless service and excellent room service (though I'd skip the tempura). The iced coffee at breakfast was the perfect way to beat the jet lag, with better pastries than you'd find in a patisserie.The concierge could not help me enough as I planned my day off in the city, writing phrases in Japanese, the price of tickets and idea on a route - fantastic.

We stayed in this hotel for 5 nights in a standard room and it was great. Rooms are big and very clean with a great view of Tokyo. Service was excellent and you get a treatment of a 6 star hotel. Location was the best only 5 minutes walk to Shibuya station and shopping area. The other plus was the 7eleven convenient store just beneath the hotel. All in all I highly recommend this hotel.

This is the hotel location you need to be in to experience the true pulse of tokyo. A couple of minutes walk from the famous shibuya crossing and heart beat of tokyo. The hotel lived up to my expectations, a true 5 star environment, great staff, and the best of it all, beautiful comfortable rooms with the perfect city views. I stayed on the 27th floor, I highly recommend this hotel if you are on holiday or business to this amazing city.

The Hotel is located in Shibuya just across the bridge from Shibuya station.The hotel is modern with large rooms but here are a few problems with the hotel that make me wonder why it is a 5 star hotel??1-No charger connectivity near the bed which means you must charge your phone on the TV table which is not a good idea.We tourists come from different time zones and would like to chat with our friends and families while resting on the bed not while sitting and charging the phone near the TV, Very uncomfortable!2-Free gym access is from 6:00 - 7:00 am, after that you are charged 2300 Japanese Yen! I was frustrated to have to pay every single day to access the gym during my 11 night stay! I am not obliged to wake up at 6:00 am to access the gym while being on holiday! 2300 Japanese Yen for gym only and if you wanted to access the swimming pool extra charges apply. No water bottles or water drinking machine at the gym, very frustrating.3-No free water bottles in the room.4-No free internet access, either daily or weekly charges! 5-No free coffee in the room, instead they have chargeable drip coffee ready cups6-Breakfast buffet is very basic and not of a 5 star hotel, my reservation was without breakfast but i visited the buffet to have a look and i score it 4 out out of 10Overall i am disappointed in this hotel and before booking in it i advise you to read my review

Modern hotel. Large rooms with spacious bathroom. Get a high floor so you have a great view of Tokyo by night. 5 minutes to shibuya station where you can connect via JR rail to airport. The walls are soundproof as you do not hear noises from other guests or from persons above you or below. Overall great value and excellent service.

Other than the hospitality, one thing that I love so much about this hotel is the spacious room. I stayed in the triple room, or double with an extra bed. And there's still space for our big luggage. I also love the big bathroom.

Very nice clean hotel with wonderful staff. The noise from Shibuya below drifts up, but is not horribly distracting. Easy walk to Shibuya Station and the Hachiko Plaza, along with all the Shibuya shopping.

I've stayed many times at this hotel and found it to be a very good hotel. Staff are always friendly and professional with a good level of English. It is well located to Shibuya Station (take south exit and use the above road pathways over the main road - no stairs if you can find the escalator just outside the station). The rooms are very nice and a good size by Japanese standards. The beds are very comfortable and the rooms are always clean and quiet. All the restaurants around the hotel offer high quality food but if you can manage it there are many restaurants nearby which offer better value. The gym is good.... and free if you arrive between certain hours in the early morning. The pool is also very good but a charge applies. The bar on the top floor is a great place for a drink with a view but if you prefer a quick cheap beer you can always pick a can or two from the 7-Eleven downstairs.

Excellent service. Great business hotel! Rooms are comfortable to work in (desk, chair, wifi). Close to lots in heart of Shibuya. 4 minute walk to train station. 20 minute walk to Yoyogi Park. Great buffet breakfast; good for breakfast meetings. Great (but pricey) restaraunts in the hotel if need to entertain business clients. One down side: lobby bar stops serving at 930P.

recommended by friends, it was a great choice. Perfect location for a quick 36 hour stopover in Tokyp. Wonderful staff - thanks for unexpected upgrade and late check out. All staff very professional and pleasant , and helpful. Huge bathroom. Japanese 'washing ' toilet. Only negative - and quite minor, but a charge for wifi internet - even the tea and coffee in the room.

This is my second stay here. I was fortunately upgraded and my room was terrific. Staff is really great and they make westerners feel very comfortable. You cannot beat the location to the train station but also just to walk around Shibuya.

We stayed at the Cerulean a few times throughout January 2013. It's lovely and close to Shibuya station and the crossing. The Cerulean staff are what really made our trip special - it was an absolute pleasure to deal with the concierge (Yoko and Naoko) even before we arrived they helped me to plan and book some unattainable restaurants, Sumo wrestling and the Kabuki. Without them our trip wouldn't have been nearly as special - thank you!The room service is also lovely at this hotel - great silver service. However, the breakfast downstairs in the morning is pretty average. They would do better to put it on a higher level like the Park Hyatt does. Would definitely recommend a drink upstairs at the bar for sunset - you can get great views to Mt Fuji when it's clear.Beware - book through Expedia as you get between 30-40% off the normal hotel room rate as we found out when we wanted to stay an extra day.

Easy for me to say as I didn't fork out the money to stay here. I've been in less pricey places (again, paid for by work) that have been much better experiences. Eating here is a strange experience in that they don't seem to get the concept of ordering a main meal and then following up with dessert (that is, they have desert on the menu, but they bring you the bill after the main course, which makes you think that perhaps you should have ordered it all in one go!) Small beer in the scheme of things. Location is great, 2 mins to Shibuya crossing and the Metro, and thence to anywhere in Tokyo. Rooms are basic, TV is 99% Japanese so if you wanted to take in a Western movie or just relax you're pretty much stuck with the odd programme from Fox!

Location was ok - its not really in the 'main' part of Shibuya, but its not so far away from Metro, Shibuya crossing and the other key streets/area. All walkable.Rooms are a bit tired and plain - you could do a lot better for the price by going for something more 'boutique'.We chose Cerulean primarily because it was a fixed drop-off point for the airport shuttle for both Narita and Haneda (very quick and cheap transfers) as well as being in an area we hadn't stayed before.Very nice high-floor bar with fantastic views of the city - a bit stuffy though with the staff trying to present a 'we are a high class establishment' attitude.Charging for Wifi? Seriously? We stayed and ate at lots of other places in Japan and always WiFi was free - like the air you breathe! Not sure why a Tokyo hotel is persisting with this very old-school, stingy approach to what is now a basic service.Overall I say Cerulean is 'solid'. I wouldn't call it an intimate or luxurious place though!

This isn't the cheapest hotel in Shibuya, but it does have the best location whilst still offering good value for your money. The accomodation starts on a high floor, so even though you are right in the action, you wouldn't know it. The best part about this hotel is that the limousine bus connects you straight to Haneda or Narita airports. A trip to Haneda will only cost you 1,000 yen, cheap compared to the 22,000 yen taxi fare for the same trip!

Stayed here (standard King City view) for 5 nights in Feb 13 with my wife and 2 kids aged 6 and 4. Hotel provided extra bed, and still plenty of space left in the room for luggages etc. Bath is spacious and quite luxurious. Good view from the room, on a clear day we can see Mt Fuji. TV selection was poor for English programmes, so the TV was rarely switched on. Room service was ordered for dinner and breakfast once. The quality was poor and prices was expensive. Easy to dine out as the hotel is 5 minutes walk away from Shibuya station, also behind the hotel there's a few eateries as well. Just to add, the hotel is located on a more 'quiet' and less busy part of Shibuya which was great! Staff were very accommodating and friendly. Loved our time there, will probably stay here again if I get the chance to visit Tokyo again.

Cerulean Tower Tokyu has an amazing location, being only a few minutes walk from Shibuya 5 Ways. There is literally days worth of wandering around the Shibuya Streets. If you're feeling energetic, you could easily walk to Harajuku, or if you're feeling lazy, catch the Yamanoto line anywhere! Cerulean Tower provides excellent service, and assistance to make Japanese bookings was happily provided by the hotel. Some here say wifi should be free for a 5 star hotel, but having a fee keeps all the leechers off it! For a minimal fee, you can have wifi for all your devices, lightning fast! Restaurant service was also exemplary. We had a few drinks on Level 40 to take in the view (expensive, but worth it) and also had dinner at the Italian restaurant on L2 (Must more affordable). Breakfast at the restaurant is very busy and generally involves a wait. For only a few dollars more, choose room service and have a table delivered to your room!

My stay here was business trip in the end of winterFirst impression was the strategic location and very kind staffs in all departmentMy room was Sky View in 29th floor, with a magnificent view of Mount FujiRoom is spacious in Tokyo standard. I like the layout, where the working table is strategic and comfortableInternet access is quite expensive. Stayed here for 4 nights, the connection had a problem on the 3rd. Staff doesn't understand English for technical problem

My son and I stayed at the Cerulean tower hotel in Shibuya for 7 nights. We chose it after reading the reviews on trip advisor, Tokyo is huge but Shibuya is where the action is. The hotel is five minutes from Shibuya railway station, one of the biggest and busiest stations in Tokyo. If you arrive by train from Narita take the west or south exit. When you come out of the station look to the left and the tower is visible. Use the overhead walkways to reach the hotel. - there are lifts if you have luggage.The reception is on the first floor but the rooms are on the 19th to 40th floor. Our non smoking room was on the 25th floor and had wonderful views of the area. The room is spacious with a spacious bathroom with lots of marble and a great shower. The hotel charges for WiFi. It costs 3600 yen for a week. We were able to run a laptop, ipad and mobile phone in our room and the speed was excellent.On the ground floor is the Caramelo restaurant where there is an excellent breakfast buffet. It might appear expensive but is a great way to start the day with excellent food. No one hurries you to leave and breakfast is served until 10.30am. Time to plan your day.Without exception the staff are helpful and friendly. They make you feel welcome. We used the concierge service to book restaurants and seek directions. The staff remembered my name 24 hours later. This is Japan at its best.On the second floor just outside the entrance is a very handy 7/11 convenience store. 7 bank has an ATM inside which works with overseas travel cards and other cards. Be aware few Japanese banks ATM will work with overseas cards, but the 7/11 chain works fine.To sum up:Whilst the Cerulean might appear expensive it is great value and a genuine 5 star hotel with service to match. Close to the railway station and all the action of Shibuya. You can get to all parts of Tokyo easily and the Narita express train to the airport stops at the station. This hotel is an oasis of calm and service with delightful staff. A stay here will not disappoint you.

If you are new to Tokyo and would want to avoid the hassel of familiarizing yourself with the spider-web metro network on your very first day upon arrival, you can simply take the airport shuttle which will take you direct from the Haneda/Narita Airport to Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel direct. It costs you 1,000 yen per person.The room in Cerulean is spacious by the Japnanese standard. The shower and bath tub are enclosed behind a glass pane to avoid the steam transmitting into the rest of the bathroom.If the weather is good, you can also get a glimpse of the Tokyo Tower from your own room. Request for a room on a high-floor zone if possible. It would enable you to have a better view of the entirety of the Shibuya area.In terms of location, there should be no complaint. When you walk down from Cerulean (check from the lift), you should come across a pedestrian walkover (please watch for the FIRST). After you cross it you would find yourself landing in the Shibuya station. It is one of the biggest and busiest transit stations. You can get a day pass to save some money. Please make sure you get the correct line e.g. JR/Metro etc. If you do not opt for breakfast in Cerulean, there are nice coffee shops and fast food shops around offering nice coffee and sandwiches to choose from to fuel youself in before staring a day for sight-seeing.If you are starved, the basement floor in Tokyu Department Store is the best place to shop for fresh and reasonably priced sashimi and sushi. Facing the Shibuya station and opposite to Tokyu Department Store is the popular shopping area of Shibuya. You will find 109 and Mark City close-by.For food gourmets who look for better quality for dinner, there is a "food" street across the pedestrian cross-over (mentioned above) close to Mark City where you will be afforded with loads of choices varying from Japanese noodles (ramen), sushi, BBQ (korean style) and teppanyaki etc. It is only approximately 5 minutes away from Cerulean. If it takes you more than 10 minutes to get there, you are probably heading on the wrong direction.

In terms of location, room size and views this hotel holds it's own. Room is large, very large for Japan (bathroom is the size of other hotel rooms I have stayed at here), the doors close silently and the foot light switch next to the bed saves you being blinded by light if you need to get up in the dark. Bar on level 40 is nice enough but the ambience is a little lacking. It could be made so much better and help them capitalise on the stunning views of the city if the brought it up a notch.Customer service overall is what you expect from Japan but as many others state here, this hotel has a bit more of a business feel, than it has character ambience and that shows in the staff. If you are looking for a hotel for a vacation with someone special you can do better, if your here seeing friends or for business then it's a solid bet.

Great location for this comfy hotel in shibuya.Spacious rooms, with large bathrooms, and very comfortable beds.The service is perfect (welcome to Japan) and the breakfast buffet is excellent.A couple of complaints though:- i had to ask for another room, as the one i initially got had a terrible smell of tobacco- the fitness center and the pool close at 9pm, which means that if you're ther for work, and you come back a bit late, you just won't be able to go to gym. A pity for a hotel of such a level...

The Cerulean Tower Hotel is in probably the best location in Tokyo for tourists. Very close to Shibuya station.The hotel itself is very nice but maybe a bit bland. The staff of course are very polite and attentive but we usually stay at the Hyatt Regency and I prefer this hotel but of course the location is not quite as good.The rooms are comfortable and relatively large with beautiful bathroom. The beds are on the hard side, the view is magnificent. Immaculately clean.I will say that it is a little noisy at night with thumping and bumping from above a little annoying.Overall though you would have to be picky to not enjoy your stay at this hotel.

We stayed at the Cerulean at the recommendation of a work colleague and if we hadn't stayed at the Hotel ICON in Hong Kong only a few weeks earlier then my review may have been very different. We booked a room on the executive 'Cerulean' floor which included breakfast and access to the lounge. I would recommend this as it is nice to have the extra facilities inclusive. The service was excellent and the staff were very attentive and polite. The room was clean and I believe large by Tokyo standards but for me was a similar size to a standard hotel room in other major cities around the world. The bathroom and shower were excellent and the whole hotel was spotlessly clean. As I mentioned, the let down for me was comparing similar facilities between the ICON and Cerulean but the ICON just managed to go one step beyond in terms of service of what the Cerulean offered. Both had breakfast included but the ICONs spread was a buffet and also full service and was a much larger selection rather than a small buffet. They both offered afternoon tea but again it was full service at the ICON rather than serve yourself at Cerulean etc etc. I don't want to keep comparing in this review as what is on offer at Cerulean is excellent but for me I only recently had better in Hong Kong.The bed was very comfortable and of course the location of the hotel is superb right in the middle of things. If you wish to travel by public transport the station is only a short walk away but as with all Japanese service, the hotel are most efficient at organising a taxi should you prefer.All in all I would recommend the Cerulean but just be aware that other than attentive staff you are getting quite a bland corporate 5 star hotel rather than a hotel with huge amounts of character or a hotel that really does go above and beyond.

I just spent a week at the Cerulean Tower and was very impressed with the stay. The location can't be beat (3min walk to Shibuya Station) and the views are fantastic. There are multiple restaurants in the hotel and an amazing bar on the top floor. The gym equipment could be updated but there was never anyone else in there when I went to work out. The pool and jacuzzi are enormous and were also empty when I visited. My bathroom wasn't very large but I did like the size of the rest of the room, especially the walk in closet. They also provide a variety of pillow types so you can mix and match to your liking. The breakfast buffet was nice ($33USD) and as a westerner I appreciated their inclusion of french toast, pancakes, & fresh squeezed OJ. There is also a convenient 7-11 practically within the hotel lobby. I'll definitely be back.
Whenever we go to Japan, this is the place to stay for the service of course we are in Japon...!Magnificient view from the roof top bar over Tokyo. Very well located next to train and subway station.

Stayed for 4 nights in a Sky View room after a trip from Kyoto. We cannot help but compare the 5 star hotel we stayed in Kyoto with this hotel. They had the same price but seems like Cerulean lacks everywhere. They have a lot of staff from assisting the traffic because of the complicated entrance to just standing in the lobby. Also, no one even cared to help us carry our heavy baggage when we checked out. Location was technically near to Shibuya station but you have to walk a lot because of the overpass. If I were to stay in Tokyo, I'll choose Shinjuku for better shopping. Toiletries were cheap quality, room design was old but the size was big. There are tons of hotels in Tokyo, look around to get a better deal with quality and value.

Stayed several nights at the hotel and had an excellent experience with my family. Three minute walk to shibuya station and the rest of the shibuya district. Service was exceptional! I would recommend this hotel to anyone looking for convenience and comfort.

Not frequent traveller to Tokoyo so don't know what the standard practice or how this hotel compares to others but in general we were not impressed. For hotel guests there are additional charges for anything and everything including room wi-fi, gym use, local calls, child playroom, even to just sit in the bar ++. Also, if we heard them correctly they also do not allow children under the age of 20 in the Japanese restaurant. We were travelling with two small kids so nearby amenities was important but when you ask for restaurant recommendations in walking distance they whip out pre-made directions to touristy places which were not the easiest to get to with huge lines basically in shopping malls if you mange to find them (I assume the have a deal with the restaurants). The second day we found loads of good restaurants which were basically just down the street (more localized, better tasting, less lines). We decided to transfer to the Disneyland Hotel and when asked about a car transfer they quoted us about $250 saying there was a taxi shortage due to a soccer game in Yokohama! I assume they only called the places they had deals with where they could overcharge you again. Not getting much help I called Hotel Disneyland myself and they sent a 9 person van for half the price so much for the shortage of local transport. Ironically we had a much better experience at the much more touristy Disneyland Hotel in Tokyo - well at least they didn't nickel and dime us to death and directed us our queries appropriately. The two stars are basically for the central location and the reasonably sized rooms but I would not recommend this place especially if you have other options especially for families.

The best thing about this hotel is it's big and very spacious room for japan standard. Other than that it is an average hotel. Staff were friendly, and somewhat helpful. The hotel is clean and well taken care of.Looking for the hotel was quite difficult. No clear sign from shibuya station. The location is about 10 mins walk from shibuya centre. Lots of shops and restaurants, even during the night time.No free wifi for my standard floor room, only available for executive floors. Quite a disappointment, considering free wifi is available at most of hotel nowadays.

Suprisingly nice hotel near the shibuya station without all the hecticness. The staff was really friendly, the business of Shibuya is just accross the street,easily accessible near the Mark City Mall. The rooms were also quiet large for a Japanese hotel at that price. For a hotel like this wifi shouldve been complimentary though (1,050 yen per day unlimited users).

Stayed here for one night on the last night of our 12-day Japan adventure. Overall the price was reasonable for a hotel of this type and the service we received was excellent. We arrived at 11am and wanted to leave luggage there until we could check-in, but our room was already available so we were taken to our room early. Porters were polite and spoke good English. The room itself was clean and quiet and had everything we needed. We didn't use anything from the mini-bar - anyone traveling on a budget knows that's a no-no! Location is excellent, very close to the Shibuya madness, and easy to locate from Shibuya station - just take the south exit and look up to your left! - that giant tower is Cerulean. We ordered a room service breakfast as a treat, (Japanese-style) however in comparison to the Japanese meals we'd had at other Ryokans and hotels this one was a little bland and not quite the 'feast' that is the usual Japanese breakfast. It's nice to have it bought to your room in the morning however I don't think it's worth the money. We missed out on checking out the on-site Noh Theatre but if you are there when there is a Noh performance on I would go - Noh Theatre really is a treat; there is nothing else like it; it is very strange and don't expect a narrative but quite a cultural experience. Overall our stay at Cerulean was pleasant and we were comfortable however the traditional accommodation in Japan is far better value for money in my opinion, but it does just depend on what suits your taste.

One would have though that being near to Shibuya station the area would be messy and chaotic, but it's not. Very rare to find a place which is so near to the shopping area but so quiet all at the same time. The rooms size is reasonable big for a Japan hotel. Also the airport limousine bus stops direct here if you are flying in from narita airport. Unlike other countries where the bus stops at several hotel, this one only serves two. This makes it relatively easy to travel back and forth from hotel. At 3000 yen, I would go as far to say that the bus ride was affordable. I would definitely love to come back again.

Nice place, great location in Shibuya District, fantastic panoramic view... Rooms big and clean, good food. Prices ok for a 5 star hotel. Wifi on the room (but not free, about 25 euros for 1 week).SPA not so good, too small and with no realxing bed (only chair!).

We stayed here for 8 nights in late Nov / early Dec, and the best thing about it is the fabulous location! Shibuya itself is real fun, and the subway and JR stations are just a 3 min walk from the hotel. The service is excellent, what you expect in Japan and at a 5 star hotel, the concierge service specifically is excellent! They were extremely helpful in getting us dinner reservations and gave excellent recommendations as well as detailed explanations that made everything simple. The room size is great for Tokyo and the view was spectacular from the room. The only reason I gave it a rating of 4 is the small things like - 1) No free internet (doesn't make sense nowadays, there is free wifi in most of the city)2) When we went to the bar on top (amazing view) and asked for a table near the window, they told us none are available, so when I said we will wait, they said there is a charge per person to get those tables, and as soon as I said yes they took us to an empty table.3) Needed to print something before checking out, the first reaction was - there is a charge of 500yen per 15 mins, which again doesnt make sense since we are staying in the hotel. Basically all these small things that don't really make you feel comfortable. That is the difference between hotels that want to gain you as a client for life, or hotels that want to make money quickly on every small thing.

My elderly father and I spent 3 nights at the Cerulean Tower in November, 2012. The location is superb and the hotel is modern, well-appointed with efficient curteous service, as you would expect at this price range. We noticed a surprising number of families during our stay, probably due to the relatively spacious rooms and it being a holiday weekend.We had a standard two-twin room with modern furnishings, a work-desk area, a stuffed chair and ottoman, flatscreen TV, mini-bar. Large picture window with panoramic views of Tokyo and beyond. The bathroom is fantastic, even by Japanese standards, with a large glass-enclosed shower/tub area. The usual brevy of bath products, plush robes, nightgowns, etc. Plenty of closet space and drawers.The only negative of the room was, amazingly enough, the noise. I'm not sure if we had especially active people above us but, frankly, it sounded like they were doing gymnastics above us. We didn't hear any noise from nextdoor neighbors but, then, it didn't seem like the rooms were occupied either.We had breakfast at the hotel each day and sampled the buffet as well as the Japanese restaurant; both start at 3,000 yen per person. The buffet is mostly western (or, rather, the Japanese version of 'western' which includes salad and brunch-style dishes as well as the typical breakfast items) and only very limited Japanese offerings (no rice or miso soup.) For a typical Japanese breakfast, you need to go to the Japanese restaurant.We also had meals at the Chinese restaurant (excellent) and the Italian restaurant (OK). Overall, the service at the restaurants was surprisingly mediocre. The servers were young and seemed inexperienced and rather inattentive -- we waited often, it seems, for water glass refills, coffee, plates to be cleared, etc. and at the Japanese breakfast, we missed a course all together.This hotel is one of the two Shibuya stops for the Limousine (Tokyu) Buses that service Narita and Haneda airports. We took the bus from Haneda (1,000 yen) and to Narita (3,000 yen) after our stay. The concierge made the reservations for us. My father has mobility issues and the bus transportation was extremely convenient and comfortable.Shibuya (train) station is less than a 5-minute walk from the hotel and can be negotiated by those with impaired mobility. The pedestrian overpasses have elevator accesses, as does the train station.All in all, we thought this was an excellent hotel for travellers who appreciate a convenient location and modern spacious rooms but aren't looking for warm gracious service. At rack rates, I think the property would be over-priced.

My husband and I spent 5 nights at the Cerulean Tower Tokyo Hotel in May 2012 and here are the reasons we loved it: - The location (in Shibuya) is excellent for touring and eating.- Having a phenomenal view from our hotel room made even those moments when we needed to rest feel like sightseeing.- The view from the bar on the 40th floor was also great and a fun way to start the night (tip: if you sit at the bar, you avoid paying the per person fee).- The staff was extremely helpful and the concierge literally draws you a map when you ask for directions or suggestions.- The Airport Limousine Bus offers door-to-door service to and from Narita on a line that only has two stops- The hotel stored our luggage for us so that we only had to take a small bag for our 3-night trip to Kyoto (free of charge).- The 7 Eleven in the building has an ATM machine that accepts American debit cards.We spent a lot of time researching dining and drinking options in Tokyo and here are some of the gems that are within walking distance of the Cerulean:Suzuran: delicious ramen shop that specializes in tsukemen/tsukesoba.Sushi Ouchi: amazing organic sushi restaurant in a quaint environment.Kaikaya by the Sea: fun atmosphere, great seafood. Reserve ahead of time if possible.Bar Ishinohana: the bartenders there make some of the most beautifully crafted and delicious cocktails I've ever had.I wrote about our experience in Japan and included a lot of travel tips: http://www.chicagonow.com/the-fourth-walsh/category/japan/I don't think you can go wrong with this hotel and I recommend it.

For a tokyo hotel it is quite spacious, clean and has great views in day and nite. It is conveniently located just far away enough from Shibuya station so it is in a quiet part of the area but easy enough to get to the station in 5 mins. It has a small gym which is good enough for quick treadmill run.Great bar at the top, but it closes at around midnight on weekdays.The beds are hard and pillows are also quite hard as well...Breakfast is a bit overpriced at 3000 yen, I'd suggest going to the ramen shop down road for 700yen.

The Cerulean Tower is a large well located modern hotel with decent rooms, friendly staff and good facilities. It's pretty expensive in the restaurant and bars but the included breakfast is great. There are a ton of places nearby to shop, eat and drink. All in all this is a decent place.

Has a business center, a gym ($25 per day extra) great top floor bar lounge with fantastic views- right out of Lost in Translation...excellent service. Check out the live jazz bar next store, great spot. Also, great ramen houses across the foot bridge past the 7-11 as you are headed down hill towards the Shibuya station make a left into the small alleyways. Take advantage of their Narita bus, much cheaper than a taxi($30 versus $250+). Ask for a room with a view of Shibuya station, helps you to get a lay of the land. Very quiet rooms, could not hear any street noise or my neighbors - I was on the 25th floor.

The hotel is located in Shibuya district where many shops and restaurants are located near by. There is 7-11 next to the hotel, which is convenient. As other reviewer said, this is a good business hotel although rate was higher this time around. It used to be around 25,000 yen with breakfast per night for queen size bed room, but this time, it was over 35,000 yen without breakfast. Room is comfortable and I liked how their closet is situated. Only complaint I would have is that there isn't enough counter space in the bathroom for your item.

My wife and I stayed at the Cerulean for one week in October. We elected it because, contrary to most US hotels in Tokyo, they offered free cancellation. We found it to be an excellent choice. A very modern hotel, with large room (even for US standards, not to mention Japanese ones) and bathroom, and -above all- and incredibly helpful staff, including the concierge who always with a smile helped us with directions on how to make our train reservations, among others. The hotel has a varietty of great restaurants and is also is very conveniently located just 300 feet away from Shibuya station, which is also located right in the center of Shibuya commercial area. We recommend it highly.

Good location in Shibuya, very nice international hotel. Served by the Limousine bus from Narita (3.000 yen) in about 1 hour on week-ends, expect about 1.5/2 hours on weekdays. Not very much of personality and rather expensive, even if I go there 1-2 times/year and have a special rate. The breakfast restaurant at the lobby level is rather good, with plenty of fresh choices, but the rate of 30.000 yen (abt. 30 euro) is a bit too high for no good reason. Even if you clearly warn them of your arrival in the morning, usually your room will not be ready until 11.00 or so. If you have some luck they will upgrade to a superior room if availbale. Last year happened, this time no.The point is that there are almost no seats in a huge lobby, and this after a long haul from Europe is not really exciting. Another weak point is the internet service: at 1300 yen/day unless inlcuded in the rate, in such a hotel and such a country is even more annoying than elsewhere. Anyway the connection is quite fast and very reliable.

We stayed at the Cerulean for 2 days and were lucky to find an exceptionally low rate of around USD270 for a Towers room (via Expedia AU). OK, that's not a small amount, but the Towers room is located on the high Exec floors and includes access to the Exec lounge for breakfast and complimentary drinks each evening from 1700-1930 as well as refreshments throughout the day. In general I think the hotel advertises its basic rooms at not much less than this rate. The hotel is very easy to locate if you arrive into Shibuya station as we did - if you've previously had a look at an exterior photo then you can't miss it when you exit the station main entrance. From there it's a less than 5 minute walk to the hotel lobby. The lobby is not particularly inspiring and lacked seating space on occasions but there are always many staff on hand to assist. Check in was quick & efficient if not particularly friendly. Our room on the 34rd floor was large by Japanese standards with a comfortable king bed & work area. There are great views in all directions and huge windows to take it all in. The bathroom was very nice with a completely separate screened off bath & shower area which I'm guessing is to prevent the rest of the bathroom getting steamy. One thing I did notice about the room that it was on the warm side...despite the A/C being set lower I couldn't get the temp much below 25C (as indicated by the thermo)...the corridors outside were very warm. My understanding is that this is fairly typical in Tokyo now as there is an attempt to reduce power consumption after the 2011 earthquake and its results on the power grid? We very much enjoyed using the executive 'salon'. It was always very quiet in there, never any issue getting a seat by the window to watch the sun setting over the city. As a business lounge the atmosphere was more conservative than party, but still a great way to start the evening. They served Moet for Champagne lovers, a small selection of beers, wine and the usual array of spirits - the choice of nibbles was fairly simple - cheese, crackers, nuts, chips etc. Towers room permits breakfast in the salon but not at any of the other hotel eateries. A simple affair but covered all the basics...tea, coffee, fruit juices, toast, fruit, cereal, scrambled eggs, poached eggs, bacon, sausages etc but nothing cooked to order. They did also serve salads & soup for breakfast. It's an entirely self service affair including the tea & coffee...some guests seemed to be waiting to be waited on! The lounge attendants were happy to provide wifi logon passwords which were complimentary (although I believe the hotel does charge some guests) and good for 24 hours - you do need one PER DEVICE though. The room certainly included complimentary wired internet but no details about wifi were offered at checkin so it was good to find out this was available after all - note that this may be executive floor only benefit? Shibuya is a good area for shopping and transport connections...it would be less than 10mins walk from the hotel to Shibuya crossing and the centre of the shopping area. It's a very quick journey to other tourist areas of Tokyo - Harajuku, Shinjuku, Roppongi, Ginza etc. The express train to Narita leaves from Shibuya and I believe the hotel is also served by the slightly cheaper Limousine buses. I'd be more than happy to stay at the Cerulean again but the price would have to be right having been spoiled by the Towers room & exec lounge this time around!

I stayed at the Cerulean Tower for a week for business in late September. It is designed for a business traveller, and is very well located in Shibuya, which makes it a good choice if you are looking for a functional place to stay. Worth noting, this place is also quite expensive, so I would only recommend it for business, and when your company is footing the bill. For a personal trip I would recommend somewhere with more uniqueness and personality at this price point.Arrival is easy, just take the shuttle bus straight from the International Arrivals hall at the airport - it drops you off straight at the hotel for a fraction of the price of a taxi. I found hotel check-in to be relatively easy, but the conversation became difficult after I asked about changing to a different view. But it all worked out in the end, and I got a room with a better view, but at a higher rate.The staff is very polite, and helpful with any requests you may make, but the service lacks personality, and you won't feel as though you are a unique visitor in the same way you will at the Conrad or Park Hyatt in Tokyo. The rooms are very functional, with a desk and internet setup that allows for easy working. And the bed is very comfortable with nice bedding and a good selection of very comfortable pillows, including memory foam. The main selling point of the rooms are the views that But overall, the decor is very 90's and slightly dated, nothing special or unique to speak of, and in general the rooms feel quite bland. No special amenities to make you feel wowed or fuzzy when you return to your room after a long day. The TV selection is all Japanese, so unless you want to watch Japanese game shows or programs dubbed in Japanese, you are kind of out of luck. The bathrooms are nice and very clean, but the toiletries provided are lackluster and generic, which I wouldn't expect from a hotel charging these prices.Room service is lackluster and very expensive. For snacks and such, though, there is a 7-Eleven in the building on the first floor which is much less expensive and with wider selection than the mini bar. The bar on the top floor is a great view, but again, very expensive. You are paying for the view. Also, I was shocked that the restaurant on the top floor wanted to charge my coworkers and I a cover charge to sit and eat dinner when we were guests at the hotel.The location is great, however, and for any wanderings you might do in your free time, you are very close to the hustle of Shibuya and very close to all major transport options.All in all, I would say that this is a good choice for business, but I wouldn't recommend it for any other purposes if you want something special.

First stop on a 3 week business trip through Asia. First, great bus service from Narita to the door of the hotel. So a great start, but rather disappointing from there on. Room was fine. Location was good - Shibuya is a nice walk-around area. Be sure to get to Harajuku and do Shibuya crossing in the evening. But the restaurants and bars aren't open late or early so you're out of luck if you can't get to sleep or wake up really early...as one is likely to do the first few days of the trip. Most irritating was the bar on the top floor. First, it's smokey...which I understand. There are non-smoking tables, but they charge you extra to sit at them. REALLY irritating. Especially since a glass of wine - a fairly average glass of wine - was $34 USD. Yes. a glass. Then they had the brass to tack on a table charge? Amazing. All the restaurants were very overpriced. Other than the location, there's not much in the redeeming qualities column here. So I'll look elsewhere for my next visit.

If you want to stay in Shibuya, i think this is definitely one of the better options. The Excel in Mark CIty is a better location as its on the station, but Cerulean is overall a nicer hotel. Its a good balance between the real fancy Ritz/Park Hyatt and your average 4 star.We stayed for one week with our two boys (both under 4) and found them relatively accommodating. Breakfast had a good spread with some really nice fresh fruit. Housekeeping was a bit inconsistent and the concierge was pretty helpful. To be honest, it wasn't amazing but it exceeded my expectations what they were charging. If you have kids in a stroller, getting to shibuya station requires going on the overpass but they have lifts that make it easier. if the lift thing annoys you, i would stay at the excel in mark city but its not as nice.Overall, if i really wanted to stay in Shibuya, would stay here for sure.

In many ways a good hotel. But comes with a total lack of personality - and worse - personal dedication and customer attention from their staff. I am staying there right now, with a few days more to go, and have by now regretted i did not go for one of my normal selections.It's hard to put finger on one specific thing. Everything works, but thats a hgenic factor in Japan and not something hotels deserve praise for.Breakfast slow, room service short, help desk, well.... how did they come up with that name?But for me the absolute worst thing is their attitude to families traveling. Friendly when charging for the kids (1 and 3). The rest of "kid's not allowed". Delivered with an attitude that would go well in a maximum security prison. I feel ashamed to my children having brought them into a place like this!I'd been traveling with (the same 2) kids in Japan and stayed at both Conrad and Grand + Park Hyatt. Never had any trouble due t the fact we were indeed a family. After 25 years of Japan travel I'm aware this is not the county's standard - only Cerulean's.We wouldn't be back!

I remember my two nights here as one of my favourite hotel stays ever. I had a single room on a club floor. I will never forget walking into my room for the first time and my jaw just dropping to the floor as I took in the view of what seemed like the whole Tokyo from the 38th floor. Watching the madness of Shibuya crossing from my window always brought a smile to my face. Furnishings were tasteful and high-quality, internet was fast, toilet was spotless. Every detail was right - even down to the great quality loaner umbrellas they give you to deal with the rain. And the 'Airport Limousine' bus stops right here too, so it's easy to get to. Factor in the outstanding location on a transport hub and you just can't go wrong here.

Right in the heart of Shibuya-ku, this hotel is luxurious and modern. Food from the restaurant is good as well. Location makes this a must stay hotel. If you like your bed a little softer than normal, be sure to ask, as they have rooms that can accommodate this request.

I loved staying here. The location is amazing. It is close to Daikanyama, which my Japanese friend described as being 'where billionaire hipsters' hangout. My partner had fun wandering around Shibuya at night. On my birthday night after dinner we went to a local bar and were given free soju which was great until I got so drunk I fell flat on my face and was basically carried back to the Cerulean Towers. *sigh* so many great memories of Shibuya.Our room was spacious and the view was breath taking.The bath room floor seemed to be fashioned out of a single slab of marble, with drainage ducts carved into it. Very sexy. There was anteroom next to the bathroom for extended personal grooming - nice touch.The service was ultra professional but cold, but who cares we weren't there to make friends with hotel workers.

We called the Cerulean Tower home for two weeks on a visit to Tokyo. The hotel is located in Shibuya and is within walking distance to Shibuya Station as well as great shopping, sightseeing, and dining. For anyone needing a Starbucks fix like myself, there is one located a short walk from the hotel at Shibuya Crossing. The rooms were very clean and spacious. I liked that there was a foyer area to remove shoes and hang up coats, umbrellas, etc. before entering the "living" space. We also had amazing views of the city from our couch as well as from the large bathroom window. Service was quite good albeit somewhat sterile.The hotel has some restaurants located within: Italian, Japanese, Steak/Seafood, a lounge, a jazz bar, and a cafe where they serve a terrific breakfast buffet for a hefty price. There is also a 7-11 connected to the hotel that is convenient for water, milk tea, and other snacks. They have an indoor pool, but you must pay an additional fee to use it. We decided there were too many other things to do than sit at an indoor pool for a fee, so can't really comment on that.The only negative I would have to say about the hotel is that the moment you enter, you are met with the noxious smell of smoke. This was pretty typical throughout Japan, as smoking is a habit many have picked up, but it would have been nice to not have to smell it when returning to rest from a long day. This was one of the reasons we never really spent time in any of the restaurants other than in the mornings for the breakfast buffet. There are non-smoking floors and rooms, so at least one can escape the toxic fumes upon returning to the room.Overall, this was a great choice for a stay in Tokyo. It's a clean, comfortable, and modern hotel. Also, the location made it easy to get around and explore Tokyo.

I will always remember this hotel fondly. I stayed here for about a week and was thoroughly impressed with the impeccable and efficient housekeeping services. It's refreshing to stay in a hotel where the staff are well-trained and polite and where every service is well-executed. Retiring to the Cerulean Tower after hours of sightseeing was always a pleasant and relaxing cap to my day.

I stayed two times at the Cerulean two times for business. Both times, I have very pleased. The staff is really nice and very helping. Room & bathroom have the perfect size. I would only complain about the TV that is not offering a lot of international channels and that is not that easy to use at first. The rooms being located on high floors, the city view is always breathtaking.I appreciated relaxing in the swimming pool (great after a long flight to fight jetlag).Room service is good and dishes are really well presented.The location of the hotel is really great. you can walk through Shibuya and take the metro very easily. The shuttle "limousine" (bus!) to and from the airport is very efficient and will make you save money.

We stayed at the Cerulean for two nights. Rooms were large and the bedding was just right. Hotel location was fantastic -- only a 5 minute walk to the shibuya crossing. Lots of malls nearby for shopping and eating. Breakfast was very relaxed and yummy. Great for families.

Extremely well located hotel that i loved staying for two business trips. You can enjoy nice and clean hotel rooms with perfect views above Tokyo. Amaneties such as gym or breakfast are very expensive and to operate the TV is complicate and can become challenging. However, taking the elevator up to the bar or down to Shibuya pulls you immediately out of the lonelyness, just nice when travelling on business.

This hotel is everything you will want.Great service, better-than-most english speaking people in the lobby, amazing views, convenience convenience convenience.If you ignore the hefty price tag, it's 100% perfect.. well, 92%, since the hotel is on the wrong side of Tamagawa Dori.

Stayed here one night. We were spoiled at the Shangria-La hotel in Tokyo, but this place was nice. Less English spoken here. The rooms were very nice. bathroom had lots of amenities, excellent room service. The restaurant was very expensive!

This is a good standard four star international grade hotel next to a happening area with lots of street life. The area is more casual / happening than the formal and straight laced Ginza.Most other hotels in this area are "local" and lower grade. LIKE MOST JAPANESE 4 STAR HOTELS - IT HAS THE ANNOYING HABIT OF CHARGING FOR TEH GYM.

This is my 2nd stay at the Cerulean. I love the location of the hotel as it is very close to Shibuya station and the shopping area. You can find food within a 1 minute walk and there are 2 convenient stores nearby. The staff here are very prfoessional and polite. I do agree with one reviewer in that while the service is good and up to standard, nobody made us feel like they were going the extra mile to make our stay even better.We decided to get a room on the tower's floor because we've had really good experiences with them. But the food that is offered at the lounge here is pretty sad. At night you only get happy cow cheese and crackers and potato chips and nuts. There are however, unlimited wine and beers offered. The breakfast was way below what we expected either. The selection of the food was really really small and tasted just okay. I wouldn't waste my money on the tower's floor next time.Our room was very clean and quite spacious for Tokyo standard. Everything you might need is in the room. I found it to be very comfortable and was happy with it. I did think it was kind of pricey, but given the location I guess it is not really overpriced.

I was pre-warned that otto was not know for boutique hotels - that it was a choice of basic and functional or corporate with an american vibe. I decided I wanted some extra comforts - a pool and sauna, a choice of restaurants and wifi in the rooms.The hotel provided exactly what was offered but with so little personality that I was left quite cold. Everything had a transactional feel, no warmth from the staff - they would do exactly as stated, but give no more, no less and certainly no personality. As a first time visitor to Tokyo I was beyond excited and had hoped for some great local tips and insider knowledge from the staff at the hotel but was met with a brick wall - and Im a pretty friendly easy going person so was most disappointed.Standards were great - cleanliness was great - staff were a let down.

I stayed at this hotel on business for 5 nights after traveling across Japan. The reception staff were very welcoming and efficient. The lobby is a large public space and has a vibrant feel due to café and meeting area etc.My room was on the 22nd floor and it was extremely comfortable. The view was amazing looking over the park and Tokyo tower! I slept very well and found the bed extremely comfortable. The bathroom was great too...the usual Japanesfacilitieses - electric toilet, heated mirror etc.The breakfast was very good, I especially liked the chef cooking omlettes to customers requests! He had a great manner and sense of humor...great start to the day.

3rd stay, and it is still excellent! Even better than before... they learned that this was our 3rd stay, so they upgraded us to a bigger room on a higher level. I traveled with my husband, 9 yo and 2 yo, and the room was spacious enough to accomodate everybody. I always love the bathroom.This time around, we had the "western" breakfast buffet on the lobby level and it was very good. They didnt have the most variety of items but I liked my omelette and coffee a lot. Fresh OJ squeezed on the spot, and seriously... I had the best waffle, ever.one thing I wish they did though is to open the pool to everybody including children, but oh well... i'd still go back.

I always stay in Cerulean Tower . It's nice , clean and the most important part for me it's located in the heart of the City. Since my business areas are Harajuku , Shibuya , Daikanyama , Ginza , it's very easy to reach these places from Hotel by Subway or Taxi.

We stayed at the Cerulean Tower Hotel for one night. We stayed on the 30th floor and the view was just stunning. The hotel is a only about 5 minutes from the Shibuya station, 5 minutes from the Tokyu department store and there is a Lawson just downstairs. The location is great.

I stayed at the Cerulean Tower hotel for three nights. It was mostly okay -- but I had spent the first three nights of my trip at the Capitol Hotel Tokyu which was 5 stars all the way. The Cerulean is definitely not in the same class as the Capitol Hotel Tokyu. Pros: * Location. In the lively Shibuya neighborhood. Close to subway (Shibuya station), shopping, and restaurants. * Hotel has an attractive lobby and a bar with a great view on the 40th floor. * My room was very clean. * My room on the 30th floor had a great view. * The staff was very friendly overall. Cons:* My room was outdated. Definitely no granite bathroom. Plain walls, very simple room. * The AC minimum is locked at 68 degrees in my room. * The only experience I had with a rude person in 6 days in Japan happened at the 40th floor bar at this hotel. The host wanted to seat us at the same two seats at the bar for the third night in a row. We asked to sit farther down. He looked and said "No seats" despite that there were two other sets of 2 seats. We asked the bartender if we could move and he said of course. The host gave us a dirty look. * Sometimes I had a faint smell of cigarette smoke in my non-smoking room. * They charge you $12/day for wifi. Ripoff!* The pillows on the bed are rock hard. * There are no outlets next to the bed to plug in devices.

I recently stayed here on a business trip and it was a very nice stay. I expected the room to be tiny - but it was comparable to a typical American hotel. Next time, I would select the deal that included breakfast and access to the gym. The hotel breakfast was DELICIOUS! Both the continental buffet and the traditional Japanese breakfast. However, it cost 3003 Yen. And the gym is only accessible without a fee from 6am-7am. But it has a nice selection of equipment, a pool, and a sauna. The hotel is walking distance to many great shops and restaurants. It is also very close to the train station. I highly recommend this hotel!!

This hotel was very clean with nice views. The room size was good, but not huge. Typical of the size of rooms we stayed at while in Japan. The bathrooms/showers-bath were very nice with granite showers. Very interesting design in the shower that were walk-in and not enclosed like typical walk-in showers. This hotel is very close to the trains and convienent access. The breakfasts were really excellent with well baked pastries, great coffee and high quality fruit. They had typical other foods, such as eggs, etc. We were part of a tour so hard to directly comment on cost. Exercise facility was extra charge. Internet wireless access if from 12;00 noon to 12:00 noon (1050 yen). Lots of activities/night life near by (easy walking distance).

The location of the hotel is superb: walking distance to the train station, great shops, nightlife and a very vibrant part of the city.We did find the room rate a little pricey but having a little experience of Japanese hotel rooms, we booked a better than average room to give us more space - which it definitely delivered.The professionalism and efficiency of the staff was noted - though that can be said of Tokyo in general. We did not eat at the hotel or use the gym/pool so cannot comment on those. However, what we did not appreciate were the quite high charges for internet usage. For a city as switched on and connected as Tokyo we felt this was quite a ripoff.

good location- you're within walking distance of the action at shibuya. the staff were very helpful and courteous. the pool was nice and we used it daily. the rooms weren't as nice as i expected for the price however.

I will start with the positives.- Arrived at 9:30 am and were checked in immediately by friendly and helpful staff.- Location is good, close to Shibuya station (One of the best locations in town)Ill now list the negatives.- Room cost was very high, comparable to Hilton, Hyatt etc (5 Star Pricing)- Room was very small, boring, dated, and definately not 5 star.- The bed is extremely uncomfortable.- Air Conditioning does not go enough.Ill now list the MAJOR negatives.Having paid extremely high pricing i was surprised to find the hotel charges for EVERYTHING- Charged extra if wishing to use fitness centre RIF OFF (or free between 6-7 am wow thanks)- Charged extra for internet RIP OFF- Charged extra to use the Swimming Pool RIP OFFSave your money, go with a well known and renowned brand such as Hilton, Hyatt, hell even stay at the Ibis it would beat this place.Worst waste of $1880 for 4 nights in existence.Im really not a negative person (read my other reviews as proof)

The Cerulean Tower is a luxury hotel that adds great rooms, service, and in-hotel restaurants to my "top 3 needs" when in Tokyo, which are 1) to be *really close* to the metro; 2) be in one of the bustling areas; 3) have great views. 1) It is really close to Shibuya Station (closer is only the Shibuya Hotel Excel Tokyu) which places you close to the famous Shibuya Square and its well known "crossing shuffle". Shibuya station is also on the Yamanote line (which goes around Tokyo like a big ring); the Yamanote is the one train line that is the best friend of all those who go to Tokyo for the first time.2) Also, the Cerulean is literally 3 and a half minutes away from Shibuya Square... if you are going to Japan, this is where you want to be. The place is so characteristically Japanese you will have a blast. You are also a short walk (or 1 station) away from Yoyogi Park (where you can visit the Meiji Jungo Mae shrine), and shopping districts like Omotesando and Harajuku. Shinjuku and Meguro are also close by on the Yamanote, and Kamakura (with its wonderful temples) is no more than a 1 hour train ride away (making it a perfect day trip).3) The Cerulean has crazy breathtaking view. Dont get to close to the windows if you have vertigo! I normally go either to the Cerulean or to the Shibuya Excel, with the Excel being closer to the metro, but the Cerulean having better rooms/service/vibe. Both are good choices, and both are in the Expedia VIP program (which is always a +).Other than that, great staff and great stay. Couple of suggestions:1) If you are leaving with a plane, always reserve a bus ride to the airport. The concierge can help you.2) The breakfast buffet is kind of "bla" - but their patisserie bar (right before the entrance to the buffet area) is excellent! You have to try one of their sweets. Apart from looking like a miniature piece of culinary architecture, they taste like paradise :)

We stayed at this hotel 2 nights. Unfortunately we could not stay longer. Too BAD. We had a great room with view to the old Tokyo Tower with an amazing view of the city. The room was huge for Japanese standards and VERY CLEAN, modern and well maintained. We had the best breakfast ever in Hotels. The quality of the food and presentation was just great.Location? Walking distance to Shybuya GO FOT IT. maybe you won`t find anything better in Tokyo.
good sized, clean, rooms. nice views of the city. close to the train station. plenty of english speakers in the very helpful staff. good food. close to everything.

We spent 6 days at the Cerulean Tower so that we could meet up with a group tour of Japan. We found it to be an excellent hotel that was clean, in a great location and with a terrific breakfast buffet. The hotel is a short walk to the Shibuyu train station, which makes all parts of Tokyo easily accessible. Anyone, with any familiarity with a big city mass transit system, will have no trouble at all navigating in Tokyo. We found the concierge to be very helpful in familiarizing us in the use and layout of the subway system.Our room overlooked the metro area, it was quiet, clean and comfortable. The room was large by most city standards and had all the amenities. It was cleaned and freshened each day of our stay. And the cleaning staff was unobtrusive. No matter what time we started our day there was no untimely attempts to enter our room.The lobby staff was friendly and helpful. We found their willingness to be helpful refreshing.The staff of the breakfast area were also attentive and friendly although I must agree with someone's earlier statement about the runny eggs in the omlettes, a small complaint when faced with the variety on the buffet. It would be a shame not to mention the fresh squeezed orange juice prepared in front of you and the homemade marmalade is not to be missed.

The Cerulean Tower has a lot going for it. It's in a fantastic part of town, right across the road from Shibuya Railway Station. There are about a hundred billion restaurants within walking distance (OK, that number may be slightly exaggerated), and some excellent shopping to be done. It has several good restaurants and bars in the hotel building itself, as well as a 24-hour convenience store (more of this please). The wi-fi is good and strong. The beds are hard as rocks (not my personal preference, but when you look at the elegant and poised Japanese compared with the slouching Westerners on the streets you can't help wondering who's got it right).But I was not overly enamored of the service. The staff were acceptably polite, and the doormen who oversee the alighting and departing were terrifically helpful, especially with my limited Japanese. But you certainly don't get the impression anyone at the front desk or the information desk is going the extra mile to make your stay a pleasant one. They performed up to a particular standard, but never exceeded it (unlike the hotel I stayed at next, in Kyoto, where the staff were overwhelmingly impressive and really tried hard to make me feel at home). So the Cerulean loses a star in my rating. As a business or vacation hotel in a great part of Tokyo, it's a perfectly functional place. But functional - nothing more...

Great location near the Shibuya station. Very clean with excellent service. Excellent sound insulation. Beds are rather hard by north american standards but are par for course in Asia.Restaurants are VERY good but expensive (e.g. $18 for a glass of white wine and $35 for buffet breakfast). Cheaper restaurant alternatives abound all around. The breakfast buffet is average. The cooked-to-order eggs can be slow to be served if it is busy as the chef only has one burner/pan and can only cook one order at a time.You can use the gym (but not the pool) for free between 6a and 7a but it'll cost Y2100/day afterward. Run the suggested 3.3km route outside instead (see map in your room).There is a 7/11 on the second floor (accessible from outside) with an ATM that accepts North American ATM cards.

The Cerulean hotel is basically your standard foreign traveller/business hotel located minutes from Shibuya Station. The rooms are fairly average and common for an international business hotel, nothing to complain about. Rooms are all equipped with those amazing Japanese toilets that have the handy dandy bidet water spout. There are these amazing, if not kitschy, automated massage chairs located in the mens locker rooms leading into the pool and gym. Do yourself a favor and have a sit. The breakfast buffet served in the lobby restaurant is above average but do ask for your eggs well done unless you like your made-to-order omelette a tad runny. The service at the Cerulean is really the star, as is common in Japan, every staffer takes their job and assigned duties very seriously and it seems that all employees of the Cerulean take deep pride in their jobs and the guests of the hotel are the beneficiaries.

On the list of top hotels I've ever stayed at. Conveniently located to pretty much everything you want in Shibuya. The place was very clean and staff very professional and friendly. Breakfast was western buffet style on the days we stayed. We didnt have a chance to try out the other restaurant but if the buffet had anything to say, I would assume the other restaurant was just as good if not better.We were in the hotel when a 5.4 earthquake hit this year and we rode it out. Place is safe ;)

Walking distance from Shibuya station and the mall. There's plenty of great food shop surrounding the hotels. The room is extremely clean too and on top of that it has such a great city view and nice vanity. We got to put in the room where it's overlooking the shibuya main crossing. And top it all, the room is extremely quiteThe bathroom is AMAZING, we are able to see view of the city from here as well (there was a huge window beside the tub) Great range of amenities provided too, so you wouldn't need to bring all those toothbrush, etc from home. They also provided us Yukata and Bathrobe!Staff was extremely polite and friendly too, they upgrade our room from standard to executive because someone has check in into our room earlier.Well to sum it up we love staying here and will definitely come back next time we are going to Tokyo!

The rooms and especially the bath room was very large and roomy with lots of space to put all your cosmetics, drop bag, etc. The separate shower stall was a big plus esp. for mature travelers. Another biggie was the covering for the beds or duvet which was changed every day like the sheets. No need to worry about the top. The surrounding area was busy, busy. Food show at the RR station was fabulous. If you can get a deal for the executive floors, it's worth it as there is a 2 1/2 hour free cocktail and snack time and a nice buffet breakfast included in the Exec. Lounge. Coffee is available all day. Would gladly return.

I had family visiting and recommended that they look into staying here. The hotel is amazing and beautiful. A short walk from Shibuya station and crossing this hotel is in a prime location to go anywhere in Tokyo. The rooms are very nice, clean and generous sized.If you stay check out the bar on the very top floor. It's got amazing views of Tokyo at night.That being said there are some major drawbacks. There is extra charge for everything. Internet? Extra. Pool? Extra and so on. Although the staff are friendly the English level for this, a five star hotel, is not up to par. If you have questions, concerns, problems, etc you will be met with confused looks and having to repeat yourself many times. When asking about shipping some luggage to our Kyoto hotel it took quite awhile for the front desk staff to understand. When we asked the concierge about where to obtain stamp books for temples we were met with more confused looks. The Italian restaurant had a small English menu that clearly did not have everything listed on it. Likewise the restaurant had huge display of wine but there were only a few listed on the English menu. The staff did not really speak English and could not even tell us how something was prepared. This being the hotel's restaurant the staff should be trained in basic restaurant English communication. For example: When a family member wanted a vodka drink that wasn't listed on the menu the waitress didn't understand "vodka", I ended up looking it up in my phone's dictionary and showing it to her. It's pronounced wadoka, by the way,One of the person's traveling with us was in a wheel chair and had trouble going over the bath tub wall to take a shower. Upon our return from Kyoto we requested a room with a separate shower and bath. This was ignored and not understood so when we came back she still had the same issues. The one handicapped friendly room only had twin beds even though the upgraded rooms have separate shower and bath she was only offered this after a fuss was made. She ended up taking it but as she was there with her husband it wasn't very romantic.The menus in the hotel's main restaurant, on the first floor, had silly spelling mistakes or weren't translated correctly instead just had the Japanese words in roman letters. Likewise, the information book in the rooms also had silly spelling mistakes. It is my view that a five star hotel, or one trying to be, shouldn't be making these silly mistakes. This is a hotel that advertises in English trying to attract foreign guests. If they cannot answer anything but "what time is check out" and "your room number is 2103" it isn't worth the money.In the end this hotel is centrally located, clean, beautiful and has great views of Tokyo and Fuji, The management needs to get all of their menus, not just a few items, translated and encourage their staff to gain a higher level of English. Because of the communication issues I do not recommend this hotel to English speakers (or non Japanese speakers) who haven't been to Tokyo before and are planning to spend a lot of time in the hotel. Also I wouldn't recommend spending the money to eat in this hotel Shibuya is an international area most places will either speak a bit of English and/or have an English menu. You can get the same good quality food elsewhere.

We stayed at the Cerulean upon the recommendations of a family member. The room over looked the city, was spacious, modern, clean and the staff was beyond friendly. Had a beautiful breakfast in the hotel's restaurant. I would highly recommend this hotel!

Within walking distance to Shibuya Station makes it an excellent choice of stay in Tokyo. The service provided was excellent and the staff were all friendly and very helpful in every way. I would definitely stay here again next time I return to Japan. The breakfast and dinner was great. The hotel view from our room was breathtaking as well. Highly recommend this place for all.

Spent 5 nights here for business. 5 minutes to Shibuya metro station. Major station served by multiple lines. Hotel is very nice. Clean, comfortable rooms although the beds are hard and like sleeping on concrete. Friendly staff.

This hotel is well located in Shibuya, near the main station. The rooms are clean, quiet and the staff is very nice. The breakfast is great and the executive floor is a perfect place to do some emails. The view is also nice. The only thing that i don't like about this hotel is that guests have to pay extra fees to access the swimming pool and the fitness room, which is something i don't understand. And careful, if you have any tatoo, the swimming pool is prohibited!

As first time visitors to Tokyo it was pretty difficult deciding where to stay. After spending a week in Tokyo I think this location was perfect. It was only a very short walk down the road and over a pedestrian overpass and you were right in the middle of Shibuya station - great for subways to all sorts of places, and the Yamanote Line train that loops the city. Also to see the crazy-busy Shibuya crossing (which is actually pretty easy to navigate!). Lots of department stores and places to eat.Staff were friendly and helpful. Breakfast was pretty expensive at 3000 yen for buffet - so if they have an option that includes the breakfast go for that. It was excellent though - with a chef on hand making fresh omelettes to order and a good selection of cooked and fresh foods. Espresso coffee included in the price. We ended up eating there most mornings as it was a great way to start the day - I just mentally added the cost to the room price.The queen room we stayed in the "lower" level (still floors 20-24, where the hotel starts) was a decent size with a good bathroom, great views, and a very firm but very comfortable bed. The bed was MUCH bigger than a standard Queen - we ended up just having our 5 year sleep there too and there was plenty of room.Overall highly recommended.

Great hotel, deserves the hype. Concierge was very helpful for restsaurants and booked us great seats to the sumo tournament. They charge $30/day to use the gym which is not cool. Also, book online through agoda as opposed to directly and save money. We extended a night and even reservationist said it was best to book on agoda.com

I've stayed at the Cerulean many times in the past 10 years and choose it for the location. A decade ago, it was one of the nicest hotels but the rooms are now terribly dated. The service remains excellent and the breakfast is nice but it's not my top choice anymore.

We stayed here for one week while my husband was a business trip in Tokyo last fall. The room itself was spacious, quiet, and very comfortable. The hotel was very conveniently located near the Shibuya station and there were a ton of excellent non-touristy restaurants nearby which the concierge directed us towards each night. She asked how adventurous we were with exploring and looking for street signs (very difficult when they aren't written in English and you have to match up characters!), and we were happily able to find each one after a 30-45 minute adventure. Finally, I fell ill one evening and my husband called the hotel manager to help us find a nearby hospital with a doctor who spoke English. The manager escorted us from our room to a taxi which drove us to the closest hospital about five minutes away. I felt very taken care of that entire week - it seemed everyone kept a close eye on me as I came and went which we really appreciated.

This hotel is extremely well positioned in Shibuya with easy access to the station both for the Narita Express as well as the local network.Absolutely no complaints about the hotel with the sole exception of this bizarre desire to charge for internet access particularly given the rather high daily rates for the establishment. Why they can't lump it in with the overall per diem rate is beyond my comprehension. One factor to watch out for is that ethernet is accessible but not Wi-Fi. You require an AirportExpress unit to create your own wireless environment.The staff were all most accommodating and we stayed twice, on our arrival in Japan and just prior to departure.

Having just stayed at this hotel during the cherry blossom season for about $300 Australian dollars per night, I can say that overall my partner and I were very happy with the experience. The hotel is in a fantastic location, nice and close to Shibuya train station which is much easier to navigate than Shinjuku - just look for the West exit. Free Wifi was convenient and there was no limit to the number of devices we could 'hook up' which was appreciated and meant that Skype phone calls were easily done, as well as using laptops etc. The room itself was modern (enough), pleasant looking and super clean (though I wouldn't expect anything else in Japan) - we were lucky enough to get a corner room which made the space a lot bigger so I would recommend others try and obtain this same position. Service was most accommodating and friendly - without any trouble we got a late checkout which was a real bonus as we had a late flight out of Tokyo. Having stayed at the Peninsula last time I can't quite call this a "luxury" hotel, though with the rate at less than 50% of the price I think ultimately you probably get more for your money. I wouldn't hesitate to stay at this hotel next time.

The hotel was great, easy to get to and from. 150 metres from Shibuya station and crossing. Also 1 min in a taxi with luggage to Narita Express station when leaving. Free upgrade and Wifi was 3250 Yen for 1 week... Normally 1000 Yen a day. One price for all laptops / iPhones / devices. A few restaurants at the lower floors and a large 7/11 in the building. I stay in a lot of hotels and this one was Proffesional. I booked on Agoda and got 20% off total price for 5 nights. The only bad experience was the club sandwich from room service that was soggy but the fish and chips where actually great. Not the normal English style fat feast. I asked the information desk where I could find a Redmoon wallet (hard to find) and they slipped perfect direction in English and Japanese so I could show people to a back street shop in Uneo. Great!

Look elsewhere, this has to be one of the worst value hotels ever, the service I received at the bar and restaurant was so bad I thought I was involved in some kind of practical joke... Sadly it was not

As has been said by many reviewers before me, the hotel is good. It's clean, beds comfy, shower is skin peeling. The location is great; near public transportation and with many good neighbor restaurants nearby. If you are on business, it is a fine place to stay but it's expensive. For an upper class hotel there are some things that are annoying, and these have been said before by travelers. Maybe some day Management will iste. At these rates it is discomforting that the management choses to charge a la carte for everything (internet, no complimentary tea service in room as is custom in Asia, pool). The management must be studying the practices of the US airline industry but apparently are not aware of the ire of their customers. Good grief, a tea bag costs, what ten cents? Why fleece the customer so much? There is great hoopla over energy saving and on check in the guest is asked to declare which items they do not need replaced during their stay. No matter what you check, you will consistently get clean towels and robes every day. Why bother pretending to be green? Service is very impersonal. Yes, lots of bowing.
