But the Concierge desk could not provide accurate directions. I would stay here again if there was no other option but I'd prefer to go someplace where I do not feel so taken advantage of. Other than that, it's a good place. Hint: if this is your first trip to Tokyo you may want to take the Airport Limo Bus from Narita rather than the Narita Express. The Airport Bus will take you door to door. The subway station can be a bit intimidating when you first experience it. Also, eat in the local restaurants. There is plenty to chose from and they try to be very accomodating. The food is excellent no matter where you go.
Best view. Stylish bathroom. Best situation to city. Very clean. Kindly stuff.

Staying next to Shibuya Station but without the crowd in a very good hotel with an amazing view and for a reasonable price. That's the Cerulean. Ask for a Sky view room from floor 32 to the top it totally deserves it

I chose this hotel because I had stayed before on business and thought it would be a good option for our first few nights in Tokyo. Rooms are very nice, clean and quiet, and even with a city view room we had a fantastic view of Fuji-san. The down side is the annoying extra charges for nearly everything, from internet (only hotel in our entire Japan trip to charge for internet!) to the green tea bags in the room. Also in our small bathroom with sliding door there was nowhere to hang up the fluffy bathrobes. So, very civilised, breakfast v expensive but there is a nice coffee shop just down the street near the pedestrian bridge.

We stayed at this hotel for 5 nights on the first leg of our Japan trip. The location is fantastic, 5 minutes walk from key Tokyo subway station (a few stops away from the bullet train). The service was very professional, albeit slightly impersonal. The concierge was excellent and very helpful in guiding me to great restaurants and sites. I cannot remember her name, but her assistance was commendable. The room was a good size and perfect for what we needed. We were craving Chinese food (my wife is a vegetarian so some good chinese vegetables) and we ate one night at the Chinese restaurant on the first floor. The food was good, but as with most of Japan, incredibly expensive. All in all, a very good place from which to explore Tokyo and overall good value for money.

Stayed at the Cerulean for 7 nights to experience Tokyo city life. The hotel is located near the famed Shibuya crossing (& its shopping stores) and the JR Yamanote line subway. "Near" means a comfy 10 min walk to the crossing and subway line (via an overhead crossing). Rooms are spacious and clean, The bathroom is probably the best I have ever seen (especially the toilet with lots of electronic features). We stayed on the 32nd floor and the view outside the window is of an open cityscape. Sleep quality was good but not outstanding as the pillows provided were not comfortable.Eating in the hotel is quite costly so going out to eat in side street restaurants (or picking up packed meals from 7-11, Lawsons) would be a better option. Food quality in all areas outside & around the hotel is very good.The information desk of the hotel is very good (look for Tanaka San), providing answers to everything from where to go & how to get there. Internet is not free and is available for a fee for either Yen 1k for 24 hrs or Yen 3k for more than 3 nights use. I would suggest getting the Yen 3K package for long staying guests as surfing the web would be a better option than having to watch the hotel TV whose channels are mostly in Japanese. Bus services to and from the airport to this hotel is available and is always on time. Good Location, Good room, good service makes this hotel worth coming back to when visiting Shibuya. It falls short of getting an excellent Rating due to the pay as you use internet service (which should be given free like other hotels).

This was a good hotel, very comfortable, all the typical business hotel services, large rooms with views over Mount Fuji (on a clear day and on the right side of the hotel!).Staff speak good English and are helpful. Good location for Shibuya Junction and walkable from the station (use the bridge to get there).Only downsides are that the restaurant (room service) wasn't great - to be honest it was the worst teriyaki chicken I've ever had and breakfast was very expensive (EUR30).Would definitely recommend but would also suggest the nearby excellent restaurants as an alternative to eating in the hotel.

The hotel is about two blocks from the Shibuya station - uphill, so a bit of a drag with suitcases. it's nice that ut's so tall - if you go out the wrong exit, you can usually see the hotel, even from the wrong side of the tracks.We arrived shortly after noon and were able to check into our room early and the boxes and suitcase we had shipped ahead to the hotel were all waiting for us. The rooms are quite large. We had a triple with a view of Mt Fuji three of four days which was stunning. The shower was great. While the toilets in the public washrooms have heated seats, the ones in the standards rooms at least don't. The carpets to the rooms and elevators was a little dirty and worn, but the overall quality of the hotel is very good.Service, as you would expect is excellent. Perhaps not that of the MO, but still excellent. The airport bus leaves from the basement level, and the hotel took care of making reservations, getting us the tickets, and storing our bags and getting them on the bus.After staying in Shinjuku and Chuo a few times I highly recommend the hotel and the Shibuya area.

Very nice rooms. We got a corner-room in 27th floor with a fantastic view. Twin beds, very good with three seperate pillows, a sofa and a good chair in front of the window. Waterheater for tea/coffee.The room also have a writing-desk, flat TV with a few English channels like BBC, CNN etc.Big bathroom with separate showercabin and all the things you need.The room was very clean. The frontdesk-staff is very helpfull to help with the trainsystem, a help you really need.By arrival you will have to take your luggage by yourself to the reception when you come from the trainstation as it is one floor up. It is an esculator from street-level.Internet is not free,and, in my opinion, quite expensive!Breakfast is not included. If you want to have it the price is around 3000 Yen.The staff is very helpfull and polite, but receptionstaff could be friendlier. Lack of personal touch!The hotel is nice, but pricy!

Spend the $$ and try this place out, rooms are quality in both finish and space. Beds were great and very quiet all round. Great views from all sides and everyone knows about the location right? Well its central to all Shibuya has to offer. I'll go back there again for sure

I stayed at the Cerulean for one week while on a business trip and found the hotel to be a very good hotel. The huge lobby was a great place to start the day by arranging meet ups there - then the walk to the train station in Shibuya is just minutes away. The breakfast was a bit pricey but very good and the hotel staff was excellent in helping. We experienced several earthquakes over 5 and I felt safe in the modern and quiet building. The beds were wonderful (if you like a hard bed) and the bathtubs are huge. I would certainly stay here again.

Make your booking early as this can keep your pricing down considerably. I wouldn't exactly say that the Cerulean has any personality or soul, its a typical business/leisure hotel. You pay for what you get. The rooms are clean, spacious enough and if you can secure a high level floor, some spectacular views. Shibuya can keep you busy for a couple days, so the location is key. You can also hop on the JR lines at Shibuya station to take you elsewhere when needed. They have a great top floor bar, but I must admit they run it like a prison. I felt more unwelcome there, than any other place in Japan. They are purely concerned about making money up there and the hotel guests have no preferential treatment in getting nice tables without a cover charge to sit down. I do understand why they want to charge, but for hotel guests, there should be some other way. I will never drink on that level again. All in all. A good hotel with decent rates.

This is a great choice for a first trip to Tokyo as it is relatively easy to find when arriving late from a long haul flight. We were able to find our way there based on comments from other TA reviewers. It is close to eveything that Shibuya has to offer and is only 5 mins walk to the train station over a pedestrian overpass. Our room was on the 32nd floor with great views over the city and the heart of Shibuya. It was spacious, quiet and smartly decorated. The bathroom was huge with a separate bath/shower compartment. It was perfect for relaxing and sleeping after a day out sightseeing in the stifling heat. We would have liked better teamaking facilities in our room; small handleless cups, japanese tea and a kettle that never quite got the water hot enough.The buffet breakfast was better value than the set breakfast but we felt it was expensive and quite ordinary compared to other places we stayed at in Japan with a poor selection of Japanese goodies. This may be a reflection of the clientele in that they are trying to cover all bases with breakfast preferences. We went up to Level 40 for drinks one night and I had what must be the worlds smallest strawberry daiquiri. We were also charged Y800 each to sit by the window. Great views and ambience but it comes at a price! Service was efficient and we were upgraded to a club room on a higher level on the other side of the building when we returned for two more nights at the end of our stay in Japan; a nice touch. Th foyer and lobby lounge however was cavernous and rather soul less in contrast to all the other spaces in this hotel. Overall we enjoyed our stay here and would return.

The hotel is right outside the heart of Shibuya and just a quick walk to Shibuya Train Station. The night life and shopping in Shibuya is great, plus it is extremely easy to get around anywhere you want to go in Tokyo with a quick walk to the Shibuya Train Station. The price was a bit on the high side compared to other hotels, but I stayed here on a recommendation of a friend and have been very happy.

The Narita Express train can whisk you directly from the airport terminals to Shibuya station in about an hour and a quarter. I am amazed that the hotel doesn't offer simple walking directions from the station though (Leave the station at the WEST exit, walk over the pedestrian walkway and the hotel is 75 metres up the road - its the large tower looking to your left when you exit the main Shibuya station complex). This being my first visit to Tokyo, I left by mistake at the new south entrance of this very large station and spent some time walking up and down a road in the dark and sleet trying to find the hotel!The hotel rooms are a good size and the higher up you go the better the view. Mount Fuji is visible in the distance. Good breakfast buffet - both Japanese and Western dishes. The restaurants were very good, especially the Italian. Large indoor pool with saunas and jacuzzi. As mentioned by other TA reviewers, you do pay extra for use of the spa, internet etc. unless paying to be on the executive level. This is very much a business hotel and quiet therefore at the weekends.

I stayed here for a week on business. I needed a hotel where the rooms were comfortable to work in for half a day each day, but with business support and convenient to the Ginza line of the subway. This was a superb answer. I had a King room on level 32. Colleagues in corner rooms were in slightly larger spaces. It is worth seeing if you can get a room facing Mount Fuji, although variable weather and poor visibility makes sightings rare.The room was very comfortable and well set up for a business traveller (and large enough to avoid cabin fever). Rooms in the nearby Excel hotel are totally unsuited to work in. The guest services staff were excellent. Shibuya station is very close. The hotel itself is well located in Shibuya. The ground floor restaurant and bar were handy for meetings and the food was fine (although lovers of good italian espresso will be disappointed, but will at least survive!).The curiously named "Airport Limosine" Bus service offers comfortable, reasonably priced transfers from hotel door to Narita.While there I had a reasonable meal in Kanetanaka-so, the inhouse Japanese restaurant. Sashimi was delightful and well presented. A bamboo rice cleverly evoked simple rural fare. Unfortunately the tempura batter was falling apart and oily. A meal at the Coucagno on the 40th floor was superb (I am unsure whether it still retains its Michelin hat, but would not be surprised if it does).Perhaps the most extraordinary act of service I have ever seen in a hotel occurred at check out. Rushing, I dropped my house keys on the floor as I left my room. I was just boarding the airport bus a few minutes later when front of house ran up to me and returned them. For housekeeping to be in the room, see them and for me to be located and identified in the space of 5 minutes was simply remarkable. It was consistent with the whole tone of the establishment.

Very nice hotel, located at only few minutes from the train station of Shibuya. Wonderful view of Tokyo from the rooms. Excellent room service, very clean, with rooms quite large. The rate of the room is acceptable. The personnel is very kind, specially at the reception desk. Breakfast is very good and with a great choice of food. Service of the Limousine bus to the airport.

Good solid reliable, few queues on checkin/out, breaksfast fine, room fine, staff quite good. Shower ok, bed a bit hard but again fine, room clean, nice view from room.It is about a hundred metres from Shibuya station and about 200m from the crossing.Somehow in here you feel like just another of the one of the million guests they've had in this big hotel this year. Feels a bit factory even though everything is fine. They always feel just a bit behind the eightball. For example breksfast is in a massive area with really high ceiling like a big noisy barn, decor not inspiring but low maintenance and you need to wait while the omelette guy does the 3 omelettes before you. There's nothing excellent about it, you just feel like a number.I stayed at the Hilton Shinjuku and that's a an example of a crew that's got their act together in terms of service.But again there's nothing wrong with the Cerulean.

We stayed at this business hotel for a leisure trip to Tokyo. It is conveniently located in Shibuya, next to Shibuya Station, so you can take the Narita Express all the way into Shibuya Station and then walk to the hotel if you wish. If not, it is less than 5min by taxi.The hotel itself is comfortable and well maintained. We opted for one of the up-graded rooms with a king bed, which had a lovely view over tokyo. The bathroom was large and well-appointed, with a large shower and bath.The reason why I gave this hotel a 3* and not a 4* was because of the lack of certain amenities you would expect in a hotel of its class as well as the inability of the staff to give accurate directions. This is in comparison to other hotels we have stayed at in Tokyo.There is no complimentary WI-FI for hotel guests, even in the lobby / reception areas. This is also the first hotel I have ever stayed in that does not provide complimentary tea/coffee in the rooms. It is available, but please do be aware that a teabag is charged at about 400 yen / US$ 5. I thought that was rather bold of them considering the room rates they charge. Also, although the hotel has a pool and gym facilities, it is not complimentary for all hotel guests - only those on the executive floors, otherwise, there is a fee.The biggest let down for us was the inability for the staff to provide accurate directions to restaurants etc. The address system in Tokyo is notoriously difficult so we can understand small inaccuracies. However, they were not able to accurately direct us to the New South Entrance of the Shibuya Station, which is about 150m from the hotel. This entrance provides direct access to the platform for the Narita Express train. They conveniently omited to tell us that this entrance exist, instead tried to send us on a round-about route through the main station, even though it is clearly marked out on the map of the station they provided us. When asked about this entrance, they recommended that we take a 5 min US$10 taxi ride to the station. Anyway, we did not have much luggage, so we took a chance and seached for the entrance ourselves. For those interested, you go up the staires on your right just as you pass under the train tracks straight up from the hotel, and it is 50m down the road there. It is incomprehensible that the hotel is not able to provide directions for such an easy route to a station that I am sure 80% of their hotel guests would use.Our main impression is that the Cerulean is mainly interested in business clientele and not the leisure traveller, which is a pity, as it's great location would suit both.

Sometimes when we make a choice to splash out on luxury we come away feeling a little disappointed by the way the staff looks down it's collective nose at you once they realise it's a once in a lifetime treat and in their eyes you don't really belong there!Not so the Cerulean Tower Hotel in Tokyo, there everyone is treated as if they were the most important person in the world and the courtesy and good manners with which every member of staff carries out their duties is second to none. From the moment you enter the large reception area and are greeted by liveried Bell Boys and Girls who whisk your luggage away to your room and the reception staff who bow as you approach the desk, you realise you have entered the world of Japanese service which is unrivalled anywhere else in the world. The rooms are all modern with large bathrooms, each having both a bath and double shower cubicle, the bed linen is thick and ironed until it's as smooth as glass and the rooms are kept spotlessly clean.The food at breakfast is incredible with traditional English beakfast competing with Japanese specialities and also fresh croisant and other French pastries. For the healthier resident there is also an abundance of fresh fruit and freshly squeezed juices.The hotel has a large gym area with a good selection of machines to use as well as a good sized swimming pool, all on the 3rd floor. Shibuya, where the hotel is sited, is a bustling area with lot's of shops and bars playing cool jazz whilst serving steaming bowls of Udon noodles, it's a young hip area and a great place to start your holiday in Japan. I recommend it as i know you will not be disappointed.

This was my second visit to Tokyo, but my first time staying at the Cerulean hotel. I was given a room on the 30th floor and my first impression was wow, what a view!! Then when I got over the excitement of having such a great view, I noticed how good the actual room was. I was staying on my own and did not ask for a twin room, but was given one. The room was exceptionally big, with 2 king size single beds, writing desk, and arm chair. The bathroom was massive! Full size bath, and seperate shower. I did not eat at the hotel, but as others have said, there are many eateries in the immediate area.The airconditioning in this hotel would have to be the most efficient and quietest I have ever encountered in any hotel.The hotel is approximately 100 mts from Shibuya station, but I must admit the first night I did get lost trying to find the hotel from the station. All in all, I would highly recommend this hotel. But it does not come cheap.

Great location, The airport bus stops right downstairs, which is great if you have heaps of luggage & don't want to drag it through the streets of Japan. Metro & JR a few mins away, great zone for some nightlife too & guitar shopping, if you are into that sort of thing. Very friendly service, but i wouldn't expect any less in Japan.Had room on 28th floor with sweeping views of Tokyo, I mean serioulsy, what more can you ask for??

We booked the hotel in advance and therefore we had a bargain to get a room at this hotel. The location is perfect - few minutes walk from Shibuya station so you can get around pretty much everywhere. The room was also nice - I felt it had more the Japanese touch in a western set up. The room was clean and the staffs there were very very helpful. One other thing which I would recommend the guest to do, is to write the hotel in advance and request for which view you would like to see from the hotel. We have chosen the Mount Fuji view which was just magnificient to see. We woke up every morning and find Mount Fuji straight in front of us from our bed, and that was such a beautiful experience. The only thing which I would mention is the bed. The matress was just too too hard for me that I woke up with a pain in my back. That's the only reason (but could be the biggest I'm afraid) I stayed away from this hotel when I returned to Tokyo a few days later.For those who like the hard matresses - this could be your hotel, as the rest is just all perfect.

Staff was nothing but welcoming and upgraded us considering we arrived the day before Christmas. Our room had a breathtaking view of the Tokyo Tower. Housekeeping replenished daily including slippers and bath robe. We had an amazing experience and would return to stay on our next trip. Staying at The Cerulean made our very first trip to Tokyo a very memorable one.

My wife and i stayed at the Cerulean Tower for 7 nights in October 2011 as a 50th birtday treat.Firstly, the location is great, just a 5 minute walk into the heart of Shibuya, which is very much the happening place with hundreds of shops/bars/restaraunts and an amazing area at night with all the neon lights.The roooms were also excellent - we chose the ones with views over Shibuya and Shinjuku, which included a bath with a full view window. The separate small room for luggage and clothes was also very useful. Bed was enormous and super comfy.Cannot comment on breakfast or dinner at the hotel as we ate out all the time - ther literally is so much choice.Also worth mentioning the staff who all seem to be genuinely lovely - we asked the concierge for some details on a trip to Nagoya on the bullet train and when we returned to the hotel, she had prepared us a pack with maps, things to do etc which we thought was tremendous and made our trip much more enjoyable.Eating out in Tokyo can be very expensive and we got caught a couple of times (avoid Inakaya in Roppongi...its stupid money) but in Shibuya, there is a pub chain called Kirin City which we loved as you can sit with a beer/wine and just order quality nibbles as and when required - much more enjuoyable than formal dining.Overall, great hotel in great location

Cerulean Tower is one of the best business hotels I've stayed at. Maybe it's because they've upgraded my room the three times I've stayed there, but the 35th floor views, even from the bath, and the spacious room have impressed. The hotel restaurants are great, but pricey. Great views from the bar at top of the hotel. When feeling more frugal, the concierge recommended a great more reasonable bar down the street. The only bad part of the stay is the crummy hotel gym - it's very limited and was way too hot.

We stayed in this hotel which was alittle over our budget but it was clean, convienently located and the staff were very helpful...the spa cost about £15 per person and was empty when we arrived (we couldnt check in early so we went to the spa to shower and freshen up) it was pure bliss... the only regret was being too jet lagged to really enjoy the pool.....Lovely clean rooms, we went to have a drink at the top of the hotel which was pricey but worth it for the viewWould definately recommend and stay here again.

I have been to this hotel twice. One time with our family and the other time just my husband and me. Rooms are spacious and very clean. Breakfast buffet is outstanding and service excellent. The hotel is just next to the Shibuya station which is very convenient.

excellent, clean, modern. luxurious hotel in Shibuya neighborhood of Tokyo. Like many hotels, this hotel is on the higher floors of a building which includes offices on lower floors. Excellent service from all staff encountered during 4 night stay in Oct 2011, from bellhop to concierge. Rooms are large with excellent views, very comfortable beds, very clean, and nice finishings. Large bathroom with soaking tub and shower. excellent closet space and sound proofing. Many restaurants in hotel however they are all quite expensive. The surrounding neighborhood (Shibuya) has many, many choices of restaurants of all types and price points. Also excellent shopping though not much for historical sights. Hotel is within walking distance to Shibuya train station which is a hub for JR as well as metro trains. JR train from Narita airport stops at this station and you can walk to hotel (only a few blocks).Only negatives is that hotel charges for use of gym, pool and internet, and wireless internet not available anywhere in hotel; in fact free wireless internet difficult to find in Tokyo - one place that had it was apple stores. Hotel is not inexpensive but well worth it for a vacation.
Perfect hotel. Walk to shibuya and train was five minutes. I would stay here again if I ever come back to tokyo

Tokyo is massive, and as many know hotels are endless with the very standard of 4*-5* western hotels such as Marriott, Hyatt, etc.... Originally my travel companion and I had opted for the Capitol Hotel in Tokyo as it seemed to mix the wonders of cultural diversity with a savvy price. Modern traditional Japanese rooms in the photos so why not? The more I did research on the location, the more I was opt for changing. Ok so Roppongi was next on the list of spots to scope out for a hotel, but thankfully having a friend who is Japanese suggested Shibuya. Shibuya? He sent me links to the hotel, read majority of the TA reviews on it, found a great deal on a booking site for the hotel, became more convinced Cerulean was the hotel to choose. My Japanese buddy was most influential in the decision as he stays there quite often when back in Tokyo so what do friends do best? Steer other friends in the right direction.....Cerulean it was.  I flew out Thanksgiving day to meet up with my bf who was flying back from a dive trip in Palau so we only had 3 days total in Tokyo. I haven't been to Tokyo city, just other prefectures north and south years ago. Cerulean is perched high enough to spot when you exit the WEST exit of Shibuya station. As soon as you exit, cross the street where the buses are lined up, or walk across the pedestrian bridge (with elevators) conveniently within a 5-minute walking distance. Narita Express platform 4 direct is the way to go. Taxi's need not apply, but be warned, it is up a small hill. The staff is extremely friendly, plenty of options for dining but keep in mind it is PRICEY at the hotel. I suggest snacks at 7-11 just outside the hotel, or of course cruising around Shibuya. Two 7-11's in and next to Cerulean with a ton of snacks so stock up! Rooms are very well kept, amenities are great, just outside the hustle and bustle of the busiest intersections. I'd suggest finding a balance of a nice hotel and cheaper food through the streets of Shibuya. Meiji Shrine is about a 15 minute walk on the way to Harajuku, Roppongi is a short taxi drive away, you can't go wrong with this hotel and I'm quite pleased my friend suggested it as I looked past it several times thinking it was too much to consider. However with the endless amount of options for food, entertainment, and distance, this is the hotel to review and consider.I did choose to put "Average" for my rating on value because of legitimate reasons, average price for a hotel like that. It's not cheap, it is a high end hotel so if you're like us who like to sleep well, have amenities, but don't mind 2* dining, then nothing wrong with the compromise. It's not cheap, BUT not putting you in an economic downfall either. I would put 5* if the rates were miraculously subdued compared to other high end hotels but let's be real here, for a hotel like Cerulean, the rates are reasonable and I say this to their benefit. Suggestion: Do your homework, find booking sites, compare rates, and then make a decision. As all booking sites say it's time sensitive (...."Only 3 left at this rate!") It fluctuates usually within $20-$80 difference comparably on average all for Cerulean.

I was lucky enough to accompany my husband on a business trip to Tokyo. This was the 6th time he has stayed at the Cerulean. The location couldn't have been better. There is an endless supply of restaurants and activity close by. The view of the city and Mt. Fuji from the room is amazing on clear days. Very friendly and accommodating staff and concierge. Best beds and pillows ever!!
Great business hotel. Surrounded by good shopping and nice neighborhoods to walk around and get a feel of the city. Very clean and quite tasteful.

Great hotel with clean nice size rooms & terrific staff. In the heart of Shibuya which makes sometimes for a slow traffic crawl in a car to the hotel. But never really a problem. Get the deal with free breakfast & all day drinks & snacks on the 35th floor. Very nice breakfast with a sweeping view of tokyo & if your lucky a view of Mt. Fuji. This was my second stay here & both times were very nice. Ask for the Shibuya station side view & you will have a nice shot of the massive groups of people who scramble across the Shibuya station crosswalk down below. Also a stunning night view of Tokyo Tower. rooms have free internet but no wifi in the entire hotel. Love This Hotel & will return.

Stayed here for 5 days to celebrate my birthday with my husband. Rooms are spacious in Japan standard with extremely comfortable bed and pillows. Key for me as that helps me sleep in unfamiliar surrounding. Being the high end of Tokyu hotel group, have to say it's posher and more comfortable than Tokyu Excel nearby, but have to say Excel has more convenient location as it's on top of the train station. One good point apart from the excellent staff & their impeccable service is the sound proofing, rooms are much more quiet than others.Japanese breakfast is my choice, but after 2 days, becomes a bit boring and I tried the western, which is pretty OK if it's included, but I will look outside I'd I need to pay Yen2k +Brought my iPad but there is no free wifi in the room, need to rent a modem which was expensive, but cannot remember how much. Have to remember to bring my PC if I ever come back. Apart from that the hotel is pretty good value for the price I got, think it was a special as I went in Sep, only 6 months after the March 11 earth quake.

We spent 4 nights at the Cerulean in October 2011. We had visited the Hotel Century Southern Tower in Shinjuku on our last trip to Tokyo, and wanted to try a new area - with Shibuya getting good reviews. The hotel was very pleasant. Our room (37 m2) was a good size for four of us (2 adults, 2 children), and the fittings were modern and comfortable. We had a lovely view over western Tokyo, including a sight of Mount Fuji one clear afternoon. Rooms were very quiet - something other reviewers have commented on - which was a great advantage. Service was excellent, with staff really eager to please. We ate in the coffee shop on a couple of occasions - the breakfast wasn't cheap at 3,000 Yen, but it had plenty to offer. The hotel has a very good location - very close to the centre of Shibuya, with lots of interesting bars and restaurants close by. The Shibuya train station is less than 5 minutes walk away (and you can get there with luggage quite easily, by using the lifts to help you access the pedestrian walkway to the station). Shibuya is very well connected, being on the Yamanote line. Only one gripe - I wanted to use the gym, and thought it would be included given we were paying over US$300 a night for our room. But it wasn't - instead they asked me to pay another US$30 for each session! This policy obviously isn't working - the gym was empty at 1930 in the evening, normally a busy period! But anyway, it did me a favour, as I ended up having a lovely run through the back streets of Dakanyama, Ebisu and Meguro - much better than a boring treadmill. So overall we were pretty happy - with only the gym experience lowering the ranking from 5 to 4 stars. I think that on our next trip to Tokyo we will return to the Century Southern Tower, which seemed slightly more comfortable and a bit swisher. But the Cerulean is definitely a good option if you want to be in Shibuya.

Hi my tripadvisor friends!!!I have to spend few words for tokyo city.......love u and i ll back to visit u again soon......The hotel is very nice and not to old....yhe position is very good...because u are near the center of shibuya...For to catch the hotel from the narita airport: by taxi!!!obviuosly...but i don't know the cost(1 hour by car)by train:express in 1 hour.the cost is around 35 euro and u stop in shibuya station..u can look around about the panorama!by bus:orund 25 euro and u stop at the parking hotel!the people that working in hotel are great..they try to help in everything....just ask and u have the answear!!!!japanese people!!!!the room are very big and u have the great view of tokyo city.....very clean and no noise......is very high level and also the price is very high!!!u have restaurant and bar a the top....missing to think:free wi fi :( and the slippers for the room :(Enjoy your tripAlex

The Cerulean is an excellent alternative to some better known hotels in Tokyo and offers stunning views of the city at a fraction of the price of, say, the Park Hyatt (the latter remaining my favourite hotel in Tokyo). Check-in was friendly and efficient and we were upgraded to a higher floor than the one we booked. Rooms are certainly spacious by Japanese standards, as well as comfortable, with a modern design style (nothing extravagant however). Room service both good and efficient. I would definitely recommend the (top floor) Hotel bar, for drinks and/or a light meal.The hotel is very conveniently located next to Shibuya station, although you may want to plan the best route beforehand, if you are walking there with bulky luggage. One of the highlights of the hotel is its swimming pool, really enjoyable, and quiet (just be aware that its depth is severely limited, probably Health & Safety regs.).

We stayed at this hotel for 8 nights.This hotel is wonderfully located right near the Shibuya Station. The room was very large. We had 3 people staying in one room and it was no problem. The bathroom was gorgeous. The staff, who speaks English very well, bends over backwards to accomodate. My son, who teaches martial arts, wanted to go to a dojo and they found him one and made the call telling the dojo that he was coming. They inform you of everything by slipping notes under your door. My son had forgotten he had made the request for the dojo, but the staff didn't forget.The view from the 21st floor was wonderful. The breakfast buffet is terrific, but not cheap (but when one eats at a hotel nothing is cheap). I parttook of two full body and two "just-feet" massages, which are done in your room at any time up until 2am. I also had room service, which runs all night. Even the "American" food was good.We had our "fancy" dinner at the restaurant on the 40th floor. We could only do one fancy dinner as it's impossible to get my son into a jacket and tie. The dinner was excellent. The service was marvelous. As we were staying more than 3 days--and actually more than 5 (there are specials for more than 3 and more than 5), we got the gym, pool and internet for free. I'd stay here again in a heartbeat.

The hotel is in a pretty ideal location, less than 5 minute walk from Shibuya train station which is a major train hub and also a NEX stop (Narita Express from the airport) so it's a straight train ride from the airport. The hotel is clean, modern and has up to date facilities; the staff is quiet nice as well. I have stayed here 3 times and have found that the room sizes vary, but all reasonably sized by Tokyo standards. I absolutely recommend this hotel especially to those who are looking to do shopping in Shibuya!

Stayed here on a business trip and thoroughly enjoyed the hotel. Sure, there are fabulous luxury hotels in Tokyo, but if you are on a budget or an extended stay, this place is great. The views from the guest rooms are amazing, and the view from the hotel bar on the 40th floor is stunning as well, you can even see Mt. Fuji, as well as watch the organized chaos of Shibuya Crossing down below. There are plenty of restaurant options at the hotel if you feel like staying in one night, and the rooms are clean and modern. For my full review of the hotel, with personal photos, please visit my blog post at:http://www.destinationsperfected.com/2011/10/tokyo-japan-cerulean-tower-tokyu-hotel.html

I reserved this hotel under a promo code and got agood deal out of it. I was worried about the size of the rooms, but it turned out that Cerulean Tower's room is not small, more like 'normal Asian' hotel room size, and maybe roomy for Tokyo standard.The location is near Shibuya station, a major MRT station. Close to department stores, getting food is not an issue.I would recommend this hotel to travellers, particulatly first-timers who want to be in the center of the action.

I just stayed 3 nights in the first leg of an Asia trip from the US, and enjoyed my stay. I am visiting Tokyo for business, and needed to be near the shopping, so it's location right by Shibuya was perfect. My room is pretty big for what I expected in Tokyo, and I have a high floor so the view is great. I ordered room service several times, and it was pretty good.The concierge was very helpful and polite. Couple tips: -I ordered a car service to pick me up, which was extremely expensive. There is a bus associated with the hotel that runs from the airport to the hotel which i would recommend.-If you get jet lag like me, there's a lovely park up the hill about a mile. Running though a deserted Shibuya is pretty fun.-If you want to visit the tuna auction at the famous fish market, you can have the concierge organize it for you on your first, jet-lagged morning. -The beds are japanese style, which means they are a bit harder than westerners are used to, but still a good night's sleep.I probably wouldn't stay here again, only because I feel like there are so many amazing experiences to be had in Tokyo, and would like to explore other neighborhoods, but I would recommend it as a 'first timer' hotel for Tokyo.

Shibuya, home to the world's craziest zebra crossing, neon city and a surprising little bit of old Tokyo with great, tiny bars, if you can find it. So a great location, and an excellent hotel, provided you don't pay full price. Also handy for bus to the airport which stops here. Wired internet only but super fast, and from memory, a ridiculous price to use the so so gym which I found very disappointing. As usual very polite and helpful staff.

We had the pleasure of staying here for 6 nights in September. This hotel is centrally located in the Shibuya district known for great restaurants and shopping. The staff was quite friendly and helpful. Located close to the train station made traveling easy and the shuttle from Narita airport was reasonbly priced. Unfortunately, there were a lot of amentities which were not included in the significantly high room rate: breakfast buffet (about $40 USD), wired internet (no wireless available and only one ethernet connection), fees for the swimming pool, fitness room, and sauna. The rooms were a bit outdated and the carpet was extremely soiled. The bed linens were clean and fresh as were the towels. Perhaps this is standard in Tokyo. Since this was our first trip, I don't have any other hotel to which to compare. Overall, our stay was quite good.

We spent nearly 2 weeks at the Cerulean hotel in Tokyo and were sad to have to leave. Staff are courteous and extremely friendly (like just about everyone in Japan) and go out of their way to help you and make you feel special. Rooms and facilities and high-quality and quite large. all rooms are located on high floors offering great views of Tokyo. Shibuya station (with great lines/connections) is less than five minutes walk away and so is the futuristic craziness that is Shibuya. Great food of all types and prices all around and a 7-11 in the building for all your snacks and supplies.

I joined my husband in Tokyo while he was on a business trip for a week. This hotel has spectacular views of the Tokyo skyline. We were on the 29th floor. The room was very comfortable - great sheets, bed and special pillows with buckwheat filling. The service is impeccable. The close proximity to shopping and the train station makes the location hard to beat. The food in the hotel is expensive. My Tokyo tip is to go to the grocery store in the bottom of any major department store and you will find the best food. If you get there right as the store opens, you can have some fun walking around with everyone bowing to greet you.

Location is excellent. Very close to Train StationThe rooms are a decent standard and I had the best sleep in a long time on their beds. They are firm however even the missus had excellent sleeps on the firm mattress.Room service is over priced, so may I suggest you take an elevator ride and walk 50 meters if you feel peckish. It's a nice stroll and ya never know what you will see. Huge amount of shops and restaurants close at hand so if you don't feel like paying 50 bucks for a club sandwich go for a quick walk to the 7/11 directly underneath or across the road and grab something for 10 bucks instead. Also many noodle shops and yaki-tori close by so no need to eat in the restaurants every night at the seriously over inflated prices. MUST go to Bellovisto Bar on the 40th floor of the Cerulean Tower. The view is intoxicating and so were the single malts !The hotel is a bit impersonal but not surprising. Staff service, as everyone else on here says, is good but that is Japan service so sort of expect nothing less. Manners go a loooong way in Japan so pack plenty of them and you might find that the hospitality goes to another level when they see you at least trying to say thank you and please in their language. BE a loud and expectant American type tourist and you will find a subtle change in the way you are treated, mind you if you are that way you probably wouldn't notice.... ( saw it happen a couple of times in different places ) Booking on their website was the better deal for me as if you are staying three nights you get the same prices as all the agoda.com and booking.com websites offer + you get FREE internet and FREE use of gym/pool.Best way to get from NARITA AIRPORT to CERULEAN TOWER Hotel is LIMOUSINE BUS. It takes about 80 minutes and goes directly from airport to hotel. Has toilet on the bus. Cost YEN 3,000 per person. This way you don't need to haul your suitcases through a busy train station.If you are heading on Shinkansen to Nagoya/Kyoto/Osaka/Hiroshima and have large suitcases and bags, easiest way is to grab a TAXI to Shinagawa Station ( West entrance ) and every time we used it, it ranged from YEN 2,340 - 2,580 .

I stayed here for a couple of nights at the beginning of September. It was a fantastic experience. I was upgraded without asking and very impressed by the subtle touches of luxury throughout the hotel: the amazing city views, the silent elevators, the incredibly plush towels, etc. The location as other reviewers mention is great if you're staying in Shibuya, though I'd have to give the Shibuya Excel slightly better marks given that it's located within the train station itself. Service was outstanding - I can recommend this hotel unconditionally.

My husband and I stayed here for 9 nights beginning of Sept 2011 as part of our honeymoon and are glad we did. We had a wonderful time and would recommend this hotel to all. It's easy to get there from the airport and all the staff are so friendly and helpful, all the service you get is first class. Everybody had such good english too which was helpful as we barely know 3 words of japanese. We got a lot of assistance and directions, even maps from the reception desk staff, every one goes out of their way here to ensure you enjoy your stay.The view from the room we stayed in was amazing! Our room was modern and attractive with a great bathroom and was stocked with everything a weary traveller might need. The bed was comfy. Hotel is in a great location in Shibuya close to the train st. and all the action. Shibuya was a fun place with plenty to see, great restaurants and good shopping and stays up late. There was a 24 hr convenience store right next door to the hotel which was good also. The Garden Restaurant had delicious food too.Tokyo was an awesome place to visit and we had a great time in Japan.We hope to stay again sometime. arigato.

This classy hotel is located just a 5 to 8 minutes walk from all the mad action at the Hachiko exit of Shibuya JR station, but it is not plain sailing: you need to go into the street, there is a pedestrian under/overpass with some steps to be negotiated and then the hotel is located a bit uphill. Persons with heavy luggage or not extremely fit should take note.The view from the room is stunning, especially from top floors. You get to see very large parts of Tokyo and the surroundings.The room is average size for Japanese standards, and tastefully well-appointed, with good wood on the bed. There is a Toto hi-tech Japanese-style throne and lots of goodies in the toilet. But free internet (a wired LAN cable is provided) is not included in the price for standard rooms, despite the stiff daily rate...

My husband and I stayed here at the end of August and we loved it! The view from the room is absolutely amazing. The prices are reasonable, we were even given an upgrade to a corner room upon check in! The staff is outstanding and will help you with any question you may have. They offer many services at the hotel, including exchanging foreign currency, which is awesome! However, they suggested we go to a nearby bank for better rates, how honest! The rooms are kept very clean. Our room had probably our favorite bathroom of all the places we stayed at. Very modern and the bathtub even had a huge window with a view of the city, along with the huge one in the bedroom.This place is amazing. The only thing we were bummed out about was that you could not go to the swimming pool without paying an extra fee.. which was a bit pricey. However, there is so much to do in Shibuya, I'm not sure anyone would want to waste their time inside swimming!
Good room, good service. Very nice pool, and great location.

Stayed here with my 15 year old daughter - she thought it was THE best hotel she had ever stayed in. Paid extra 4500Y to upgrade to executive floor. Totally worth it for the view and free breakfast and cocktail hour (5-7.30pm) with complimentary nibbles and drinks and free internet. Perfect for us. Only downside was that my daughter couldn't use the fitness centre and gym (need to be over 18). On the plus side, really helpful and friendly staff. The location couldn't have been better for us - shopping, access to subway etc. Getting to airport also made very easy with shuttle coach direct from hotel for very reasonable price - no schlepping of suitcases to Narita express....I would definitely recommend this hotel to friends and stay again. Not super cheap but good service and accommodation made it value for money.

Either for leisure or for business, the location is perfect. It takes only 5 minutes to walk to Shibuya, where you can dine, shop, drink and feel at Tokyo. The hotel is a huge tower, that you may enjoy a spectacular Tokyo view if you are in the floors over 25. Very clean and spacious rooms. Lacks some soul and ambiance, but a very good choice especially for business.

This gorgeous hotel is located just moments away from Shibuya station and is easy access to just about anywhere in Tokyo. Getting to the hotel is super easy. Take the South Exit from the station. Search the skyline for the tallest building and walk towards it using the overhead cross walk and you're there. The hotel staff were very friendly but I found their English to be limited. When we called to see if we could check in early they didn't understand and kept saying that check in was at 2. This is fine for bell hops and house keepers but those who are answering the phones and checking in people should have much higher level of English for a hotel of this stature. Also there were silly spelling and wording mistakes on their menus and information guides that a hotel of this stature shouldn't have.When we arrived we were told we had been upgraded to the Executive floor which was great. Our room was huge and had great views in both the main room and the bathroom which was super cool.Because we had been upgraded to the Executive floor we looked it up in the hotel guide and saw that it included breakfast and free internet. Yet much to our surprise the next morning when we showed up for breakfast we were told it wasn't included with our room and had to pay the full price. The buffet as alright but not worth the money they charged. Finally upon check out we were once again surprised to learn we had been charged 1,000 yen for the internet access. When we questioned the employee who was checking us out she said something along the lines of because we were upgraded, and didn't pay for the Executive floor, we didn't get any of the perks, such as the breakfast and internet, that came with it (except for the room itself). Because her expiation was in broken English we ended up paying it and not arguing it.Overall the hotel is very nice and the staff were helpful but didn't speak a high enough level of English as one would expect of a five star hotel. Also we felt they were acting a bit cheep by not giving the perks of the upgrade. If they had just said "we upgraded you to a nicer room" it wouldn't have been a problem.

The hotel is great, amazing views, very close to Shibuya station and easy to find, combinis close and what have you. Staff is the best I've seen so far anywhere ever - they really went out of their way to help us. Be careful with Narita express at Shibuya though - it runs very scarcely, we were at Shibuya at 8:20am just to find that the next Narita "express" ran not at 8:45 but 9:45, had to use Yamanote line to go to Nippori then take the Skyliner there (non-JR and expensive if you're used to rail pass) to get to Narita, missing latest check-in by 4 minutes and had to rebook our flight ...

If you can bear being shepherded into breakfast by a relay of four staff, and endlessly being bowed as you're steered towards the lifts, this is a good business base. Perfectly serviceable business hotel but without any soul or character. Highlights are the good 40th floor bar. Gym, sauna and pool, ok but not great. Frustratingly has only in-room wired internet, so no WiFi anywhere (seems standard for Japan). Weedy showers and cheap shower gels etc. In room shiatsu massage should be avoided... Awful. Good breakfast but forget your breakfast-included ticket at your peril. Restaurants best avoided except for breakfast, but well informed concierge will advise on several options within a 5 minute walk.

This may look as a standard business hotel, but you would be mistaken to stay anywhere else. The service is out of this world. All rooms have very spectacular views of Shibuya and Roppongi. The Shibuya stations - both JR and subway - connect you to wherever you might want to go. Within walking distance of the hotel you will find a wild variety of dining and shopping options.The quality of the beds, linen and towels puts all much more expensive Paris and London hotels to deep deep shame.And best of all, the view of the bar at the top floor will cure your jetlag in just a few seconds.In Tokyo there is for me and my partner no other hotel imaginable.

Cerulean hotel is the best hotel in Tokyo. I have been staying at the hotel for past 5 years and I have enjoyed each time. Hotel offers many benefits,but they truly have the world class customer service. I would recommend to both first timer or frequent Tokyo visitors to stay at Cerulean. I will be back early August and am looking forward to staying at Cerulean again.Mason Cho

This was my first trip to Tokyo area, I stayed in Shibuya near the office. First, it is one of the tallest building in the area...so you can find it easily from the training station. The trains are great and easy to use. It is entry way is magnificent, and rooms/ pool area very clean. Secondly, the location is great! It is in the central of all activities. Lastly, the food at the hotel was ok, however, walk outside and you can find some of the best food in the world. I had my son with me and we found it very safe!

I was very surprised at how nice this hotel was. It took me a while to find a good place using TripAdvisor, and I can easily say this is the best hotel in terms of location. The Cerulean Tower is literally across the street from Shibuya Station, which links you up to all parts of the city. The NEX (Narita Express train) stops at this station making it super easy to get to and from the airport. With hot weather and lugging all my baggage, having the hotel a 2 min walk from the station was a life saver. I recommend this hotel because Shibuya is the perfect neighborhood for tourists to stay in. There is nightlife, fun restaurants, the quintessential "pedestrian crossing" that is awe inspiring to look at and best of all, the Cerulean Tower is the nicest hotel in the area with amazing views of all the districts on Tokyo. I would describe this hotel as the "lost in translation movie experience" without the gigantic price tag and pretentiousness as the park hyatt in Shinjuku.This hotel made my trip one of the best trips of my life. Amazing views, huge bathrooms, the best showers around and an awesome staff. Oh yea, the breakfast buffet is amazing too!! You won't be disappointed. Thanks Cerulean Tower! Domo'arigato'gosaimasu!!!

Very good hotel at very good prices right in the heart of Shibuya. Restaurants were quite good and service was impeccable. Hotel view was also excellent. No complaints whatsoever. I can't say anything particularly floored me with its brilliance (perhaps other than how well the Japanese make French pastries!), but not a single thing to complain about and I don't think I would prefer to stay anywhere else in Tokyo. Extremely convenient to transportation and all nightlife.

This is a truly superior hotel, right in the heart of Shibuya. You can walk out the door and be in the heart of one of Tokyo's most vibrant areas in about 3 minutes. Getting here from the airport is a snap: just go right to the airport limo bus service (orange and white counters at Narita) and there is a bus that takes you directly there for about 10% of what it would cost by cab. The hotel itself is superior in many ways, from the superb staff who cater to your every need to the excellent dining available on location and the amazing views from your room. On a clear day (especially in winter), you can actually see Mt. Fuji in the distance!

I stayed in the single room for 2 nights. Room was facing the city view, can see Shibuya crosswalk and Tokyo tower. Room was spacious, but the furnitures were old, time to refurbish the room. Only land internet connection but no WIFI.Overall service was good. Front desk staffs were friendly and spoke good English. The airport shuttle was very convenient and worth for the 3K yen, you don't have to carry the luggage and go thru the hassles of taking train.

This was our second time staying at this hotel and i still liked it very much. For Japan standard, i think the standard room is spacious enough for us and our children with 1 crib. Very clean and contemporary interior. The corner room from our previous stay though is bigger and is considered very spacious for Tokyo with very nice view from the bedroom and bathroom.Service is very good, helpful and polite. Location is perfect in my opinion. Very close to the heart of Shibuya but secluded enough to be away from the hustle and bustle. Next door is family mart, and it's surrounded by restaurants. We even found an excellent yakitori place nearby and tonkatsu place inside the Shibuya Mark City, the best we've ever had. 5 min walk to Shibuya main station.The only downside though, the pool i think is not open for children or something. But other than that, definitely will recommend this hotel to friends.

After staying in many hotels in Tokyo, i've heard many good things about Cerulean and decided to book a week there after finding a great deal. Check-in was a breeze with staff speaking perfect English. Within 5 minutes we were in our room and greeted with an amazing view. Picking a flaw with Cerulean was quite hard since everything is spot on. Room was extremely spacious even with 3 beds in the room and having 2 other guests stay with us for a night. Location is simply the best thing about this hotel. Shibuya on your door step, Harajuku and Omotesando a comfortable walk away, everything seemed so close. After staying in other hotels close to the Yamanote line, Cerulean was by far the most convenient location and saved us many Yen in train tickets. Only downside was the price of internet, ¥1,050 is a tad bit much especially when the connection was poor with certain websites. Highly recommended and I don't think we'd stay in any other hotel in Tokyo, especially for the price.

As mentioned before a very well situated hotel in the Shibuya neighborhood. Hotel is very nicely decorated, staff very professional, not extremely friendly but this is a very big a big hotel that makes it not very personalized. Rooms are very nice with beautiful bathrooms. We asked for a connecting room which we got and they were just perfect. Breakfast is an american style buffet, excellent! Check in and out very quick. We have absolutely nothing negative to say about our stay in this hotel, except that there isn't free wifi internet connection in the rooms! We're in 2011. Even in very small ryokans in the middle of nowhere there was free internet.

Great hotel in a great location, within easy walking distance of the lively shibuya.. The hotel itself is modern, with friendly and accomodating staff. When we arrived, we were dealt with promptly and were checked in in no time.. The hotel has all you would expect from such a hotel, with amazing city views from the higher floors .. best of all is the location!! ...would definately stay here again, and would recommend it to anyone visiting tokyo...

Our family of 3 stayed here for 4 nights recently. As our flight arrived late at night, there were no direct airport limousines to the hotel so we caught one to Shinjuku and then took a taxi to the hotel (just under 3000 yen for the taxi ride).Pros:- Room was very spacious even with three beds. - Bathroom was also very large. We loved the bathtub and walk-in shower.- Great views (we requested the Tokyo Tower view in our online booking which the hotel was happy to accommodate).- Shibuya subway station and JR station are close by (5-10 minute walk using the pedestrian overpass).- Shibuya crossing, shops, restaurants all close by.- Next to a highway but room was so quiet, we couldn't hear a thing.- Concierge was amazing. We asked for a recommendation for a teppanyaki restaurant and the older gentleman personally escorted us there.- Starbucks is in office building attached to the hotel- Convenience store is located right outside hotel- Closest supermarket is in basement of Tokyu department store (in between Shibuya subway station and JR station).Cons:- Hard to navigate pedestrian overpass to Shibuya station with luggage as there are no elevators/escalators. We ended up catching a taxi to Shinagawa station (approx 3000 yen) to catch the Shinkansen to Osaka.- No late check-out- No magnifying shaving mirror in the bathroom

I stayed at the Cerulean Towers for 2 weeks in Jan/Feb 2011. Some bullet points on what I liked about it:* easy to get there for YEN 3,000 with the airport bus* extremely friendly and polite staff at reception* very nice, clean and spaceous room, good desk and work area* I took the 'upgrade' for YEN 4,500 / day which included free internet, breakfast on 35th floor and lounge access throughout the day* Not a huge breakfast buffet but I think sufficient choice for the person with average breakfast needs* Very nice bathroom and spacious shower, heated toilet with all the fancy features you will be surprised of if you are also a first-time-to-Japan traveller* Phantastic view on Tokyo and Mount Fuji from the room and the lounge* An incredible amount of restaurants of all kinds and price ranges just around the corner. You couldn't get to all of them even if you were staying there for a year* Great supermarket just across the street at Shibuya station ("Food court") - open until 9 pm* Very clean room, enough towels, nice bathrobe and night gown. What could have been better:* The 'upgrade' package also included free alcoholic drinks from 5 - 7:30 pm. If you are a business traveler you are not likely to have any benefit from that. Outside of those hours it's just a small selection of soft-drinks and coffee and tea. Also the 'snacks' offered during 5-7:30h don't vary, I found it to be the same every time I went there and I personally would have preferred something more local* I like the environmental consciousness, in my opinion the replacement of bedsheets every 2nd day is not necessary * The lobby bar is only open until 10 pm and the restaurant downstairs which opens until midnight is not really a place to feel 'cozy', especially if you are going for a drink and snack by yourself

Male staff at the reception was not very polite and friendly. They put me in a smoking room instead of non-smoking as requested claiming that this room is non-smoking. I felt a smell of smoke and found a sign in the room "Please refrain from smoking in the bed" that eliminated my doubts. I talked to female staff at reception and within minutes front manager came and apologized and moved me to executive non-smoking room ten floors higher. I also got free internet in my room. This was a free upgrade and executive rooms are much nicer with more impressive views. Hotel location is great. Shibuya area around is fantastic with lively young crowds in all days. Easy to go anywhere once you figure out the subway system. Seven eleven store is nearby and cash machine that accepts foreign cards is around the corner - check with concierge since Japanese ATM's do not recognize foreign cards. Overall good location and reasonable hotel, but customer service needs improvement and lack of wireless internet is a bummer. Stay at executive rooms:)

Cerulean Towers in Shibuya was the PERFECT location in Tokyo - It's about a block from a major JR station which makes it easy to get to Narita, Fuji, or anywhere else in the country, but just far enough away from the main intersection to avoid most of the noise and mayhem. Shibuya was the perfect setting for shopping, restaurants, nightlife, and sightseeing. The hotel is really well appointed with a great restaurant/viewing area on the top floor, and we had clear views of Fuji from our room. Cerulean Towers would be perfect for business or leisure, although they didn't have wi-fi in the rooms which was a letdown. Decor was standard hotel-style, clean and nice with large rooms. We would have liked more japanese touches, but it was a great Western experience.
No way to get response from Mr. Hiroshi Namesawa/GM of the Hotel, even I sent a letter to him in reception to file a complaint. VERY BUREAUCRACY!!

For convenience this hotel gets top marks. You get the the train from Narita virtually to the hotel in Shibuya. it is very central and in a good shopping district. I found it well appointed and the rooms while nothing exceptional were really quite good and much bigger than the average Japanese room. All in all i would say this is a good location for business or pleasure when visiting Tokyo

Booked here for our final days in Japan. Hotel in Shibuya a short walk from the station. It is the tallest building in the neighbourhood which means you get fantastic views from the higher floors. We were upgraded to the 33rd floor which has fantastic views of the city.Service was good. Didnt use the expensive breakfast option or any of the restaurants although the bakery is quite nice next to reception. The conceirge was very helpful. Location excellent since lots of malls and restaurants in shibuya all within 5 minutes walk from the hotel. Also the station is 5 mins walk and you can get anywhere in tokyo from there on the JR trains or the metro.If you are travelling with large luggage to or from airport, easiest option is the airport bus which stops at the hotel or you can drag the luggage on narita express train from shibuya which is actually not as bad as it sounds which is what we did due to time we were travelling. Price is about the same.Rooms were large with large bathroom with walk in shower. All the normal amenities were there of a business hotel. TV had english channels. We had complimentary bottles of water and newspaper everyday.Overall expensive but similar price to most 5 star hotels in tokyo. Recommend room only and eat out since not only are there numerous eateries close by, they are less expensive and offer more authentic japanese cuisine.Would recommend it though.

Stayed at the Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel for 5 nights while in Tokyo with a friend and found it to be a fantastic 'base' while touring around. Located right near the famous Shibuya crossing, many malls, love hotels, great clubs etc, as well as a subway station making visiting farther parts of Tokyo very convenient too, it was the perfect place for us to stay.The room was kept spotlessly clean and was large by Tokyo standards. The view from the window was wonderful (CTTH is one of the tallest buildings in Tokyo) both at night and at day. The restaurants in the hotel were delicious - the breakfast buffet in particular was one of the best I've seen to date. The spa/pool/gym area was great too, including the massage chairs that one could use for free once a day pass had been purchased (but they let us try them out before deciding).There were loads of facilities inside the hotel that we didn't use, but I'm sure are used often by businesses (beautiful meeting rooms, as well as an in-house Kabuki theater!). We visited some friends who were staying at the Park Hyatt and, though it was beautiful, felt we'd made an incredible choice both in terms of location and in terms of value for the money. I highly recommend staying at the Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel while in Tokyo, whether you're travelling with friends or on a business trip.
I always stay at Cerulean Tower everytime I visit Tokyo. Speaking of accessibility, It's one the best hotel I've come across comfort, service and view.

We spent a night at Cerulean for our special day. I knew about the hotel as I live in Tokyo but this was the first time for me to stay there. Service is great, room is simple and beautiful, location is just perfect. It's only a couple of minuets walk from the big Shibuya crossing. Staying at Cerulean is kind of pricey but if you want to make your stay in Tokyo very special, it's worth. A night view from the bar on 40th floor is breathtaking.

This is my second trip to this Shibuya - my most favourite shopping destination in Tokyo. Having loved the Cerulean so much last time, I didn't hesitate to go back for more.Japanese service is second to none and this hotel certainly does not disappoint in this area. It is a little on the expensive side, with a Tower's Room being about AU$550 per night but this allowed access to the Club Room for breakfast, afternoon tea and cocktails at dusk. The views from the rooms are spectacular and your really get a sense of the enormity of Tokyo. The Cerulean also provide free shuttle service to and from Narita Airport, which is more convenient than dragging your luggage on the trains.The rooms are clean and comfortable but had we stayed for longer than 2 nights, I would have liked a little more space. Internet access was free with the room. The downside for me was the bathroom. It's a little small in size with nowhere to place your toiletries, which we ended up having to place on the floor.We didn't try any of the restaurants in the hotel, to be honest there is so much on offer close by that we got out and explored each night. We did use the Bar on the top level both nights which has spectacular views to Shinjuku and a base rate of AU$19.50 for a glass of Australian wine which I find a little on the ridiculous side, but I'm sure comparable with other Hotel bars of this quality.During our previous stay we had used the pool and spa facilities which were splendid but there was an additional charge for their use which I chose not to pay this time around.The best thing about this accommodation is it's location - a 3 minute walk across the overpass and right into Shibuya Station. Shibuya is a fantastic area for shopping and restaurants and people watching. Be sure to cross the street at the main square during peak hour.I'm sure there are more affordable places in the area than the Cerulean Tower - even if you were to get a standard room, you might expect to pay around AU$400 per night but there are alot of things on the plus side of this Hotel and I would recommend it to anyone visiting Shibuya.

My spouse and I are frequent travellers, and we have been fortunate enough to stay in many excellent hotels around the world. This is our 1st visit to Tokyo and we decided to stay in a lesser-known hotel as we heard about its good service-level. The HOTELWe arrived Cerulean early in the morning. Not only they accomodated our early checkin request, the process was speedy, our luggage was safely tucked in our room BEFORE we even got in. All the staffs we interacted with are English-speaking, they are very courteous, and requested services are delivered fast and accurate. The room we had is designed in a typical minimalist style, comfortably big, very clean, love the bed, bathroom layout is well thought of. The view [WOW!] is breathtaking. Mount Fuji greeted us in our final morning in Tokyo...it was a perfect end to a perfect holiday.The ACCESSShibuya station is a mere 5-minute walk away, so moving around Tokyo is a breeze. It's connected to both Japan Railway as well as the Underground. Another brownie point for this hotel is that access to-fro Narita Airport is so convenient. The Airport Limousine Bus service picks you up from the airport and drops you off at Cerulean's door-step. This efficient service only cost 3000yen [approx US$35] per pax each way.

I am used to a certain level of quality when I travel-whether it be for a personal or a business trip. Although this hotel was perfectly fine, I found myself disappointed. And so did my colleagues. It was clean and generally nice, and in an interesting neighborhood. But the toilet seats didn't even flip open when you walked into the room. Nor did they play music! Seriously, though, it just felt a little bland. Not much art on the walls, a little sterile, mediocre toiletries, excruciatingly slow check in and an eternal wait for my bag to be delivered, no iron in the room, outrageous breakfast, gym and internet prices, and the thing I missed the most, no magnifying mirror in the bathroom. I was flying blind on my mascara application. I kept comparing it to the place I stayed last time I was in Tokyo. A place I paid for out of my own pocket. It was much nicer, with a huge, beautiful Japanese garden, huge rooms and much better service-especially upon checking in.But if you have nothing to compare it to, I'm sure it would be quite alright. The pool is nice. The gym is fine, but a tad small. There is a nice view from the top floor restaurant. And the best part about the whole stay was, I got a surprise view of Mt. Fuji from my room one morning.

3 of us stayed at this hotel for my birthday and it was one of the most incredible places we have ever stayed.The rooms, general decor and service were exceptional and cant be faulted. The rooms are all super modern and the bathrooms are something to behold. What is fabulous is that all the rooms are on the 19th floor and above so all have a view of Tokyo and some have views of Mount Fuji.On my birthday the bar on the 42nd floor gave me a cake.The Noh theatre within the hotel is fabulous and they do a free shuttle service to and from the airport which saves alot of money.The breakfast is very western but is useful to make that transition between western cusine to a sole diet of no dairy, sugar or yeast cookery - sometimes bacon and pancakes sets you up better for a day's full on sight seeing than miso soup and cold rice!The French Restaurant at the top of the hotel is absolutely out of this world too!It's location just over the footbridge from the buzzing Shibuya is perfect.

Arriving at this hotel was my first introduction to Tokyo, It's worth the price. The room is great, we had views of the crazy busy Shibuya intersection. The hotel staff recommended a great restaurant with authentic cuisine, they even walked us there because we had trouble findiing it, their recommendation didn't disappoint as we got to try some local puffer fish and wicked Sake. Highly recommend. Loved Shibuya.

This is a big business hotel with all the usual bells and whistles. Everything is very well done - the rooms are tastefully decorated, the showers are superb, the breakfast excellent and staff very nice. Nothing particularly unique apart from one thing. Somehow they have achieved what so many modern hotel buildings fail to do - sound insulate the rooms. Stomping idiots upstairs, street traffic or dubious late night liaisons between business colleagues in the room next door may still occur, but you will be oblivious to it all as your room is a cocooned box of serenity!For this reason alone, I always stay here.

When reserving a room over the internet I doubted at first to pay so much for a room with a view. However I was not disappointed at all. The hotel is very well located. If you arrive to Narita take the Limo Bus that will leave you on the premises. Just like that. it is a long ride but for 3,000Y is a good value. The hotel is very businesslike and a little cold but very clean an personnel is extremely nice. English is a little broken but you can get through. I reserved a Skyview King on the 33rd floor so my check in was on the 35th floor. They were expecting me and upgraded me to a Cerulean King on that same floor. room is spacious and comfortable. It was very hot and air conditioning took a while to refresh the room. The view is amazing from the room and from the bathroom. Bed was perfect and had 3 choices of pillow which was great for me. Gym, internet and breakfast are included in the rate. Japanese breakfast recommended. Also cocktail time from 5 to 7 is free. Hotel is at a walking distance from Shibuya train and metro stations, very functional to go in and about the city. I would recommend this hotel, to anyone although maybe it would not be a very good choice for families with kids or students looking for good fun... I would go back, no doubt!

Used to stay at the New Otani before, but swapped to the Cerulean Tower a few years ago and had a much more pleasant Tokyo hotel experience. Great attentive staff (the General Manager came to assist when my daughter was taken ill and had to go to hospital), comfortable rooms, fantastic position and good sky bar. The never changing sameness of the hotel menu gets difficult after repeated visits, but as the hotel is so close to Shibuya, and the Tokyu food hall, Dean & DeLuca, etc, etc you can get away and eat very well on a sensible budget.

Negativ: Deposit of 30000 Yen, the room rate was just 25000. Me as a foreigner, I had to pay the deposit, last time my japanese partner checked in, he didnt had to pay any deposit...The view from the window is very nice. The windows are huge. This time the batrromm had also a huge window, beside the bathtube, but when you are sitting in the bathtube, you cant enjoy the view, exept you are very tall, because you are sitting very low. Generally the bathrooms are very nice. The rest of room is ok.the rooms are very clean and the personal ok.

We were in Japan for our honeymoon and probably stayed at 7 different hotels. By far, the cerulean was THE BEST. We stayed at the Cerulean for a total of 5 nights. I think I can say it 's probably the best hotel I've stayed at generally speaking. Actually...the bed could be softer, but after experiencing all other hotels in japan...I think the hard mattress is the norm for Japan.The hotel is located very close to the Shibuya station (5minute walk), and walking distance to plenty of shopping (ie Uniqlo, starbucks, Koen Dori, shibuya 109, etc). It's also walkable to Harajuku and Yoyogi park. However, if you want to take the subway to Harajuku, it's only 1 stop away for 130yen (approximately ~$1.50-2 depending on currency rate.) Luckily I downloaded the Metro App onto my iphone (no internet connection necessary) which helped me navigate through all the stations/trains in tokyo. It saved us a lot of time and I highly recommend it.  We're really pleased that our Tour Agency (Super Value Tours) recommended that we stay here. The hotel is ultra modern and clean. Our room was on the 23rd floor facing Mt. Fuji. Unfortunately, it was hazy everyday so we couldn't view the mountain, but for short moment (10min) the haze dissipated so we were able to see the outline of mountain. I heard that it's really rare to see mount fuji, so perhaps seeing the outline was as good as it got for us.My husband and I had to try the Japanese breakfast and it was really delicious...but it wasn't enough to fill our tummies for a full morning's adventure. Maybe it's because we're accustomed to the american culture where you stuff your face when eating. The next 4 days we stuck with the american breakfast buffet. Considering it's a buffet, I never felt disgustingly full. Even the bacon was light, airy, thin and surprisingly ungreasy! go figure! I looked forward to breakfast everyone morning at the Cerulean. Since our breakfast was included in our hotel stay...it might be on the pricier side for those who have to pay extra out of pocket. I recommend this hotel to anyone who visits Tokyo. If I come back...this is the place I want to be. Excellent!

I stayed in this hotel for 4 nights with my 18 year old daughter. We stayed in an executive club room on the 33rd floor and the service throughout the hotel was fantastic. Our room had a great view over the Shibuya crossing area and city. The hotel is close to the subway and has many fantastic places to eat close by. We particularly enjoyed the 'standing sushi bar' in Shibuya. The room was very comfortable and the staff in the executive club were amazing.
