The Cerulean is located in Shibuya, about 6 minutes walking distance from the Metro/JR station right in the middle of the action! Staff was very polite and helpful during our stay and spoke English.Even though it's a great property, it's by no means a "cool/trendy" hotel; rooms are big, clean and comfortable, but plain, lobby is huge, but also very plain. I do not say this to complaint, just to give travelers heads up that artistically, there's nothing here.We had a great view from the 23rd floor, king size bed was very comfortable, TV had at least 5 channels you could listen to in English, the bathroom was huge and had a tub + shower and the toilet featured a TOTO + it's Western-friendly handle.The location is excellent with it being so close to public transportation you could be on your way anywhere in Tokyo in a metter of minutes. You get a free pass to the gym/indoor pool area when you check in (we didn't use them).Breakfast; buffet was 3003 YEN or around US$33 which is pricey but had plenty of options; eggs, omelettes, sausages, bacon, ham, pastries, bread, coffee, juice, etc. No WIFI available, you have to pay around 1000 YEN for 24 hours of IP based, LAN connectivity which is fine if you only have one laptop but would have to pay twice if you had two :(We would definitely stay here again :)

The main benefit is the location. There is a 7-11 on site which is invaluable for business travelers. Only 5 min walk away from the Shibuya subway station and plenty of small charming eateries in the vicinity.

We spent two weeks and four hotel stays in Japan. This was our "home base" for four nights. It's hard to pick "a spot" to stay in Tokyo. There are may fun neighborhoods. But Shibuya is really central, there is lots to see and do around the hotel, and the hotel was very nice.The staff was friendly, helpful and spoke great english. Anything questions or needs, they fell all over themselves to help us. The hotel is a five minute walk to the ever-famous and ever busy Shibuya subway station. The rooms are large by Japanese standards, and by western standards typical of what you'd find in a Ritz or nice Hyatt.There is an Am/PM convenience store actually in the buliding which we used to get snacks and sandwiches. My only knock on this hotel, is the following. The lobby is a little sterile, which you would find in Manhattan too. But it lacks that Japanese cultural feel. You could have been in any big city in the world. And also the food is mega expensive, again like what you'd find in a NYC hotel. We had two cups of coffee in the coffe shop and it was $20. (that includes what you'd tip in the US, since you don't tip in Japan). So we grabbed stuff in the AM/PM mart and snacked in our room, which was actually fun. (bring cash though, c-stores in Japan generally don't take plastic).Gym (which is pretty small...three tread mills, a couple stationary bikes and weights) is free to 18+ if you use between 7:00 and 8:30 I think. Forget exact hours, but if you want to workout, it's free in the morning. You do have to pay $20 PP to use the facility the rest of the day. My daughter and I did pay the fee once while the rest of the crew recovered from jet lag, and we did have fun. They have massage chairs in the spa (in the locker rooms). The pool is heated and very nice, and we enjoyed the hot spa too. But having to pay, and excluding kids (common in Japan) was a bit of a drag.Like hotel a lot, and have no regrets about staying there. But you might be albe to kind more charm elswhere.

Although there is a little bit of the business blandness about the place, this is a classy hotel (with prices to match) in a great part of Tokyo. You will not regret staying in this hotel and the Shibuya area in general, which we thought was much classier than Shinjuku, which was the area we intially toyed staying in. You can easily explore Tokyo from the numerous subway lines running from Shibuya direct, without the need to change lines. We stayed here for 3 nights on our return leg from Kyoto and Hakone (after starting off our Tokyo trip at the Asakusa View Hotel - I've reviewed this too) and our room (booked through expedia for about GBP £200 a night) was excellent with great views of the Tokyo skyline (as the rooms start on the 19th floor I'm sure they all have good views). The hotel is easy to get to from Shibuya station - take time making your way up through the station as you can avoid most of the stairs if you look out for elevator and escalator signs and if you make your way to the attached Mark City shopping mall exit. From outside the station it's about a 7-10min walk with luggage, part of which is uphill as you approach the footbridge to the hotel which can leave you looking a little undignified (we still managed it ok with 2 heavy suitcases). The footbridge has an elevator to the hotel level. Without luggage, it will just take you a couple of minutes to get to the heart of Shibuya and the Haichiko crossing, which is also a great area to have your morning coffee/breakfast - like most foreign tourists we would start the day in the Starbucks overlooking the crossing because of the great location. Yes it's disappointing breakfast is not included, which is about GBP £30 a head (had it just the once given the cost) and that there is no free LAN or wi-fi access (about GBP £10 charge), which is outrageous for a business orientated hotel, and that the swimming pool fee was about GBP £18. We did manage a drink in the tower bar which was expensive but worth it for the classy ambience and views (don't bother ordering the mixed nuts/crisps to go with your drinks - costs about GBP £10 for a couple of spoonfulls). The cost of a formal dinner in the hotel was too horrific to contemplate but Shibuya has hundreds if not thousands of informal eateries for the after work office crowd so food is not a problem in the area. As others have commented, there are also plenty of convenience stores offering Japanese snacks/take-out nearby where the Japanese also happily buy and eat from.

First off, the location is great! This is the type of hotel that probably has everything you can imagine ready to be served to you but you won't even get past the tip of the iceberg of all those things.Friendly and helpful staff. Gorgeous and tasteful design, decor, and furnishing. Very comfortable and prompt service. As far as location goes, given the many prefectures, it really depends on whether or not you were aiming on touring the prefecture highlights and of the neighbouring prefectures too. However, it is Tokyo and it does indeed have great public transport so getting around is easy. Absolutely wonderful view, especially during the night.Again, the type of hotel that probably is ready to help you with any possible concern that may come up. Has a great breakfast buffet, room service, concierge, large lobby for rendez-vous, and much more. They even had strong build-quality umbrellas to lend us when it was raining!Very very impressed! Obviously, however, it costs a bit of money but save up because it's really worth the comfort.

My family and I enjoyed this high end hotel and it's location made it easy to shop in Shibuya and get the trains to other parts f Tokyo. Of course with all hotels at this level, prices at the hotel restaurant are ridiculously expensive! There is a 7-11 at the hotel and department store basements food courts to grab food to eat in your room while you look at the astounding views!

The + :the very convenient location in Shibuyathe outstanding service (especially the concierge for the restaurants recommendations and the day trips)the yummy morning breakfastthe large, comfy and quiet roomsthe beautiful views from the roomthe kids zone (small and very expensive but at least it's an option for a couple of hours)The - :the swimming pool doesn't accept guests under 18 years old !!!!! Hello ????no free internet in the room....Really a fantastic experience and the staff is very warm (and most of them speak good english)

When I first stayed at the Cerulean Tower, I was 25 years old, on the tail end of a month long homecoming trip to Japan. Having lived in Shibuya for three years, I wanted to find a place that would lend to my love of Shibuya as a hub of Tokyo. My Mother and younger bro met up with me for a week at the Tower, and we were all blown away. In the three years since, not much has changed. They've got a solid staff, who truly want to help each guest to have the best possible stay in Tokyo. The rooms are appointed with amazing woods, fabrics, tiles and marble. What really makes my stays amazing is a trip up to the 40th floor, to Bello Visto, a bar/lounge with views of Shinjuku, the Tokyo Tower and the new Mori building in Roppongi. If you edge close to the windows, you can see Shibuya Crossing, in all it's mayhem. I've stayed at some of the top ranked hotels in the world, and I can say that the Cerulean Tower is still at the top of my list for city stays.

I love this hotel and suggest anyone coming to Tokyo stays here. The views, the service and the food is all excellent. From the bar the view over Tokyo and from most of the rooms is superb. In one of the rooms I stayed in on my last visit I could see all of Tokyo and Mt Fuji, which really made my day. The service is so smooth on check in, I don't stop walking from arrival until I am in my room. They even look after me when I arrive early from the airport (11am) and allow me to check in.

Beautiful room on the 32nd floor with panoramic views of Tokyo - exactly what we wanted. High quality room, very large, good sized granite bathroom and bed (not granite). Despite arriving at the hotel at 10:30, absolutely shattered after an 8am arrival from London, the reception staff were kind enough to let us check in early - unexpected but hugely appreciated. The only annoyance was the buffet breakfast, which while delicious and with a great selection, was ridiculously expensive. There is a 7/11 just outside the hotel though. Hotel is very close to Shibuya station - come out of South Exit, and its the really tall brownish skyscraper you can see across the road.

I love, love, love this hotel. If we ever go back to Tokyo, we are definitely going to stay here again. We booked Queen Rooms and were upgraded to King Room (the first two nights) and (after we returned from Hakone) Corner King room for no extra charge. The views for both types of rooms were amazing. The Corner King had a bathtub right by the view, so naturally I had to draw a bath to admire the Tokyo skyline. The rooms were also large, contrary to what people had warned me about Asian hotel room sizes. Loved the complimentary items they provided for use. I also loved that they had Animal Planet and Discovery Channel in English, especially because I was a bit homesick.Being right across from the Shibuya Station, the hotel location was superb. Shopping malls/stores/awesome restaurants were all walking distance. What I loved the most was the 7-11 right at the second level. It made it very convenient for emergency water/beer/coffee runs. To the person who complained about coffee in the restaurant. The coffee was actually espresso and not regular drip. If you wanted regular coffee, Starbucks and Tully's were right across the street. 7-11 also had machine made coffees. The restaurants in the hotel were overpriced and not all that great (too fusion?). A few steps away, you'd find some really tasty and decently priced food.Cerulean Tower is a gorgeous hotel. It is a bit expensive but you definitely get what you pay for ... and it's worth every cent.* Oh, if you have a visible tattoo, you can't swim in the pool. Go figure.

booked this hotel based on tripadvisor experts recommendations in the forum section. We were very happy with our decision. We booked 4 nights in 2 adjoining standard rooms. We were pleasantly surprised to be upgraded to a higher floor with a newly renovated room. It was fantastic. View was very nice. We had the Mt. Fuji side, and saw it briefly on our first day. But then it got foggy after that.Room was nice and modern. It was very clean and new. Bathroom was big as there was a separate shower and tub area. Hotel toiletries were nice as it was the Italian Brand of ACCA KAPPA.... which I personally use even before the trip. Toilet was good as it had a seat warmer and built in bidet. I wanted to buy one to bring home!Service was excellent. Concierge gave very good restaurant and shopping recommendations. Hatsutsubome was our favorite restaurant. And the sushi conveyor belt restaurant they recommended was very good, clean and surprisingly cheap! Hotel restaurant Chen was worth it. Location was tops! Literally. We had to walk uphill. After a long day of walking and pushing 2 strollers, it was a bit of a challenge. But it didn't really bother us too much because we knew we'd be coming home to a clean and modern room. There was a 7-11 in the second floor so it was easy to get milk and yoghurt for the kids. It's also a short walk to the train station, Hachiko and the famous Shibuya crossing. I loved that it was near some favorite Japanese stores such as Uniqlo, Muji, etc. Downside was that I had to pay for internet access :-(. I would definitely stay here again. Shout out to reservations officer Sachiko, who took care of all our requests for the kids. Big shout out to Shibuyakko et.al who recommended that this was the best hotel for our needs.
Conveniently located near shibuya station but not at all bothered by the crowds, this business hotel is a nice place to rest your feet.

If you are a UK resident almost everything abroad will seem expensive, especially Tokyo. We had a room on the 32nd floor with a corner bathroom, great view, but was just over £300 a night without breakfast--we paid 3000yen each for breakfast and compared to what you could get outside it was a good option for us. The hotel is in a very good location for transport (cheap) and siteseeing. There is a restaurant attached to the hotel called Oli where we eat twice--a set lunch of 3 courses plus coffee was 1550 yen with a small beer 1000yen, the food was very good but drinks very expensive, 2 beers in the bar on top of the hotel £18. Take the Limo bus from the airport, its worth waiting for the one to your holel as the journey is over an hour and a taxi would be expensive. Also went to Gonpachi restaurant not far from hotel on 14th floor of high rise building--had the Kushisoba option as opposed to Sushi--it was great--need to book, not too expensive. Tip--go to Food show under Shibuya station to see what fresh food is all about.

This place is good, but not great. Fantastic location close to the Subway and JR Shinkansen line and the rooms have fantastic views. The room was a decent enough size and the bathroom was great . The bath had a window right in front of it and we could see the Shibuya crossing from our room. All these things should have meant this hotel was WOW, but it really isn't.It lacks personality and it lacks charm. Yes the staff are polite (They are in 99% of hotels in Japan, I have stayed in 7 this month alone so trust me I know this without sounding arrogant). There are waaaaaay too many staff littering the place and the lobby is usually full of them bowing every time you walk by. It does get a bit tiresome. Why not get rid of some of the staff and free up some of that wage bill to offer your guests free internet as this is supposed to be a business hotel! Crazy! (1500 Yen per day)The breakfast buffet was okay. Fruits, pastries, Hot stuff like omelettes cooked to order but to be honest none of this hot stuff is any good. The scrambled eggs are disgusting and kept in a rice cooker on the side. YUK! It takes 2 minutes to scramble some eggs so this is just unacceptable in a hotel of this cost.The coffee is gross and extremely bitter (okay with 3 sugars though) - they are also not very forthcoming with refills either should you want some more. Tiny cups provided and the juice that is freshly squeezed is like a thimble full! Oh and please I mustn't forget this. In the hotel you have tea and coffee making facilities provided in your room. Crap coffee again and just green tea. We made some for ourselves one afternoon and as in every hotel I have ever stayed in this is included..... oh no not here! We were charged something like 700 yen for these 2 pouches of coffee! You have got to laugh at this otherwise you'd cry.Honestly the location is great as are the rooms but the whole place has this really weird vibe like something out of the Stepford Wives. It is way too pricey for what you get. Needless to say if we go back to Tokyo anytime soon we will look for other accommodation this time round.
Stayed for one night on a stop over from the UK to Oz. Fantastic hotel. Great bar on the top floor. Expensive, but worth it for the views.

Stayed here to visit adult child working nearby, who joined me. Accommodations large as noted by others, upgraded to 29th floor Wonderful American buffet breakfast available from 6:30-10 AM, with Japanese breakfast also provided buffet style. Concierge staff always helpful, finding Cirque du Soleil tickets, outlining carefully rail to Yokohama as well as journeys within Tokyo. Excellent bus terminus right inside/under hotel, with bags taken and delivered to room. ATM, 7/11 on mez. level. Variety of restaurants. South Exit (not New South) is most expeditious exit from Shibuya station, arriving at bridge over expressway which has elevator. Great attention to solving problems, with wireless provided as needed after paid wired internet was too limiting for our use (iPhone, two computers, etc.).
Didn't get a package, so breakfast, internet, gym, etc. was extra, but was upgraded to a bit larger room - very comfortable and easy to sleep in (no street noise).

Like most of Tokyo this place is no cheap but it is far superior to the competition and worth the extra money. When you ask for an ironing board you get a real one not one of those tiny numbers that Japanese hotels usually produce. Have drinks at the bar on the top floor and look out over the ligths of Tokyo. Amazing

We stayed for 3 nights in a superior triple room on the high floors. Prior reviews are generally very accurate of this hotel. However, we did find it very easy to travel from the airport to the hotel using the airport express train unlike some other reviewers - just make sure you catch a train that stops at Shibuya, exit via the west exit and just look up as you go other the pathway over the highway - you can't miss seeing the hotel. As there was lifts up to the ground floor from where the train stopped we had no problem coping with 3 large bags and 1 child. Hotel is in a great location with many interesting dining options nearby. Our room was reasonably spacious with a great view across the city to Mt Fuji. I would recommend checking the rates on Concorde Hotels website against the properties own website. We got the room 25% cheaper by going through Concorde- it was also much cheaper than other website booking agents.

This hotel is a bit of a find. Good value and spacious with bathrooms that hang over the city so you get a superb nightime view of Tokyo whilst luxuriating in a bath!!Shibuya is just five minutes and then there's easy connection to the park in cherry blossom time and easy connection to the Airport . I would definitely go back but if you're on the early flight don't expect an early check in. Service is just OK by Japanese standards but still pretty good. Good place for first and last night stay in Japan.

Not bad place, nothing spectacular, service was generally superb in Japan wherever we went, such polite, genuine and honest people. The location was good, food ok, room not bad but a little small like a lot of hotel rooms there (so I've heard) we were in the sky room i think...not sure how much better the rooms higher up were, they had I believe a view from the bath or something but they were all booked!...The bar upstairs was nice, very slick.Not much to say about this one, just a pretty good place with a pretty good location. However I loved Japan so much the hotel took a back seat to all the things I got up to when I was there.

Stayed here a few nights in Jan. Is my 4th stay here. Rooms are fairly spacious, all the normal ammenitities in the bathroom (except body cream), internet in room (my rate had it included, but there is a fee otherwise). Flat screen TV, and free daily paper. Good view of Shibuya from the room. Hotel is very short walk to Shibuya station, shops and restauran area, so great location to base yourseld from. Gym costs about US$20 a day to use unless you go before 6:30am. If it was a free Gym it would be ok, but for that price would except more. Had 5 bikes, 5 treadmills, 5 weight type machines and some free weights all in a compact room. No TV etc on the equipment. Overall for the price paid the hotel is good value for Tokyo standards

I stayed in this hotel while on honeymoon in Japan. It was such a bargin for the quality. I almost cried when I was 'introduced to the room' as I thought that I must have gone to heaven. I have stayed in many good hotels over the years and thought that I could no longer be impressed but I was.It is perfect for an amazing blend of quality hotel and fab loaction for trendy nights out.LOVED IT!

We stayed on the Tower Floor (floors 33-34). Our view was beautiful, although the did put us on the side facing away from Shibuya Crossing. The room was great - super comfortable and perfectly clean. The linens were very fresh. The bath was also excellent. The bath/shower portion itself, was more or less in the Japanese unit-style, where there was a tub and one could shower outside the tub in a larger open space. I recall it was all granite. We had a little noise from the people above one night. The hotel is nicely located with all the chaos and lights of Shibuya Crossing about a 5-minute walk away.Due to the floor we stayed on, we could make use of the club room breakfast, which was quite extensive and good. It included both Japanese and Western style (American and European) dishes. There was also an espresso machine which made coffee which was good enough (not great). Tea and cocktails were also available (free) in this lounge. The view from the lounge was great too, a bit different from the one in our room, but equally nice.Now, the downside. First, avoid the "jazz" club. That comment is based on only one night, so it's possible other nights might have been better. The real negative is the food, and the price of the food. We were there for quite a few nights. We were also jet-lagged. So, over the course of the stay, we sampled a couple of the restaurant options, and the room service. They were uniformly disappointing, and unbelievably overpriced. We also noted that Western guests were not treated as well as the Japanese. One does not have to be sensitive to pick up on this - it's quite blatant. Unless you're really desperate, I would walk to somewhere in Shibuya. The bar on the top floor has a great view, but again the price to quality ratio is terrible. Note that the top floor bar gets a bit crowded, as anyone (not necessarily staying at the hotel) can go, whereas the club lounge is not open to the general public.

First time traveling to Tokyo and couldn't have picked a better location. Easy walking distance to shopping, restaurants, nightlife & most importantly, the Metro! English-speaking staff was helpful & friendly. BelloVisto Bar on the top floor has great panoramic views, and is a great way to relax after a full day exploring the city. Our room was very nice & comfortable with a great view of Mt. Fuji.

We stayed 3 nights at Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel Dec 24-27, 2009. We arrived at Haneda Airport at 6am on Christmas Eve. Arrived at hotel by taxi, we had to go inside to ask for help with luggage. Funny reaction from the staff at bell desk, they asked, "CHECK IN ?" I had to explain yes, check in, later in the afternoon today. It was funny that we had about 10 suitcases, 2 families with 4 young children, and arrived at the front door, and they seemed reluctant to let us inside. We left our luggage at the storage, and as minimum of a chance of getting early check in requested granted, I still asked. I understand some Japanese, so when I asked, the man at the front desk asked the supervisor next to him about letting us early check in since we had so many children, and tired from a sleepless night on a red eye flight, and it was 6 degrees outside, with no stores or restaurants opened..... but the supervisor said very coldly to him "don't give them early check in. Get them out of here until 2pm". Then the man translated all that in English to me. Of course, I understand it would be a favor if they did, but standard procedure if not.Anyways, we went out, hung out with the kids at different eateries like Soba places, convenience stores, and Excelsior Coffee, until 10am, stores opened, we walked around, had lunch, and finally made it back to check in at 2pm. Rooms were ready, and we settled down and took a nap for the afternoon.Room was good size, good amenities, I really liked the bathroom, very big in size, and the shower and bath were in one big shower box so it was so much easier to shower the kids because the shower just sprays onto the floor. Floor isn't slippery, lots of counter space, and design of the whole room was very efficient.We had a king size bed, and internet is 1000yen for 24 hours, but cut off is 12 noon. We didn't have breakfast at the hotel. Very convenient location, there is a convenient store right outside the entrance of the hotel, and JR and Metro was about 5-7 minutes walk. Concierge was great. Front desk staff were all very very cool mannered. That's the only thing we didn't like, but wasn't an issue that affected our stay.Will consider staying here again next time.

After travelling lots for work, am quite picky about my holiday hotels. Cerulean passes with flying colours. Large room, especially for a Tokyo hotel. Room was well appointed, the bath/shower area was very sizeable and very comfortable. The concierge service was first rate - which is critical in a country like Japan. They are comprehensive, responsive and give excellent recommendations. It helps that it's just 5 min from Shibuya metro and good food like Krispy Kremes, Maisen and other good places like Ometosando.Have a couple small gripes - the gym/pool is chargeable (2000Y) which is a waste. Ditto for the internet. The bed is a tad firm for my liking. But other than that, excellent hotel with great views and awesome service.
the room was big and nice, the bathroom was great (shower and bath) and the view from the room was awesome !what do you want more ?

The hotel is in a superb location for people who enjoy Shibuya. And for those new to Tokyo, Shibuya serves as a great home base as it is on the Yamanote-sen (the circle train line that takes you to major areas in the city). You can walk out of the hotel and across the pedestrian bridge and be in amongst the excitement of the city in two minutes! I rate this as one of the best hotels in Shibuya (and I have stayed in most of them). The staff are extremely helpful. Our flight was cancelled and we had to book another flight and stay at the hotel another night. I was very satisfied with their help in arranging this. Bad points would include the expensive restaurants in the lobby and a severe lack of seating in the lobby. For a massive hotel like this, when you need to wait for the airport limo bus etc., there are only around eight chairs and many people were standing around. I would have gone into one of the lobby restaurants to buy a drink and wait there, however even a green tea was 1000 yen - crazy! But despite this, I would definitely stay there next time I am in Tokyo.

just returned fromt 4 wonderful nights at the Cerulean. The service was wonderful at every level. The room was fantastic with a spectacular view from room and bath. The location was perfect. I will definitely stay at Cerulean on my next trip to Tokyo.

Stayed at the hotel from 17 Nov to 20 Nov for work.The location of this hotel wins big. It is at the tip of Shibuya, so connectivity is amazing as the hotel is just a few minutes walk to the main station.I love the location because if you have a couple of hours to spare, you can just walk around Shibuya and be entertained. There is food, shopping and night life within easy reach.For breakfast, be sure to try the Japanese choice at least once. It's served in an elegant restaurant and the food is equally refined.The staff members are - as expected - exceedingly polite. But the info they give may not be the most updated or accurate. I had asked for the opening time for H&M in Shibuya and was told it was 10am. I had a bit of time so I dashed over, only to find out it opens at 11am.Also, they struggled trying to find me information about the boutiques I was keen on.Then there is the state of the room.While it is in fair to good condition, the TV volume and channel control were hell to deal with (the remote control is problematic).

The Cerulean Tower is located in very busy fashionable Shibuya and close to the metro - about five minutes walk. We arrived by limousine bus from Narita which drops one right at the door - to be met by hotel staff. After an efficient and friendly check in we were taken to our Sky View room on the 30th floor by Gerald - the French guest relations manager. The room was spacious by Japanese standards, squeaky clean, elegant and comfortable. Lighting was very pleasant. The view fascinating by day and night. Good, though firm matresses on the bed and our request for sheets and blankets rather than a duvet was quickly met. There was a comfortable armchair and a desk and desk chair. The bathroom was stylish in black and chrome but also very functional though a built in makeup/shaving mirror and appropriate lighting would be a nice addition. The air conditioning was extraordinarily quiet and effective.One of the best things though about this very fine hotel was the concierge desk. It was staffed by unfailingly pleasant and very helpful people who would always go out of their way to sort out whatever one wanted. We were first time visitors to Tokyo and with no Japanese language skills we found the concierges invalauable in making our trip a success. They even lent us passes for the subway and gave us instructions on how to use them.

The hotel was great. When we got to the room the view just blew us away. We wre on the 23rd floor and we could see right across tokyo. It was even better at night. We didnt go for the bathroom view but I dont think that would be any better. We could see just fine from the bed. 40th flood dining was just great with even better views (although quite expensive compared to the ground floor resteraunts). Good value compared to shinjuku hotels and better area. You can see the 5 a side football pitch on a roof top that was used in fast and furious!! Staff were great, and serive was of a high standard. I would go back and would reccomend to my friends!!

hotel was very nice, clean, staff was so friendly. it was in the heart of shibuya, which was great. right near the train stations and a quick walk anywhere else you wanted to go. i would definitely stay there again.
Nice hotel, quite big for japanese standards and very well located in this fashionable Tokyo district. Confortable, clean and very safe. Services and smiles are standard.

This hotel was everything I wanted out of a hotel in Tokyo without having to pay the prices at the Hyatt. My father and I stayed here for 3 days when we arrived in Japan and another 3 days on our way out and both stays were excellent.1. Get a room with a city view - we had one on the other side during our first stay and a city view on our way out and the city view will blow you away! 2. We were upgraded to a corner room on our stay on our way out and that was amazing, windows all around, a tub with a view of the city, amazing!3. The room and bathrooms were large in both rooms we stayed in.4. The staff was impeccable! The people that helped you find your way in the lobby, the staff that helped you with your luggage, the people in the restaurant, everyone was helpful, kind, and professional.5. The Concierge was great - one in particular helped us find someone to take us on a special little evening tour, even though she didn't really understand what we were looking for (small whiskey bars) she kept working on it and it worked out beautifully.6. The restaurants are VERY expensive - but there is a 7-11 within the hotel and many small resaturants nearby. 7. The hotel is very close to a main subway station in Shibuya so its extreemly convenient. 8. The bar on the 40th floor was wonderful! After visiting there I didn't need to make a treck to the Hyatt to see the "Lost in Translation" site because this gave me exactly the same experience.I will certainly stay in this hotel when I return to Tokyo!

I am a simple business traveller - just need a comfortable room with easy and reliable climate control, great bed/pillow and central location. This hotel scored exceptionally well in all of those areas and the service is really outstanding. Broadband in the room is free and fast and the gym is also fine. Location is in the heart of Shibuya within walking distance of everything you need. No complaints whatsoever.
Great locationVery nice, a bit pricy, what a shame to pay extra for the gym and pool!

I stayed here with my 2 sons aged 9 and 14. It is a very nice hotel in a great area - especially for teenagers. The room was a bit smaller than we were used to, but by Japanese standards fairly large, I think. Seem to be mainly Japanese tourists and business people staying while we were there which is probably a good thing! We were on the 30th floor so had a good view facing Mt Fuji (which we could not see because of the fog/smog/mist??)Service was excellent and the concierge recommended an excellent small family run restaurant within walking distance to the hotel. She was very helpful with all our questions while staying there.However, it is one of those hotels where you could be in any city in the world! Typical rather than special. Probably more suited to business travellers. Breakfast buffet was good but like all hotels - not cheap. Boys could not use the pool - have to be over 18. What an absurd idea - not only do you have to pay extra you have to be an adult. This could make all the difference between a great stay and an average stay - it was very hot every day and the boys would have loved to come back to the hotel for a swim after traipsing all around Tokyo all day.It is only a 5 minute walk to the Shibuya station so it is easy to get around from here but Tokyo is so spread out it is hard to know exactly where is the best place to stay when getting to the attractions. Plenty of shopping nearby but would probably stay somewhere different next time.

Stayed here on business and it was a vey nice hotel. Super close to the Shibuya train station and close to the Shibuya crossing with all of the shopping and restaurants.Rooms were a pretty big with great views. Elegant hotel, great service, and super clean.Bathrooms had huge tubs. Wifi is available but is not free.Gym was adequate and their is a pool. Again, not free unless you work out before 8 AM.Overall, great hotel and I would stay here again.

Great business hotel, 5 minutes walk from Shibuya. Staff were attentive, and most spoken English fluently. The one staff member I encountered who did not speak English, sent an English speaking person to sort out my problem.
This hotel was both luxurious and well located. The service was excellent. This is my favourite hotel in Shibuya. It may be a little more expensive, however the rooms are large and well appointed.

This sleek, luxurious hotel's location is one of its best features. It is in the heart of Shibuya, near fun shopping, great restaurants and the train/metro station. A park is also close by. The rooms are well appointed and the views of the city, beautiful. The beds were very comfortable. A 7-11 with an ATM machine was located on the second floor. There was a steep fee for the adult only pool and gym. There was no wi-fi, just cable connection. The small rather sterile lobby was composed of several chairs facing the reception desk backed by a cafe. The room rate was fantastic (less than $200/night). We tried but were unable to extend our stay at this rate - the rate they quoted in person was almost triple so we switched hotels after a week.

The rooms can be embellished a bit more, but overall our stay there was fantastic. The concierge service is probably the best in any hotel in Tokyo, the rooms, at least ours, had great views, large beds, very roomy, the staff was extremely helpful, and the location is perfect- 3 min. walk from Shibuyu station. Highly recommended. Plus, there's a bus from Narita Airport straight to the hotel's door.

Cool hotel - we were only there one night so just got a cheap room (no view from bathroom) but if I went back I'd pay a bit extra for one of the executive rooms. It was going to be a $50 upgrade so not worth for us. Great view from room though, big for Tokyo, friendly and efficient staff, absolutely fantastic location. We did struggle to find the hotel at first - make sure you take the correct exit from Shibuya station. We spent 45 minutes circling the station! Once you know the way though it is only a 2 minute walk from the station!

I did my fair share of research before I went to Tokyo. I was recommended to stay in the Shibuya area as it is very convenient to get around but not as hectic as Shinjuku. This hotel was perfect for my two night stay. I was traveling with my sister and we both loved the hotel. It was a little confusing to find it at first but I suggest you ask the information desk at the JR Shibuya station before leaving. The hotel was extremely clean and modern with amazing service. I would definitely stay here again!!!!

We have stayed at the Cerulean Tower the last 2 years and are staying again this December. This is a top notch hotel in a fantastic location. Moments from the Shibuya crosswalk (featured in Lost in Translation) and one stop from each of Harajuku (a hit with the teenage girls) and Daikanyama, a fabulous shopping district with quirky shops (a hit with the wife). Sign cafe near the station is excellent - this is where Bill first tried out his Aussie menu on the Japanese. Book using the Concorde Hotels website and get great rates. The winter (and summer) special is usually around 20,000 yen for a twin room. If catching the limousine bus from the airport, this hotel is the first stop but its a cinch using the Narita Express as well. They also have some interconnecting rooms which work well for us.

Thank God for the Cerulean Towers Hotel! Fantastic location, short walk from Shibuya station, Shibuya shopping district and the famous Shibuya Crossing. The service surpasses any accommodation we have EVER stayed at. Upon arriving in Tokyo, we had lost a bag of ours on a train. We were overcome with worry as all our travel documents and valuables were in the bag. Our lack of the Japanese language added to our concerns. Somehow the composed staff member, to our complete amazement, managed to track down our bag through the complex maze of the Tokyo railway system. The staff truly went above and beyond the call of duty for us and turned , what could have been a very stressful holiday into one of our favourite and most memorable. We couldn't thank the staff enough! Can't say a bad word about the hotel. Clean rooms, great view, value for money and a fantastic time had by all thanks to the Cerulean Towers Hotel.

I've lived in Japan for three years now, and i've stayed in almost a dozen Japanese hotels. This is by far the most well rounded of the lot. First off, the location is difficult to beat. You are located about 2 blocks from the famous Shibuya Crossing and station. The view is better than the Park Hyatt Shinjuku and the Royal Park Yokohama. Plus, both of those are more expensive. I stayed here over New Years, and we had views that ranged from the Tokyo Tower to downtown Shinjuku. It was amazing. The price actually wasn't that bad relative to other luxury hotels i've visited in Japan. My bill for three nights was under $800 US Dollars. The Park Hyatt Shinjuku (Lost in Translation hotel) cost me better than $600 for one night. I'd argue that I had more room than both of those hotels as well. The rooms were large for Japanese standards.The service was excellent. I speak very bad Japanese so everybody spoke English to me. They even sent one of the Western bellhops up to the room to drop off our luggage. He then explained the sights we were seeing from our massive windows. I was extremely pleased with everything from price to location. If I decide to stay in downtown Tokyo again, this is where i'll stay.

We stayed at Cerulean Tower for 2 nights at the end of 2 weeks in Japan. For our earlier 6 night stay in Tokyo, we picked a different, more budget-friendly hotel in Shinjuku, but wanted to "splash out" a bit for our last couple of nights. The Cerulean Tower really delivered in that regard. From the moment we checked in, we truly felt like honored guests. We were greeted warmly and offered a half-price upgrade to the Executive Level (rooms on floors 33-36), which also includes free Internet, free breakfast in the executive lounge, and some other nice perks. Since we got a great rate booking online, we jumped at the upgrade and thought it well worth the additional price. Our deluxe single room faced Shinjuku, with the famous Shibuya crossing at our feet. The style was modern Japanese minimalist, but nicely done and we didn't think it was tired, as a few others have said. The bath was quite nice as well; spacious and with good quality bath/shower fittings, etc. The room had a desk area (with Internet cable) as well as a sitting area (two chairs and a table) near the large windows. The beds were the most comfortable we experienced during our stay in Japan.The executive lounge was on floor 35 with excellent views. We even saw Mt. Fuji at breakfast the day we left. Breakfast was good and sufficient to start the day. Given hotel breakfast prices, that amenity alone probably made the upgrade worthwhile.While we didn't have a lot of extra requests, those things that we did need help with were quickly and expertly addressed. Arrangements for the limo bus were a snap and got good help with restaurants for our last dinner in Tokyo. We did not dine in the hotel other than our breakfast.All in all, I'd recommend this hotel very highly, particularly with some of the reasonable prices to be found now on the internet.

I'll join in the chorus of great reviews for the Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel. We selected the hotel primarily for its location in Shibuya, as well as offering big/luxury hotel amenities (concierge, business center, english-speaking staff, etc.) at a far more reasonable price than the well-known luxury chains. First, the location worked out perfectly. The stores, restaurants and bars of Shibuya surround the hotel, Harajuku and Shinjuku are a nice walk or short ride away and the Shinjuku station is just a couple blocks from the hotel. As a bonus, the airport bus/limo goes straight to the hotel and, as the tallest building around, it's always easy tto navigate your way home.Based on some reviews, I was expecting the hotel/rooms to feel a little outdated. That was not the case at all. The lobby/common areas and rooms all felt as if they'd been updated. This isn't a W or luxury boutique hotel, so the decor is relatively uniteresting, but it was certainly modern and not at all run down. The staff at the hotel were extremely friendly and helpful, and we did not have many communication problems. The hotel facilities -- gym and restaurants -- were expensive, but not outrageous. We only ate the morning buffet in the hotel and, depending how hungry you were, that could be a bargain compared to some other meals in Tokyo. Regarding rooms, the corner rooms were nice, but not so spectacular that I'd necessarily pay extra for one. I would recommend a room facing towards Harajuku for a better view.I would definitely stay at the Cerulean if/when I return to Tokyo.

This was our first trip to Tokyo and we would stay here again without hesitation. We were there for 10 days & upgraded to the corner queen & it was completely worth it. The three huge windows offered uncompromised views of the city, the mountains and, in the early morning, Mt. Fuji! The staff was fabulous, the amenities were excellent and the hotel was quite possibly the nicest I've ever stayed in. The rooms were big, clean and well appointed. The bathroom was fabulous! Between the tub with a view and the great toilet, it was difficult to leave! The location of the hotel was great as well with 2 foot bridges leading away from the hotel into the center of the city. The concierge helped us with everything from money exchange, purchasing sumo tickets and drawing a map for us to find a dumpling house in nearby Shinjuku. There is a 24 hour 7 Eleven located on the 2nd floor that was also very convenient.We loved it!
I was very happy w my stay. We didn't try the restos or treatments, but rooms are very clean, at the heart of Shibuya. Nice big spacious rooms and bathrooms.

Stayed here for 3 weeks last year. Rooms were clean & well equipped and absolutely fine unless you are a princess.. The place is not high end (like the Westin), but is pretty luxurious.. Pool is on site, good restaurants available, amazing bar on the top floor with stunning views.As we were staying for a while, we got a 10-15% discount on the room prices, which made the place really pretty reasonable.If I went back, this place sets a very good value for money benchmark..

The Cerulean Tower is a 5 star hotel and makes no bones about it. It is in a pretty good location close to Shibuya station. We booked through Expedia which was good and had requested a Sky View King, exactly what we got. Front desk staff had reasonable English, some better than others, and were fairly helpful.View from the room was outstanding, looking over Tokyo Tower and North. Bed was great and the bathroom clean and spacious.On the negative side, in our whole trip to Japan this was the only hotel that did not provide free Internet access - rather mean as it was also by far the most expensive. In a similar vein access to the pool is charged at 2,100 Yen per person per day (this is also access to the Fitness Centre whose staff were decidedly unfriendly when asked for a look).Drink prices in the rooftop bar were outrageous, and we didn't bother to even look at the restaurants.Location great, rooms and facilities good, but haughty staff and a mean spirited approach made it an overall disappointing experience.

We stayed at the Cerulean Tower for 3 nights and found it to be an excellent choice. The service at check-in was fantastic, all staff we dealt with spoke enough english for us to clearly understand, and they were always so polite and helpful and ready to assist before we'd even asked! The room was awesome, on the 33rd floor with a 180 degree view over Tokyo. We stayed in a standard king city view room and found it perfect. The bathroom was a highlight, with a separate bath and adjacent 'wet-room' with a handheld shower, all enclosed behind a glass screen. Complimentary toiletries included toothpaste & toothbrush, hairbrush, razor & shave cream, cotton wipes and hair ties, as well as Molton Brown shampoo, conditioner & body wash (which i looooved!) The room itself was large enough, with a fabulously comfortable king bed, separate chiase lounge, desk and large flatscreen TV. The hotel is perfectly situated, around a 5 minute walk from Shibuya station, and the famous intersection crossing. Be warned though, if arriving/departing via train at Shibuya Station, you will have a (albeit short) walk down a steep'ish hill to get there (or uphill if coming from the station to the hotel) Okay if you're just walking, bit tough with suitcases! There were several restaurants within the hotel, but we didnt try any of them as there are so many cheaper options in Shibuya (and all delicious!) There's a little noodle place just down from the hotel's entrance that you can order a hot bowl of noodles for around $5 (AUD) You choose the dish from the plastic models in the window, then order using a vending machine & then take your ticket to the chef and request "soba" or "udon" noodles - ingenious! Overall, fantastic hotel, fantastic location, unforgettable experience for my first time in Tokyo!

This is an extremely wonderful hotel - high class, professional service, and great location!The room we stayed in was clean and big, the bed was a king size bed - soft and comfortable, the television was a LCD, and the bathroom was HUGE!The both bathtub and the wide shower area are divided by a huge glass window (with a glass door) from the rest of the bathroom - very unique design!The location of the hotel is in heart of Shibuya which is absolutely convenient for travellers! You can easily go to the metro station, train station, restaurants, shopping district, and department stores by just a few minutes walk from the hotel. Since it is a luxury hotel, there is no free breakfast for the guests, there is a buffet restaurant on the 1st floor. The price of breakfast is expensive, and the food is not as good as you would expect.

When I reached the Narita Airport I called the hotel from the airport to confirm my reservation and they said that you were suppose to come yesterday and your reservation has been canceled . I told the hotel staff that there was some confusion as I was traveling to multi location and now what do we do. The hotel staff told me that it is not a problem I can come and stay there but I have to pay more as I will stay for only one night. I had no other choice as my other colleagues were also staying there. So I said ok I will come, I went there and stayed , the hotel staff was nice and professional. Internet was working fine since my blackberry was not working I immediately logged in and checked my mails.overall it was ok experience and finally I have paid the amount initially what was agreed. Saved some money for the compay.

Four nignts at the Cerulean in early April. I read every review on tripadvisor prior to deciding to stay here, and thought I'd just answer some of the questions I had.Definitely take the airport limo bus (really just a bus). Trying to navigate the train/subway with a lot of luggage would be a poor decision.I booked a Tower room, for the free internet and complimentary breakfast in the Executive Lounge. The breakfast buffet is small, but pretty comprehensive, and the food is excellent; in fact, all the meals I ate at the hotel were really good. I also had access to lounge in the afternoon, and it was nice to be able to stop in for a free drink and snack.I found the location to be excellent, with a short walk to Shibuya station and all the nightlife, etc., of Shibuya.The views out over the city were spectacular, the room was not huge but well laid out. Very convenient to have a 7/11 on the second floor of the hotel.

From the bathtub we could see the view of shibuya lights below us. Super-large windows from bathroom and bedroom are really a gem, without worrying somebody will look to us sincethe hotel is the highest building there (choose higher floor). The room was really big. We had superior room from tablet hotels com for 31200 yen. We didnt eat in the restaurant, but restaurant food in tokyo is excellent and good priced especially if you go to the narrow street and struggled a bit with japanese language like gyu=beef, ton=pork, and sometimes just point out at what you'd like to have.

Pretty decent hotel with around 5/6 restaurants - one of which has a great view on 40+ floors. Located right next to Shibuya station and famous 'crossing' so very handy for shopping and entertainment.Rooms are the classic 80's boom Japanese rooms , which are fine but a little dated....Hotel is a little pricey - but guess this is Tokyo so to be expected!

This is an excellent hotel just across the pedestrian bridge from Shibuya station. The best way to get to the hotel is by bus (they call it 'limousine') from the airport. At the limousine counter at the airport, buy a ticket to Shibuya. The first stop is Cerulean Tower. This is the best way to get to the hotel. All rooms at the hotel have views over Tokyo and on a clear day, some rooms can see Mount fuji. I was satisfied with my stay at the hotel and service was excellent. However, I thought breakfast at the hotel was tasteless and overpriced. The freshly squeezed orange juice was US$13/ glass !!! There are plenty of places to eat around the hotel across the pedestrian bridge and you can have a drink and a hot breakfast for less than US$5

The hotel is in shibuya and its perfect for walking around during the day time and at night. It's a very convenient location. The train station is just five minutes walk, lots of shops and restaurants in the same area. The hotel reception and service are just the best. The bar/lounge at the hotel is overlooking the city. The view in our room is just great. Not much to complain.

Have you watched "Lost in translation"? This is the type of Tokyo hotel depicted in the movie. It's just awesome. Location: just across from Shibuya station, can't miss it. Checkin: polite, efficient.... wham porter takes you to the room, explains everything and leave you politely with a bowView: OMG!! Tokyo is best viewed at night, from top down, thru the big windows of this hotel (Make sure you get a room facing Yokohama)Beds: comfy clean and bigBathroom: again, another awesome part of the experience. includes a glass door shower area + soaking tub.... and they also pipe music into it :) TV: I expect a hotel of this age to have a flat screen, but it didn't, of well, who cares about the TV.The hotel also has like 5 different restaurants and some bars, concert hall and some other venuePorter service is also tip top, need anything? just ask and they'll figure it out for you.

Cerulean is a rare find in Tokyo - it's a luxury hotel with a price that wont make your heart stop beating. It isn't cheap (at all) but in Tokyo if you stay somewhere cheap, you're going to end up wishing you had forked over some more money for decent place to sleep.We stayed on a fairly high floor, and requested a corner room. The room was -- wow. Breathtaking views, comfy beds, and the bathroom was fantastic. From the bathtub, I could look out over the city and sip my wine, and it felt almost like a honeymoon spot. The staff was very cordial and helpful, when one of my friends became lost, she called the hotel and they put notes on each of our bags (which were at the front desk), so that when we came to claim the bags, we saw big notes which said "Friend at airport marriott the number is..." this was incredibly helpful since we were all quite frantic. The area it's in is really lively and there are tons of places to grab some food, shop, and just wander around. This is one of my favorite places to stay in Tokyo, and I've sampled quite a few. It's a great value for the money in my opinion.

We stayed here for 8 nights in Nov. and Dec. 2008. It was an extremely clean, well-appointed hotel. We easily made the walk from the Shibuya train station to the hotel with rolling luggage and that station is really convenient for getting around Tokyo. There were some good restaurants close by, including Kaikaya which was our favorite restaurant in Tokyo. Surprisingly, there was also a great wood-burning oven pizza place a couple of blocks away called al forno. We weren't completely impressed with the room service and restaurant selections, but exploring Tokyo's awesome food scene is best anyway. Another serious convenience--the hotel has a 7-11 on the second floor. No slurpees, but they do have an international atm, beer, pocky, and other funky snacks for those late night munchie runs.

Great hotel, conventient for Shibuya station. Very tall hotel and we stayed on the 40 something floor. I was a little nervous, dreaming about earthquakes and all the stairs I would have to walk down in an emergency. However the views of Tokyo are amazing from the hotel, so much so that there are queues for the cocktail bar at the top floor but we didn't have to wait too long. Rooms are excellent standard, clean and very modern.

We stayed at Cerulean Hotel over four nights in November and found it to be a great hotel in an excellent location. Upon our arrival we were instantly upgraded to an executive room with a spectacular view at no extra cost. The room we had was quiet, comfortable and clean with a great bathroom.The restaurants and bars are of a high standard, staff were friendly and very helpful. Just be aware of the baggage handling fee, we were not told about this until we were checking out. Overall Cerulean is a very nice hotel, I would not hesitate to stay again.
room was smaller than other same range hotels. View was nice from 36th Floor room.

We booked the hotel with expedia.com and we had a very nice rate, (we discovered that in August, for this kind of high-quality business hotel, is low season). We booked a twin room because was the only available at the time of booking. When we arrived we ask for a king size bed, and for very little money they upgrade us to a higher floor room, king size bed and breakfast included. They also help us to book a top rated japanese restaurant speaking japanese language. The position is very central in Shibuya, 5 min by feet from the subway. A drink after dinner at the 40th floor bar is worth the money...

We usually stay at the Peninsula when in Tokyo for business, but a Japanese colleague recommened the Cerulean. The location was great, walking distance to the side-streets of Shibuya and the Shibuya train station which has connections to many of the major tourist sights. The hotel itself was adequate and clean. Service was good, but still not compable to five star hotels like the Peninsula or Four Seasons. A friend mentioned the Italian restaurant there was good, but we didn't have the chance to try it.

Was in Tokyo for 3 nights for business. Our Japanese colleagues has suggested Cerulean and, after reading the tripadvisor reviews, we decided to accept their suggestion.Based on what I'd read here, I asked if there were any corner rooms available when I checked in. The man at the desk offered me a much more expensive corner room. I declined, as it would have increased the rate from 3500Yen to 5000 -- too much for my company's blood (and I was traveling with the boss).The main at the desk then thought about it and said, "Will you be coming to Tokyo frequently?" I said, "Oh yes."He said, "You seem like you know a lot about the hotel. [True -- thanks to Tripadvisor reviews!] How about you join the Cerulean guest club (for 500Yen = $5) and I give you a free upgrade to a corner room?"Since I was staying three nights, this was the best $5 I ever spent at a hotel!The hotel room was exceptional. The view overlooking Shibuya is tremendous. I could see the mobs of people crossing the big intersection 32 stories above and off in the distance. Very cool.Our group ate at the Mediterranean restaurant one night. I wouldn't recommend it. The food was ok, but incredibly expensive. The beer was $10 for a small glass. I had a shrimp risotto that was tasty, but small portions. The menu is also quite small.The staff was very friendly. I enjoyed the view from the bathtub and there were plenty of nearby shopping and restaurants so it was a fun place to take a walk.The breakfast in the lobby restaurant was pretty good. Not a huge selection, but enough to fill us up. If you want something lighter, walk to the Starbucks not far away.The Shibuya train station is almost directly across the street, so that is a major convenience too if you will be doing any train traveling in Tokyo.If I make it back to Tokyo, Cerulean would be on the top of my list.

I recently stayed here on a business trip to Tokyo. The view from my room on the 32nd floor was stunning. The rooms are spacious, clean and very comfortable. The staff was helpful with directions, restaurant reservations, intenational dialing support, everything! Nothing bad to say at all. I stayed at The Four Seasons last time and this hotel is much better.

I cant really say to much with out spoiling the suprise. This hotel rocks, and being a frequent traveler to Tokyo, I dont need to even show ID anymore upon check in. Can I tell you that I left something in the room during my last stay and 6 months later checking into my new reservation I asked if it was still in lost and found and it was.The Gym rocks, dont eat the food there, I went to the Excelser Cafe, the bar is breathtaking, and beer is good.

We are very particular about accommodation and we loved the Cerulean.More often than not you can feel let down when you arrive at a hotel. Not here. The lobby itself is extremely well designed and tastefully decorated.The staff make you feel welcome. Not just with Japanese precision but with genuine warmth.We arrived very early in the day from Narita - the manager went out of his way to arrange one of our rooms to be ready for our use straight away. What's more it was an upgraded room.The rooms were of a very high standard. However, the upgraded room was more spacious and had a beautiful bathroom with fabulous views, from the bath as well, of Tokyo. The bed in this room was also much more comfortable than the firmer beds in the standard rooms. Such comfortable beds are very hard to come by in Japan!I would recommend paying a little extra for the superior rooms, even on the lower floors, as the views are still fabulous,the rooms are a more spacious, the beds are wonderful and the bathroom is really special.The location of the Hotel is perfect for tourists or frequent visitors such as ourselves who want to be in a very central area.Shibuya station has great transport links with the Ginza subway line and the Yamonote Circle line which covers all of central Tokyo.There is plenty of great shopping and lots of restaurants nearby. You can spend hours lost in the maze of shopping streets in Shibuya alone.The hotel can also give you details of a nearby coin laundry if you are staying for a longer period.We will definitely stay here on our next visit to Tokyo.

We wanted a stylish and modern hotel in the centre of Tokyo and booked this hotel on the recommendation of others on Trip Advisor.We were not disappointed!! The hotel was very easy to locate and had an impressive entrance and foyer area. Staff were polite, friendly and spoke good english. On checking - in we were surprised by a free upgrade to a corner room which had the most fantastic views from both the windows in the bedroom and bathroom.The room was spacious and the bed extremely large and comfortable. The bathroom was luxurious and bathing at night looking out across the city lights was something we will never forget!!As the weather was really bad we enjoyed an lovely evening meal in the Hotel's Mediterranean restaurant followed by a glass of champagne in the roof top cocktail bar - where my boyfriend rounded off the most amazing evening by proposing!!Breakfast is a pricey addition however there are plenty of cafes nearby where we were able to have a reasonably priced breakfast. I have already recommended this hotel to colleagues visiting Tokyo as it provided the ideal base to explore all of Tokyo's major sites.

We arrived soaked by a sudden rainstorm and the staff immediately appeared with towels to dry us and our luggage down. So sweet! The service, rooms and breakfast were second to none. We were travelling with teenagers who loved the Harijuku fashion district only 2 stops away on subway. Loved Tokyo, so clean and efficient.

Let's start with the good. The hotel's lobby is the biggest I have seen in downtown Tokyo. The location is great - once you know your way around the overhead bridge. Their staff are polite, eager to help, spoke good English - a rare skill in Japan.The rooms (we had two), are spacious in Tokyo standards. They were also very clean and had great views overlooking Shibuya.Now the disappointments. I booked a room to house three people and booked via the internet - expedia. However, upon check in we realise the room accommodated two people and an extra bed cost an extra 5,000 yen/night. In no fault of the hotel, shops in Shibuya closes relatively early. If you are in Japan and keen on experiencing night life the Tokyo way, I suggest you stay in Shinjuku.

Absolutely the best hotel experience I've ever had, bar none.I travel frequently for business, and my experience at this hotel surpassed that of any other stay. When you get to the higher-end hotels, the minute details are what make the difference, and there were no shortage of those here. Since everyone else has spoken in general terms about the hotel, here are a few of the details.I came back from my day and tossed the business cards from my briefcase on the desk. The next day, after I returned to my room, the business cards were sorted into piles, by company, and stacked in perfectly square piles next to each other. I left my pants crumbled up on the bed. They were perfectly folded when I returned. Rather than disturbing where my things were in the bathroom, they moved the hand towels to the other side of the counter top.Everyone wants perfection in a room but has to settle for second best. We all subconsciously accept defects in the room, like a handle that doesn’t work right, a scratch on the counter, or a dent in the fridge. But there wasn’t a single defect in the room that I could find, and the quality of construction was superb. The grout lines in the granite on the walls was so perfect, they were art. There were great details like the way the granite tile was rabbited where it came together, details that they didn’t have to do, but did. There were no scratches, dents, rips, smudges, in anything in the room. And the service was incredible. Others have described the quality of the staff. I’ll cite one example. My colleague and I were taking the 11:50 a.m. shuttle to the airport. We had been asked to be at the porter’s desk by 11:40 a.m. I was running late packing and hadn’t yet checked out. At 11:38 a.m., the phone rang: “Mr. <name>, are you still planning on taking the 11:50 p.m. train to the airport.” “Yes I am.” “Very well, you must hurry.” I got down to the checkout desk at 11:42 a.m. Two people were waiting for me with my bill already pulled. While I checked the bill, a porter came to me and apologized, but she needed to take my suitcase to the bus. She handed me a tag and whisked it away. Another person apologized, explained to me that they would call us in just a few minutes and motioned for me to sit in the lobby. In one minute a woman came through the lobby with a sign saying “11:50 p.m. Narita Bus”. I watched as simultaneously each bus passenger (ten or so people sprinkled about the lobby, intermixed with other people not waiting for the bus) was approached by a staff member and invited to follow the woman with the sign. The woman walked us to an escalator holding the sign and motioned us onto it. She then ran down the stairs next to the escalator (presumably out of respect), and directed us out to the bus. There was no way they could have made that experience better for me.I have many more examples about the quality, but you get the idea. Superb!

I've stayed here many times on business. It is walking distance to the Shibuya area and the Shibuya train station with access to the JR Line. The service is impeccable. Everywhere you go, there's someone there to greet you. They handle your bags, press the elevator button for you, just impeccable service. I would recommend this hotel. I have also stayed at the Grand Hyatt (best hotel in Tokyo) and the Hilton Shinjuku (old outdated hotel) and the Intercontinental Yokohama (great hotel). Pro: - nice modern rooms, good size rooms by Japanese standards- impeccable service - comfortable beds, with three types of pillows including memory foam pillows- nice work desk area- Gigabit Ethernet interface in the room, internet access tested at 25Mbps download- Awesome buffet breakfast, very high quality food, but EXPENSIVE- Great restaurants in the hotel - Walking distance to Shibuya where there are tons of restaurants and bars Con:- outrageously expensive buffet breakfast (3,000 yen) - not affiliated with any major frequent guest program such as Hyatt, Hilton, etc Tip:- I recommend taking the LimoBus to and from Narita airport, you can buy your ticket at the hotel desk and they will handle your bag for you, it is so much more convenient than taking the train because it is door to door and you don’t need to carry your luggage around the train stations

I had a short stay here at the end of May. It has a fantastic location about 2 city blocks from Shibuya train station and all of the Shibuya shops & entertainment are right around the corner. The hotel service staff is friendly and seem to be well-trained (but isn't that the case in all of Japan). My room was on the 21st floor and it faced north to Shinjuku. It was a big room with plenty of space. The bed was a wee bit too hard I thought. Surprisingly, the TV isn't a flat screen newer model. The bathroom was of good size but its layout was quite odd because the toilet faced the wall.

The Cerulean was a great experience. The staff was attentive and friendly. We had a room with a great view of a park and the nightlife in Shibuya. The room was nicely decorated, and big enough for two and had a great path with granite tile, a bidet and a terrific shower in an area next to the tub. Not too practical if you owned it, but fine with maid service to clean the room. Great but expensive buffet. Lots of good restaurants close by. But Shibuya is the gathering place for Tokyo youth, hordes of them. You will feel out of place if you are a Westerner and older. But they are polite. There are a couple of train lines across the street. Express bus service goes from Narita directly to the hotel every hour. You can take the express train to Shinjuku, a few stops away and then take a Japan Rail line to Shibuya. If you're not dragging a lot of big bags, that would be faster. The Tokyo subway is great and it's easy to get around the city. Taxis are very expensive, so avoid them unless you are taking short trips.

The selection of a Tokyo hotel can be tricky given the size of the city. The Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel is located in Shibuya and after having stayed here for 4 nights I believe it is perfectly located for exploring Tokyo's neighbouring "Wards".All that has been previously written about this hotel I totally agree with. Firstly the hotel is easily accessed from Narita by the Airport Limousine Bus - its a door to door service and it took roughly 1 hour 20 minutes in each direction. The Cerulean is one of only 2 hotel drop off points for Shibuya. The Cerulean has an impressive entrance and grand foyer which is ultra minimalistic in its design. Huge windows look onto a formal Japanese garden - it all makes for a wonderful first impression. Check in is brisk and efficient. We also used the Concierge several times and the staff were all friendly and knowledgeable. Rooms are located from floors 19 to 37 and this is the selling point for this property - all have incredible panoramic views from large windows. All of Tokyo seems layed out before you. They are nicely fitted out in the less is more Japanese style and are quite spacious by Japanese standards. The bathrooms are also generously proportioned. Lastly - the hotel is within quick walking distance to Shibuya Railway Station and the famed Shibuya Crossing which has be seen to be believed.

The cerulean room was a little small but every hotel room in tokyo is small. The view from my room was amazing. We could see as far as the mountains and the wide expanse of tokyo. At night the views were magical. Then Shibuya is RIGHT THERE. You can walk to tokyu hands! You have the rail right there. Seriously I would never stay elsewhere...plus the service was impeccable. To this day, I have never stayed in a place that had that much attention to your comfort, We needed toothpaste and within 2 seconds there was a bellhop with toothpaste, an adapter, 2 minutes, a pen, anything and they were at our doorstep.So stay at the cerulean. They have everything you need and its in the heart of tokyo. And then take a walk through the love hotels and eat at Gonpachi. Truly memorable experience.

For my third visit to Tokyo I decided to forego staying at a more expensive hotel where I stayed previously and asked the Embassy to try the Cerulean in view of its location as my 24 year old son was coming out to join me (on airline points). The location at Chibuya puts one within a short walk of an endless number of restaurants and all kinds of shopping. If one wants the high end stores then there were several department stores with all the high end possible.(Worth a visit just to see the quality of merchandise with men's shirts starting at $165 and ties at $100..and one of these great department stores even had a real theatre pipe organ where a young lady was giving a mid-morning performance). My son found a store (Ulo I think) nearby where he could not believe the deals and ended up buying so much I had to carry home a pile of t-shirts (at $19 each) and a linen sports jacket at $49. To visit Chibuya Square at 10pm and see literally hundreds lined up obediently waiting for the light to cross and then they come like a tidal wave of humanity...sit upstairs at Starbucks and marvel at the Times Square of Tokyo). And a tip with all the many restaurants, go to the top floor of the department stores..you will find a dozen restaurants and all reasonably priced with excellent food..in fact I have lived and travelled over much of the world over 35 years and have never eaten so well so reasonably.Now as for the hotel all I can say is outstanding. First the staff are so courteous and helpful..the concierge insisted in wallking me outside to show me the 711 which is in the hotel where there is an ATM and the chamber maid refused any tip..what a change from almost anywhere! As many other reviews point out the room is quite spacious, well and tastefully furnished, the internet at $10 a day worked perfectly on my laptop, but the bathroom is to write about...we loved the walk-in marble shower with glass separation so the bathroom does not get steamed up. Beds are very comfortable with European duvets and three types of pillows so I had my favourite down-filled. The fridge has room to add a few things of your own...(I was surprised that they did not provide an ice bucket or wine glasses, only regular drink glasses). The breakfast is excellent and well presented but like any top hotel at $30 for the buffet a little pricy especially when outside nearby the Starbucks or a myriad of other little coffee shops offer sufficient for less than $10...even $5. The hotel gave me a room facing away from the Square on the 27th floor but at my request moved me when my son arrived to a room on the 37th overlooking what I call Tokyo's Central Park with all the skyscrapers like the Hyatt in the distance..incredible view night or day and on top Mount Fuji as well became visible one weekend of my 2 week stay. The beauty of this hotel is that although next a major cross-city 6 lane roadway because the rooms are all on 20 or above floors with excellent sound-proofing there is absolutely no outside sound except an occasional helicopter. And finally it was well worth the price to have dinner in the bar on the 42nd floor..incredible view..(the French restaurant is one star Michelin but expect $100 a person minimum)...the only complaint about the bar is that the non-smoking is in a small area so we preferred to be in the smoking area with the incredible view and the ventilation system was so good despite the two men smoking cigars nearby we could not smell the cigars. With pre-dinner drinks, wine, a full three course meal for 4 persons and after dinner brandy plus the cover charge of $8 each the meal came to just under $300. On top of everything, I can only praise the excellent and very courteous helpful service at all times..wonderful.

Tokyo, Japan was the first of several stops on a 10-day Japan roller-coaster style vacation. After making it through customs, traveling on the N'EX to Tokyo Station, then hopping on the JR Yamanote line to Shibuya (as a travel tip, purchase a Japan Rail Pass in advance of your departure), we were ready for a brief period of relaxation at our hotel. The Cerulean, from the minute we steped into the hotel, was just what we needed. The hotel has everything a weary traveler requires, including a spa, workout room, pool (for a fee), and several restaurants for a first evening after a long flight. It is also centrally located, approximately 3 minutes from Shibuya Station on foot. By JR rail or subway, a resident of the Cerulean is no more than 30 minutes from any major site in Tokyo. The rooms of the Cerulean are immaculate, and are certainly on par with many American 5-star hotels. They each come with a dramatic view, regardless of your floor. If you feel lucky, and are able to catch Tokyo on a relatively smog-free day, ask for a room facing south for a view of Mt. Fuji. During our stay in Tokyo, we were able to see other hotels, including the Park Hyatt (of Lost in Translation fame) and the Prince Park. While both hotels are nice, for the money do yourself a favor and book at the Cerulean. If you have any questions, or are interested in a Tokyo-centered activity once you reach the hotel, ask for the concierge, Yoko. She speaks excellent English, and goes out of her way to make your stay in Tokyo a little bit better. Here is another quick tip for Tokyo-goers interested in sushi. No matter what you read, or who you speak with, the Tsukiji fish market is the ONLY place a rationally-minded individual should go to for sushi. After eating at one of the oldest (and supposedly "best") sushi places in Tokyo, there is little difference in quality or selection (although an unbelievably huge difference in price). For the money, and to keep your child's college fund in tact, go to Diawa-zushi in Tsukiji.

We stayed here at both the beginning and end of our trip, so experienced two different rooms. The first was a deluxe double, which was a corner room on the 31st floor with two double beds. It was marvelous. Immaculately clean, contemporary design, spacious (and not just for Japan!) and very well thought out in so many ways. Take for example the desk - it was situated at right angles to the corner window, alongside a small counter containing a lamp with a dimmer switch, numerous outlets, telephone jack and Ethernet port, pen and paper, and tissues. In the desk drawer was a LAN cable! As I set up my laptop, I realized that my power cord had a 3-prong plug and the outlet was only for a two-prong plug. A call to housekeeping brought the adaptor to my room in minutes. The climate control worked beautifully in the room, there were 3 of each towel for two people, and two different bathrobes for each of us.
