There were both a "normal" and a buckwheat pillow on each bed, and extras in the closet. The comforters were thick and comfy and warm. And yes, they change the duvet cover every day. It's an awesome process - if you get a chance, watch them do it - you'll learn how to make a really awkward process easy and quick!Our second stay was in an Executive Double on the 33rd floor which can only be accessed by using your key in the elevator. It was almost exactly the same room, but on a different corner, and this one was set up with a third bed for my daughter. It was a cot - but more of a portable bed than what you would think of as a cot, not some thin flimsy piece of junk. There was plenty of room even with it, and they rearranged the other furniture so we could still use the sofa and chairs. The Executive room added a DVD player to the flat screen tv (though they don't rent or sell DVDs, so if you want to watch, bring your own!). It also added complimentary bottles of water, and the 3-prong plug adaptor was already in the desk socket. It included breakfast in the Executive lounge on the 35th floor. I have seen several people complain here about the crowds there - we did not experience that. We ate there on a Sunday and a Monday morning, and it was very quiet both times, with plenty of choices, and they refilled things constantly. It was fine - although the buffet we paid for downstairs in the lobby in the Garden Cafe was absolutely outstanding! But it was $25 pp.As a matter of fact, all the food we ate at the hotel was outstanding. The service was excellent. Everything was excellent about the dining experiences except of course the prices. As in every other hotel I've stayed at in Japan, the prices were exorbitant. But when you're exhausted and it's cold and rainy out and you don't want to experiment any more for one meal, it's an awesome treat...I'm not going to repeat what all the other reviews said about the awesome views, fabulous bathrooms, etc. other than to agree.Overall, if you can afford it and want to be pampered, stay here. I can't imagine staying anyplace in Tokyo other than this if I ever go back!

This hotel came well recommended and... yes... in relatively expensive Tokyo it offers okay bang for buck. The rooms are small and the best thing in my room was the bathroom...but..they are often great in Japan. I was put off by the room being twin and not double as booked. Access to the fitness facilites cost and a lot (as do most services at the hotel) from what I can remember. Room service is fast and good. There is a good turndown service though. The business center is expensive and not adequate for the huge size of the hotel. The location is good for those more drawn to Shibuya. Stay here if you get a good rate and insist HEAVILY on a double bed. Its good but I havent been back.

GREAT room service. Nice rooms. Quiet. Very modern. Super location 4 mins walk from Shibuya station - although super hard to find if taking train from Narita (45 mins) then to town, switching to another train to then walk to hotel.....you MUST take the bus right ot the hotel! Easy peasy.Overall hotel - killer. The bar at top is fantastic with awesome views.Stay here - a little more expensive but well worth it.

This hotel is amazing! From the service to the views to the location, this place will satisfy any traveler! Situated in the hip, exciting neighborhood of Shibuya there is a lot to do and see. And just steps away are two major lines of transportastion, the JR line and the Shibuya subway station. Travel sites offer better rates than booking direct- nearly 40% cheaper in the low season. Expect heated seats and grand views in the bathroom, and a myriad of lounge options throughout the hotel. The Cerulean will exceed your expectations and satisfy your taste for the invigorating heart of Tokyo!

As a single traveller, I was well recieved. The ambiance through modern is very warm. My room, on the 25th floor with a panaramic view, was large, well appointed, and spotlessly clean. I loved the Japanese bath, fluffy robes, and the Somo bath products were the best. I am not a good sleeper but I needed a wake-up call. The bed was divine. I loved the crisp linens and long to buy the duvet (if only I knew where).The young evening porter at the Transportation Desk directed me to a nearby bookshop to find a Japanese comic book for a Christmas present and assured me the area was safe. It is an area where there are lots of people out on the streets and I, too, was out walking and shopping late in the evening feeling a sense of adventure in the air. At 9:45 p.m., the bookstore was packed and I found a variety of comic books from which to choose. The only glitch was supper in the Carmelo room after a late arrival from Kyoto. When the restaurant manager was made aware, he took care of the problem and the next morning when I arrived for breakfast, he greeted me warmly and was very attentive to my needs. I would happily stay at The Cerulean on my return trip to Tokyo. I would like to get to know the Shibuya area better.....Los Angeles, CA. Resident

The location, service and amenities are excellent. The room size is quite large and the bathroom amenties, design, materials and detailing are superb. I could see Mt Fuji from my hotel window this evening. This hotel exceeded my expectations in every way except one - the fabulous pool facilities do not admit children under 18. As you can imagine, this was a terrible disappointment to my 10 year old son. I sincerely hope the hotel changes this policy in the future.

I have stayed here several times & find it great. Rooms are very clean (as you'd expect in Tokyo) & relatively large. All facilities are there.Breakfast is good, with freshly squeezed orange juice as well as all the basics.Check in can be typically regimented Japanese style but very efficient & fast.Getting to the airport is very easy & efficient again - via the "limousine bus" (not sure what is 'limousine' about it but it is great & gets you there relatively fast).Access to the GREAT shopping & night life is Shibuya is 100m from the front of the hotel.Only slight negative are the TV channels - you need to be clever to get English working.

Very modern and sleek yet personnable hotel - just one word: for the price of another old-fashioned 4/5 star hotel, you are going to stay in a prime location coupled with top personnel and incredible views

I stayed at the Cerulean for two nights in November, and was extremely pleased the entire stay. The room was large (especially for Tokyo standards) and the bathroom simply amazing. I booked a room with the bathtub in a picture window overlooking Tokyo, and would recommend it to everyone—it’s just a very cool way to relay after a long day. Bathrooms in Asia are exceptional anyway, and this one took the cake: washlet commode with seat warmer, great sound system, Molton Brown toiletries and a separate walk-in shower. The service was very good and staff more than helpful, and I did not have any problems communicating in English. Once you step off the airport bus or cab, your luggage is taken and appears in your room before you do. The hotel has a few good restaurants, and I had dinner at the French one overlooking Tokyo. Spectacular setting and very good food, but a bit steep at $137 for one person for the chef’s menu. Also had coffee and desserts in the Italian one, and I had one of the best tiramisus I have ever had—who knew I had to go to Tokyo for that. If you can, try the traditional Japanese breakfast through room service—it’s not cheap, but so worth it. The hotel is very close to the major Shibuya metro and JR lines and the famous Shibuya intersection is a thing to experience. Thousands of people cross it at every light cycle—amazing. There are also a lot of upscale stores and department stores in the immediate vicinity. Overall an amazing hotel in a great location. I would most certainly stay there again.

I have stayed in quite a few hotels in Tokyo now on business and this is by far the best.Firstly, it's location - in the heart of Shibuya and within 2 minutes walk of the subway station and you can get everywhere you need to.Secondly, it's one of the tallest buildings in Tokyo, a real sky scraper and you get the best views of Tokyo - the rooms have massive panoramic windows and you can marvel at the density and diversity of the city - great at night.The rooms, as always in Tokyo are fantastic and have everything you need - fluffy bath robes, little hair brushes, great toiletries and everything - I was on the executive floor, so can't say whether this is the same throughout the hotel.A really nice big bed, with lovely bed linen and furnished fantastically - I really couldn't knock this hotel, it's stylish, sophisticated, comfortable and excellent service.Take a trip to the sky lounge for a drink...but beware the prices, just make it the one!

This was a wonderful hotel in a great location. As a first timer to Tokyo and a solo traveler, I couldn't have picked a better hotel. The location was perfect, a few blocks from the heart of Shibuya. The service was friendly and helpful. The ladies at the concierge desk were very generous with maps and information. The hotel bar had a wonderful view as did my room. The beds were heavenly and the view from my bathtub was awesome! If this hotel is in your budget I would highly recommend it!

The hotel is lovely, the staff speak good english and rooms are fantastic. We had a non smoking room on a high floor and the view was amazing. Shibuya is a great area to stay in as there are many shopping centres, the train station is five minuts away from the hotel and even at 3am there are people roaming the streets ! Great Experience , would definately recommend this hotel !

Upon reading the reviews, I can recommend one thing. When checking in, ask for one of the larger rooms (on each floor, there are 4-6 rooms that have a different layout than the standard rectangle room). My colleagues and I stayed here for 4 nights on a recent business trip, and two of us (for the exact same price as everyone else's room) got a separate shower, bath tub with large window view of Tokyo, spacious bed with sofa and chairs.

Stayed at this hotel for 8 days in August 2007. Firstly, the positive. It's in a good location, very close to the subway station which can be difficult to negotiate at first but is worth the effort. Secondly, the staff at the hotel are friendly and helpful but, and this leads on to the first negative, the standard of English spoken is very poor. Any problems which would not be covered by a standard phrasebook are beyond them and this can lead to a difficult stay at this hotel. Also, although the rooms have internet ports for laptops, there are only two computers at the hotel available for guests. They are located in the business centre and have to be paid for - that's if you can get on them. The room was also a disappointment. Although the view of the city was spectacular, the carpet had several nasty-looking stains and clearly needed to be cleaned properly. Overall, i just wasn't impressed with Tokyo, full-stop and this hotel was symbolic of that feeling.

My wife and I stayed at the Cerulean for 5 nights in July. It was our first time in Tokyo and we chose this hotel based on the reviews here at TA. We really enjoyed the comfortable room, great bathroom with japanese style shower/bath enclosure. The room itself was spacious and well appointed, no discrepancy between what has been reported by other travellers. We did not experience any of the inconveniences of other reviewers : ie we asked housekeeping for our pillows to be changed to hypo-allergenic and it was done within 15 minutes. The room was immaculate, and daily housekeeping very good. The staff was most helpful, especially the concierge desk helping out with dinner reservations (in places a tourist wanderoing the streets would NEVER find!) and with train reservations (the young lady at the concierge desk made sure we booked the proper seats on the Shinkansen to Kyoto because we had luggage... she suggested we request seats at the back of the train car where there is room behind the seats for large suitcase. She then wrote all this in japanese to make it easy for us at the ticket purchase office... small details but very helpful). Not all staff speak fluent English, as acurately reported by others, but hey, if you want everyone to speak English... don't go to Japan. That is the joys of travel. We found the overall level of the staff very high.The Shibuya location is fabulous. A short 3 minute walk from the station makes JR train and subway access to all of Tokyo a breeze. Plus, compared to other hotels (we stayed at the Park Hotel at the tail end of our holiday) the Shibuya location is great, it is actually a NEIGHBORHOOD, and not just an office complex with only overhead walkways. You actually find LIFE right outside the hotel doors.Our 33rd floor room afforded great views to Roppongi and the Tokyo Tower.All in all, the Cerulean was a perfect choice, and a great home base to explore all of Tokyo.

I stay here frequently. The rooms are modern, clean, great bathrooms, and excellent location by Shibuya train station. If it's clear get a room with a view of Fuji-san. There are a number of good restaraunts within the hotel, and a bar & restaraunt with a great view on the top floor.

My husband I lived in this area 25 years ago and find it very convenient. However, the hotel was a big disappointment. Though all the hotel staff had good manners, it was next to impossible to get extra bath towels because the Housekeeping staff spoke very poor English. Also, though there were many people standing about the Lobby ready to help, very few could answer any questions, again because of poor English skiils. Finally, the room had a soiled carpet, an extremely uncomfortable bed, and a very small bath. I would not return and know there are better places to stay in Tokyo.Carol

stay in Cerulean tower tokyu 5 nights in late june 20071.super easy limousine bus to catch at Narita airport that drop you off in front of the hotel,porter will take care of your luggages at the bus terminal and at the hotel.(300yen per person by bus)2.check in was very smooth and fast,staff extremely ,extremely polite and helpful with every thing you need,one minor detail is that they can't give us 2 rooms on the same floor because they said that we book by expedia seperately?i still can't understand what it has to do with the distribution of room.3.very close to Shibuyia subway and rail so it can take you everywhere 4.lot of places very near by so you can eat and buy grocery.5.room very nice,marble bathroom with every amenities possible6.contemporary design which is exactly what i would like7.one minus is that internet is not free,no ironing board in room but you can borrow it,and use of pool and fitness center cost you 10US$ each person each use,but i think it is like that in every hotel in Japanoverall,excellent hotel,excellent location,excellent staff and i miss their bow and smile when on the return we have to stay in Hyatt regency in Detroit because our plane with NW was delay for a day

I read rave reviews about this hotel so I wanted to check it out. I stayed here as a single female traveller for 2 nights in February 2007. I booked via the hotel website direct. After I made a booking using the email I called them and they didn't speak English when they picked up the phone and the person I spoke to had difficulties understanding what I was asking. Eventually they transferred me to someone who spoke English to deal with my enquiry.I stayed in a standard single room. It was roomy, clean and very comfortable, but not quite 5 star standard furnishing that you would expect to see in a 5 star hotel.All the hotel staff spoke English and were very attentive. Service at the reception/room service/housekeeping/concierge level was mostly impeccable except in the restaurants. I called their Italian restaurant to reserve a table for myself. When I got there the waiter at the entrance looked at the booking and argued with me alleging I booked for 2 persons. Why would you argue with a customer about that, it wasn't like they were fully booked that night. When I ordered my meal almost every other dish was "sold out". I arrived at the restaurant at around 8pm so it wasn't that late in the evening. The food was nonetheless very good and reasonably priced.The hotel was around 10 minutes walk to Shibuya station, very conveniently located as a good base for exploring Tokyo. But it was an uphill walk from the station so if you were carrying heavy luggages or travelling with young kids, take the airport shuttle (which provides literally door to door service) instead of the railway. If it's your first time navigating around Shibuya station, it's a big station and you could easily get lost trying to find the correct exit to the hotel.As some other reviewers have said, the lobby is always very busy and full of people. If you are looking for a quiet relaxing stay and like to spend time in and around the hotel, go somewhere else. If you only stay in your room mostly or go out sightseeing a lot, this is a comfortable hotel to stay in.

We stayed in the Cerulean Tower for ten nights, and it was very good. We were on the 25th floor and had an excellent view of Shinjuku and Shibuya- we could even see Fuji on one clear day! The room was very nice and well furnished, and the bed was extremely comfortable. The service was also excellent, and the staff were only too willing to help with anything. The bathroom was large, and the shower excellent. But I should stress that it was expensive. You get what you pay for though, and the Cerulean Tower was certainly worth the money. It's located only 5 mins walk from Shibuya station, and the central Shibuya area in general, but it's quiet (up on the 25th floor at least!).I'd definitely recommend taking the airport bus there, not the train though, as we found that lugging large suitcase through Shibuya station at 5.30pm is not the greatest idea. The one are where the hotel was a little disappointing was taking the airport bus back- the organisation was a bit lacking and it seemed more luck than judgement that we even got on the bus in the end. Also, there is a charge to use the internet every day, I can't remember exactly how much but it wasn't hugely expensive. Overall I'd highly recommend Cerulean tower, if you're willing to pay highly.

I used to stay at the Capitol Tokyu on every visit to Tokyo. However, Capitol Tokyu is now being rebuilt so this time I stayed at one of their other hotels in the much more hip area of Shibuya. Capitol Tokyu was a very old and well established hotel, so everyone knows where it was. This time, I had trouble with the taxi guy at the bullet train station who had never heard of Cerulean. The name is not so familiar yet and Shibuya is so big and busy that if they have not heard of it, it would be very hard to find, with so many tall buildings in the area. The taxi arrived at the hotel after being stuck in Shibuya traffic for quite a long time (taxis are not cheap in Tokyo, let me remind you, so being stuck in bad traffic will cost you the price of flying with a low cost airline in another country). And when we got to the front, there was no-one there to welcome us or help us with our luggage. I had to run inside and ask someone at the reception to come out and take our luggage inside. Not a good first impression. Check in was ok good and the room itself was nice. The view from the bedroom was absolutely AMAZING, looking down to see all of the craziness of Shibuya from the 30th floor, and looking out to see all the buildings, parks and streets of Tokyo in the distance, you can even see the Tokyo Tower from your room! I doubt if the view from any other hotel room in Tokyo can be as good as this. Truly Truly amazing. However, here's the worst thing about this place: the Internet connection. I was there for business and need to use internet and email constantly. First of all, Internet in the room here is not free, which I think if you are paying this kind of price for a business hotel in a modern city like Tokyo you really should be getting complimentary internet access. Second of all, the connection itself was very shoddy, constantly getting disconnected and timed-out, not the fastest connection to begin with. This is a very frustrating thing to have happen when you are supposed to be communicating with people back home and writing emails all night. Can't download any large file because once your connection is cut you have to start it up again from the beginning. If the hotel is slowing your work progress down, that is not a major problem for business travellers who already don't have enough time in the office. Being right in Shibuya has its good and bad, but it's still a cool place to be in Tokyo, everything is here, shops, department stores, restaurants, bars, subway and JR lines. But Shibuya is pretty much at the left corner of the map at the end of the line so it's also quite far from other areas like Ginza. When I used to stay at Capitol Tokyo at Kokkai-Gijido Mae it was not in a hip area like Shibuya but it was in the middle of many places like Roppongi, Ginza, Shinjuku, Harajuku and even Shibuya so it was a good central base to be in. Breakfast here is served in 3 different restaurants for 3 different styles/ cuisines so you have to make a choice of what cuisine you want before you sit down. This means that you can't be having western breakfast while your colleague has Japanese. I tried both and was more impressed with the Japanese breakfast eventhough that restaurant was totally empty. Try the Croissant in the western breakfast buffet though, one of the best I've ever had. Room service was very good, although very very expensive. A bowl of Unagi and Rice will set you back about 4300 yen! No complimentary water in the room either. Again, with this kind of room rate, what's a little thing like bottled water for guests? Seems like they're forgetting the small details that make a difference.  Overall, has the potential to be really excellent, with good location and a great view. All the basics are there, management just needs a little fine tuning.

I stayed here from April 20 - April 22. The hotel was relatively average by Tokyo standards. The best feature is that it is within easy walking distance to Shibuya station (5 minute walk) and reasonably close to shopping and restaurants in Shibuya.The restaraunts in the hotel are exhorbitantly priced (even by Tokyo standards), and the hotel charges are NOT as advertised. In addition to the room charge, there was a service charge, a consumption tax, and an accommoation tax added to the bill... all of which, according to the hotel staff are "customary charges". Interestingly, the other three hotels I've stayed in Tokyo in the past two months charged NONE of these. Unless you book through a 3rd party that charges you up front, expect to pay approximately 20% more than the advertised price. Also expect to pay 1,000 yen for each day of internet service and 3,500 yen for each day of gym/pool use.The room (a superior queen bed with sky view) was reasonably sized, was similar to an average Westin hotel in the states, and the view (from my corner room on the 30th floor) was unexpectedly rather mediocre. Unlike other Tokyo hotels, there wasn't too much interesting in the room (no heated toilet seats, no automatic shades, etc.). If it weren't for the location, I think it would be easy to do better.

Let's get one thing out of the way - this place is not cheap. But what you get, in Tokyo, is truly outstanding. In the past my wife and I have stayed in Tokyo business hotels, which are several times cheaper. But they are also several times smaller, and frankly after a long day immersed in the hustle and bustle of central Tokyo they were not very relaxing to come home to. The Cerulean Tower, on the other hand, makes an ideal "base of operations" - after a long day of whatever you are doing in Tokyo (sightseeing, business, etc.) you can come home to a place that is truly well planned, relaxing, and more than large enough for American standards.The service, typical for Japan, is a cut above normal expectations. From the moment we entered the lobby (after walking from the nearby train station) porters and greeters came, took our luggage, and escorted us to the check-in. All the staff spoke excellent English. Whenever we needed it, someone was there to help us. They also arranged for our return to Narita, they have shuttle bus (for a fee).Our room, on the 26th floor, was what I believe their web site lists as a "deluxe corner king". The room was roughly 500 square feet. There was a small entryway, with a dresser and a place to put luggage. There was a full closet (with motion sensitive lights!). The room has a doorbell and electric "do not disturb" sign. The room is one large main room, with a California King, a love seat, chair, and a panoramic picture window. There was also a smalll desk with internet connection ($10/day), with another picture window. There was a widescreen tv, and a mini-bar fridge. We stocked it with soft drinks from the convenience store. The bathroom was jaw-dropping - the spacious tub (although not a 2-person model) also has a panoramic picture window overlooking Tokyo. There is a glass shower, the usual heated, computerized toilet, and polished stone floor to ceiling. All tastefully decorated - I applaud whoever designed these rooms - for once someone got it right, as opposed to just pasting expensive stuff on the walls.The hotel itself is conveniently located about a block from the Shibuya station - it is a short walk with overhead walkways over the street intersections. Note that the main overhead walkway near the station has stairs both up and down, but the one on the north of the hotel sports an elevator and there are escalators on the east from street level, which may an issue for some. It is also only a block or two from the Shibuya shopping madness - there is plenty going on here all the time. There is a 7-11 in the hotel itself, and a Lawson's down the block, which should fulfill most of your minor shopping and late-night snack needs. We never used the pricey room service, but we did eat in Chinese Restauraunt "Chen" (yes, the Iron Chef). The food was good.All in all, a truly fine hotel and for those with the means it is more than worth it. We will certainly stay there again the next time we are in Tokyo.

We had an overall bad experience with this hotel. The room that we reserved was not the room they gave us and when we complained they just said it was the room we reserved and too bad basically. Internet is not free which is crazy in a place like Tokyo - we stayed in 2 other hotels and it was included in the price. So on top of a bloated rate for what you get you have to pay $10 a day for internet. On the other hand the hotel is in a great location. And the room was ok - our view was nice but... the price of this hotel and the service that we received was substandard. We stayed at the Park Hotel in the Shiodome and it was cheaper and about 5 times better. Theres not too many hotels in this same area and I think they take advantage of that. I would never stay here again and I wouldnt recommend it.

My wife and I have just returned from a week at the Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel. We stayed in a Deluxe King Room (44 sq. meters) on the 35th floor (executive floor).We picked this hotel based on passed tripadvisor reviews. We were a little unsure of the location at first, due to the long ride from the airport. Also, the Shibuya area is known as a “young persons” area.Well let me tell you, the airport limousine bus could not be more convenient. It is literally door to door service. Most people get off and carry on to another part of the city, but if you are staying at the hotel, your luggage will be picked up from the bus and delivered directly to your room (very convenient). Don’t be fooled, the “little girls” that handle your luggage are more than capable to carry them.Check in was quick and efficient. Key-card was in your hands within a couple of minutes. The elevator to the 35th floor was as fast as it gets. The room was larger then expected for Tokyo, and the bathroom was large, by anyone’s standards. The workmanship of construction in the room was not to be believed. Everything fit like a glove. I only wish that my house had the same workmanship! The view from the room was breathtaking. I’m not sure that you need to spend $$$ on the view of Mt. Fuji. We could only see it for a day and a half due to fog (haze).The money spent for the executive floor is a must. Breakfast in the 40th floor dining room was fabulous. Great service and a lovely meal. Also included was use of the 35th floor executive lounge including teas, coffee and cold drinks all day, with snacks and alcoholic beverages for a few hours in the evening. Also free in room internet on the executive floors. Service from the executive lounge people was marvelous. They were extremely helpful and had a genuine need to satisfy you. They were a pleasure.The location is indeed very convenient. Lots of great shopping and subway, JR line and Keio(sp) lines are all within a seven minute walk. Be prepared to see a chiropractor when you return home. The amount of people there to greet you and help you will keep you bowing 50 times a day. This is truly a 5* property and deserves more then there 4* rating. Would go back in a heartbeat.

I stayed at this hotel for 10 nights on vacation and loved it.The Friendly Limousine Bus took me from Narita straight to the hotel.The moment I arrived I knew this was going to be something special – the service was instantly top class. I was met by a porter as I got off the bus and my luggage was taken for me to reception where I was checked in straight away even though I had arrived 4 hours before check-in time.My room was perfect.A bathroom to die for – with bath and shower wet room, separate wash room area and an electronic toilet!The room was very spacious and very clean.Best of all was the view across Tokyo – especially at night with the neon lights.The service was always impeccable – the staff seemed to genuinely take pride in their jobs.The location is bang on – right next to Shibuya and great for public transport links to the entire city.This is a seriously cool hotel – with superb staff. I will definitely return.

Second time we stayed here. The check-in staff we very cold to the point of being unfriendly but maybe she was having an off-day. The room was great and very spacious. This is a large and pretty anonymous kind of hotel but it is well located and is very nice. The concierge sent us to a great, and reasonably priced sushi restaurant called Midori near the hotel. You have to queue for 30 minutes but it is so worth it!

We stayed here for 3 nights in February. Being totally new to Japan we were unsure about what to expect but right from the start our experience was positive. The check in staff were helpful and efficient, and the porter who showed us to our room was ludicrously attentive. It also had the fastest lift I've ever been in.Based on what I had heard about Tokyo I was expecting a small room but the room was a reasonable size by UK standards, very clean and nicely decorated. What took my breath away was the view from the window. We were on the 26 floor looking towards Mt Fuji and at sunset the views were stunning.The other great thing about this hotel was the bathroom which was huge with a separate walk in shower & bath room, and the most technologically advanced toilet (complete with heated seat) I've ever seen. Certainly one of the best hotel bathrooms I've ever experienced.The location is good. It's a short walk from Shibuya where there is plenty going on, and is close to the station where the Ginza metro line provides cheap and easy access to the rest of the city. We were on a room only basis so didn't have breakfast in the hotel, but we were quite happy to grab a croissant from the excellent bakery at the station on our way into town.Getting here from Narita is a doddle as the limousine bus company run a bus every hour or so that will drop you at the door. As I recall this was quite cheap but took around 1h 30min.My only criticisms would be that our room seemed a little hot at night even with the a/c on full, and the hotel bar is comically expensive. But overall this is a great hotel and we really enjoyed the time we spent here.

I know this hotel gets rave reviews. This is not one of them. This is a four star hotel masquerading as a five star hotel. The difference between a club room here on a Saturday night and a room at the Park Hyatt was about $50-100 and there is no comparison. The room is not in same class as the Park Hyatt and was frankly a disappointment for the money. It was on the small side and in terms of style; more department store catalogue rather than a designer experience.The staff at the Cerulean are obviously trained to be attentive, however, it can become a bit too much. They were all lovely but such enthusiasm at breakfast! The club breakfast was served in the signature dining room with a sensational view and it was very good. But a formally served five course breakfast is a bit like the enthusiasm, a bit much first thing in the morning. Wonderful coffee was a big plus. You can opt for a continental breakfast at the club, but the selection is ridiculously meagre.The club cocktail hour was very light on too, the club area was small and the standard range of hors d'oeuvre was so poor as to be laughable. It is not comparable to the normal Club lounge scenario, however again the view is wonderful.The location is good for this side of Tokyo so if you really want to stay in Shibuya then I suggest you take a standard room and skip the extra expense of a Club Room.. I suspect all rooms are identical to the club rooms but others are on a lower level of the hotel.. The lobby was full on, always full and bustling. Some people may like that, but it felt like the rest of Shibuya, packed and trendy. It was no retreat from the outside world.Yep, after three days the Cerulean made me finally feel my age. I probably resent that but what I resent more is paying for 5 stars and getting a good solid four star experience with a few flourishes around the edges.The Cerulean is a hotel that really tries to be more than it is.The Park Hyatt or Mandarin Oriental are in a different class.

Traveled for the first time to Tokyo, and I must say this was a great choice to stay. Everyone here was very helpful and did it with a smile, whether it was asking for directions or carrying my luggage.Rooms were perfect in every way. Everything was spotless. Bathroom was gorgeous and the view was phenominal. I had a great view of the Rainbow Bridge and Tokyo Tower. It was a great way to relax after a long day of exploring.Location was great too, within a 5 minute walk from the famous Shibuya crossing and subway. A small store next door carries cheap snacks and drinks when you need it.Overall a great experience and will definately recomend this place.

Stayed two nights at the Cerulean Tower and was hard-pressed to find anything to be critical about...and I tend to be pretty critical about hotels especially when it comes to the cleanliness, service, and value for money. The Cerulean is nicely located in the Shibuya area of Tokyo, but not in the busy, crazy, noisy area of Shibuya. Walking distance to all the shopping and good restaurants! The hotel has a nice modern design, very clean, uncluttered and by any standard (not just Japanese), the rooms are quite spacious and quiet. Wonderful bedding, rich, fluffy towels, robes, slippers, easily rivaling the Westin's, Ritz Carlton's, and W's! The service is amazing! The staff truly anticipates your every move everything from pushing the elevator button before you get to it, to bringing you water to your table before you even think about it! They are very polite and cheerful, they seem to like working there. Bottom line, I highly recommend it if you're looking to get the most out of your $$, yes, it's not that cheap (I paid $250 a night) but worth every penny especially in Tokyo!

My family and I stayed 5 nights at the Cerulean and we absolutely enjoyed our stay. The rooms were spacious by Tokyo standard and we love the soft, earthly colour schemes which give the rooms a nice, cozy feel. The bathrooms, with their polished marbled walls and vanity tops were lovely too. In addition, we find the hotel very well-located. It is just 5 minutes walk away from the Shibuya station, from which you could easily reach most places in Tokyo. For alternatives from the hotel food, one can easily find a wide plethora of restaurants within walking distance from the hotel. We had tasty noodle soup breakfasts at this little noodle shop just a couple of minutes' walk from the hotel! Last but not least, the service at this hotel is excellent! The concierge was enthusiastic and patient, and helped us tremendously in figuring out how to get around Tokyo via the subway (we are not subway-savvy people). All in all, it was a great experience, and the Cerulean would definitely be the hotle of our choice when we visit Tokyo again.

A business conference landed me and my wife at this hotel. We were awed from the first minute. We extended our stay by four days at an unbelievable corporate rate of 23.000 Yen a night, for a double corner room.Competence and friendliness of the staff, tranquility, connectedness to the subway and railway, everything just perfection. A human warmth that was never fake made the entire place feel like staying at a friend's place.This level of service at this price is sensational. No hotel in London or New York comes even near. In fact we have, since staying here, come to notice how awfully bad service in most US hotels is.

If money's no object for you, the Cerulean's a good place to stay. The location--just over the walkway from the JR station in Shibuya--is central and the facilities are excellent. And there are some stunning views to be had from the guest rooms. However, if I'm dropping more than three hundred bucks a night on a room, I don't take kindly to being nickle-and-dimed for everything from internet access to tea bags. It left kind of a bad taste in my mouth from what was otherwise a good experience.

I travel to Tokyo fairly often on business. I've tried a hotels, but for the money the Cerulean is my favorite. It's very conveniently located with respect to dining/shopping, and the Narita-Express gives you direct transportation to/from Narita. The decor is modern, which suites my preferences, the staff have always been very attentive to my needs. When I have breakfast there, the help literally anticipates my needs based on what I'm doing. I remember once taking a bowl of cereal to my table from the buffet, only to find a waiter 1 step behind me with the cereal spoon I'd neglected to take! I like all the restaurants in the Hotel, but there are many good ones within a 10 minute walk. People who complain about a lack of cable channels need to spend more time out and about and less in front of the tube. I often am lucky enough to get a room from which you can see Mt. Fuji in the mornings. I agree that the $10 charge for internet and $20 for the gym seem like nickle and diming you ... but compare it to the $120 more a night you pay for the Westin in Ebisu Garden...For $220 (what I normally pay), it's a bargain in Tokyo.

The Cerulean Tower was a nice find. As a single woman traveler spending 4 days in Tokyo on business/vacation I thoroughly enjoyed this property. Although its right in the heart of crazy, trendy Shibuya (entertaining to watch the teen trends there), the location was great for subway and Japan Rail access (20 minute ride on the JR Yamanote line to Tokyo station and the Shinkansen). Hotel itself was a quiet oasis from crowded, busy Tokyo. I ordered room service twice and both times it was fast, tasty, and servers were polite. Lots of help and attention from bellhops and staff. In-room internet access worked well - just had to keep logging back in to the hotel's site. The best part was the room itself. Got upgraded from a small twin room to a corner King on the 23rd floor, no extra charge and such a nice surprise after the long trip from the US East coast. Not only wonderul view towards Shinjuku but bathroom was large and had a deep bathtub plus separate shower. All marble and all the amenities one could want. Room itself was good sized with a nice workdesk and closet. Clean overall. Comfy bed and choice of pillows was a nice touch: choices are 1) traditional Japanese rice husk-filled; 2) tempur-pedic foam; 3) feather. I did not eat in the hotel restaurants but instead explored the local yakitori and other treats around the area - there are lots of them - and the Tokyu and Mark City Department stores within a 10 minute walk had some fun and interesting supermarkets to explore with tasty to-go food for less than 1000 Yen. I did not use the fitness center or pool or the hotel bars. I would recommend this hotel to anyone who wants to stay in a comfortable, quiet, clean, friendly, and modern hotel in Tokyo. It's not the Mandarin Oriental, but more of a sleek, well-run, very cushy and attractive business hotel, with affordable (read: under $200 a night off season or on a government budget) rooms. Another added bonus is the express bus to/from Narita Airport stops right at the hotel entrance. This is much more convenient than taking the subway to/from Narita. I will stay here when again in Tokyo and would recommend this to friends. Hint: try booking through Concorde Hotels website (corporate owner of this property) for the best deal.

We just returned from our Japan holiday and want to recommend highly the Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel. Like other posters have mentioned, this hotel is near the JR Shibuya station, a real plus for travelling to other parts of Tokyo on the JR Yamanote line. The service we received was impeccable, and we had a lovely corner room with a fantastic view of Tokyo Tower. Though not overly large, our room was comfortably spacious for our four-night stay. The bathroom, clad in marble, provided an added measure of luxury to the accommodations. Breakfast at the hotel, though quite pricey (2700 Yen per person), was excellent - we especially enjoyed the station where an attendant squeezed orange juice for guests. What decadence!

I was lucky to have stayed at such a great hotel my first trip to Tokyo. The rooms are on the small side (like almost every room in Tokyo except for the Park Hyatt types), but well designed and a pleasure to stay in. Very comfortable beds and pillows. Gorgeous spacious bathrooms. The service is great and the location is probably one of the best for exploring on the JR line.Highly recommend staying here if it is your budget or even for just your last night. A shuttle bus picks up from the hotel to take you to Narita. Very convenient.

The Cerulean Tower Hotel is a fabulous hotel located in hectic and lively Shibuya (not for the faint hearted!). As the name suggests, the hotel is a gigantic tower block - not overly appealing on the eye, but very handy for locating when you come out of one of the station's many exits and need to know which way to head!The porters at the hotel will probably be your first experience - they are so eager to help and overly polite. Be prepared to be bowed down to at every opportunity! The porters are mainly young girls who are TINY, which was quite amusing, as I had no idea how on earth they would manage to lift my heavy case on to the trolley - but somehow they did. Any offer to help was deemed highly offensive, so best just to let them get on with it. The vast and spacious lobby is a real hub of activity with constant toing and froing, and there was usually a small (but orderly) manned queue at the check-in desks, although the process is quite smooth and hassle-free. There are a huge number of staff milling around - some of whom's sole purpose seemd to be to greet people and bow! However, everyone was more than willing to help and answer any questions, which was great. Free area maps were also available - and a god-send, as Tokyo is a NIGHTMARE to find your way around!Our room was on the 22nd floor and it was great. It was quite big (but not MASSIVE) and perfectly comfortable. The "king-size" bed wasn't as big as other king-size beds I have stayed in in other countries, but then again the Japanese are all so tiny it's hardly surprising! The beds were SO comfy and the special pillows made sleeping pure heaven. The air-conditioning was easy to use, and our internet access was problem-free throughout. There was a small desk and chair, plus a comfy chair and small table. There was also a large walk-in wardrobe area with a rail and hangers plus a ledge for suitcases. The TV was fine, although the remote control was a bit of a minefield - and mainly in Japanese. Thankfully some of the programmes are in both English and Japanese, but you have to locate the button on the remote to allow you to switch to English. Watch out for accidentally pressing the Pay-TV button by mistake - VILE! Not pleasant! The overall choice of programmes wasn't overwhelming - mainly CNN, Fox and BBC World 24 (which started to grate after a while!!), but it's better than nothing. The minibar was stocked mainly with soft drinks, water and beer, but the prices were astronomical. Much cheaper to pop to the shop next door! Free robes and slippers are provided, which was great. The bathroom was really nice and clean, with plenty of marble and shiny chrome fittings. There was a bath with an overhead shower, which could be detached so used whilst in the bath. Sadly our bathroom didn't have a window, but I believe corner rooms have bathrooms with views over the city, which would be wonderful - although I am sure they come at a premium! There were a selection of free toilettries and a hairdryer. There was also a very hi-tech toilet, with all mod-cons (built in washer and bidet - be prepared - it is quite a shock at first - believe you me ... brace yourselves!!). Undoubtedly the most FABULOUS thing is the view from the bedroom over Shibuya - it is SPECTACULAR! I don't normally get overly excited about views but this one was incredible - I spent hours looking out of the window watching the world go by. I felt just like Scarlett Johannson in Lost in Translation - it is almost overwhelming!The rooms were very clean and the chaimbermaids were very efficient and polite. Most of the ones I saw were actually men, and they always knock (well, actually - ring your personal doorbell!) before entering. If you fancy a lie-in you can always switch on your electronic DO NOT DISTURB sign!!!There are several restauarnts in the hotel, but we only ate in three. We had an amazing meal in the Italian restaurant on the Second Floor, but it's not cheap and the portion sizes aren't massive. Drinks are also REALLY expenisve, and last orders are at 22.00 - so Europeans used to eating late could be in trouble.We also had a snack in the lobby restaurant (I think it is called the Garden Restaurant), which was nice enough, but rather overily fussy (and expensive!) for just a quick snack, which was what we wanted! There was a good choice on the menu, and I believe it was open until midnight, which was useful as the other restaurants all shut at 22.00. On the last night we decided to treat ourselves by eating in the spectacular Tower Restaurant on the 40th floor. It is very high-brow and exclusive - and the prices reflect this! It was exceedingly expensive, and although the food was very good, it was quite fussy and again the portion sizes were small, so despite a 6 course (set) meal we still didn't feel overly full. It is very pretentious, and formal dress is expected. They lent my partner a suit jacket to wear (although he was already really smart in shirt, trousers and posh shoes) - and I was surprised to see a Japanese girl getting away with wearing jeans - albeit smart designer jeans! Similarly, we took 2 photos with a flash, before the waiter rushed over and urged us not to use a camera with a flash as we would be "disturbing the other guests". It made me smile how, only moments later, another waiter was actually taking a photo of a Japanese couple with their camera with a flash! One rule for one, and one for the others, it would seem! Anyway, the food was good, and the wine was great too (although again far too over-priced!) and although it was an amazing experience it was rather overbearing, as the waiters prowl around and attend to your every need constantly, so it wasn't overly relaxing! They even insist on accompanying you to the entrance to the bathroom (sorry - "washroom" as they always say) - even though it was only a 10 metre walk from our table!! The main feature of the restaurant is the fabulous view, which stretches out all over Tokyo, and it was worth the money, and it was definitely a memorable experience! It was just a shame we don't have more photos to remember it by!!!Next door is the intimate Tower Piano Bar, which again has excellent views, and a real atmosphere that oozes class and sophistication. I would advise that you get there early, or book in advance, as there was usually a queue. Champagne or cocktails are the order of the day - and be prepared to pay through the nose. I dread to think how much we spent here - probably best not to dwell on it, but it just has to be done! I really felt that this was how it should be - all glammed up, sipping Bellinis and sitting in a sleek hotel bar overlooking the glitz and lights of the biggest city in the world ... surely this was how it was meant to be!?!The other restaurants all looked great, and they were always busy which was a good sign. In particular, the Chinese restaurant looked great fun and very popular - the chefs are positioned for all to see, and it seemed quite relaxed. We didn't have breakfast at the hotel as it was HIDEOUSLY expensive, and really not worth the money. Instead we tended to grab something from the local shop next door for a fraction of the price. We did use the pool and jacuzzi once - and I knew that there was an extra charge, but was quite horrified to learn that it was JPY 2100 per person per day - which is about £11 - ouch! This was a total rip off, although the pool was amazing and the jacuzzi was fab (albeit VERY hot!). We were the only people there for the whole time (probably as it was so damn expensive!), so it did feel quite exclusive, which helped to justify the expense. The changing rooms were very posh with everything you could ever possibly need, and best of all were the massage chairs which were FANTASTIC and highly recommended! Bliss! If you do go swimming, be prepared to be forced to wear a hideous BRIGHT PINK swimming cap. I wish I were joking, but I'm not - it was quite a sight - awful, and so NOT sexy! The Japanese are very hot on hygiene, and a shower blasts you before you even get near the pool to remove all impurities!! One thing that I did noticre (although it didn't affect us) was that anyone with tattoos is not allowed to use the pool - which seemed particularly harsh!! To sum up, this is a great hotel - particularly for business people, and is very well located - just a 5 minute walk from Shibuya station (over a big footbridge that crosses the hugely busy highway just in front of the hotel). The area was very safe, although Shibuya is a hive of activity at all times of the day (and night)! The service at the hotel is impeccable and the rooms are great. Just be prepared to spend, spend, spend - Tokyo is ridiculously expensive. But nothing can beat the views from the Cerulean Tower, which are simply staggering,. You will be transfixed! Enjoy! xx

I've stayed here 3x now, and I do think the rooms (all with good views) are very nice. I don't like the fact that they wont let me use the pool because I have a few tattoos (they say that it's to prevent Yakuza gang members from coming in, but there is no doubt that I do not look like a Yakuza member.) They're just so overstaffed and helpful that it actually gets annoying sometimes. I can't believe I'm writing that, but it's true. But the views from the rooms, and I mean all the rooms, can't be beat. And the location in Shbuya is a winner. I would stay here again and again without hesitation (don't give into staying in Shinjuku- Shibuya is a lot more interesting and fun.)

This hotel had the nicest room of any we encountered in Japan, and we managed to get it for a very reasonable price as well. All things considered, it was the best lodging found in our 8 day, 4 hotel trip. We had a corner room on the 26th floor, with views to Shinjuku and to the east. The room, closet, and bathroom were large, nicely appointed, and clean. The service was quite good, though the lobby can sometimes get sufficiently crowded with non-hotel guests (the hotel occupies the top floors of a business tower) that you might get lost in the shuffle to some extent. The hotel's location, a 3-minute walk from the Shibuya train station, is good, though the immediate area in front of the hotel is marred by an elevated highway. The area behind the hotel feels almost European, with its small streets and many tiny restuarants. In contrast, on the other side of the hotel and across the highway is the heart of Shibuya, an area that is most definitely Tokyo all the way. The hotel is close to Aoyama, a really nice shopping and strolling area, and close to Shinjuku as well. I would recommend this hotel to anyone looking for fantastic views, good service, an active location, and larger rooms.

The rooms were incredibly spacious. The bathrooms were awesome and the view of Mt. Fuji couldn't be more amazing. The staff was beyond attentive. I highly recommend booking the Cerulean on Tablet Hotels website. It had the best price available and a selection of hotels that will have you daydreaming for a long long time to come.

I enjoyed my stay at this hotel but since I was there on business I had other needs that were not met. The good points:- Very friendly and attentive staff.- Breath-taking views of the city. Large windows in both the bedroom and bathroom. We were luck enough to be in one of the corner rooms on the 32nd floor.- Wonderful amenities: comfortable bed with down comforters, clean sheets, large array of toiletries in the bathrom, good water pressure, and plenty of closet space.- Has a stop for the Friendly Limousine Bus that goes from the hotel to another stop in Shibuya, then directly to Narita airport.- Great location. It's just a 10 min walk from the Shibuya train station and surrounding bars/restaurants. Also, the hotel itself is part of the Cerulean Tower Office building as well so it's very convenient to stay there on a business trip to one of the companies in that tower. This was the primary reason that I stayed at this hotel.The bad points:- The in-room fax machine and printer did not work. They sent someone up to the room to help us but after 40+ min, it still didn't work. They finally just faxed our documents for us on their own machines. This was a bit of a hassle and I was surprised that they didn't come across this problem more often since they market themselves as a business oriented hotel.- Internet access was unreliable. When I did have access it was only 10Mbps, slower than the service that I usually get at other hotels. The service also "out" for hours at a time.

I loved everything about the Cerulean. Check in was swift and efficient, and the concierge assisted in booking shinkansen tickets and making restaurant bookings at our request before our arrival. Although we requested early check-in and did not receive it, the front desk gave me access to the gym to take a shower, which was good because use of the gym/pool is an extra charge. The pillows and beds seemed as if they were made for my back-- they have temper-pedic and buckwheat pillows -- the only two types of pillows I'll rest my head on! Be sure to request a corner room because the corner rooms have view from the bathtub-- which is just exquisite after a long day and you want to soak in the tub. The location is unbeatable-- just a two minute walk from the Shibuya train station or a hotel shuttle bus ride away. The limosine bus from the airport also stops at the hotel. Only thing I don't understand is the female bellhops because some of them were tiny and didn't seem to have the strength to lift our luggage. In a city where hotels are the size of shoeboxes (or the size of the Cerulean bathroom), and where after a long day of shopping you want to relax and enjoy a hotel rooom, the Cerulean was my sanctuary. My only regret is that I didn't have the opportunity to try any of the restaurants-- one of which is opened by one of the Iron Chefs. We did go to the lounge on the top floor, which had a grand view of the Tokyo skyline but be prepared to spend US$25 per drink.

This is mainly a business hotel. Apart from the location, there is nothing to write home about. I was not impressed considering the amount we were paying per night. It is more like a 3.5/4 star hotel than a 5 star one. Everything was in japanese and we even had to pay to use their gym! Not many TV channels to choose from either - with only one channel in English. I won't be returning.

I stayed at the Cerulean Hotel recently on business. My company normally requires us to stay at the Okura, however, I wanted to try a different hotel in order to have an alternate choice. The Cerulean is a very nice hotel located near the Shibuya train station. The room I had was a comfortable size, with nice contemporary furniture. The bathroom was great and the toilet had heated seats which was a nice touch. However, their customer service/front desk has a lot to learn about how to treat hotel guests.Upon checking in, I had reserved a superior, non-smoking room on a high floor. However, I was given a smaller standard room on the lower floor at the same rate as the superior room. When I complained, I was told the hotel was full and that I had to take that room at the higher rate. Upon entering the room I noted that is was a "smoking" room and it smelled of smoke. I again complained and was upgraded to an Executive Floor room because that was the only location with non-smoking rooms available. With the Executive Floor comes free internet and free access to the gym.However, upon checkout, I was shocked to see that my bill contained a charge for the gym and the internet. When I inquired about this, I was told that even though I was upgraded, they were not going to allow me to enjoy the benefits associated with the Executive Floor. I couldn't believe that the hotel would actually do this. I paid the $50 extra that was on my bill for those services and immediately told my company that the hotel should not be put on our preferred vendor list. I am surprised that a luxury hotel would do something like that. So for $40, they lost thousands of dollars in business. This proved to me that they have no class and don't deserve the four stars that they have.The hotel is nice, but they have no sense of customer service or making customers feel welcome. The upgrade really wasn't an upgrade and coupled with the fact that they tried to charge me the same rate for a standard room that was smoking as the superior non-smoking room that I had originally requested warrants the low rating I gave them. I have stayed in many luxury hotels around the world and have never received this type of treatment. I wouldn't recommend this hotel.

i visited japan for a vacation. This is more of a business hotel, very cold but it is incredible. Its very modern and new. The beds are the most comfortable ive slept in...maybe at par with banyan tree bangkok's beds. But it is very comfortable. The view from my room is amazing. Looks like the deathstar in starwars. You get a glimpse of mt. fuji with amazing sunsets. Bathroom is very spacious with a separate shower and bathtub encase in clear glass. Toilets have those bidet systems. I used the gym and the pool, its not free...i think it was $30-$50 per use. Hey, its japan...you're gonna be spending money here. But its a nice pool that's indoor...theres also a big jaccuzi area... they like their jaccuzi's really hot in tokyo... ive been to a hotspring resort in shuzenji, and its super hot. anyways....i was the only one there so it was awesome.I ate at the lobby restaurant and the italian place in the same hotel. Its ok... i think their desserts are better.The service in this hotel is exceptional...the manager, and basically everyone here was very polite, helpful, profesional and very friendly. The best thing i like about this hotel is that it is very new...it doesnt have that old hotel smell...or the hint of nicotine cigarette smoke smell back from the 60's or 70's. I hate that.... its just brand spanking new. the location is also very close to shibuyas commercial center and it is conviniently in the route of the narita busline.... i will definitely return to this hotel if i get another chance to go to japan.

My office in Shibuya is just around the corner. We have a coroporate rate at this hotel and most of our executives stay here (this trip was my 7th stay.)The rooms are great in every respect. Nicely appointed, comfortble double bed, enough closet spacem great bathroom. Views are out of this world. The rooms are perfect I feel.The hotel has many other features that I love. The executive level gives you free broadband and access to the health club which is quite nice. It also has expresso machines so you can get a cappucino anytime you like.The Chinese resturant is off of the charts. Its created by Iron Chef Chen. Sit at the counter. I go there everytime I can. The food is worth coming to the hotel for and a respit if you have been in Japan for an extended stay. Lobster in Chen's chili sauce..mmm...well you get the point.The French Iron Chef has his resturant across the street for that special business dinner if your Chen'ed out.I am not a huge fan of the lobby resturant. No soul to the food, not that its bad but its just stiff as board. Lighten up people.The bar on the 40th is fabulous, especially to watch sunset. The manager once he gets to know you is just great.JZ Brat is a classy jazz club in the building. Its quite nice with interesting artists and great service.Concierge is very resourceful and allways seems to be able to get me a reservation.Last stop on the bus ride to Narita makes that the best way to get out of town. I love this hotel and would reccomend it to anyone.

Great hotel. We had a corner room with an amazing panoramic view from the bathtub! The room was very spacious by any standards and well equipped. The concierge was also very helpful. By tokyo standards, it was great value for money. On the downside, there is a pool and health club in the hotel but is is not free and very expensive to use.

The Cerulean Tower is a 4-5 Star Hotel in the busy Shibuya district, very close to the station. So you can easily visit all other districts quickly. Shibuya is oine of the best spots for shopping and dining. The hotel has a very modern lobby, friedly staff and the views from the top-floor rooms are excellent. Health club, indoor pool and fine restaurants complet my impression. The Cerulean Tower is the perfect place for first time visitors
